Article I - IN GENERAL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-08, § 1, adopted May 27, 2014, designated §§ 5-5-1-5-5-10 as Article I. 

Sec. 5-5-1. - Chief executive officer. 
    The mayor shall be chief executive officer of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 2-1) 
Charter reference- Mayor, § 2.21 et seq. 
Sec. 5-5-2. - Regular meetings-Number; place. 
    The mayor and council shall hold two (2) regular meetings in each month, which shall be held in the mayor and council chambers located at 208 Ridley Avenue in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 2-2; Ord. No. 91-13A, § 1, 6-11-91; Ord. No. 00-03, § 1, 2-22-00) 
Editor's note- Sections 5-5-2 and 5-5-3 were amended to read as herein set out by an ordinance adopted June 11, 1991, and numbered 91-13. Inasmuch as another ordinance was also numbered as 91-13, the suffix A was added to the June 11 ordinance number to facilitate distinction. 
Charter reference- Regular and special meetings, § 2.31. 
State Law reference- Conduct of meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-5-3. - Same-Date; time. 
    The regular meetings of the mayor and council shall be held on the second and fourth Tuesday of each month at 5:30 p.m. The mayor and council may by majority vote change the date, time or place of a regular meeting if it is anticipated that a quorum will not be present at such regular meeting or for such other reasons as the mayor and council shall deem appropriate. 
(Code 1972, § 2-3; Ord. No. 91-13A, § 2, 6-11-91; Ord. No. 03-01, § 1, 1-14-03) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 5-5-2. 
Charter reference- Regular and special meetings, § 2.31. 
Sec. 5-5-4. - Parliamentary practice. 
    The proceedings of the mayor and council shall be governed by the general rules of parliamentary law and practice for other deliberative bodies, so far as applicable and consistent with the special rules of the mayor and council, the charter and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 2-6) 
Sec. 5-5-5. - Presiding officer's duties. 
    The presiding officer of meetings of the mayor and council shall preserve order and decorum, appoint all committees unless otherwise directed by the mayor and council, may cast the deciding vote in all cases where the council is equally divided and shall perform such other duties and exercise such other powers as are usual and customary and authorized or required by parliamentary law. Any person dissatisfied with the rulings of the presiding officer may appeal instanter to the council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-4) 
State Law reference- Disrupting meetings, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. 
Sec. 5-5-6. - Order of business. 
    The order of business at meetings of the mayor and council shall be as set forth in the agenda prepared prior to each meeting. A departure from the order of business shall not affect the validity of any action taken at such meeting. 
(Code 1972, § 2-5) 
Sec. 5-5-7. - Ordinances. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provisions of section 2.40 of the charter of the city, each ordinance, except an emergency ordinance as specified in section 2.41 of the charter, shall be introduced and read at a regular meeting of the mayor and council and such ordinance shall not be adopted prior to the next regular meeting following the meeting of initial introduction. 
(b)  Reading of the ordinance shall consist of the reading of the title or caption of the ordinance at the meeting at which the ordinance is introduced and reading of the title or caption of the ordinance at the meeting at which the vote to adopt or reject the ordinance is taken. At either such meeting, the reading of the entire ordinance shall be required when ordered by the mayor or by a majority of the members voting therefor. 
(c)  An ordinance may be amended, corrected or revised or a substitute ordinance introduced and amended, corrected or revised at any time after the first reading but prior to the vote on its adoption or rejection. 
(Code 1972, § 2-7; Ord. No. 91-42, § 1, 10-8-91) 
Sec. 5-5-8. - Committee of the whole; work session. 
    The mayor and council shall meet as a committee of the whole for a work session at 11:00 a.m. on the date of each regular council meeting, such meeting to be held at City Hall, 200 Ridley Avenue, LaGrange, Georgia. Such committee meetings may be cancelled from time to time. 
(Code 1972, §§ 2-8-2-10; Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, 3-13-12) 
Sec. 5-5-9. - City attorney's examination of records. 
    The city attorney shall examine the minute and ordinance books kept by the city clerk and shall advise the city clerk as to the form in which such books are to be kept. 
(Code 1972, § 2-30; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 2, 12-13-16; Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Sec. 5-5-10. - Compensation. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of section 2.13 of the Charter of the city, the monthly compensation of the mayor and each member of the council of the city shall be as follows: 
Mayor ..... $800.00 
Council member ..... 600.00 
(Ord. No. 91-18, § 1, 6-18-91; Ord. No. 02-27, § 1, 9-10-02) 
Secs. 5-5-11-5-5-19. - Reserved. 
Article II - CODE OF ETHICS 

Sec. 5-5-20. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this code of ethics is to: 
(1)  Encourage high ethical standards in official conduct by city officials; 
(2)  Establish guidelines for ethical standards of conduct for all such officials by setting forth those acts or actions which are incompatible with the best interests of the city; 
(3)  Require disclosure by city officials of private financial and other defined interests in matters affecting the city; and 
(4)  Serve as a basis for discipline of those who fail to abide by its terms. 
(Ord. No. 14-08, § 2, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 5-5-21. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this code of ethics shall be applicable to the mayor and council members, as well as those appointed city officials defined herein below. Notwithstanding any other aspect of the ordinance from which this article derived to the contrary, state law and the Charter of the City shall control in the event of an actual conflict with the provisions of this code of ethics. This article shall be interpreted to supplement, and not replace, such provisions of state law and the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 14-08, § 2, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 5-5-22. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the following meanings ascribed to them, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City official or official , unless otherwise expressly defined means the mayor, members of the city council, city manager and city attorney. The term "city official" also includes all individuals, including city employees, appointed by the mayor and/or city council as appropriate to city authorities, commissions, committees, boards, task forces, or other bodies which can or may vote, take formal action or make official recommendations to the mayor and/or city council. 
    Decision means any ordinance, resolution, contract, franchise, formal action or other matter voted on by the city council or other city board or commission, but shall not be construed to include a ministerial action undertaken in compliance with council directive. 
    Employee means any person who is a full-time or part-time employee of the city. 
    Immediate family means the spouse, mother, father, grandparent, brother, sister, son or daughter of any city official related by blood, adoption or marriage. The relationship by marriage shall include in-laws. 
    Incidental interest means an interest in a person, entity or property which is not a substantial interest as defined herein and which has insignificant value. 
    Remote interest means an interest of a person or entity, including the city official, which would be affected in the same way as the general public. For example, the interest of an official in the property tax rate, general city fees, city utility charges or a comprehensive zoning ordinance or similar matter is deemed remote to the extent that the official would be affected in common with the general public. 
    Substantial interest means an interest, either directly or through a member of immediate family, in another person or entity, where: 
(1)  The interest is ownership of five (5) percent or more of the voting stock or shares or equity of the entity, or ownership of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more of the equity or market value of the entity, excluding investments held inside mutual funds or managed investment accounts; 
(2)  The funds received by the person from the other person or entity during the previous twelve (12) months either equal or exceed: 
a.  Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in salary, bonuses, commissions or professional fees, or ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in payment for goods, products or services; or 
b.  Ten (10) percent of the recipient's gross income during that period, whichever is less; 
(3)  The person serves as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors or other governing board for a for-profit entity other than a corporate entity owned or created by the city council; or 
(4)  The person is a creditor, debtor or guarantor of the other person or entity in an amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more. 
(Ord. No. 14-08, § 2, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 5-5-23. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No city official shall use his or her official position to secure special privileges or exemptions for himself or herself or others, or to secure confidential information for any purpose other than official duties undertaken on behalf of the city. 
(b)  No city official, in any matter before the council or other city body, relating to a person or entity in which the official has a substantial interest, shall fail to disclose for the record such interest prior to any discussion or vote, and shall not participate in his or her public capacity in such discussion or vote; however, nothing herein shall prohibit a public official from acting as a private citizen in support of or against a matter. Notwithstanding the prohibition contained herein, it shall not be a violation of this article to have participated in a decision if the city official did not know, and should not reasonably have known, of the substantial interest. 
(c)  No city official shall receive, or agree to receive, any compensation, gift, reward or gratuity in exchange for, or with the expectation of providing, special treatment or official action by said city official. 
(d)  Neither the mayor nor any council member shall enter into any contract, or have any interest in a contract with the city, except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Designation of a bank or trust company as a depository for city funds; 
(2)  The borrowing of funds from any bank or lending institution which offers the lowest available rate of interest in the community for such loan; 
(3)  Contracts entered under circumstances that constitute an emergency situation, provided that the mayor prepares a written record explaining the emergency; 
(4)  Contracts for city services available to the general public; 
(5)  Sale of real property as allowed by law with proper disclosure. 
(e)  No city official shall disclose or otherwise use confidential information obtained by reason of his or her elected office for the purpose of furthering a private interest. 
(f)  No city official shall use his or her official position to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide financial benefit to such official or persons within the official's immediate family, or those with whom the official has business or financial ties amounting to a substantial interest. 
(g)  No city official shall draw travel funds or per diem from the city for attendance at meetings, seminars, training or other educational events and fail to attend such events without promptly reimbursing the city therefor. 
(h)  No city official shall attempt to unduly influence the outcome of a case before the Municipal Court of the City of LaGrange. 
(i)  A city official serving as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors of [a] non-profit entity must disclose such interest to the mayor and council prior to participating in a vote or decision regarding funding of the entity by or through the city. 
(Ord. No. 14-08, § 2, 5-27-14; Ord. No. 14-17, § 1, 12-16-14) 
Sec. 5-5-24. - Ethics hearing officer. 
    The mayor and council shall appoint a pool of three (3) hearing officers to investigate, hear and render findings as more fully set forth herein on ethics complaints filed pursuant to this article. In order to serve as an ethics hearing officer, an individual must be admitted to the practice of law in the State of Georgia, have a minimum of five (5) years in the practice of law as well as significant experience in the area of local government law. The city manager shall recommend to the mayor and council for approval a pool of qualified candidates, who, when appointed, shall serve a term of two (2) years and may be reappointed to additional terms of service in discretion of the mayor and council. Each complaint shall be assigned to a single hearing officer on a rotating basis. 
(Ord. No. 14-08, § 2, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 5-5-25. - Receipt of complaints; procedure. 
(a)  All complaints under this article against city officials shall be in writing and filed with the assistant city manager. Upon receipt of a complaint in proper form, the assistant city manager shall forward a copy of the complaint to the mayor and council and city official or officials charged in the complaint within no more than seven (7) calendar days. 
(b)  All complaints shall be submitted and signed under oath, shall be legibly drawn and shall clearly address matters within the scope of this article. 
(c)  Also within seven (7) calendar days of the filing of the complaint, the assistant city manager shall forward a copy of the complaint to the ethics hearing officer who shall review it to determine whether the complaint is unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or fails to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of this article. The hearing officer is empowered to dismiss in writing complaints that are determined to be unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or fail to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the city council; provided, however, that a rejection of such complaint by the hearing officer shall not deprive the complaining party of any action such party might otherwise have at law or in equity against the city official. 
(d)  The hearing officer is empowered to conduct investigations, to take evidence, and to hold hearings to address the subject matter of a complaint. A hearing shall be held within sixty (60) days after the filing of the complaint, which shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures and regulations promulgated by the hearing officer. 
(e)  The hearing officer shall have the authority to conduct in camera inspections of any financial records produced pursuant to the investigation and shall only make a part of the record such records as are relevant to the finding of a violation. 
(f)  At any hearing held by the hearing officer, the city official who is the subject of inquiry shall have the right to written notice of the hearing and the allegations at least fourteen (14) calendar days prior to the hearing, to be represented by counsel, to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses. 
(g)  The findings of the hearing officer, which shall include whether the city official violated this article as alleged in the complaint, shall be rendered in writing to the mayor and council within thirty (30) days after completion of the hearing. 
(h)  Upon receipt of the findings of the hearing officer, the mayor and council may take the following action: 
(1)  Dismiss the complaint; 
(2)  Issue a public reprimand or censure; 
(3)  Request resignation; or 
(4)  Remove from office, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 14-08, § 2, 5-27-14; Ord. No. 16-12, § 2, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 5-5-26. - Timing of complaints; action subject to ethics ordinance. 
(a)  Complaints as authorized within this code of ethics shall be accepted only for conduct of a city official alleged to have occurred during the official's term of office or, for appointed officials, during the term of said appointment. Moreover, complaints shall only be accepted for actions alleged to have occurred subsequent to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, June 1, 2014. Resignation of a city official subsequent to the initiation of a complaint hereunder, but prior to action by the mayor and council pursuant to section 5-5-25(g), shall divest the council and the hearing officer of jurisdiction of the complaint and thereby terminate such proceedings. 
(b)  To discourage the filings of ethics complaints solely for political purposes, complaints will not be accepted against a person seeking election as a city official, whether currently serving as a city official or not, from the date qualifying opens for the elected office at issue through the date the election results for that office are certified. Properly filed complaints will be accepted and processed after the election results have been certified. 
(Ord. No. 14-08, § 2, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 5-5-27. - Appeal. 
(a)  Any city official or complainant adversely affected by the decision of the mayor and council under 5-5-25(g) may obtain judicial review of such decision as provided in this section. 
(b)  An action for judicial review may be commenced by filing an application for a writ of certiorari in the Superior Court of Troup County within thirty (30) days after the decision of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 14-08, § 2, 5-27-14) 
Chapter 5-10 - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Creation and alteration of departments and other agencies, § 2.20; city manager, § 3.20 et seq.; personnel administration, § 3.50 et seq.; official bonds, § 9.11. 
Cross reference- Taxes and finance, Ch. 5-15; recorder's court, Ch. 5-20; public safety and health, Ch. 10-1 et seq.; public services and franchises, Ch. 15-1 et seq.; city utilities, Ch. 20-1 et seq.; community and economic development, Ch. 25-1 et seq. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-10-1. - Official bonds. 
(a)  City manager may require. The city manager may require bonds from city officers and employees in such amounts as he may deem necessary. Such bonds shall be approved by the mayor and council and shall be payable to the city. 
(b)  Attestation. Official bonds may be attested by the mayor, the mayor pro tem, a member of the council, the assistant city manager or any officer of this state authorized to attest deeds. 
(c)  Conditions. The conditions of official bonds shall be for the faithful performance of the duties of the office and such other conditions as may be prescribed by the city manager. 
(d)  Obligations; multiple recovery; joint and several: 
(1)  The obligation of official bonds shall be obligatory on the principal and sureties thereon: 
a.  For any breach of the conditions during the time the officer continues in office or discharges any of the duties thereof; 
b.  For the faithful discharge of any duties which may be required of such officer by any law or ordinance passed subsequent to the execution of such bond, although no such condition is expressed therein; and 
c.  For the use and benefit of every person who is injured, as well as by any wrongful act committed under the color of his office, as by his failure to perform, or by the improper or negligent performance of those duties imposed by law. 
(2)  Such bonds are not discharged by a single recovery, but proceedings may be had from time to time until the whole penalty is exhausted against the officer and his sureties, or either. 
(3)  Said bonds are joint and several, whether so set forth or not. 
(e)  Validity. When an officer or employee acts under a bond which is not in the penalty payable and conditioned, or approved and filed as required by law, such bond shall stand the same as if it were made in conformity to law. 
(f)  Relieving sureties; giving other security. On good cause shown, notice being given to the principal, the mayor and council may, in their discretion, relieve the sureties on any official bond, and cause such officer or employee to give other security, and any such officer or employee failing to give such other security shall be dismissed from office. 
(Code 1972, §§ 2-24-2-29; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 2, 12-13-16) 
Charter reference- Official bonds, § 9.11. 
State Law reference- Requisites of deeds, O.C.G.A. § 44-5-30 et seq.; official bonds of public officers and employees, O.C.G.A. § 45-4-1 et seq. 
Secs. 5-10-2-5-10-14. - Reserved. 
Article II - PERSONNEL SYSTEM[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Personnel administration, § 3.50 et seq. 

Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-10-15. - Personnel policy manual; adopted, effective. 
(a)  A manual containing the personnel policies for the City of LaGrange is hereby enacted and adopted as the personnel policies for the City of LaGrange and shall supersede all prior personnel policies except to the extent hereinafter provided. 
(b)  All provisions of the Personnel Policy Manual of the City of LaGrange shall be effective and shall be in full force and effect on and after July 12, 1988, except that the provisions of the personnel policy relating to the employee assistance program contained in Section 6.11 thereof and the provisions of the substance abuse prevention program as contained in Section 8.04 thereof, having been previously adopted on January 12, 1988, are hereby readopted as a part of the personnel policy manual of the city, but the effective date of these two (2) sections shall continue to be January 12, 1988. 
(Ord. No. 88-100, §§ 1, 2, 7-12-88) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 88-100, §§ 1, 2 adopted July 12, 1988, did not specify manner of codification, but have been included herein as § 5-10-15 by the editor. The policy manual referenced in such section is not set out at length in this Code, but is on file and available for inspection in the personnel offices of the city. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 88-100 contained no specific repealer, should conflict arise between the manual and the provisions of this chapter, it is presumed that the more recent provisions will prevail. 
Sec. 5-10-16. - Penalties. 
    Any person who willfully violates any provision of this article or of the personnel policies established hereunder may, upon action of the proper authority as outlined in the personnel policies, have one (1) of the following judgments rendered: 
(1)  Dismissal from government service; 
(2)  Demotion in rank or grade; 
(3)  Suspension for a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days; or 
(4)  Ineligibility for appointment to or employment in a position in the city service for a period of time or indefinitely. 
(Code 1972, § 2-83) 
Sec. 5-10-17. - General purpose. 
    The general purpose of this article is to establish a system of personnel administration that meets the social, economic and program needs of the people of the city. This system shall provide means to recruit, select, develop and maintain an effective and responsive work force, and shall include policies and procedures for employee hiring and advancement, training and career development, job classification, salary administration, retirement, fringe benefits, discharge and other related services. All appointments and promotions in the city service shall be made without regard to sex, race, religion, political affiliation or handicapped status and shall be based on merit and fitness. 
(Code 1972, § 2-76) 
State Law reference- Discharge of employee subject to garnishment, O.C.G.A. § 18-4-7; age discrimination, O.C.G.A. § 34-1-2; sex discrimination, O.C.G.A. § 34-5-1 et seq.; discrimination against the handicapped, O.C.G.A. § 34-6A-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-10-18. - Administration. 
(a)  There is hereby created in the city a human resources department, the executive head of which shall be the human resources director. The director shall be experienced in management and administration and shall be appointed by the city manager in the same manner as other appointed department heads. 
(b)  The director shall be the executive head of the human resources department and shall, under the general supervision of the city manager direct all of its administrative and technical activities and appoint its employees. It shall be the duty of the director to: 
(1)  Encourage and exercise leadership in the development of effective personnel administration within the several departments in the government service, and to make available the facilities of the department of personnel to this end; 
(2)  Advise the city manager on manpower utilization; 
(3)  Foster and develop programs for the improvement of employee effectiveness, including training, safety, health, counseling and welfare; 
(4)  Investigate from time to time the operation and effect of this article and of the policies made hereunder and to report his findings and recommendations to the city manager; 
(5)  Establish and maintain records of all employees in the government service, in which there shall be set forth as to each employee the class, title, pay or status and other relevant data; 
(6)  Make a semi-annual report to the city manager regarding the work of the department; and 
(7)  Apply and carry out this article and the policies hereunder and perform any other lawful acts which may be necessary or desirable to carry out the purposes and provisions of this article and related activities. 
(c)  The director, or a consultant empowered by the mayor and council, shall prepare personnel policies, rules and regulations which shall be submitted to the mayor and council for consideration and adoption. Such personnel policies, rules and regulations, upon adoption by resolution of the mayor and council, shall have the force and effect of law and may be amended by resolution of the mayor and council at any regular or special meeting. The policies shall provide: 
(1)  For the preparation, maintenance and revision of a position classification plan for all positions in the career service, based upon similarity of duties performed and responsibilities assumed, so that the same qualifications may reasonably be required for, and the same schedule of pay may be equitably applied to, all positions in the same class. After such classification plan has been approved by the mayor and council, the director shall allocate or reallocate the position of every employee in the career service to one (1) of the classes in the plan. Any employee affected by the allocation or reallocation of a position to a class shall, after filing with the city manager a written request for reconsideration thereof in such manner and forms as the city manager may prescribe, be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard thereon; 
(2)  For the annual submission of a pay plan to the city manager; 
(3)  For recruitment of capable persons and for administering appropriate evaluations to determine the relative fitness of applicants for positions in the public service; 
(4)  For the certification to the appointing authority of the names of persons who are categorized as qualified to fill a vacancy; 
(5)  For the establishment and maintenance of eligible lists of appointment and promotion, upon which lists shall be placed the names of successful candidates; 
(6)  For promotions which shall give appropriate consideration to the applicant's qualifications, record of performance and ability; 
(7)  For, upon appointment or promotion, a period of employee probation, not to exceed one (1) year, prior to permanent appointment; 
(8)  For emergency employment for not more than ninety (90) days with the consent of the city manager and for provisional employment without open evaluation when there is no appropriate eligible list available. No such provisional employment shall continue longer than six (6) months, nor shall successive provisional appointments be allowed; 
(9)  For the establishment of programs, including trainee programs, designed to attract and utilize persons with minimal qualifications, but with potential for development, in order to provide career development opportunities among members of disadvantaged groups, handicapped persons and returning veterans. Such programs may provide for permanent appointment upon the satisfactory completion of the training period without further examination; 
(10)  For keeping records of performance of all employees in the career service, which performance records shall be considered in determining salary increments or increases for meritorious services; as a factor in determining the order of layoffs because of lack of funds or work, and reinstatement; and as a factor in demotions, discharges and transfers; 
(11)  For lay-offs by reason of lack of funds or work, or abolition of a position, or material change in duties or organizations, and for reemployment of employees so laid off; 
(12)  For establishment of a plan for resolving employee grievances and complaints; 
(13)  For the establishment of disciplinary measures such as suspension, demotion in rank or grade or discharge. Such measures shall provide for presentation of charges, hearing rights and appeals for all permanent employees in the career service; 
(14)  For establishing hours of work, holidays and attendance regulations in various classes of positions in the career service; 
(15)  For development and operation of programs to improve work effectiveness including training, safety, health, welfare, counseling, recreation and employee relations; 
(16)  For recommending and publicizing fringe benefits such as insurance programs, retirement and leave policies; and 
(17)  For such other policies and administrative regulations, not inconsistent with this article, as may be proper and necessary for its enforcement. 
(d)  The city manager or his authorized agent shall be responsible for certification that the persons employed under the career service have been appointed and employed in accordance with the provisions of this article and the policies hereunder. No city disbursing or auditing officer shall make or approve or take any part in making or approving any payment for personal service to any persons holding a position in the city government unless the payroll authorization bears the certification of the city manager or his authorized agent. 
(Code 1972, § 2-78; Ord. No. 94-39, § 1, 9-13-94) 
Sec. 5-10-19. - Career service. 
(a)  The career service shall be a permanent service to which this article shall apply and shall comprise all tenured positions in the public service now existing or hereafter established, except the following: 
(1)  The mayor and members of the council; 
(2)  Members of boards and commissions, the city manager, the city recorder, the city attorney and the city auditor; 
(3)  Persons employed to make or conduct a temporary and special inquiry, investigation or examination on behalf of the mayor and council, a committee thereof or the city manager; and 
(4)  Temporary or part-time positions unless specifically covered by action of the mayor and council. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as precluding the appointing authority from filling any position in the manner in which positions in the career service are filled. 
(Code 1972, § 2-77) 
Sec. 5-10-20. - Grievance procedure. 
(a)  A grievance is any dispute concerning the interpretation or application of this article, or of the personnel policies governing personnel practices or working conditions, or decisions relative to any disciplinary action, dismissal, demotion or charge of discrimination. 
(b)  Grievances shall be processed in accordance with procedures established by the mayor and council in the personnel policies. 
(Code 1972, § 2-79) 
Sec. 5-10-21. - Agreements authorized. 
(a)  The city may enter into reciprocal agreements, upon such terms as may be agreed upon, for the use of equipment, materials, facilities and services with any public agency or body for purposes deemed of benefit to the public personnel system. 
(b)  The city manager, acting in behalf of the mayor and council, may cooperate with other governmental agencies charged with public personnel administration in conducting personnel tests, recruiting personnel, training personnel, establishing lists from which eligibles shall be certified for appointment and for the interchange of personnel and their benefits. 
(Code 1972, § 2-80) 
Sec. 5-10-22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-41, § 1, adopted Dec. 19, 2002, deleted § 5-10-22, which pertained to political activities, derived from the 1972 Code, § 2-81. 
Sec. 5-10-23. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No persons shall make any false statements, certificate, mark or report with regard to any test, certification or appointment made under any provision of this article or in any matter commit or attempt to commit any fraud preventing the impartial execution of this law and policies. 
(b)  No person shall, directly or indirectly, give, render, pay, offer, solicit or accept any money, service or other valuable consideration for any appointment, proposed appointment, promotion or proposed promotion to, or any advantage in, a position in the career service. 
(c)  No employee of the personnel department, examiner or other person shall defeat, deceive or obstruct any person in his right to examination, eligibility, certification or appointment under this article, or furnish to any person any special or secret information for the purpose of affecting the rights or prospects of any person with respect to employment in the career service. 
(Code 1972, § 2-82) 
Sec. 5-10-24. - Status of employees. 
    Employees holding positions in the career service of the city on December 28, 1972, shall be continued in their respective positions without further examination, until separated from their positions as provided by law. Those who shall have failed to qualify as provided herein shall be dismissed from their positions within thirty (30) days after establishment of an eligible list for their respective positions. Nothing herein shall preclude the reclassification or reallocation as provided by this law of any position held by any incumbent. 
(Code 1972, § 2-84) 
Secs. 5-10-25-5-10-29. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - GRIEVANCE APPEALS HEARING OFFICER 

Sec. 5-10-30. - Created; authority. 
(a)  A hearing officer shall preside over, hear and decide those employee grievance appeals as authorized by the personnel policies of the city. In order to serve as hearing officer, an individual must be admitted to the practice of law in the State of Georgia, have a minimum five (5) years in the practice of law as well as significant experience in the area of public employment law. The city manager shall recommend to the mayor and council for approval a pool of qualified candidates, who, when appointed, shall serve of term of two (2) years and may be reappointed to additional terms of service in the discretion of the mayor and council. Out of the pool of available hearing officers, the city manager shall select individuals to conduct evidentiary hearings on an as needed basis for employee grievance appeals. The decision of the hearing officer as to those employee grievance appeals submitted shall be final. 
(b)  The hearing officer shall have the authority to adopt such internal procedural rules and regulations as he or she may deem necessary and appropriate for the transaction of hearings, which shall at all times be conducted as required by the Open Meetings Law and the Open Records Law of the State of Georgia. The hearing officer or assistant city manager shall have the authority to issue subpoenas to require the attendance of witnesses or the production of documents evidence, to fix a standard witness fee and provide for enforcement of same. 
(c)  No current or former employee of the city shall at any time be appointed to or serve as a hearing officer hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 94-39, § 2, 9-13-94; Ord. No. 97-36, § 1, 9-26-97; Ord. No. 97-41, §§ 1, 2, 11-11-97; Ord. No. 98-5, § 1, 2-24-98; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 2, 12-13-16) 
Secs. 5-10-31-5-10-40. - Reserved. 
Chapter 5-12 - PURCHASING AND PURCHASE ORDERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- Procurement procedures, § 4.40 et seq. 

Sec. 5-12-1. - Purchase order defined. 
    "Purchase order," as used herein, shall mean and shall be interpreted to include any document, memorandum or writing authorizing a vendor, seller or supplier to deliver to the city supplies, materials, equipment and contractual services with payment to be made by the city upon receipt thereof or as provided in such document, memorandum, or writing. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 4-9-96) 
Sec. 5-12-2. - Authority of city manager to execute contracts and purchase orders. 
(a)  The city manager shall be authorized to execute on behalf of the city, contracts and all purchase orders for goods or services which have been previously authorized and approved by the mayor and council as a budgeted item in the current budget of the city. 
(b)  The city manager is authorized to execute contracts and purchase orders on behalf of the city within operating accounts provided for by the mayor and council which are necessary for the operation of the affairs of the city. Any capital items or construction projects not provided for in the current budget must have prior approval of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 4-9-96) 
Sec. 5-12-3. - Competitive bidding contracts, acceptance by mayor and council. 
    Contracts for which competitive bidding is required by the laws of the State of Georgia as the same may now or hereafter exist and which require the acceptance by the mayor and council of the low or appropriate bid therefor must be executed by the mayor or mayor pro tem or by some other person designated by the mayor and council and shall be authenticated by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 4-9-96; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 2, 12-13-16; Ord. No. 18-06, § 2, 7-10-18) 
Chapter 5-15 - TAXES AND FINANCE[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- City clerk, § 3.40; tax collector, § 3.41; finance and fiscal, Ch. 4; occupational taxes, § 5.20. 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 30-1 et seq.; financial institutions business license tax, § 30-5-12 et seq. 
State constitution reference- Taxation and finance, Art. 7. 
State Law reference- Municipal bonds, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-38-1 et seq., 36-82-1 et seq.; budgets and audits, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-1 et seq. 

Sec. 5-15-1. - Department of finance created; director; appointment; bond. 
    There is created the department of finance, the head or director of which shall be the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 2-36; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 3, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 5-15-2. - Powers and duties. 
    The city manager shall have charge of the administration of the financial affairs of the city and to that end shall have authority, and shall be required to: 
(1)  Maintain and supervise a general accounting system for the city government and each of its officers, departments and agencies; keep books for, and exercise financial budgetary control over, each office, department and agency; keep separate accounts for each item of appropriation contained in the city budget; 
(2)  Submit to the mayor and council a monthly statement of all receipts and disbursements in such detail as will show the financial condition of the city; 
(3)  Receive and account for all monies payable to the city by any county, state or federal government, by any court, or by any office, department or agency of the city, or payable from any other source not otherwise provided for; and 
(4)  Have custody of all public funds belonging to or under the control of the city or any office, department or agency of the city government, and deposit all funds coming into his or her hands in such depositories as may be designated by resolution of the mayor and council; 
(5)  Have custody of all investments and invested funds of the city government, or in the possession of such government in a fiduciary capacity, and have the safekeeping of all bonds and notes of the city, and of the receipt and delivery of city bonds and notes for transfer, registration, exchange or payment; 
(6)  Make expenditures within the appropriations approved by the city council; 
(7)  Make interim and annual financial reports; 
(8)  Inspect and audit any accounts or records of financial transactions which may be maintained by any office, department or agency of the city government, apart from or subsidiary to the accounts kept in his or her office; 
(9)  Enforce all ordinances and applicable state laws relating to the collection, foreclosure and sale for taxes; 
(10)  Collect the fees required by section 5-15-8; and 
(11)  Perform all other duties as may be directed by ordinance or resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-37; Ord. No. 91-22, § 1, 7-23-91; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 3, 12-13-16) 
State Law reference- Registration of voters, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-120 et seq.; revenue and taxation, O.C.G.A. Title 48. 
Sec. 5-15-3. - Signing of warrants or checks. 
    All checks given, issued or delivered by the city shall be signed by the reproduced facsimile signature of the city manager or assistant city manager or by the original signature of any one of the following: Mayor, mayor pro tem, city manager or assistant city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 10-1; Ord. No. 89-33, § 1, 9-26-89; Ord. No. 93-62, § 1, 12-14-93; Ord. No. 98-25, § 1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 03-26, § 1, 8-26-03; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 3, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 5-15-4. - Marshal in department of finance; appointment; duties. 
    The city marshal of the city shall be appointed by the city manager. The person appointed as city marshal shall be an employee of the city and may hold other positions or have other responsibilities for the city. In addition to such other responsibilities, the person designated as city marshal shall perform the duties of that office which shall include but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  Investigate and make recommendations on all applicants for alcoholic beverages, wine, beer and amusement center licenses as required by law; 
(2)  Enforce the collection of delinquent taxes and paving assessments, levy all executions, serve notice of executions and sell property levied on as provided by law; 
(3)  Assist in locating and collecting delinquent utilities and miscellaneous accounts receivable; 
(4)  Perform such other duties as may be assigned by the director of the department of finance or the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 2-38; Ord. No. 91-22, § 2, 7-23-91; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 3, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 5-15-5. - Tax returns, assessments, appeals and tax digest generally. 
    The filing of tax returns for real and personal property, the preparation of assessments therefor, the hearings of appeals from such assessments and the preparation and filing of the city tax digest shall be the responsibility of the tax assessor of the county as far as may be prescribed by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1972, § 10-20; Ord. No. 16-12, § 3, 12-13-16) 
Charter reference- Taxation and city service charges, § 4.10 et seq. 
Sec. 5-15-6. - Tax due dates; bills; delinquent taxes. 
(a)  All taxes on tangible property other than motor vehicles shall be due on the date of the tax levy by the mayor and council. 
(b)  Ad valorem taxes which are not paid on or before November fifteenth of the year in which assessed are hereby declared to be delinquent. Any person who shall willfully fail to pay within ninety (90) days of the date when due, any such ad valorem tax, except ad valorem tax of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less on homestead property as defined in O.C.G.A. title 48, chapter 5, article 2, section 48-5-40 et seq., shall pay a penalty of ten (10) percent of the amount of tax due, plus interest allowed by law. 
(c)  In all cases where executions are issued by the city for delinquent taxes, the city manager shall collect such costs, including advertising costs, incurred for issuing, levying and collecting taxes, as are allowed for collection of the county ad valorem tax executions under state law. 
(d)  Such execution, when issued, shall be directed to the city marshal and shall be levied and executed by him or his authorized representative, as provided by law. 
(Code 1972, § 10-21; Ord. No. 94-10, § 1, 3-8-94; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 3, 12-13-16) 
Charter reference- Property tax levies, § 4.35. 
State Law reference- Installment payments of taxes, 
O.C.G.A. § 48-5-23. 
Sec. 5-15-7. - Banks, etc.; taxes as authorized by law. 
    Banks, banking associations, certain trust companies, savings banks and building and loan associations shall be taxed by the city as authorized by the law of the state. 
(Code 1972, § 10-22) 
State Law reference- Taxation of financial institutions, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-90 et seq. 
Sec. 5-15-8. - Miscellaneous fees. 
(a)  There shall be a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), or five (5) percent of the face amount of the instrument, whichever is greater, assessed against the maker of any check paid to the city which is returned unpaid for insufficient funds or for any other reason except a reason attributable to the fault or neglect of the city or an employee of the city. Moreover, if such dishonored payment causes a disconnection of utilities, there shall be an additional fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) assessed prior to reconnection of utilities by the city. 
(b)  There shall be paid a fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) to defray the cost of advertising requests and/or applications pertaining to actions by the board of zoning appeals. 
(c)  There shall be paid a fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) to defray the costs of the city for any application for annexation of real property within the corporate limits of the City of LaGrange. 
(Code 1972, § 2-14; Ord. No. 86-39, § 1, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 88-98, § 1, 6-30-88; Ord. No. 90-50, § 1, 10-9-90; Ord. No. 92-15, § 1, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 97-14, § 1, 4-22-97; Ord. No. 97-16, § 1, 5-13-97; Ord. No. 06-25, § 1, 9-12-06; Ord. No. 09-11, § 6, 8-11-09) 
Sec. 5-15-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Pursuant to Ord. No. 93-37, § 1, adopted July 13, 1993, § 5-15-9, pertaining to penalties for false alarms, has been recodified as § 10-5-3. 
Sec. 5-15-10. - Interest rate. 
    In all instances where sums of money shall be due and payable to the city and which provides for interest allowed by law or for which no interest rate is fixed or provided, any such obligation shall bear interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum from the date such obligation becomes due. 
(Ord. No. 90-36, § 1, 6-27-90) 
Chapter 5-20 - MUNICIPAL COURT[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Act No. 766, § 1, Georgia Laws 1990, amended the Charter by changing recorder's court to municipal court; hence, Ch. 5-20 has been editorially amended to conform the following terms to those of the Charter: 
Recorder's court is now municipal court; 
Recorder is now judge; and 
Recorder pro tem is now assistant municipal judge; 
Otherwise, no substantive changes have been made. 
Charter reference- Municipal court, § 7.01 et seq. 
Cross reference- Police, Ch. 10-5. 
State constitution references- Judicial power of the state, Art. 6, § 1, Par. 1; effect of constitution on municipal courts, Art. 6, § 10, Par. 1. 

Sec. 5-20-1. - Terms of court; when sessions held. 
(a)  The terms of court for the municipal court of the city shall commence on the first Monday in February, May, August and November. 
(b)  Regular sessions of municipal court shall be held at such hours and upon such days as fixed from time to time by the Municipal Court Judge as in his discretion shall be required for the proper administration and adjudication of the court calendar. 
(Code 1972, § 19-1; Ord. No. 96-68, § 1, 12-19-96; Ord. No. 11-19, § 1, 11-8-11) 
Charter reference- Court rules, § 7-07. 
Sec. 5-20-2. - Clerk; prosecuting attorney. 
(a)  The court administrator of the city or a designated employee of the office of the court administrator shall act as clerk of municipal court and as such shall be responsible for the collection of all fines and forfeitures under order of the municipal court. 
(b)  The city manager may appoint a prosecuting attorney of the municipal court who shall have the duties and authorities as outlined in Georgia law to represent the city in municipal court. Such individual shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia and admitted to practice before the appellate courts of this state. The prosecuting attorney shall serve on a part-time basis, and will be otherwise allowed to engage in the private practice of law. The part-time prosecuting attorney shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager, and the city manager shall also be authorized to appoint such substitute prosecuting attorneys as may be in the best interests of the city. Nothing herein shall prohibit the city attorney from prosecuting ordinance violations in municipal court or otherwise representing the interests of the city in municipal court or appeals therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 7-10-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, adopted July 10, 2012, repealed the former § 12-13, and enacted a new § 12-13 as set out herein. The former § 12-13 pertained to clerk of municipal court and derived from the Code of 1972, § 2-62 and Ord. No. 87-100, September 22, 1987. 
Sec. 5-20-3. - Records. 
(a)  The clerk of court shall keep a criminal docket whereon he shall docket all cases of persons charged with violation of the city ordinances or state statutes, the time of docketing the same, the offense charged, the name of the arresting officers, the final judgment and sentence and other entries to show the progress of the case and its final disposition. 
(b)  The clerk of court shall also keep the other books and records of the municipal court. Such records shall show an accurate account of all moneys handled by the court. 
(c)  The clerk shall be responsible for maintenance of pre-adjudication documents, maintenance of the court docket, preparation of the court calendar, administering the municipal court while in session at the discretion of the municipal judge, maintenance of all financial records of the municipal court including preparation of bank deposits, reporting dispositions of adjudicated cases to the appropriate agency, forwarding of adjudicated arrest and booking reports to the chief of police, transmitting adjudicated traffic citations and drivers licenses to the Department of Public Safety and forwarding a copy of traffic citations to the chief of police for filing. 
(Code 1972, §§ 19-2, 19-30; Ord. No. 87-100, § 2, 9-22-87) 
State Law reference- Cases to be called in order in which they stand on docket, exceptions, O.C.G.A. § 17-8-1. 
Sec. 5-20-4. - Superior court rules. 
    The practice in the municipal court shall be governed by the rules of the superior court as far as practicable. 
(Code 1972, §§ 19-3, 19-6, 19-15) 
Charter reference- Court rules, § 7.07. 
State Law reference- Superior courts, O.C.G.A. § 15-6-1 et seq.; criminal procedure, O.C.G.A. Title 17; evidence, O.C.G.A. Title 24. 
Sec. 5-20-5. - Limitations. 
    All prosecutions for a violation of city ordinances shall be commenced within two (2) years after the violation, and any offense against said ordinances for which no prosecution is begun within two (2) years after its commission shall be barred, unless the accused shall have been beyond the limits of the city, in which case the time of absence from the city shall not be embraced or computed as within said two (2) years. 
(Code 1972, § 19-7) 
State Law reference- Limitations on prosecution, O.C.G.A. § 17-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-20-6. - Continuances. 
    In all cases, the party making an application for a continuance must show that he or she has used due diligence. All applications for continuances are addressed to the sound legal discretion of the court and, if not expressly provided for, shall be granted or refused as the ends of justice may require. 
(Code 1972, § 19-4; Ord. No. 96-68, § 2, 12-19-96) 
State Law reference- Continuances, O.C.G.A. § 17-8-20 et seq.; consideration of motion for continuance, O.C.G.A. § 17-8-22. 
Sec. 5-20-7. - Administrative fee. 
    In addition to any fine, forfeiture, cost or other monetary penalty imposed upon a defendant, there shall be assessed an administrative fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) which shall be paid into the city treasury. 
(Code 1972, § 19-5; Ord. No. 96-68, § 3, 12-19-96; Ord. No. 02-10, § 1, 4-9-02) 
Sec. 5-20-8. - Defendant's rights generally. 
    Any person charged with an offense against any of the ordinances of city shall be informed by summons in writing served on him of the nature of the cause of his accusation and the time and place at which he shall appear; if requested shall have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his behalf; shall have a speedy trial before the municipal judge; shall be confronted with the witnesses against him and have the privilege of cross-examination; and shall have the privilege of defending himself, by counsel or by himself, or both, as to him shall seem proper. No person shall be condemned, fined or punished without full opportunity of being heard in his own defense, and without having the opportunity of employing counsel; and no person shall be incarcerated in the city jail for more than seventy-two (72) hours without being tried by the municipal judge, except where the accused elects to waive trial at the first session in writing. 
(Code 1972, §§ 19-6, 19-8) 
State constitution reference- Similar provisions, Art. I, § I, Par. XIV. 
State Law reference- Testimony of criminal defendant, O.C.G.A. § 24-9-20. 
Sec. 5-20-9. - Failure to appear. 
    Any person, duly summoned, or issued a citation, to appear before the municipal judge, who fails, neglects or refuses to appear, without sufficient excuse, may be fined for contempt by the municipal judge; and the accused, if to be found in the city, shall be arrested by the police and brought before the municipal judge for trial, at such time as the recorder may designate. 
(Code 1972, § 19-9) 
Charter reference- Punishment for contempt, § 7.03. 
State Law reference- Penalty for contempt in court, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-2. 
Sec. 5-20-10. - Arrest-Generally. 
    The arresting officer instead of summoning any person charged with violating any city ordinance may, in his discretion, arrest the accused, releasing him upon his giving bond as provided in this chapter. The person arrested shall be notified of the charge against him and the time and place of his appearance, shall be entitled upon demand to a written statement of the charges against him and have compulsory process to obtain his witnesses. 
(Code 1972, § 19-10) 
State Law reference- Arrest of persons, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-1 et seq.; bonds and recognizances, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-20-11. - Same-Warrants. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law, warrants for offenders against the ordinances of the city, and the affidavits to obtain the same may be issued by the municipal judge or in his absence the assistant municipal judge, and shall be directed to the policemen of the city, or to the sheriff of the county or his deputies. Said affidavit and warrant shall be substantially in the form of affidavits and warrants of offenders against the laws of the state, substituting for "Troup County" the words "City of LaGrange." The officer will execute the warrants placed in their hands; and the arresting officer shall exercise reasonable diligence in bringing the person arrested before the municipal judge. 
(Code 1972, § 19-11) 
State Law reference- Warrants for arrest, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-40 et seq.; contents of affidavits or warrants, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-41; form of affidavit for arrest warrant, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-45; form of warrant for arrest, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-46; taking of persons arrested before judicial officer, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-61 et seq. 
Sec. 5-20-12. - Proceeding against corporation. 
    Whenever complaint is made, under oath, that a corporation has violated any ordinance of this city, it shall be the duty of the officer to whom complaint is made, having authority to issue warrants for violation of city ordinances to issue a summons directed to said corporation, requiring it to appear by agent or attorney, at the municipal court, at a time therein named, to answer said charge. Service in such cases may be made by delivering a copy of the affidavit of complaint and of the summons, to any agent or employee of the defendant, at least three (3) days before the time set for the hearing. Any policeman being competent to make such service, the entry of the arresting officer of the city, or affidavit of any other person, shall be evidence of such service. The trial may proceed ex parte, if the defendant fails to appear. If judgment is against the defendant, it shall be for a fine and costs, the same to be collected by execution. 
(Code 1972, § 19-12) 
State Law reference- Criminal responsibility of corporations, O.C.G.A. § 16-2-22; accusation against corporation, O.C.G.A. § 17-7-92. 
Sec. 5-20-13. - Admitting to bail-In first instance. 
    Any person arrested by city officers may give the arresting officer a bond with good security, resident of this county, approved by the chief of police or municipal judge. 
(Code 1972, § 19-13) 
State Law reference- Bonds and recognizances, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-1 et seq.; acceptance of bail in misdemeanor cases generally, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-2. 
Sec. 5-20-14. - Same-After rearrest. 
    When, from any cause, the municipal judge deems it necessary in order to secure the attendance of a defendant, out on bond, at the trial, that the defendant shall be taken in custody, he shall issue his warrant for the rearrest of the defendant, except as otherwise provided by law, and shall commit the defendant to jail or require new bond, as the necessities of the case may demand. 
(Code 1972, § 19-14) 
State Law reference- Amendment of bonds, giving of new security, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-18. 
Sec. 5-20-15. - Appearance bond forfeiture. 
(a)  Generally. Upon failure of any party or witness or other person who is under bond to appear, such bond shall be forfeited, unless legal excuse is offered in his behalf; the duties in such case that would apply in the superior court to the district attorney, clerk and sheriff shall be performed by the city attorney, clerk of court and chief of police respectively. 
(b)  Special bail, rule to show cause. All bonds taken under this chapter, and bonds given for appearance to abide the sentence of the court, shall be special bail, and the power of the surety over the principal shall be the same as in special bail. Upon the failure to appear of any principal in any such bond or recognizance, the municipal judge shall pass a rule, requiring the principal and sureties on such bond to show cause on any day therein named, not to be less than ten (10) days from the passage of such rule, why they should not be required to pay the amount of such bond. This subsection does not apply to cash bonds. 
(c)  Service of rule. A copy of such rule shall be served upon the principal and surety, if to be found in the city, by any officer or member of the police force, at least five (5) days before the time therein set for hearing. 
(d)  Judgment on failure to show cause. If no sufficient cause is shown, the municipal judge or other officer presiding shall proceed to enter judgment against such principal and surety, for the amount of said bond. Execution shall be issued for the amount of such judgment and placed in the hands of the chief of police, who shall proceed to collect the same by levy and sale as in the case of tax executions; provided, however, judgment shall not be entered against either principal or surety until service shall have been perfected on either the principal or the surety. 
(e)  Issuance and service of scire facias. The clerk of court shall issue a scire facias on all forfeited bonds and recognizances, whether the same were for appearance before the municipal court or the mayor and council, returnable to a regular session of the municipal court against the principal and his sureties, which shall be served by any policeman at least ten (10) days before the return date; or, if the party resides out of the city, scire facias may be served by the publication of the same one (1) time in a public newspaper in the city at least ten (10) days before the return date. The official return of the policeman as to the service of the scire facias shall be sufficient evidence of such service. 
(f)  Entry of judgment. If at the regular session of the municipal court to which the scire facias is returnable, no sufficient cause is shown to the contrary, judgment on motion shall be entered against such principal and sureties, or such of them as have been served. 
(g)  Collection of judgment. Such judgments, so rendered, shall be a lien on the property of defendants from the date of rendition and shall be enforced by execution to be issued by the assistant city manager, which may be levied and sales made thereunder as other executions. 
(h)  Surrender of principal. The bondsmen may surrender their principal at any time prior to the rendition of judgment on the scire facias issued by the clerk. Such surrender shall release the bondsmen except as to the costs accruing up to the time of such surrender. 
(i)  Not to abate proceedings. Forfeiture of bond shall not abate the proceedings against a defendant, and he may be rearrested and proceeded against for the offense committed. 
(Code 1972, §§ 19-15-19-23; Ord. No. 07-12, § 2, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 2, 12-13-16) 
State Law reference- Proceedings for forfeiture of bonds of recognizances, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-70 et seq.; executions, O.C.G.A. § 9-13-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-20-16. - Entry and signing of judgment. 
    The judgments of the court shall be entered by the clerk on the docket and then signed by the presiding officer. 
(Code 1972, § 19-24) 
Sec. 5-20-17. - Costs. 
    The costs taxed against the defendant and his sureties shall be in the same sums as the costs allowed officers of the magistrate court in criminal cases, which shall be paid into the city treasury. 
(Code 1972, § 19-25) 
Charter reference- Costs, § 7.06. 
State Law reference- Fees and costs in magistrate courts, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-80 et seq. 
Sec. 5-20-18. - Payment of fines and costs-Confinement for failure. 
    The officer in attendance on the municipal court shall take all persons who have been convicted by the court into his custody. In case such offender is financially able to do so and shall fail to pay the fine and costs immediately upon conviction, such officer shall confine such offender in the city jail until all fines and costs are paid, or shall execute the sentence of the court, whatever it may be. 
(Code 1972, § 19-26) 
State Law reference- Sentence and punishment, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-20-19. - Same-Execution. 
(a)  On failure of any person on whom a fine is imposed to pay the same immediately, where he is financially able to do so, execution may issue to collect the same, although such person is imprisoned in default of paying such fine. 
(b)  The execution may issue instanter, to be levied upon the goods, chattels, lands and tenements of the person fined, which execution shall bear teste in the name of the mayor, be signed officially by the clerk and be directed to the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, §§ 19-27, 19-28) 
Chapter 5-25 - YOUTH ADVISORY BOARD AND YOUTH ADVISORY COUNCIL 

Sec. 5-25-1. - Establishment; purpose. 
    There is hereby created a youth advisory board for the City of LaGrange for the purpose of selecting, assisting and supporting a youth advisory council (or youth city council), the mission of which is to work with local community leaders, including but not limited to members of the mayor and council, for the betterment of our community as more specifically set forth herein below. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-27-15) 
Sec. 5-25-2. - Appointment; terms. 
(a)  The youth advisory board shall consist of seven adult members, to be appointed by the mayor and council, who shall be residents of the city during any term of office. The governing authority may appoint no more than one of its members to serve as a member of the board. Initial appointees shall serve staggered terms of two and three years with appointments thereafter being for three year terms for all members. Such board shall elect among its members a chair, vice chair and secretary. 
(b)  The city manager shall designate a staff member or members to serve as liaison between the youth advisory board and the mayor and council. 
(c)  The members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-27-15) 
Sec. 5-25-3. - Authority; responsibilities; quorum. 
(a)  The youth advisory board is authorized to and shall undertake the following responsibilities: 
(1)  To select and provide guidance to a youth advisory council which shall serve as a forum to assist the youth advisory board and the mayor and council in determining the needs and concerns of youth in the city; 
(2)  To expose and educate the city's youth to the operations of local government; 
(3)  To assist the city's youth in dealing with issues affecting the city's youth as well as the broader community; 
(4)  To develop plans, to sponsor and to coordinate with other organizations as appropriate youth programs, activities and events in the city and to present such plans as a recommendation to the mayor and council as often as may be necessary to ensure orderly development of such programs, activities and events. All such undertakings are to be in coordination with, and with the assistance of, the youth advisory council; 
(5)  To assist and coordinate its activities with city staff, other organizations and the public to ensure a successful youth advisory council program in the City of LaGrange; and 
(6)  To elicit, as needed, volunteer assistance from other members of the community to accomplish its duties and responsibilities. 
(b)  A majority of the members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting the business of the board, and a majority of the members present shall be required to pass any measure. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-27-15) 
Sec. 5-25-4. - Youth advisory council (youth city council); composition; terms; appointment. 
(a)  The youth advisory council shall be composed of junior and senior students in high school who are residents of the City of LaGrange, with the total number not to exceed 24 members. Members are to be appointed by the youth advisory council. In appointing members to the youth advisory council, consideration should be given to individuals with a proven interest in community improvement, and also to achieving a broad representation for all local area high schools. 
(b)  Initial terms of appointment shall be staggered terms of one and two years, with terms thereafter being two-year terms. 
(c)  The youth advisory council shall elect from its members a chair, vice chair, secretary, and such other offices as are deemed prudent. 
(d)  A majority of the members of the youth advisory council shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting the business of the council, with a majority vote of those present being required for the passage of any measure. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-27-15) 
Sec. 5-25-5. - Meetings. 
    The members of the youth advisory board and youth advisory council are authorized to provide for the rules and procedure for the holding of regular and special meetings of each body as deemed advisable and necessary. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-27-15) 
Title 10 - PUBLIC SAFETY AND HEALTH[1] 
Footnotes:

Chapter 10-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS [2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- This chapter is reserved for future ordinances. 

Chapter 10-5 - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 10-5-1. - Department created; chief of police; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the police department of the city, the head of which shall be the chief. The chief shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 18-13, § 2, 11-27-18) 
Sec. 10-5-2. - Powers and duties of chief generally. 
    The chief shall be responsible for the administration, coordination and control of all police activities for the city, and to that end shall: 
(1)  Plan, organize and command all police activities involved in protecting lives and property; preserve the public peace, prevent the commission of acts of crime and investigate and detect acts of crime; 
(2)  Establish procedures, rules and regulations for the conduct of the department within the framework of the general policies approved by the mayor and council; 
(3)  Develop, approve and conduct training programs for police department employees and attend conferences, schools and conventions to keep abreast of the latest police methods and administration; 
(4)  Supervise all departmental personnel and the operation and maintenance of all equipment and property; maintain any city jail; be responsible for the custody and care of prisoners and cooperate with all county, state and federal law enforcing officers in the prevention and detection of acts of crime; 
(5)  Enforce all laws, ordinances and the judgments of courts; execute warrants; serve summons, subpoenas and citations issued by the courts or by the mayor and council in accordance with the law; 
(6)  Collect and remit to the city clerk all fines, forfeitures and costs imposed by the court under the jurisdiction of the mayor and council; 
(7)  Maintain a system of complaint, arrest, identification and accident records; prepare monthly and annual reports of activities and assist in the preparation of the annual budget; and 
(8)  Perform related duties as may be directed by the city manager or prescribed by ordinance or resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 18-13, § 2, 11-27-18) 
Chapter 10-10 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) ---

Former §§ 10-10-1, 10-10-2 pertained to the designation, powers and duties of the chief of the fire prevention and protection department and derived from the 1972 Code; Ord. No. 92-8, adopted Apr. 14, 1992; and Ord. No. 93-60, adopted Dec. 14, 1993. Section 4 of Ord. No. 06-01 directed the renumbering of §§ 10-10-3-10-10-5 as §§ 10-10-1-10-10-3, respectively. 
Charter reference- Codes of technical regulations, § 2.42; fire prevention, § 5.23.

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-10-1. - Division designated; chief; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the fire prevention and protection department of the city, the head of which shall be the chief. The chief shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 18-13, § 4, 11-27-18) 
Sec. 10-10-2. - Powers and duties of chief. 
    The chief shall be responsible for the planning, directing and supervising of all the activities of the fire prevention and protection department, and to that end shall: 
(1)  Exercise general control and supervision of the equipment, apparatus, and personnel of the department; 
(2)  Investigate or cause to be investigated the cause, origin and circumstances of all fires within the city; maintain a system of records; prepare monthly and annual reports of fire department activities and assist in the preparation of the annual budget; 
(3)  Develop, approve and conduct training programs for fire department employees and attend conferences, schools and conventions to keep abreast of the latest fire-fighting methods and administration; 
(4)  Enforce all laws, ordinances and resolutions of the mayor and council pertaining to fire prevention, fire control and fire safety. 
(5)  Establish procedures, rules and regulations for the conduct of the department within the framework of the general policies approved by the mayor and council. 
(6)  Serve as local fire marshal deputized by the state fire marshal and as such perform the duties imposed by the state laws; and 
(7)  Perform related duties as may be directed by the city manager or prescribed by ordinance or resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 18-13, § 4, 11-27-18) 
Sec. 10-10-3. - Persons allowed near fire; obedience to orders. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except firemen, the mayor, members of council, the police force, employees of the city in performance of their duties, the owners of the property, their agents and the agents of insurance companies, to be within the immediate vicinity of any fire, without being ordered there by the officer in command of the fire department; and every person shall obey the orders and directions of such officer. 
(Code 1972, § 11-1; Ord. No. 06-01, § 4, 2-28-06; Ord. No. 18-13, § 3, 11-27-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-13, § 3, adopted November 27, 2018, renumbered § 10-10-1 as § 10-10-3. 
Sec. 10-10-4. - Fire alarms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, destroy or in any manner interfere with the electric fire alarm system of the city, or with the batteries, boxes, stations, wires or other apparatus or appurtenances belonging thereto or used in connection therewith. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to give or cause to be given, with intent to deceive, a false alarm of fire, or to pull the slide of any station or signal box, except in case of fire. 
(Code 1972, §§ 11-2, 11-3; Ord. No. 93-37, § 2, 7-13-93; Ord. No. 04-14, § 2, 4-13-04; Ord. No. 06-01, § 4, 2-28-06; Ord. No. 18-13, § 3, 11-27-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-13, § 3, adopted November 27, 2018, renumbered § 10-10-2 as § 10-10-4. 
State Law reference- Transmitting false report of a fire, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-27. 
Sec. 10-10-5. - Obstructing fire station exit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the exit of any building housing fire trucks or other mobile apparatus of the fire department. 
(Code 1972, § 11-4; Ord. No. 06-01, § 4, 2-28-06; Ord. No. 18-13, § 3, 11-27-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-13, § 3, adopted November 27, 2018, renumbered § 10-10-3 as § 10-10-5. 
State Law reference- Standing or parking a vehicle near entrance to fire station, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-203.
