Article III - FIRE PREVENTION CODES 

Secs. 10-10-46-10-10-49. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-08, § 1, adopted Mar. 26, 2002 deleted § 10-10-46 which pertained to the fire prevention codes adopted and amended and derived from Ord. No. 85-45, § 1, adopted Nov. 14, 1989; ord. No. 91-39, § 5, adopted Sept. 24, 1991; Ord. No. 95-32, § 1, adopted July 25, 1995. 
Ord. No. 91-39, § 5, adopted Sept. 24, 1991, deleted §§ 10-47, 10-49. Such sections pertained to modifications of the 1988 fire prevention code and appeals from decisions of the fire chief as derived from the 1972 Code, § 11-43 and Ord. No. 89-45, § 1, adopted Nov. 14, 1989. Further, Ord. No. 89-45 had previously deleted § 10-10-48, derived from the 1972 Code. Section 17 of Ord. No. 93-60, adopted Dec. 14, 1993, amended the deleted § 10-10-49. 
Sec. 10-10-50. - Fire protection systems. 
    All fire protection systems will be installed in accordance with the most current applicable codes. Such system must be installed and served by certified personnel of the manufacturer of the particular system, and shall be subject to the approval of the fire prevention bureau. 
(Code 1972, § 11-30) 
Sec. 10-10-51. - Group homes. 
(a)  Generally. This section applies to group homes providing sleeping accommodations for eighteen (18) or fewer persons. In addition to the provisions hereof, every group home shall comply with the minimum requirements for one-and two-family dwellings. A group home with sleeping accommodations for more than eighteen (18) persons shall meet the requirements for dormitories as set forth in the National Fire Protection Association 101 Life Safety Code (or other title thereof), as is currently in force in the city. 
(b)  Means of egress: 
(1)  Every sleeping room shall have access to two (2) separate means of exit if more than three (3) persons are occupying said sleeping room; 
(2)  Exit access shall have flame spread ratings class A finish or class B; 
(3)  Measurement of travel distance to exit shall not exceed one hundred (100) feet. 
(c)  Bedding. Bedding (mattresses) will be one hundred (100) percent cotton boric acid treated with the ticking approved under D.O.C. ff 4-72. 
(d)  Alarm system: 
(1)  Buildings will be equipped with automatic smoke detection. 
(2)  Smoke detectors shall be installed on each floor level and in all sleeping areas. 
(3)  Two (2) telephones are required. 
(4)  Fire drills shall be conducted monthly. A report shall be submitted to the fire prevention bureau no later than the fifth of each month. 
(e)  Occupant load. The occupant load for any floor shall be the maximum number of persons intended to occupy that floor but not less than one (1) person for each one hundred twenty (120) square feet gross floor area, pending approval of the fire department. 
(Code 1972, § 11-29) 
Sec. 10-10-52. - Application of building and fire related codes to existing buildings. 
(a)  In accordance with the provisions of Section 8-2-203 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, there is hereby adopted and designated for enforcement thereof in the City of LaGrange the Uniform Act for the Application of Building and Fire Related Codes to Existing Buildings. In so doing, there shall be incorporated into the Code of the City of LaGrange, by reference, the applicable provisions of O.C.G.A. section 8-2-200 through section 8-2-222. 
(b)  The right to appeal enforcement decisions rendered pursuant to this Code section shall be in accordance with the appeal procedure set forth in Section 10-10-46 above. 
(Ord. No. 95-33, § 1, 7-25-95) 
Secs. 10-10-53-10-10-60. - Reserved. 
Article IV - FIRE LANES 

Sec. 10-10-61. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the City of LaGrange Fire Lane Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-62. - Purpose and scope. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the designation and identification of fire lanes; the manner, method and language for the posting of signs for fire lanes; to provide for enforcement of this article and the authority therefor; to prohibit parking in fire lanes; to identify the property subject to the provisions of this article; and to provide a penalty for violation of the provisions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-63. - Definitions. 
    The words in this article shall have their normal accepted meanings except as set forth below: 
    Authorized emergency vehicle shall include a vehicle designated as an emergency vehicle by the department of public safety; an authorized emergency service vehicle; a vehicle of the LaGrange Police Department or LaGrange Fire Department; a motor vehicle of a federal, state, local law enforcement agency; a vehicle of any utility of the city or of any other public utility corporation; provided any such vehicle is at the time being used as an emergency vehicle by a person authorized to use the same for that purpose. 
    City of LaGrange means the corporate limits of the City of LaGrange, Georgia. 
    Enforcement officer(s) shall refer to any duly authorized law enforcement officer or fire official employed by the City of LaGrange, Georgia. 
    Fire lane(s) are areas designated by the fire official providing access for fire department vehicles to buildings, fire department connections and fire hydrants. This includes all alleys, driveways or lanes, on public or private property available or devoted for use by the general public, where the parking of motor vehicles or other obstructions may interfere with or obstruct the ingress or egress of fire department vehicles for the protection of persons and properties and includes but is not limited to shopping centers, theatres, hospitals, bowling lanes, churches, multi-family housing, and high-rise buildings. 
    Fire official means the LaGrange Fire Chief, or other designated authority, or their duly authorized representative, charged with the administration and enforcement of the fire prevention code. 
    New building(s) means any commercial structure or facility whose certificate of occupancy was issued after the effective date of this article. 
    Property owner(s) shall refer to each person, firm, corporation, or entity possessing any estate, usufruct or leasehold right in the property being designated as fire lane(s). 
    Return mail parking citation shall mean an order issued out of Court, by an enforcement officer of the City of LaGrange, directing a violator of this article to comply with all penalties as set forth. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-64. - Identification. 
(a)  All existing fire lanes shall be recognized as meeting the requirements of this article and shall not be obstructed in any manner, including the parking of vehicles, and shall be accessible to fire department vehicles or apparatus. All new buildings shall be accessible to fire department apparatus by way of fire lanes constructed in accordance with the SBCCI Standard Fire Prevention code, 1991 edition. Designated fire lanes shall be provided with an all weather driving surface of not less than twenty (20) feet, of unobstructed width. There shall be adequate roadway turning radius capable of supporting the imposed loads of fire apparatus and having a vertical clearance of thirteen (13) feet, six (6) inches. During construction, when combustibles are brought onto the site in such quantities as may be deemed hazardous by the fire official, access roads and a suitable temporary supply of water acceptable to the fire department shall be provided and maintained. 
(1)  Where fire protection systems approved by the fire official are provided, the above required clearances may be modified by the fire official. 
(2)  The fire official shall have the authority to require an increase in the minimum access widths where they are deemed inadequate for fire or rescue operations. 
(3)  The creation of a fire lane at existing locations shall be done solely at the discretion of the fire official. 
(b)  The areas designated as fire lanes shall be marked and shall have signs erected thereon at the sole expense of the property owner meeting the following criteria: 
(1)  Signs shall be aluminum reflective, standard size of eighteen (18) inches by twenty-four (24) inches, with red letters on a white background, and shall be placed seven (7) feet from ground level. 
(2)  Signs shall read "NO PARKING FIRE LANE" or "FIRE LANE NO PARKING AT ANY TIME". 
(3)  Letters on signs shall not be less than two (2) inches in height. 
(4)  One (1) sign shall be posted at the beginning of the fire lane and one (1) at the end of the fire lane. Additional signs may be required within the fire lane and each sign erected shall not be more than fifty (50) feet apart. 
(5)  Signs posted shall not be more than four (4) feet from the edge of the curb, and shall be visible from both directions of the driving surface. 
(6)  The fire lane shall also have the words "FIRE LANE" painted on the paved surface at distances of not more than fifty (50) feet apart. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-65. - Approval; subsequent maintenance. 
    All fire lanes shall be approved by the fire official pursuant to these regulations, and thereafter shall be maintained by the property owner. Designated fire lanes or roads deemed necessary for fire department access by the fire official shall be maintained in a passable condition. 
(1)  Private property owners or their representative(s) shall be responsible for keeping all fire lanes on their property free from obstructions. 
(2)  Public property owners or their representative(s) shall be responsible for keeping all fire lanes within the corporate limits of the city free of obstructions. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-66. - Erection of fire lane signs. 
    No person or property owner shall place, erect or maintain any sign for control of parking or traffic which includes the words "fire lanes", unless such location has been designated a fire lane by the fire official. Any person failing to meet the applicable sign requirements specified in section 10-10-64 shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each violation; provided however, that such fine may be waived if the required specifications are complied with within fourteen (14) days of the date of citation. If the property owner fails or refuse to meet said requirements on his property within such fourteen (14) days he shall, on the fifteenth (15) day after receiving the citation, be subject to the one hundred fifty dollar ($150.00) fine for each violation and an additional five dollars ($5.00) fine for each violation for each day that the owner fails to comply with the provisions of this subsection until the area is properly designated and constructed. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-67. - Violations. 
(a)  The parking of any vehicle in violation of the provisions hereof, will authorize the issuance of a citation therefore in accordance with the provisions of the code which shall be left with the vehicle or delivered to the person in charge or in possession thereof. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in section 10-10-66, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provisions of this article, shall upon conviction, be fined as provided in this article, but not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00), or otherwise punished as provided in section 1-1-6 of this Code as such provision may now exist or hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-68. - Enforcement authority. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by any duly authorized law enforcement officer or fire official employed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-69. - Liability of owner and/or operator of vehicle. 
    For the purposes of the enforcement of the provisions of this article and for the assessment of any fines or penalties for violation thereof, it shall be presumed that the owner of a vehicle is in control and/or is in possession of the same. The lessee or owner of any vehicle shall not be liable for any fine or penalty assessed if notification is given to the appropriate court in which any violation is pending, certifying the name and address of the person or persons who, with permission of the lessee or owner, was operating the vehicle on the date and at the time the violation occurred. Failure of the lessee or owner to submit such notice while such proceeding is pending and prior to disposition thereof shall render the lessee/owner liable for such parking violation. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-70. - Liability from enforcement of Fire Lane Ordinance pertaining to maintenance and clearing of fire lanes. 
    The city assumes no liability for any damages, injuries, or deaths resulting from enforcement, or lack of enforcement, of the laws pertaining to maintenance and clearing of the fire lanes. The city has the authority to issue individual citations for fire lane violations, but the property owner shall have the ultimate and final responsibility to maintain clear fire lanes on his property. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-71. - Enforceability of properly placed signs. 
    The disregard or disobedience of the instruction of any sign placed in accordance with the provisions of this section by the driver of a vehicle shall be deemed prima-facie evidence of a violation of law, without requiring proof by whom and by what authority such sign has been erected. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-72. - Enforcement-Suspended. 
    Enforcement of the provisions of this article at a specific location may be suspended only pursuant to written agreement between the appropriate fire official of the city and the property owner involved. Such agreement shall be in writing and will make the property owner involved solely responsible for any damages, injuries or deaths resulting from lack of enforcement of the Fire Lane Ordinance. The property owner shall also be required by the agreement to indemnify, release and hold harmless the city and any other person, board, commission, or agent from any cause of action which relates either directly or indirectly to the suspension of enforcement of the Fire Lane Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93) 
Sec. 10-10-73. - Identification and marking of fire lanes. 
    The chief of the fire department of the city shall have the right and is hereby authorized and directed to enter upon private property for the purpose of designating those areas on private, residential, commercial or industrial property which in the exercise of fire safety shall require the identification, marking and existence of fire lanes for the protection of the occupants thereof and the general public. Any such fire lanes shall be designated by the fire chief or his designated representative in writing and it shall thereupon be the responsibility of the owner of such property to identify the fire lanes and to mark the same and to prohibit parking thereon or therein in violation of the provisions of this article. Any parking lanes when so identified by the fire chief or his designated representative shall become fire lanes of the city and shall in all instances be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1, 8-10-93; Ord. No. 06-01, § 7, 2-28-06; Ord. No. 18-13, § 5, 11-27-18) 
Chapter 10-15 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- Emergency ordinances, § 2.41. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 5-1 et seq.; police, Ch. 10-5; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10-10. 
State constitution reference- Emergency, special session of General Assembly, Art. 5, § 2, Par. 7. 
State Law reference- Forest fires, O.C.G.A. § 12-6-89; state militia, O.C.G.A. § 38-2-1 et seq.; emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.; retirement of employees of state emergency management division, O.C.G.A. § 47-5-2; emergency funds for local government, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-2; liability of firemen for emergency activities, O.C.G.A. § 51-1-30. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-15-1. - Definition. 
    As used in this chapter the term "civil defense" or "emergency management" shall mean the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions, other than functions for which military forces or other state and federal agencies are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies, energy emergencies, disasters or the imminent threat thereof, of man-made or natural origin caused by enemy attack, sabotage, civil disturbance, fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, wave action, oil spill or other water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot or other hostile action, or other causes. These functions include, without limitation, fire fighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, warning services, communications, defense from radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to total emergency and disaster preparedness for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. 
(Code 1972, § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Definitions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3. 
Sec. 10-15-2. - Violations. 
    No person shall violate any provision of this article, nor any rule, order or regulation made pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1972, § 8-6) 
State Law reference- Local orders, rules and regulations, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-28. 
Sec. 10-15-3. - Construction. 
    This article shall be construed liberally in order to effectuate its purpose. 
(Code 1972, § 8-7) 
Sec. 10-15-4. - Civil defense office; local director. 
    There is hereby established the LaGrange Civil Defense Office. The mayor, with concurrence of other city officials, shall nominate, for appointment by the governor, a local director of civil defense for the city. When appointed, the local director shall: 
(1)  Represent the mayor and council on matters pertaining to civil preparedness and emergency management; 
(2)  Assist city officials in organizing city departments for emergency operations; 
(3)  Develop, in conjunction with city departments and agencies, the city plan for emergency functions set forth in section 10-15-1. Such plan will be in consonance with the state emergency management plan and program and shall be submitted to the mayor and council and thence to the state director of emergency management for approval; 
(4)  Maintain the civil defense office in carrying out the day-to-day administration of the city civil preparedness and emergency management program including the rendering of required reports to the emergency management division of the state department of defense; 
(5)  Render reports such as financial, daily activity, etc., as required by the mayor and council in keeping with good business practices; 
(6)  Procure, with the authority of the mayor and council, a facility to be used as the City of LaGrange Emergency Operating Center; and 
(7)  Coordinate the activities of the City of LaGrange Emergency Operating Center staff during periods of a declared emergency, and under the supervision of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 8-2) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 5-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- State of emergency defined, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5); local organizations for emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27; emergency powers of governor, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-51. 
Sec. 10-15-5. - Emergency management organization. 
    The LaGrange emergency management organization shall be established around existing city departments and agencies and the emergency functions listed in section 10-15-1 are assigned as follows: 
Department Emergency Functions (1) Executive (city manager) Direction and control, public information, supply, finances (2) Police (city police department) Security, movement, search, communications, warning (3) Fire control (city fire department) Fire control, rescue, damage assessment (4) Public works and engineering Utilities and public services, restoration, hazards analysis (5) Human resources, including: Human needs, including welfare a. Division of family and children services b. Division of physical health c. Hospital services Medical and mortuary service d. Ambulance services Casualty transport (6) Civil defense Shelter, radiological defense (radet), rescue, assistance in industrial and institutional emergency, planning  
Heads of departments listed above are responsible for developing the plan for their assigned emergency function. Such plans will be submitted through the local director to the mayor and council for approval. 
(Code 1972, § 8-3) 
State Law reference- Local organizations for emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27. 
Sec. 10-15-6. - Emergency powers. 
    In the event of man-made or natural disaster, actual enemy attack upon the United States or any other emergency which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of LaGrange, the mayor and council may declare that a state of emergency exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such state of emergency exists or continues, the following emergency powers: 
(1)  To enforce all rules, laws and regulations relating to civil defense and to assume direct operational control over all civil defense resources; 
(2)  To seize, take for temporary use or condemn any property or supplies for the protection of the public; 
(3)  To sell, lend, give or distribute all or any such property or supplies among the inhabitants of the city; to maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies; and 
(4)  To perform and exercise such other functions and duties and take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well being of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 8-4) 
State Law reference- Orders, rules and regulations of governor, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-22; control of traffic, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-24; lease or loan of state property, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-25; power of city to acquire sites for temporary housing, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27(b)(6); local orders, rules and regulations, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-28. 
Sec. 10-15-7. - Volunteers. 
    While engaged in emergency functions under this chapter, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as city officers and employees. 
(Code 1972, § 8-5) 
State Law reference- Aid to other political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-30; permitting use of premises, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-32; providing equipment, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-33; qualifications and oath of personnel, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-34; immunity of workers, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-35. 
Secs. 10-15-8-10-15-20. - Reserved. 
Article II - CONTINUITY OF GOVERNMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Title 5. 
State Law reference- Emergency interim successors to officials, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-50. 

Sec. 10-15-21. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise clearly indicates, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    Disaster: Any happening that causes great harm or damage. 
    Duly authorized deputy: A person who is authorized to perform all of the functions, exercise all of the powers and discharge all of the duties of an office in the event the office is vacant or at such times as it lacks administration due to the death, absence or disability of the incumbent officer. 
    Emergency: A sudden generally unexpected occurrence or set of circumstances demanding immediate action. 
    Emergency interim successor: A person designated pursuant to this article for possible temporary succession to the powers and duties, but not the office, of a city officer in the event that such officer or any duly authorized deputy is unavailable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office. 
    Unavailable: Either that a vacancy in an office exists and there is no deputy or other successor authorized to exercise all of the powers and discharge all of the duties of the office, or that the lawful incumbent of the office (including any deputy exercising the powers and discharging the duties of an office because of a vacancy) and his duly authorized deputy are absent or unable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office. 
(Code 1972, § 8-21) 
State Law reference- Definitions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-50. 
Sec. 10-15-22. - Designation, status, qualifications, terms of emergency interim successors. 
(a)  Elective officers. Within thirty (30) days after first entering upon the duties of their office, the mayor and each member of the council shall, in addition to any duly authorized deputy, designate such number of emergency interim successors to their office and specify their rank in order of succession after any duly authorized deputy so that there will be not less than three (3) duly authorized deputies or emergency interim successors or combination thereof for the office. 
(b)  Appointive officers. The mayor and council shall within the time specified in subsection (a) of this section, in addition to any duly authorized deputy, designate for appointive officers including the city manager, chief of police, chief of the fire department and recorder, such number of emergency interim successors to these officers and specify their rank in order of succession after any duly authorized deputy so that there will be not less than three (3) duly authorized deputies or emergency interim successors or combination thereof for each officer. 
(c)  Review of designations. The incumbent in the case of those elective officers specified in subsection (a) of this section, and the mayor and council in the case of those appointive officers specified in subsection (b) of this section, shall review and, as necessary, promptly revise the designations of emergency interim successors or duly authorized deputies or any combination thereof for each officer specified. 
(d)  Qualifications. No person shall be designated or serve as an emergency interim successor unless he may under the constitution and statutes of this state and the charter or ordinances of this city hold the office of the person to whose powers and duties he is designated to succeed, but no provision of any ordinance prohibiting an officer or employee of this city from holding another office shall be applicable to an emergency interim successor. 
(e)  Status of emergency interim successor. A person designated as an emergency interim successor holds that designation at the pleasure of the designator; provided he must be replaced if removed. He retains this designation as emergency interim successor until replaced by another person appointed by the authorized designator. 
(Code 1972, § 8-22) 
Sec. 10-15-23. - Assumption of powers and duties of officer. 
    If, in the event of a disaster or emergency, any officer named in subsections (a) and (b) of section 10-15-22 and any duly authorized deputy is unavailable, his emergency interim successor highest in rank in order of succession who is not unavailable shall, except for the power and duty to appoint emergency interim successors, exercise the powers and discharge the duties of such officer. An emergency interim successor shall exercise these powers and discharge these duties only until such time as the lawful incumbent officer or any duly authorized deputy or an emergency interim successor higher in rank in order of succession exercises, or resumes the exercise of, the powers and discharge of the duties of the office, or until, where an actual vacancy exists, a successor is appointed to fill such vacancy or is elected and qualified as provided by law. 
(Code 1972, § 8-23) 
Sec. 10-15-24. - Recording; publication. 
    The name, address and rank in order of succession of each duly authorized deputy shall be filed with the assistant city manager, and each designation, replacement or change in order of succession of an emergency interim successor shall become effective when the designator files with the assistant city manager the successor's name, address and rank in order of succession. The assistant city manager shall keep on file all such data regarding duly authorized deputies and emergency interim successors and it shall be open to the public inspection. 
(Code 1972, § 8-24; Ord. No. 07-12, § 3, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 4, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 10-15-25. - Formalities of taking office. 
    At the time of their designation, emergency interim successors shall take such oath and do such other things, if any, as may be required to qualify them to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office to which they may succeed. 
(Code 1972, § 8-25) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-50(g). 
Sec. 10-15-26. - Quorum; vote by mayor and council. 
    In the event of a disaster or emergency, quorum requirements for the mayor and council shall be suspended, and where the affirmative vote of a specified proportion of members for approval of an ordinance, resolution or other action would otherwise be required, the same proportion of those voting thereon shall be sufficient. 
(Code 1972, § 8-26) 
Chapter 10-20 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Police department, Ch. 10-5; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10-10; animals and fowl, Ch. 10-30; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 15-5; use of refuse disposal area, § 15-10-7; parks and recreation, Ch. 15-15; cemeteries, Ch. 15-20; signs obstructing clear vision or similar to traffic-control devices, § 25-10-11; off-street automobile parking and storage, § 25-35-6; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 30-1 et seq.; sanitation of food vehicles, § 30-5-2; rental vehicles, § 30-5-181 et seq.; noise, § 35-1-19. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, O.C.G.A. Title 40. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-20-1. - Jurisdiction. 
    Any violation of this chapter which is also a violation of the laws of Georgia may, in the discretion of the recorder, be tried as an offense under this chapter or may be treated as an offense of such state law. In the latter event, the recorder shall bind the defendant over to appropriate court having jurisdiction over said offense. 
(Code 1972, § 23-211) 
State Law reference- Commitment hearings, O.C.G.A. § 17-7-20 et seq. 
Sec. 10-20-2. - Statutes adopted by reference. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. sections 40-6-372-40-6-376, that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. section 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited in this section. Any future amendment or repeal of a provision of such laws shall so amend or repeal the pertinent provision, if any, of the original ordinance adopted by the city pursuant to the authority of O.C.G.A. section 40-6-372 without any action by the city being required. 
(Code 1972, § 23-1) 
Sec. 10-20-3. - Offenses by persons owning or controlling vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or any other person, employing or otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle, to require or knowingly permit the operation of such vehicle upon a highway in any manner contrary to law. 
(Code 1972, § 23-170)

Sec. 10-20-6. - Railroad crossings; train speed. 
(a)  At every place in the city at which any railroad track or tracks intersect or cross a public street or right-of-way, the railroad company which owns and operates such track or tracks shall cause traffic-warning devices to be erected and maintained as follows: 
(1)  The Greenville Street, Main Street, Park Avenue, Vernon Road, Depot Street between Morgan and Whitesville Streets and Hines Street at McGee Street crossings shall each have installed and maintained an automatically activated train approach signaling device as described and specified in sections 5-128 through 5-137 of The Georgia Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, adopted July 3, 1962, as amended on November 17, 1966, and as the same may be thereafter amended; provided, however, that a railroad company having a track or tracks at any of the above named crossings upon which a train does not activate an installed and maintained automatically controlled signaling device, as above-referred to, shall provide, for the protection of users of such crossing, a flagman or watchman at each such crossing prior to each train crossing such intersection and to remain until such crossing is completed. 
(2)  All other crossings within the corporate limits of the city shall have erected and installed a railroad crossing "crossbuck sign" described in and specified by The Georgia Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, section 1-111, and the stop sign described and specified in section 1-33, subparagraph 6. 
(b)  Railroad trains shall not be operated at speeds in excess of 45 miles per hour within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 23-11; Ord. No. 89-30, § 1, 8-22-89) 
State Law reference- Railroad crossings, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-140 et seq. 
Sec. 10-20-7. - Garages; service stations. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or proprietor of any garage to wash or allow to be washed any motor vehicle on the streets or sidewalks. The sidewalks in front of garages and oil and gasoline filling stations shall be kept clean from oil and grease. Containers of oil and grease shall not be kept adjacent to sidewalks or in any place where oil or grease leaking from or wasted around such containers shall drain into the street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1972, § 23-12) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 30-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Storage, transportation and handling of hazardous materials, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-16. 
Sec. 10-20-8. - Certain vehicles, access limited on certain streets or parts thereof. 
(a)  "Vehicle" as used herein is defined to mean any truck, bus, car, trailer, or other means of vehicular transportation, or any combination thereof, which shall contain greater than six wheels. 
(b)  Any vehicle as defined in subsection (a) shall be operated upon the street or streets named herein only in accordance with and subject to the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Except as provided in subsection (d), no vehicle as defined in subsection (a) shall be operated upon the following streets or portions thereof: 
North Barnard Avenue from its intersection with Hogansville Road west to its intersection with Youngs Mill Road. 
Beechwood Circle, in its entirety. 
Elm Drive, in its entirety. 
Fort Drive from its intersection with Hamilton Road to its intersection with Whitesville Street. 
Grady Street, in its entirety. 
Hoffman Drive beginning at a point three hundred (300) feet south of its intersection with LaFayette Parkway (Highway 109) and extending south for a distance of two hundred fifty-six (256) feet. 
Jefferson Street, in its entirety. 
Ragland Street from its intersection with LaFayette Parkway south to its intersection with Colquitt Street. 
(d)  Vehicles owned and operated by public or private utility companies, commercial vehicles making deliveries to property abutting upon such streets, vehicles in use for construction repair or maintenance of real estate located on such streets, or used for construction, repair or maintenance of such streets, are not prohibited, but shall only be used for the period of time required for the delivery of service or the construction, repair or maintenance required. 
(e)  The vehicular traffic prohibited in this section is incompatible with the normal and safe movement of traffic and the exercise by the city of the right of prohibiting and/or restricting such traffic is pursuant to the police power granted to the city by the Charter and by the General Assembly of Georgia. 
(Code 1972, § 23-16; Ord. No. 95-40, § 1, 9-26-95; Ord. No. 96-30, §§ 1, 2, 4-23-96; Ord. No. 97-24, §§ 1-3, 7-8-97; Ord. No. 98-29, § 1, 10-13-98; Ord. No. 07-04, §§ 1, 2, 2-27-07; Ord. No. 19-03, § 1, 3-26-19)

    Any traffic which shall have a height of more than fourteen (14) feet is prohibited on Medical Drive, from its intersection with Doctors Drive north for a distance of seven hundred (700) feet. 
(Code 1972, § 23-17)

    O.C.G.A. sections 33-34-12 and 33-34-13 are adopted by reference and made a part of the provisions of this section without the necessity of publishing or posting the same in their entirety, with like affect as if recited herein so that any future amendment to or the repealing of a provision thereof shall so amend or repeal provisions adopted by this reference. 
(Code 1972, § 23-18; Ord. No. 85-10, § 1, 6-6-85) 
Sec. 10-20-11. - Wrecker service. 
    The maximum fees or rates charged by a wrecker service performing towing and storage services pursuant to the block towing system currently utilized by the city shall be as follows: 
(a)  For services of wrecker for vehicles with two axles, the rate shall be $150.00 per tow, and the storage for such vehicle per day shall be $20.00. 
(b)  For vehicles with more than two axles, the storage fee shall be $40.00 per day per truck and $40.00 per day per trailer, and the wrecker services fees shall be as follows: 
(1)  Truck with no trailer, occupied ..... $200.00 
(2)  Truck with no trailer, unoccupied ..... 250.00 
(3)  Truck with empty trailer, occupied ..... 300.00 
(4)  Truck with empty trailer, unoccupied ..... 350.00 
(5)  Truck with loaded trailer, occupied ..... 450.00 
(6)  Truck with loaded trailer, unoccupied ..... 500.00 
(Ord. No. 93-10, § 1, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 95-35, § 1, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 01-13, § 1, 5-22-01; Ord. No. 05-10, § 1, 8-9-05; Ord. No. 06-05, § 1, 4-11-06; Ord. No. 07-24, § 1, 7-24-07; Ord. No. 08-18, § 1, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 18-16, § 1, 12-20-18) 
Sec. 10-20-12. - Motorized carts. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall have the meanings designated below: 
(1)  Licensed driver shall mean an individual with a currently valid driver's licence or any other license or permit to operate a motor vehicle issued under, or granted by, the laws of this state, except a temporary license or instruction permit. 
(2)  Motorized cart means every vehicle having no less than three (3) wheels and an unladen weight of thirteen hundred (1300) pounds which cannot operate at more than twenty (20) miles per hour and which is designed to carry not more than two (2) persons, including the driver. 
(3)  Street means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
(b)  Except as provided herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorized cart on any street within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  Motorized carts may be operated only by a licensed driver and only on that portion of any street within the city with a speed limit of thirty (30) miles per hour or less, and during daylight hours only. 
(d)  Motorized carts shall not be operated upon any street or highway within the city under the jurisdiction of the department of transportation except at crossings or intersections designated for that purpose by the department of transportation, regardless of the speed limit upon said street or highway. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorized cart on any herein allowed portion of the streets of the city with a number of passengers or occupants in excess of the recommended specifications of the manufacturer of said motorized cart. 
(f)  No regulation or prohibition contained within this section shall apply to motorized carts owned by golf courses, country clubs or such organized entities which own such carts and make them available to members or the public on a rental basis. 
(g)  Any person who violates the terms of this section shall if convicted be punished as provided in section 1-1-5. 
(h)  Any parent, legal guardian or person legally in loco parentis or other person having legal custody or control of or responsibility for a minor child who violates the terms of this section, and who has knowingly or recklessly allowed or caused said minor child to violate this section shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-1-5. 
(Ord. No. 00-23, § 1, 9-12-00) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 00-23, § 1, adopted Sept. 12, 2000, enacted provisions which pertained to motorized carts, designaged as § 10-20-120. Such provisions were redesignated by the editor as § 10-20-12 for purposes of classification. 
Sec. 10-20-13. - Skates, skateboards and certain activities prohibited. 
(a)  No person upon roller skates, skateboard, inline skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, hover board or similar devices (hereafter "skating or riding") shall go upon any public roadway within the city except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, and when so crossing the person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(b)  Skating or riding on the sidewalks, alleyways, promenades, or any parking lot or parking deck within the downtown retail parking district (as defined in Code section 10-20-100) is prohibited. In addition to such facilities within the downtown retail parking district, this prohibition also extends to the public parking lot which abuts Broome Street and the Troup County Government Center property which abuts Ridley Avenue. 
(c)  Skating or riding is allowed upon the sidewalks outside of the downtown retail parking district, however, persons so skating or riding shall not take hold of or hang onto any vehicle or in any way interfere with the natural progress of vehicles along and in the streets of the city, nor shall two (2) or more persons join hands while skating or riding on said sidewalk. In all instances, persons skating or riding on the sidewalk shall yield the right-of-way to and may not interfere with pedestrians on the sidewalks. 
(d)  Any person violating subsections (a), (b) or (c) of this Code section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished in accordance with section 1-1-6 of the Code. 
(e)  No parent, legal guardian or person legally in loco parentis or other person having legal custody or control of or responsibility for a minor between six (6) and through and including sixteen (16) years of age shall at any time, through insufficient control or supervision, allow any such child to engage in an offense defined above in subsections (a), (b) or (c) hereinabove. Responsibility for the prevention of such offenses by any minor child shall be attached to the parent or other such person having legal custody or control of the child upon proof of prior notification of said child's potential to so offend. Such prior notification shall be established through confirmation by local law enforcement agency records or other evidence that the parent or other such person having legal custody or control of the child was notified, within the immediately preceding twelve (12) months, of at least two (2) previous warnings against such child for an offense referenced hereinabove in subsection (a), (b) or (c). 
(f)  Any person who shall violate the provisions of subsection (d) of this section shall, after trial and upon conviction, be penalized as provided in section 1-1-6 of this Code. The municipal court may, in its discretion, consider alternate sentencing, including parenting classes, for first offenders or in other appropriate circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 06-12, § 1, 6-22-06; Ord. No. 16-07, § 1, 4-26-16) 
Secs. 10-20-14-10-20-25. - Reserved. 
Article II - EQUIPMENT[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq. 

Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-20-26. - Scope and effect of regulations. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to drive or move, or for the owner to cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any street or highway, any vehicle or combination of vehicles which is in such unsafe condition as to endanger any person, or which does not contain those parts or is not at all times equipped with such lights and other equipment in proper condition and adjustment as required in this article or by law, or which is equipped in any manner in violation thereof, or for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required thereunder. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the use of additional parts and accessories on any vehicle, which use is consistent with this article. 
(c)  This article shall not apply to implements of husbandry, road machinery, road rollers, farm tractors or three-wheeled motorcycles used only for agricultural purposes, except as herein made applicable. This article shall not apply to motorized carts. Every farm tractor and every three-wheeled motorcycle used only for agricultural purposes equipped with an electric lighting system shall at all times, mentioned in section 10-20-46, display a red taillight and either multiple beam or single beam road lighting equipment meeting the requirements of section 10-20-49 and section 10-20-56 respectively. 
(Code 1972, § 23-150) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-8-1, 40-8-7. 
Sec. 10-20-27. - Horns; warning devices. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle when operated upon a highway shall be equipped with a horn in good working order and capable of emitting sound audible under normal conditions from a distance of not less than two hundred (200) feet, but no horn or other warning device shall emit an unreasonably loud or harsh sound or a whistle. The driver of a motor vehicle shall, when reasonably necessary to ensure safe operation, give audible warning with his horn but shall not otherwise use such horn when upon a highway. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a vehicle any siren, whistle or bell, except as otherwise permitted in this section. 
(c)  No vehicle shall be equipped with a theft alarm signal device which is so arranged that it can be used by the driver as an ordinary warning signal. 
(d)  Any authorized emergency vehicle may be equipped with a siren, whistle or bell capable of emitting sound audible under normal conditions from a distance of not less than five hundred (500) feet, but such siren shall not be used except when such vehicle is operated in response to an emergency call or in the immediate pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law, in which latter event the driver of such vehicle shall sound the siren when necessary to warn pedestrians and other drivers of the approach thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 23-164) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-8-70, 40-8-94. 
Sec. 10-20-28. - Mufflers; prevention of noises. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle shall at all times be equipped with an exhaust system, in good working order and in constant operation, meeting the following specifications: 
(1)  The exhaust system shall include the piping leading from the flange of the exhaust manifold to and including the muffler or mufflers and tail pipes. 
(2)  The use of flexible pipe shall be prohibited except on diesel tractors or according to the manufacturers' original specifications. 
(3)  The exhaust emission point shall extend beyond the rear or outside of the passenger compartment. The trunk shall be considered as part of the passenger compartment. 
(4)  The exhaust system and its elements shall be securely fastened, including the consideration of missing or broken hangers. 
(5)  There shall be no part of the exhaust system passing through the passenger compartment, or any exposed stack so located that any individual entering or leaving the vehicle may be burned. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any muffler which causes excessive or unusual noise or annoying smoke, or any muffler cutout, bypass or similar device for use on a motor vehicle, or for any person to use, to sell or to offer for sale any motor vehicle equipped with any such muffler, muffler cutout, bypass or similar device. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle within the city with an exhaust attachment referred to as a "Smittee" attached to said exhaust pipe. The use of such an attachment or device is declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1972, § 23-165) 
Cross reference- Health, Ch. 10-25. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-71. 
Sec. 10-20-29. - Crankcase and exhaust emission controls. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any motor vehicle to operate or permit the operation of such vehicle on which any device controlling or abating atmospheric emissions which is placed on a motor vehicle by the manufacturer pursuant to regulations promulgated by the United States Secretary of Health and Human Services in accordance with the provisions of Title II, the National Emissions Standards Act, of the Air Quality Act of 1967, Public Law 90-148, approved November 21, 1967, as amended, has been rendered unserviceable by removal, alteration or other interference with its operation. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to any person repairing any such device described in that subsection or to the removal of any such device by any person for the purpose of repairing or replacing such device. 
(c)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to any person removing any such device for the purpose of converting any motor vehicle to operate on natural or liquefied petroleum gas or to make any other modifications which would reduce atmospheric emissions. 
(d)  Any vehicle suspected of being operated in violation of this section may be the subject of an inspection conducted by an officer of the police department who has reason to believe such violation is occurring, without the necessity of obtaining a warrant to permit such inspection. 
(Code 1972, § 23-166) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-8-130, 40-8-131. 
Sec. 10-20-30. - Mirrors. 
    Every motor vehicle which is so construed or loaded as to obstruct the driver's view to the rear thereof from the driver's position shall be equipped with a mirror so located as to reflect to the driver a view of the highway for a distance of at least two hundred (200) feet to the rear of such vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 23-167) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A, § 40-8-72. 
Sec. 10-20-31. - Windshields; windshield wipers. 
(a)  No person shall drive any motor vehicle with any sign, poster or other nontransparent material upon the front windshield, side windows or rear windows of such vehicle which obstructs the driver's clear view of the highway or any intersecting highway. 
(b)  The windshield of every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a device for cleaning rain, snow or other moisture therefrom, which device shall be so constructed as to be controlled or operated by the driver of the vehicle. 
(c)  Every windshield wiper upon a motor vehicle shall be maintained in good working order. 
(d)  No opaque or solid material including, but not limited to, cardboard, plastic and taped glass shall be employed in lieu of a glass windshield or window. 
(e)  No motor vehicle shall be operated with a windshield or rear window having a starburst or spider webbing effect greater than three (3) inches by three (3) inches. 
(Code 1972, § 23-168) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-73. 
Sec. 10-20-32. - Tires. 
(a)  No vehicle equipped with sold rubber tires shall be used or transported on the highways, unless every solid rubber tire on such vehicle shall have rubber on its entire traction surface at least one (1) inch thick above the edge of the flange of the entire periphery. 
(b)  No person shall operate or move on any highway any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer having any metal tire in contact with the roadway. 
(c)  No tire on a vehicle moved on a highway shall have on its periphery any block, stud, flange, cleat or spike or any other protuberance of any material other than rubber which projects beyond the tread of the traction surface of the tire, except that it shall be permissible to use: 
(1)  Farm machinery with tires having protuberances which will not injure the highway; and 
(2)  Tire chains of reasonable proportions or tires equipped with safety spike-metal studs upon any vehicle when required for safety because of snow, ice or other conditions tending to cause a vehicle to skid. 
(d)  The mayor and council may in their discretion issue special permits authorizing the operation upon a highway of traction engines or tractors having movable tracks with transverse corrugations upon the periphery of such movable tracks, or of farm tractors or other farm machinery, the operation of which upon a highway would otherwise be prohibited under this section. 
(Code 1972, § 23-169) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-74. 
Secs. 10-20-33-10-20-45. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - LIGHTING EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 10-20-46. - When lights required. 
    Every vehicle upon a highway within the city at any time from a half hour after sunset to a half hour before sunrise and at any time when it is raining in the driving zone and at any other time when there is not sufficient visibility to render clearly discernible persons and vehicles on the highway at a distance of five hundred (500) feet ahead, shall display lights, including headlights, and illuminating devices as required in this article for different classes of vehicles, subject to exceptions with respect to parked vehicles as stated in this article. 
(Code 1972, § 23-151) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-20. 
Sec. 10-20-47. - Visibility distance and mounted height of lights. 
(a)  Whenever this article declare the required distance from which certain lights and devices shall render objects visible or within which such lights or devices shall be visible, such provisions shall apply during the times stated in section 10-20-46 in respect to a vehicle without load when upon a straight, level, unlighted highway under normal atmospheric conditions, unless a different time or condition is expressly stated. 
(b)  Whenever this article declares the required mounted height of lights or devices, it shall mean the distance from the center of such lights or device to the level ground upon which the vehicle stands when such vehicle is without a load. 
(Code 1972, § 23-152) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-21. 
Sec. 10-20-48. - Headlights. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle other than a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with at least two (2) but not more than four (4) headlights, with at least one (1) on each side of the front of the motor vehicle, which headlights shall comply with this article. 
(b)  Every motorcycle and every motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with at least one (1) and not more than two (2) headlights, which shall comply with this article. 
(c)  Every headlight upon every motor vehicle, including every motorcycle and motor-driven cycle, shall be located at a height measured from the center of the headlight of not more than fifty-four (54) inches nor less than twenty-four (24) inches, to be measured as set forth in section 10-20-47(b). 
(Code 1972, § 23-153) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-22. 
Sec. 10-20-49. - Taillights. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer and pole trailer manufactured prior to January 1, 1954, shall be equipped with at least one (1) taillight mounted on the rear, which when lighted as required in this article shall emit a red light plainly visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the rear. 
(b)  Every motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer and pole trailer manufactured after January 1, 1954, shall be equipped with two (2) taillights which meet the specifications provided in this section. 
(c)  Every taillight upon every vehicle shall be located at a height of not more than sixty (60) inches nor less than twenty (20) inches to be measured as set forth in section 10-20-47(b). 
(d)  Either a taillight or a separate light shall be so constructed and placed as to illuminate with a white light the rear registration plate and render it clearly legible from a distance of fifty (50) feet to the rear. Any taillight or taillights, together with any separate light for illuminating the rear registration plate, shall be so wired as to be lighted whenever the headlights or auxiliary driving lights are lighted. 
(Code 1972, § 23-154) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-23. 
Sec. 10-20-50. - Reflectors. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle manufactured after March 12, 1954, and operated upon a highway, other than a truck tractor, motorcycle or motor-driven cycle, shall carry on the rear, either as a part of the taillights or separately, two (2) red reflectors, and every motorcycle and every motor-driven cycle shall carry on the rear at least one (1) red reflector, meeting the requirements of this section. 
(b)  Every such reflector shall be mounted on the vehicle at a height not less than twenty (20) inches nor more than sixty (60) inches measured as set forth in subsection (b) of section 10-20-47 and shall be of such size and characteristics and so mounted as to be visible at night from all distances within three hundred (300) feet to fifty (50) feet from the rear of such vehicle except that visibility from the greater distance is required by law or ordinance of reflectors on certain types of vehicles. 
(Code 1972, § 23-155) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-24. 
Sec. 10-20-51. - Brake lights and turn signals required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any motor vehicle manufactured after January 1, 1954, including any motorcycle or motor-driven cycle manufactured after January 1, 1954, in this city or for any person to drive such vehicle on the highways unless it is equipped with at least once (1) brake light meeting the requirements of section 10-20-55. 
(b)  If a motor vehicle is manufactured with two (2) brake lights, both must be operational. 
(c)  No person shall sell or offer for sale or operate on the highways any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer registered in this state and manufactured or assembled after January 1, 1954, unless it is equipped with mechanical or electrical turn signals meeting the requirements of section 10-20-55. This subsection shall not apply to any motorcycle or motor-driven cycle manufactured prior to January 1, 1972. 
(Code 1972, § 23-156) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-25. 
Sec. 10-20-52. - Light or flag on projecting load. 
    Whenever the load upon any vehicle extends to the rear four (4) feet or more beyond the bed or body of such vehicle, there shall be displayed at the extreme rear end of the load, at the times specified in section 10-20-46, a red light plainly visible from a distance of at least five hundred (500) feet to the sides and rear. The red light shall be in addition to the red rear light required upon every vehicle. At any other time there shall be displayed at the extreme rear end of such load a red flag or cloth not less than twelve (12) inches square and so hung that the entire area is visible to the driver of a vehicle approaching from the rear. 
(Code 1972, § 23-157) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-27. 
Sec. 10-20-53. - Lights on parked vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever a vehicle is lawfully parked upon a street or highway during the hours between a half hour after sunset and a half hour before sunrise, and there is sufficient light to reveal any person or object within a distance of five hundred (500) feet upon such street or highway, no lights need be displayed upon such parked vehicle. 
(b)  Whenever a vehicle is parked or stopped upon a roadway or shoulder adjacent thereto, whether attended or unattended, during the hours between a half hour after sunset and a half hour before sunrise and there is not sufficient light to reveal any person or object within a distance of five hundred (500) feet upon such highways, such vehicle so parked or stopped shall be equipped with one (1) or more lights meeting the following requirements: At least one (1) light shall display a white or amber light visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the front of the vehicle, and the same light or at least one (1) other light shall display a red light visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the rear of the vehicle; the location of such light or lights shall always be such that at least one (1) light or combination of lights meeting the requirements of this section is installed as near as practicable to the side of the vehicle which is closest to passing traffic. This subsection shall not apply to a motor-driven cycle. 
(c)  If a vehicle is manufactured with two (2) lights meeting the requirements of subsection (b) of this section, both such lights shall be maintained in good working order. 
(d)  Any lighted headlights upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed. 
(Code 1972, § 23-158) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-28. 
Sec. 10-20-54. - Spotlights; foglights; auxiliary lights. 
(a)  Any motor vehicle may be equipped with not to exceed one (1) spotlight, and every lighted spotlight shall not be aimed and used upon any approaching vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any person except law enforcement officers and persons licensed under O.C.G.A. Title 43, Chapter 38, to operate a spotlight from any moving vehicle on any highway or public roadway. 
(b)  Any motor vehicle may be equipped with not to exceed two (2) foglights mounted on the front at a height not less than twelve (12) inches nor more than thirty (30) inches above the level surface upon which the vehicle stands and so aimed that when the vehicle is not loaded none of the high intensity portion of the light to the left of the center of the vehicle shall at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet ahead project higher than a level of four (4) inches below the level of the center of the light from which it comes. 
(c)  Any motor vehicle may be equipped with not to exceed one (1) auxiliary passing light mounted on the front at a height not less than twenty-four (24) inches nor more than forty-two (42) inches above the level surface upon which the vehicle stands, and every such auxiliary passing light shall meet requirements and limitations set forth in this article. 
(d)  Any motor vehicle may be equipped with not to exceed one (1) auxiliary driving light mounted on the front at a height not less than sixteen (16) inches nor more than forty-two (42) inches above the level surface upon which the vehicle stands, and every such auxiliary driving light shall meet the requirements and limitations set forth in this article. 
(Code 1972, § 23-159) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-29. 
Sec. 10-20-55. - Brake lights; signal devices. 
(a)  Any motor vehicle may be equipped and when required under this article shall be equipped with the following signal lights or devices: 
(1)  A brake light on the rear which shall emit a red light and which shall be actuated upon application of the service (foot) brake and which may but need not be incorporated with a taillight; and 
(2)  A light or lights or mechanical signal device capable of clearly indicating any intention to turn either to the right or to the left and which shall be visible from both the front and the rear. 
(b)  Every brake light shall be plainly visible and understandable from a distance of three hundred (300) feet to the rear both during normal sunlight and at nighttime, and every signal light or lights indicating an intention to turn shall be visible and understandable during daytime and nighttime from a distance of three hundred (300) feet from both the front and the rear. When a vehicle is equipped with a brake light or other signal lights, such light or lights shall at all times be maintained in good working condition. No brake light or signal light shall project a glaring or dazzling light. 
(c)  All mechanical signal devices shall be self-illuminated when in use at the times mentioned in section 10-20-46. 
(Code 1972, § 23-160) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-26. 
Sec. 10-20-56. - Multiple-beam road lighting equipment-Standards. 
    Except as provided in this article, the headlights or the auxiliary driving light or the auxiliary passing light or combination thereof on motor vehicles other than motorcycles or motor-driven cycles shall be so arranged that the driver may select at will between distributions of light projected to different elevations, and such lights may, in addition, be so arranged that such selection can be made automatically, subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  There shall be an uppermost distribution of light, or composite beam, so aimed and of such intensity as to reveal persons and vehicles at a distance of at least three hundred fifty (350) feet ahead for all conditions of loading. 
(2)  There shall be a lowermost distribution of light, or composite beam, so aimed and of sufficient intensity to reveal persons and vehicles at a distance of at least one hundred (100) feet ahead; and on a straight level road under any condition of loading none of the high intensity portion of the beam shall be directed to strike the eyes of an approaching driver. 
(3)  Every new motor vehicle other than a motorcycle or a motor-driven cycle registered in this state which has multiple-beam road lighting equipment shall be equipped with a beam indicator which shall be lighted whenever the uppermost distribution of light from the headlights is in use and shall not otherwise be lighted. Such indicator shall be so designed and located that when lighted it will be readily visible without glare to the driver of the vehicle so equipped. 
(Code 1972, § 23-161) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-30. 
Sec. 10-20-57. - Same-Use. 
(a)  Whenever a motor vehicle is being operated on a roadway or shoulder adjacent thereto during the times specified in section 10-20-46, the driver shall use a distribution of light, or composite beam, directed high enough and of sufficient intensity to reveal persons and vehicles at a safe distance in advance of the vehicle, subject to the following requirements and limitations: 
(1)  Whenever a driver of a vehicle approaches an oncoming vehicle within five hundred (500) feet, such driver shall use a distribution of light, or composite beam, so aimed that the glaring rays are not projected into the eyes of the oncoming driver. The lowermost distribution of light, or composite beam, specified in paragraph (2) of section 10-20-56 shall be deemed to avoid glare at all times, regardless of road contour and loading. 
(2)  Whenever the driver of a vehicle follows another vehicle within two hundred (200) feet to the rear, except when engaged in the act of overtaking and passing, such driver shall use a distribution of light permissible under this chapter other than the uppermost distribution of light specified in paragraph (1) of section 10-20-56. 
(Code 1972, § 23-162) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-31. 
Secs. 10-20-58-10-20-70. - Reserved. 
Division 3 - BRAKES 

Sec. 10-20-71. - Required. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle, other than a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle, when operated upon a highway, shall be equipped with brakes adequate to control the movement of and to stop and hold such vehicle, including two (2) separate means of applying the brakes, each of which means shall be effective to apply the brakes to at least two (2) wheels. If these two (2) separate means of applying the brakes are connected in any way, they shall be so constructed that failure on any one (1) part of the operating mechanism shall not leave the motor vehicle without brakes on at least two (2) wheels. 
(b)  Every motorcycle and motor-driven cycle manufactured after January 1, 1974, when operated upon a highway, shall be equipped with at least two (2) brakes which may be operated by hand or foot. 
(c)  Every trailer or semitrailer of two thousand five hundred (2,500) pounds gross weight or more shall be equipped with brakes on all wheels. Any farm trailer with two (2) or more wheels, pulled from a tongue, used in or operated for farm purposes, including transporting fertilizer and agricultural materials to the farm, shall not be required to have an independent braking system thereon, provided such farm trailer shall not weigh over four thousand (4,000) pounds when empty. 
(Code 1972, § 23-163) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-50. 
Sec. 10-20-72. - Means of operation. 
(a)  One (1) of the means of brake operation shall consist of a mechanical connection from the operating lever to the brake shoes or bands, and this brake shall be capable of holding the vehicle or combination of vehicles stationary under any condition of loading on any upgrade or downgrade upon which it is operated. 
(b)  The brake shoes operating within or upon the drums on the vehicle wheels of any motor vehicle may be used for both service and hand operation. 
(Code 1972, § 23-163) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-51. 
Sec. 10-20-73. - Parking brakes. 
    Every 1966 model motor vehicle and all subsequent model motor vehicles shall be equipped with parking brakes adequate to hold the vehicle on any grade on which it is operated, under all conditions of loading on a surface free from snow, ice or loose material. The parking brakes shall be capable of being applied in conformance with this division by the driver's muscular effort, by spring action or by equivalent means. Their operation may be assisted by the service brakes or other source of power, provided that failure of the service brake actuation system or other power assisting mechanism will not prevent the parking brakes from being applied in conformance with this division. The parking brakes shall be so designed that when once applied they shall remain applied with the required effectiveness despite exhaustion of any source of energy or leakage of any kind. The brake drums, brake shoes and lining assemblies, brake shoe anchors and mechanical brake shoe actuation mechanism normally associated with the wheel brake assemblies may be used for both the service brakes and the parking brakes. If the means of applying the parking brakes and the service brakes are connected in any way, they shall be so constructed that failure of any one (1) part shall not leave the vehicle without operative brakes. 
(Code 1972, § 23-163) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-52. 
Sec. 10-20-74. - Performance ability. 
    Every motor vehicle or combination of motor-drawn vehicles shall be capable at all times and under all conditions of loading of being stopped on a dry, smooth, level road free from loose material, upon application of the service (foot) brake within the distances specified below, or shall be capable of being decelerated at a sustained rate corresponding to these distances: 
Feet to Stop 
From 20 Miles 
Per Hour Deceleration 
in Feet Per 
Second Vehicles or combinations of vehicles having brakes on all wheels 30 14 Vehicles or combinations of vehicles not having brakes on all wheels 40 10.7  
(Code 1972, § 23-163) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-53. 
Sec. 10-20-75. - Maintenance. 
    All brakes shall be maintained in good working order and shall be so adjusted as to operate as equally as practicable with respect to the wheels on opposite sides of the vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 23-163) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-53. 
Secs. 10-20-76-10-20-90. - Reserved. 
Article III - PARKING[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Parking near garage sale, § 30-5-241; automobile parking for tourist courts, § 30-10-39; parking in mobile home parks and trailer parks, § 30-10-64. 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq.; power of local authorities to prohibit parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371 (a)(1). 

Sec. 10-20-91. - Streets in residential zones. 
(a)  In order to protect and promote the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city, to insure the safe and orderly transition of traffic in residential areas and to protect property values in certain residential areas in the city, the parking of certain vehicles within residential zones R-1, R-2, and R-3 is prohibited upon the public streets, alleys and rights-of-way within such residential districts. 
(b)  The vehicles, the parking of which is prohibited by subsection (a) are defined as: 
(1)  Any truck or other vehicle which has a rated capacity of greater than one (1) ton or which has a wheel base of one hundred twenty-five (125) inches or more; 
(2)  Truck tractors having dual rear wheels; and 
(3)  Trailers or semitrailers having dual rear wheels, or either such trailers having an overall length of greater than twelve (12) feet; provided, however, that an exception to the prohibition outlined in this subparagraph may be granted, upon application to the building official, and in the discretion of the building official, provided said trailer or semitrailer at issue may be parked in the street safely without unduly impeding sight distance, traffic flow, federal, postal or other deliveries and emergency vehicle ingress and egress. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the parking of vehicles of public or private utility companies, or commercial vehicles making deliveries or vehicles in use in the construction, repair or maintenance of any road, street or alley in such districts, but only for the period of time required for the delivery of service reasonably required by such vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 23-13; Ord. No. 99-30, § 1, 8-10-99; Ord. No. 99-30A, § 1, 8-10-99) 
Sec. 10-20-92. - Parking vehicle for purpose of repair or sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle on the public streets of the city for the purpose of making repairs on same. It shall be unlawful for a vehicle not in use to be parked on the public streets of the city for sale. 
(Code 1972, § 23-14) 
Sec. 10-20-93. - Signs, etc., to designate parking areas and manner of parking. 
(a)  Parking areas and the manner of parking shall be accomplished by appropriate markings on the street, by appropriate markings on the curb, or by installation of signs. Yellow lines on the curb or a no parking sign adjacent to the street right-of-way shall signify a no parking area. In areas where parking is permitted, parking shall be in accordance with the parking lines or as shown on the street surface and where there are no markings, parking shall be parallel to the curb on the right side of such street and in a manner so as to allow the proper passage of traffic on such street. 
(b)  Vehicles shall at all times be parked wholly within the parking spaces as marked upon the public streets of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle so that the same is not wholly within an area designated by the lines on the streets as a parking space. 
(Code 1972, §§ 23-190, 23-199) 
State Law reference- How vehicles to be parked, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200. 
Sec. 10-20-94. - Parking beyond curb. 
    No vehicle shall be parked in the space between the property line and the curb. 
(Code 1972, § 23-191) 
State Law reference- How vehicles to be parked, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200. 
Sec. 10-20-95. - Alleys, driveways and intersections. 
(a)  Parking of a motor vehicle in front of or which blocks the entrance to a public alley or public or private driveway is prohibited. 
(b)  In order to provide for safe sight distance, it shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle within up to thirty (30) feet on either side of the entrance to a public or private driveway. The area upon which parking is prohibited shall be clearly marked by a yellow stripe along the curb. The city manager is hereby granted the discretion to determine the distance from the entrance to the driveway upon which parking shall be prohibited in order to protect appropriate sight distance up to and including a distance of thirty (30) feet. 
(Code 1972, § 23-192; Ord. No. 88-117, § 1, 10-25-88; Ord. No. 04-11, § 1, 3-23-04) 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specified places, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-203.
