Sec. 10-20-97. - Parking within industrial park. 
    No parking shall be permitted on the following streets in the LaGrange Industrial Park: 
(1)  On the north and south sides of Executive Drive, from its intersection with Orchard Hill to its end. 
(2)  On the north and south sides of Lukken Industrial Boulevard, from its intersection with Troup Street west to the city limits. 
(3)  On both sides of Glenn Bass Road, from its intersection with Orchard Hill Road to its end. 
(4)  On both sides of Glen Long Road, from its intersection with Orchard Hill Road to its intersection with Shorewood Drive. 
(5)  On the north and south sides of Longley Place, from its intersection with Lukken Industrial Drive to its end. 
(6)  On both sides of Orchard Hill Road, from its intersection with Boatwright Street south to the city limits. 
(7)  On both sides of Redding Drive, from its intersection with Lukken Industrial Drive to its intersection with Orchard Hill Road. 
(8)  On both sides of Shorewood Drive, from its intersection with Executive Drive to its intersection with Glen Long Road. 
(9)  On both sides of Sewon Boulevard, from its intersection with Shorewood Drive to its intersection with Pegasus Parkway. 
(10)  On both sides of Piedmont Circle, from its intersection with Wiley Road to its end. 
(11)  On both sides of Pegasus Parkway, from the city limits west to its end. 
(Code 1972, § 23-208; Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 5-12-09) 
Sec. 10-20-98. - Tow away zones. 
(a)  The following areas or portions of streets are hereby established as tow away zones: 
    W. Bacon Street , on both sides, between New Franklin Road and Marshall Street. 
    Center Plaza Drive , on both sides beginning at its intersection with State Route 109 (Lafayette Parkway) and extending south and east to its intersection with Callaway Church Road. 
    North Greenwood Street , the east and west sides, from its intersection with the north right-of-way line of Broad Street, north to its intersection with the south right-of-way line of Mitchell Street, as extended. 
    Highland Avenue , on north and south sides, between Ridley Avenue and North Greenwood Street. 
    Hunnicutt Drive , on the north side, between North Greenwood Street and Granger Drive. 
    Jameson Drive , on both sides, beginning at its intersection with State Route 109 (Lafayette Parkway) and extending north 220 feet. 
    Marshall Street , on both sides, between Highland Avenue and Bacon Street. 
    Ridley Avenue , on both sides, between Smith Street and Mitchell Avenue. 
    Vehicles found to be parked beyond the curb in violation of municipal code section 10-20-94 or parked blocking a driveway or alleyway in violation of municipal code section 10-20-95 in the noted areas within this code section are deemed to be parked improperly and are subject to removal at the owner's expense and the owner/operator is subject to penalties described in section 1-1-6 of the municipal code. 
(b)  Provided any such area or portions of streets have been posted with signs indicating the same as a "tow away zone," and in addition to any other penalties, any vehicle found to be parked in such area or portions of streets may be removed by a towing service upon order of the police department at the expense of the owner. 
(c)  Upon conviction, any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be fined an amount no less than $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 06-06, § 1, 4-11-06; Ord. No. 11-13, § 2, 9-13-11; Ord. No. 11-18, § 2, 10-25-11; Ord. No. 16-05, § 1, 4-12-16) 
Sec. 10-20-99. - Parking from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. restricted. 
    Between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday of each week, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle: 
(1)  On the north side of Highland Avenue between Marshall Street and Ridley Avenue and on the south side of Highland Avenue from its intersection with Marshall Street east for a distance of three hundred eighty (380) feet. 
(2)  On either side of Marshall Street between Highland Avenue and Bacon Street. 
(Ord. No. 89-23, § 1, 6-27-89; Ord. No. 89-42, § 1, 11-14-89) 
Sec. 10-20-100. - Downtown retail parking district. 
(a)  There is hereby created in the City of LaGrange the downtown retail parking district, which is defined as that area within the city which is bounded on the north by the north right-of-way of Broad Street, North LaFayette Square and Greenville Street; on the west by the west right-of-way of West Lafayette Square and Bull Street; on the east by the east right-of-way of Morgan Street; and on the south by the south right-of-way of Byron Hurst Street and East Depot Street; also, (1) that area of Ridley Avenue from its intersection with North Court Square to its intersection with Haralson Street; (2) that area of Greenville Street from its intersection with East Lafayette Square to its intersection with Morgan Street; and (3) on the south side of Broad Street, beginning at the curb line of its intersection with Lewis Street east for a distance of 84.91 feet. 
(b)  Except where parking is otherwise specifically prohibited or limited in this Code, within the downtown retail parking it shall be unlawful for a motor vehicle to park for a continuous period of more than two (2) hours between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, on the streets, off-street parking lots or portion thereof located within the downtown retail parking district. The parking limitation established herein shall not apply to the public parking deck located at the corner of Broome and Morgan Streets; the public parking lot situated between said parking deck and Lafayette Parkway; nor to any private parking lots situated within the downtown retail parking district. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, remove, erase, obliterate or otherwise destroy any mark or marks placed on the tires of a vehicle parked in the downtown retail parking district by a member or authorized representative of the LaGrange Police Department other than by the normal use of driving such vehicle by removing the same entirely from such parking space and driving the same for a distance of not less than twenty (20) feet. Any person who shall violate the provisions of this subsection, upon conviction therefor, shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or sentenced to such community service as is authorized by law and which the court shall find to be appropriate. 
(d)  As a penalty for violating the provisions of this section relating to parking, for the first parking ticket within a sixty-day period the owner or operator shall pay a fine of five dollars ($5.00) if the fine is paid within five (5) working days and if not, the fine shall be not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00); for the second violation within any sixty-day period as measured from the date of the first violation, the fine shall be not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00); and for the third violation within any sixty-day period the offender or owner of the vehicle shall be required to appear before the judge of the appropriate court in the City of LaGrange and upon conviction shall be fined an amount not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 96-25, §§ 1, 2, 4-23-96; Ord. No. 04-38, § 1, 12-13-04; Ord. No. 07-22, § 1, 7-10-07; Ord. No. 12-24, § 1, 12-11-12; Ord. No. 15-07, § 1, 8-11-15; Ord. No. 17-01, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 10-20-101. - Overnight parking. 
    There shall be no overnight parking on the parking lot located at the intersection of Main Street and East Depot Street and the parking lot located at the intersection of Broome Street and Barnard Alley, nor shall there be parking on such lots between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Code 1972, § 23-198) 
Sec. 10-20-102. - Handicapped parking. 
(a)  The following areas in the public parking lots or public streets of the city are defined and designated as "handicapped parking places," to wit: 
(1)  Two (2) spaces on the east side of Main Street between Lafayette Parkway and Broome Streets; 
(2)  Two (2) spaces on the west side of Smith Street between Vernon and Broome Streets; 
(3)  Two (2) spaces on the south side of Smith Street between Church and North Lewis Streets; 
(4)  Four (4) spaces on the west side of Trinity Street between Vernon and Broad Streets; 
(5)  One (1) space on the north side of Lafayette Square, one (1) space on the east side of Lafayette Square near Greenville Street and one (1) space on the west side of Lafayette Square near Vernon Street; 
(6)  Two (2) spaces on the west side of Church Street near Broad Street; and 
(7)  One (1) space on the west side of North Lewis Street beginning at a point approximately one hundred sixty-eight (168) feet south of its intersection with Battle Street and extending north twenty-three (23) feet. 
(b)  The spaces designated in paragraph (a) hereof shall be appropriately marked and appropriate signs erected thereon to designate the same as a "handicapped parking space" as provided in section 40-6-221 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated as the same may now or hereafter exist or be amended. 
(c)  Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be fined in accordance with the penalties established and provided in section 40-6-226 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated as the same now exists or may hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-26-88; Ord. No. 88-111, § 2, 8-23-88; Ord. No. 88-108A, § 2, 8-23-88; Ord. No. 88-129, § 1, 12-27-88; Ord. No. 93-55, § 1, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 95-38, §§ 1, 2, 9-26-95; Ord. No. 95-41, § 1, 9-26-95; Ord. No. 96-39, § 1, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 98-28, §§ 1-4, 10-13-98; Ord. No. 00-29, § 1, 11-14-00; Ord. No. 05-14, § 1, 9-27-05; Ord. No. 14-02, § 1, 2-25-14) 
Sec. 10-20-103. - Loading/unloading spaces-Regulation of use. 
(a)  The creation of loading and unloading spaces upon the public streets and thoroughfares of the city is hereby authorized in order to control and regulate the loading and unloading of vehicles upon such public streets and thoroughfares and thereby limit and reduce, as much as is possible, traffic congestion, hazards, or obstructions caused by or resulting from the uncontrolled and unregulated loading and unloading of vehicles. 
(b)  Any such loading or unloading space, when designated, shall be marked by a sign identifying the same as a loading/unloading space and shall be cross-hatched with yellow stripes for additional identification. 
(c)  No commercial vehicle shall use a loading/unloading space for any period in excess of thirty (30) continuous minutes and no other vehicle shall use such space for a period in excess of fifteen (15) continuous minutes; provided, however, no vehicle shall be parked in a loading/unloading space unless such vehicle is actively loading or unloading material or merchandise and then only in accordance with and for the time permitted by the provisions hereof and in no event shall such loading/unloading space be used for parking purposes only. 
(d)  No vehicle shall be permitted to park or stop in a traffic lane or to obstruct traffic upon the public streets or thoroughfares of the city for the purpose of loading or unloading unless a space for that purpose or unless off-street parking which can be used for such purpose is not available within a distance of three hundred (300) feet but then only for a continuous period not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1, 8-28-90) 
Sec. 10-20-104. - Same-Designated. 
    The following areas upon the public streets and thoroughfares of the city are hereby designated as loading/unloading spaces in the city: 
(1)  Begin at a point on the west curb of North Lewis Street which is one hundred thirty-five (135) feet south of the southwest intersection of North Lewis and Smith Streets and extending south along the west curb of North Lewis Street a distance of thirty-four (34) feet. 
(2)  Beginning at a point which is the southwest corner of the intersection of South Lewis Street and Broome Street and extending south along the west curb of South Lewis Street a distance of eighty-seven (87) feet. 
(3)  Beginning at a point on the west curb of Main Street which is twenty (20) feet north of the northwest intersection of Broome and Main Streets and extending north along the west curb of Main Street for a distance of sixty-eight (68) feet. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1, 8-28-90; Ord. No. 90-54, § 1, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 98-12, § 1, 4-28-98; Ord. No. 00-29, § 2, 11-14-00; Ord. No. 05-01, § 1, 1-11-05; Ord. No. 05-13, § 1, 9-27-05; Ord. No. 05-18, § 1, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 06-27, § 1, 9-26-06; Ord. No. 07-01, § 1, 1-23-07; Ord. No. 11-03, § 1, 3-8-11; Ord. No. 12-08, § 3, 4-10-12; Ord. No. 12-09, § 1, 6-26-12) 
Sec. 10-20-105. - Penalty for violation of sections 10-20-103 and 10-20-104. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation who shall violate the provisions of section 10-20-103 or 10-20-104 shall upon conviction in the municipal court be punished as provided in section 1-1-6 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1, 8-28-90) 
Sec. 10-20-106. - Parking within the Sweetland Amphitheater parking lot. 
    Parking within the Sweetland Amphitheater parking lot located at the north end of Church Street shall be permitted unless otherwise prohibited as follows: 
(1)  Permitted parking. Parking shall be permitted only in those designated parking spaces in the amphitheater parking lot. Designated parking spaces as used herein is defined as being those lined parking spaces located on the east side of the parking lot. 
(2)  Prohibited parking. Parking is prohibited in all areas of the Sweetland Amphitheater parking lot except in designated parking spaces defined in subparagraph (1) hereof. Parking is specifically prohibited in all areas of said parking lot except designated areas, including, but not limited to, entrances, exits, traffic lanes, curbs, grassed areas or any other areas thereof used for passage of vehicular or emergency vehicle traffic. 
(3)  Penalties. Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-1-6 of this Code. Additionally, any violating vehicle may be removed or towed by the appropriate officials of the city and the cost of removing such vehicle and any impoundment charges shall be paid by the owner prior to or at the time of retrieval of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 16-02, § 1, 3-22-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-02, § 1, adopted March 22, 2016, deleted the former § 10-20-106, and enacted a new § 10-20-106 as set out herein. The former § 10-20-106 pertained to parking within the city pool parking lot and derived from Ord. No. 95-14, adopted May 9, 1995. 
Sec. 10-20-107. - Permit parking areas. 
(a)  Program established. There is established in the city a permit parking program whereby motor vehicles bearing a special parking permit issued pursuant to this code section may be parked on streets or within certain areas known as permit parking areas. For the purposes of this code section, the following streets areas are designated as permitted parking only: 
(1)  Ridley Avenue between Smith Street and Mitchell Avenue; 
(2)  W. Bacon Street between New Franklin Road and Marshall Street; and 
(3)  Highland Avenue between Ridley Avenue and N. Greenwood Street. 
(b)  Application for permit. The application for a parking permit shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The name of the operator of the motor vehicle to be permitted; 
(2)  The operator's residential address; 
(3)  The operator's state driver's license number; 
(4)  The motor vehicle make, model and license number; and 
(5)  Any other information reasonably requested on the application form. The applicant shall also provide proof of residency within the designated permitted parking area. 
(c)  Permit term; fee. Annual parking permits shall be valid for the calendar year of issuance, will expire on December 31st of each year, and shall be issued free of charge. 
(d)  Issuance of permits. The department of community development shall issue parking permits as follows: A permit shall be issued only to a motor vehicle operator who resides or operates a business on property that is located within the designated permit parking area, which permit shall be issued in accordance with the following limitations: 
(1)  For single-family dwelling units (one residential structure containing only one housing unit) or commercial uses: 
One parking permit may be issued for each valid street address where said dwelling unit or commercial use contains off-street parking. 
(2)  For multiple family dwelling units (including but not limited to, apartments, condominiums, attached dwellings, row houses and townhouses): 
One parking permit may be issued for each legally constituted and existing dwelling unit in any two-family or multiple-family dwelling facility at a valid street address within the permit parking area where said dwelling unit contains off-street parking availability. 
(3)  Additional parking permits may be issued, for good and sufficient cause, to any resident or business operator within the permit parking area if, in the opinion of the LaGrange Police Department, exceptional circumstances exist warranting an additional permit issuance. 
(e)  Permit form and display. 
(1)  The parking permit shall be a hang tag type and shall be displayed only on the motor vehicle for which it was issued in accordance with the limitations of use. The permit shall be prominently displayed by hanging from the rear view mirror so that is clearly visible from outside the vehicle. Information shown on the permit shall include the expiration date. 
(2)  Visitors to a residence within the permitted parking area may utilize the registered owner's parking permit while visiting said residence. 
(f)  The department of community development office may issue a temporary parking permit, valid for not more than one year, for a vehicle operated by a person who provides health care services on a regular basis at an address within a permit parking area. Such temporary permit shall be a permit bearing special validation and may be issued upon satisfactory proof of need presented by the resident at such address. 
(g)  Limitations of use. A motor vehicle which displays a valid parking permit shall be allowed to stand or park in the parking permit area for which the permit has been issued. Such permits shall not authorize a motor vehicle to stand or park in any place where or during any time when the stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle is otherwise prohibited or the area is designated for other uses. 
(h)  Signage. Signs will be erected in each permitted parking area indicating that the street is designated as permitted parking only and that parking is prohibited without a permit. 
(i)  Penalties for violations. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stand or park any motor vehicle on any street within the permitted parking area which does not display a valid parking permit. However, a public utility vehicle or commercial vehicle which is actively engaged in utility work or delivery or picking up of items is exempt from obtaining a permit and will not be in violation of this section. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this code section for a person to furnish false information in an application for any permit authorized by this section or to represent falsely that such person is eligible for such permit. 
(3)  A person holding a valid parking permit issued pursuant to this code section shall not be allowed the use or display of such permit on a vehicle other than that for which the permit was issued or a visitor to his/her residence or business. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this code section for a person to produce or display a facsimile or counterfeit parking permit in order to evade the limitations on parking in a permit parking area. 
(5)  Violation of this section shall constitute an offense and shall be punishable as provided under Code section 1-1-6. In addition to said penalty, a vehicle found to be in violation of this code section is subject to immediate removal, at the owner's expense, by a law enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 16-01, § 1, 3-22-16) 
Secs. 10-20-108, 10-20-109. - Reserved. 
Sec. 10-20-110. - Left turn and other traffic movements prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to make a left turn traffic movement at the following intersections: 
Bell Street, proceeding in a westerly direction to turn to proceed south on Whitesville Street; 
Mooty Bridge Road, proceeding in an easterly direction to turn onto New Franklin Road in a northerly direction; 
Vernon Street, proceeding in an easterly direction to turn onto Broad Street in a northerly direction; 
Whitesville Street, proceeding in a southerly direction to turn in an easterly direction onto Bell Street; and 
Wilkes Street, proceeding in an westerly direction to turn in a southerly direction onto Park Avenue, during the hours of 7:00 a.m. through 8:30 a.m., and 1:00 p.m. through 2:30 p.m., weekdays on which school is conducted and students are transported according to the calendar of the Troup County School System. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to make a left turn traffic movement at the following locations: 
Smith Street, while proceeding in a westerly direction from its intersection with Church Street, for a distance extending 221 feet from its intersection with Church Street. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 9-13-94; Ord. No. 96-14, § 1, 3-14-96; Ord. No. 96-56, §§ 1-3, 10-22-96; Ord. No. 00-04, § 1, 2-22-00; Ord. No. 00-16, § 1, 5-23-00) 
Sec. 10-20-111. - Illegally parked vehicles, owner/driver citation. 
    For parking violations under article III of this chapter, citation may issue to either the registered owner of the vehicle or the driver of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation. Proof that the defendant was at the time of the violation the registered owner of the vehicle shall permit the trier of fact in its discretion to infer that such owner of the vehicle was the driver of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation. Such an inference may be rebutted if the owner of the vehicle: 
(1)  Testifies under oath in open court that he or she was not the operator of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation; 
(2)  Presents to the court prior to the return dates established on the citation a certified copy of a police report showing that the vehicle had been reported to law enforcement as stolen prior to the alleged violation; or 
(3)  Submits to the court prior to the return date established on the citation a sworn notarized statement identifying the name of the operator of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 3-23-04) 
Chapter 10-21 - ENVIRONMENT 
Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-21-1. - Intent. 
    It is declared to be the intent of the governing authority of the city, in furtherance of its responsibility to protect the public health, safety and welfare of its citizens, to enact the following regulations governing the maintenance of property and the removal of hazards therefrom, all in order to assure the prevention and abatement of nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-2. - Definitions. 
    Except as specifically defined in this section, all words used in this chapter have their customary dictionary definitions. Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following words shall have the meaning herein indicated: 
    Ashes shall mean the residue from the burning of wood, coal or other combustible material. 
    Breeding places shall mean a mound or mass of construction debris, garbage, trash, cut vegetation or woody material. 
    Buffer shall mean a ten-foot wide strip of land maintained in such a manner that the growth of vegetation does not interfere with the property of another or exceed twelve (12) inches in height. 
    Developed property shall mean property upon which a structure has been erected which requires permanent location on the ground or which is attached to something having permanent location on the ground. 
    Filth shall mean foul, rotten or putrid matter which causes offensive odors and creates unhealthy conditions. 
    Garbage shall mean putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Inoperable vehicle shall mean any vehicle that is resting on blocks, without tires, with major parts missing, in a state of repair which precludes use, or lacking required current registration certificate. 
    Litter shall mean any kind of discarded and uncontrolled or uncontained solid waste, garbage, trash, dirt, sand, gravel, refuse, debris, dead animal or thing or substance, whether liquid or solid, that may be carried or deposited, in whole or in part, by wind, rain, snow, water, animal or any other such force into any public or private property, or into any river, public waterway, drain, sewer or receiving basin. 
    Livestock means all animals of the equine, bovine or swine class, including goats, sheep, mules, horses, hogs, cattle, and other grazing animals, and all rarities, including, but not limited to, ostriches, emus and rheas. 
    Person shall mean firms, partnerships, associations, organizations, trusts, companies and bodies, politic and corporate, or any other group of individuals acting as a unit, or any combination thereof, as well as individuals. 
    Poultry shall mean domestic fowl, including, but not limited to, water fowl such as geese and duck, birds which are bred for meat and egg production, exhibition, or competition; game birds such as pheasants, partridge, quail and grouse, as well as guinea fowl, pigeons, dove, peafowl; and all other avian species. 
    Private property shall mean property privately owned by one (1) or more persons. 
    Public property shall mean any street, alley, sidewalk or other public thoroughfare in the city or property owned and controlled by any governmental entity. 
    Refuse shall mean all putrescible or nonputrescible waste (except body waste) including, but not limited to, garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, equipment, appliances, machinery, and solid market and industrial waste. 
    Rubbish shall mean nonputrescible waste (excluding ashes) consisting of both combustible and noncombustible waste, including, but not limited to, paper, cardboard, cans, yard clippings, wood, woody tree cuttings, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
    Running at large shall mean any livestock which is not under manual control of a person and which is on any public road of the city or any property not belonging to the owner of the livestock, unless by permission of the owner of such property. 
    Street shall mean the entire width between boundary lines of every right-of-way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular or pedestrian travel. 
    Trash shall mean organic and inorganic waste that is too large or heavy to be routinely broken down, compressed, or otherwise disassembled to fit into the normal solid waste containers authorized for use by a household or business for the collection of its waste. Trash includes, but is not limited to, items such as lumber, bedding, furniture and garden tools, but does not include yard trimmings. 
    Undeveloped property shall mean property that does not have upon it anything constructed or erected which requires permanent location on the ground or which is attached to something having a permanent location on the ground. 
    Vegetation shall mean grass, weeds, or plants having no permanent woody stem less than one (1) inch in diameter at breast height and showing no visible signs of having been maintained, as distinguished from a tree or shrub. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-3. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person found to be in violation of this chapter shall be subject to the penalties as described in section 1-1-6 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Secs. 10-21-4-10-21-13. - Reserved. 
Article II - ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS 

Sec. 10-21-14. - Inoperable vehicles. 
(a)  Except as provided herein, the open storage of inoperable or unclaimed operable vehicles on private property is prohibited. 
(b)  Any person lawfully engaged in the repair of damaged or inoperable vehicles may store such vehicles on private property for a period not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) days, providing that such vehicles shall be screened from view on all sides of the property upon which the vehicles are stored by a building, fence, landscaping or other visual buffer. 
(c)  Only a person lawfully engaged in the operation of a junkyard or salvage yard in accordance with the zoning and other requirements of the City Code shall be authorized to store inoperable, damaged or unclaimed vehicles for a period exceeding one hundred eighty (180) days. Such vehicles shall be screened from view by a fence or shrubbery on all sides of the property upon which the vehicles are stored. 
(d)  A vehicle lacking a current, valid Georgia tag shall be considerable inoperable for the purposes of this section. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section, either the owner of the real property upon which such vehicle is situated, or the lawful possessor in control of said real property, or both, may be held liable for violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97; Ord. No. 01-22, § 1, 9-11-01; Ord. No. 01-33, § 1, 12-11-01) 
Sec. 10-21-15. - Health standards. 
    All developed and undeveloped property shall be maintained in such a manner to prevent the establishing of breeding places for small animals or insects that are destructive, annoying or injurious to the public health. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-16. - Animals. 
    No person shall livestock or poultry to run at large in the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-17. - Property maintenance. 
    The growth of grass shall not exceed one (1) foot in height on any developed property. The growth of vegetation on any undeveloped property shall not encroach upon any developed property adjacent thereto. Undeveloped property lying adjacent to and bordering developed property shall provide a ten-foot buffer with vegetation no greater than one (1) foot in height. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-18. - Collections of filth. 
    No person shall allow the collection of filth, such as but not limited to, stagnant water, decayed vegetables and fruits, dead animals, tainted meat, sewage or excrement of any kind to remain on land owned or controlled by him. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-19. - Littering. 
    No person shall dump, deposit or throw litter, including but not limited to refuse, garbage, rubbish, construction or demolition debris, woody or vegetative debris, appliances, equipment of any type or inoperable vehicles, or trash, on any public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-20. - Streets. 
    No person shall cast, place, sweep or deposit anywhere within the city any refuse in such a manner that it may be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, public right-of-way, sidewalk, alley, sewer or onto any occupied premises. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-21. - Washing or repairing vehicles. 
    No person shall wash for profit or gain or repair any vehicle on the streets, sidewalks or rights-of-way in the city. Sidewalks in front of all properties shall be kept clean from oil and grease. Businesses or persons engaged in washing, repair or maintenance of vehicles shall collect all wash water in a system connected to the city sanitary sewer system. Such sewer connections must have a properly installed interceptor or separator as may be required by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-22. - Bringing fertilizer materials into city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into the city any conveyance containing blood and bones, tankage, fish scrap or any odorous material for making fertilizers, and to allow the same to remain within the city for more than two (2) hours. It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to keep any car containing these materials on its tracks or premises at any one (1) place within the city for more than thirty (30) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-23. - Uncovered wells. 
    All wells not properly covered, on enclosed or unclosed lots in the city, are hereby declared nuisances, and it shall be unlawful for any person to have an uncovered well on his premises or to refuse or neglect to cover the same and properly protect all persons and animals from danger of any open well on his premises within six (6) hours of notice so to do by any authorized officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-24. - Burning leaves, rubbish. 
(a)  Leaves, rubbish or refuse of any kind shall not be set on fire or burned on any paved street or sidewalk. 
(b)  All authorized open burn permits issued by the LaGrange Fire Department may be revoked and such fire immediately extinguished if such is deemed a danger to public safety, reveals signs of environmental harm, or upon substantiated nuisance complaints from neighbors or other citizens. 
(c)  Control burns shall only be authorized between 10:00 a.m. and sunset. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Sec. 10-21-25. - Notice to correct conditions. 
    If it is determined that any of the conditions specified in sections 10-21-17 (property maintenance) and 10-21-18 (collections of filth) exist on any property within the city, the responsible party (owner or occupant) of said property shall be notified in writing that the conditions exist, and that if the conditions are not abated within fifteen (15) days after receipt of such notice, the city may direct that such conditions be abated at city expense. If, after diligent search, the responsible party cannot be located then said notice may be posted on the property and at such other public places in the city as the building official or his designee may determine. 
(Ord. No. 11-11, § 1, 6-30-11) 
Sec. 10-21-26. - [Liens]. 
    If the conditions specified in sections 10-21-17 (property maintenance) and 10-21-18 (collections of filth) are abated at city expense as provided in section 10-21-25, the city shall assess a lien against the property for the costs described in this section. Said lien shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the superior court and recorded as other liens are recorded. A copy of the lien shall also be kept in the office of the assistant city manager. The actual direct cost of abating the conditions remedied, together with the necessary expenses for preparing, filing and recording the lien, including any legal expenses, shall be assessed against the property and shall be collected in the same manner as provided for the collection of unpaid ad valorem taxes. 
(Ord. No. 11-11, § 1, 6-30-11; Ord. No. 16-12, § 4, 12-13-16) 
Secs. 10-21-27-10-21-34. - Reserved. 
Article III - NUISANCES 

Sec. 10-21-35. - Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to create a nuisance on his premises or premises occupied by him, or to permit a nuisance to remain six (6) hours after notice. The following, among others, are declared to be nuisances: Stagnant water, decayed vegetables, decayed fruits and fruit refuse, dead animals or tainted meat, filthy privies, filthy water or excrement, broken or ruptured sewer lines, raw sewage or anything that causes offensive odors or that works hurt, damage or inconvenience to another; the conducting by pipes, sewers or otherwise into any street, public alley or on the lot of another, of any filthy water or excrement of any kind, such as comes from kitchens, bathtubs, laundry places, privies, stables and other places. 
(b)  All nuisances and dangerous objects in and about the streets and other public places may be removed at once by the city, without any notice, and the expense incurred in the removal shall be paid by the owner of the dangerous objects or of the person maintaining the nuisance. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the person creating or maintaining any nuisance within the city to fail or refuse to abate and remove same after having been ordered to do so in accordance with the provisions of the charter and ordinances of the city. 
(d)  Any nuisance on private property may be removed on the written complaint of any officer or inhabitant of the city, which complaint must set forth particularly the nature and location of same and the person complained against. On such complaint being filed with the municipal court judge, he shall issue a summons to the person charged with maintaining such nuisance, requiring him to show cause before the municipal court judge at some time therein specified, within not more than five (5) days, why said nuisance complained of should not be abated. Such notice shall be served personally by any policeman at least one (1) day before the hearing. At the trial, the court shall hear evidence as to the facts and pass an order as may be just. If the thing complained of is a nuisance, the order shall specify within what time it is to be abated by the defendant. If it is not abated within the time specified in the order, the court shall issue a writ directed to the chief of police directing and requiring the abatement of the nuisance. 
(e)  Whenever the person creating or maintaining any nuisance within the city shall fail to abate after notice to do so, and it shall become necessary to issue a writ, directed to the chief of police, requiring him to remove same, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to keep an account of the necessary expenses incurred and to render to the court a statement of same. The court shall issue an execution against such order for such amount, the same to be levied upon and collected in the same manner as is provided for the levy in collection of executions for taxes. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § 2, 1-14-97) 
Chapter 10-30 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[12] 
Footnotes:

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-30-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Adequate shelter means a protective covering for a domestic animal that provides adequate space and protection to maintain the animal in a state of good health, and that prevents pain, suffering, or significant risk to the animal's health. Adequate shelter shall consist of a completely enclosed structure with four (4) sides, a constructed floor, and a roof with a door opening. It should also be clean, dry and compatible with current weather conditions, in addition to age, size, species and condition of the animal. The structure should be of sufficient size to allow the animal to stand, turn around, lie down and go in and out of the structure comfortably. To be adequate, some type of bedding that is quick drying, such as hay or pine straw, must be provided to maintain comfortable temperatures within the structure during times when the ambient, outside temperature is below thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit. In addition, the structure shall include a heavy plastic or rubber flap to cover the door and/or window openings during the months of December through March or when the ambient, outside temperature is below thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit. From April through November, the structure shall either be shaded or moved out of direct sunlight. If the shelter is made of wood, it shall be raised at least two (2) inches off the ground to prevent seepage or rotting. Examples of inadequate shelter include, but are not limited to, lean-tos, metal or plastic drums, boxes, abandoned vehicles, porches, decks, or material that does not provide sufficient protection from the elements. 
    Livestock means all animals of the equine, bovine or swine class, including goats, sheep, mules, horses, hogs and cattle, and other grazing animals. 
    Owner means any person, association, firm or corporation, natural or artificial, owning, having custody of or in charge of livestock. 
    Running at large means any livestock which is not under manual control of a person and which is on any public road of this city or on any property not belonging to the owner of the livestock, unless by permission of the owner of such property. 
(Ord. No. 18-18, § 3, 12-20-18) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-2. 
Sec. 10-30-2. - Violations. 
(a)  An animal control officer of the city is authorized to issue and serve citations for appearance before the municipal court for violations of the provisions for the animal control ordinances of the city. 
(b)  An animal control officer of the city is further authorized to investigate and report to the proper officials for appropriate prosecution any violations of the Code of the city relating to cruelty to animals or any violations of the Georgia Animal Protection Act (Section 4-11-1 of the "Georgia Animal Protection Act," et seq. of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, 1986 Supplement). 
(c)  The power and authority given hereby under subsections (a) and (b) of this section does not include the right of arrest or detention, but is merely to authorize issuance of citation and service of the same under subsection (a) and the right to investigate and report violations as authorized under subsection (b) and shall not make such animal control officer of the city a peace officer as that term is commonly used in the state or as that term is defined by Paragraph (11) of Section 16-1-3 of the Criminal Code of Georgia (O.C.G.A. Section 16-1-3). 
Code 1972, § 19-8; Ord. No. 89-3, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 10-30-3. - Animal cruelty. 
(a)  For the purposes of this code section, "animal" shall not include any fish nor shall such term include any pests that might be exterminated or removed from a business, residence or other structure. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Cause physical pain, suffering or death to an animal by an unjustifiable act or omission; 
(2)  After having intentionally exercised custody, control, possession of ownership of an animal, to fail to provide such animal adequate food, water, sanitation conditions or ventilation that is consistent with what a reasonable person of ordinary knowledge would believe is the normal requirement and feeding habit for such animal's size, species, breed, age and physical condition; 
(3)  After having intentionally exercised custody, control, possession of ownership of an animal to fail to maintain adequate shelter and general protection from extreme natural elements of hot, cold and wet weather conditions; or 
(4)  Maliciously administer poison to an animal, or expose an animal to any poisonous substance, with the intent that the substance be taken or swallowed by the animal. 
(Code 1972, § 5-1; Ord. No. 15-14, § 2, 12-8-15) 
State Law reference- Abandonment of dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-3; cruelty to dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-5; destroying or injuring police dog, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-107; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; care of wild animals, O.C.G.A. § 27-5-6. 
Secs. 10-30-4, 10-30-5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 98-31, § 1, adopted Oct. 27, 1998, deleted in their entirety §§ 10-30-4 and 10-30-5. Formerly, such sections pertained to livestock running at large and prohibited the keeping of hogs in the city and were derived from the 1972 Code, §§ 5-2 and 5-3. 
Sec. 10-30-6. - Removal of carcasses. 
    Any person having an animal or other quadruped to die within the city shall forthwith bury or otherwise dispose of such carcass in compliance with the sanitation laws and regulations applicable thereto. Upon failure to comply with this section, the city shall immediately have said carcass removed, and the cost of said removal, together with any fine imposed by the court for such violation, shall be collected from said owner by execution or otherwise. 
(Code 1972, § 13-9) 
State Law reference- Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq. 
Secs. 10-30-7-10-30-20. - Reserved. 
Article II - DOGS AND CATS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1 et seq.; technical assistance for control or elimination of wild or abandoned dogs, O.C.G.A. § 27-1-7; hunting with dogs, O.C.G.A. § 27-3-16; killing dogs that endanger deer, O.C.G.A. § 27-3-49; guide dogs for the handicapped, O.C.G.A. § 30-4-1 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; control of rabies in municipalities, O.C.G.A. §§ 31-19-3. 31-19-9. 

Sec. 10-30-21. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    At large means off the premises of the owner and not under the immediate control of the owner or a member of his immediate family, either by leash, cord, chain or otherwise. 
    Owner means any person owning, keeping or harboring a dog or cat, as the case may be. 
(Code 1972, § 5-14) 
Sec. 10-30-22. - Running in certain areas prohibited. 
(a)  No dogs shall be permitted within the fenced children's playground within Granger Park located at the northwest corner of the intersection of Granger Drive and Hunnicutt Place. 
(b)  The designated employees of the city, county and state are authorized to take into custody and impound any dog within said premises in the city pound or other suitable place, and to detain the same as specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 02-03, § 1, 2-26-02) 
Sec. 10-30-23. - Inoculation and tag required. 
(a)  No dog shall be kept, harbored or maintained within the city, unless such dog is licensed by having been inoculated against rabies by the administration of antirabies vaccine, approved by the state department of human resources, and administered by a licensed veterinarian and shall have attached by collar or otherwise a numbered tag showing such inoculation, in accordance with the regulations of the state department of human resources, and in accordance with an act to provide for the control of rabies codified as O.C.G.A. Title 31, Chapter 19. 
(b)  Prior to the redemption or adoption of any dog, an amount equal to the current cost of a rabies inoculation shall be paid by the owner or proposed owner to the city, whereupon he shall receive a certificate from the city that is redeemable at a veterinarian's office in LaGrange for a rabies inoculation. 
(c)  If, after any dog has been adopted or redeemed and coupon for rabies inoculation given as specified in subsection (b) above, and the owner fails to cause the coupon to be redeemed and the dog inoculated, if the dog is thereafter picked up or brought into the shelter, or if the owner is given a citation for violation of the provisions of this chapter, a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fine shall be added to any other fine or redemption fee levied under the provisions of this chapter and a new certificate for rabies vaccination issued. This twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fine is for the first time the dog has been found without vaccination after receiving the vaccination certificate and for all subsequent findings. 
(Code 1972, § 5-15) 
State Law reference- Inoculation of canines against rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-5; certificates of inoculation, tags, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-6. 
Sec. 10-30-24. - Running at large; impoundment. 
(a)  No dog shall be permitted to run at large within the city. 
(b)  The designated employees of the city, the county and the state are authorized to take into custody and impound any dog running at large within the city, in the city pound or other suitable place, and to detain the same as specified in this article. 
(Code 1972, § 5-16) 
State Law reference- Damages done to livestock or poultry by dog, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-4; dogs in heat at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; contracts for joint services or exchange of services, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2. 
Sec. 10-30-25. - Holding period in pound; notice to owner. 
    Any dog seized and impounded under this article shall be detained in the city pound or other suitable place for a period of ninety-six (96) hours after seizure, and if the owner of the dog is known, such owner shall be notified of the seizure and impoundment of such dog. 
(Code 1972, § 5-17) 
Sec. 10-30-26. - Reclaiming from shelter; fees. 
    The owner of any animal impounded under this article may reclaim such animal upon payment of the following redemption fee.

Fourth time impounded ..... 80.00 
Fifth time impounded ..... 100.00 
Each time thereafter ..... 100.00 
Redemption Fee for Cats

Each time impounded ..... $15.00 
(Code 1972, § 5-18; Ord. No. 92-28, § 1, 8-25-92) 
Sec. 10-30-27. - Surrender of dogs and cats. 
    Any dog or cat may be surrendered to the city pound by delivery of the animal to the pound and by the signing of a statement of surrender by the owner giving consent to the disposition of the animal at the discretion of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 5-19) 
Sec. 10-30-28. - Adoption of animals. 
(a)  Any dog not claimed by the owner within four (4) days or any other animals surrendered by the owner may be placed for adoption at any time at the discretion of the animal control officer. Adoption will be made only to individuals who express a humane intention for the maintenance and care of the animal. 
Adoption Fees 
Fee 
Cats and kittens ..... $50.00 
Dogs and puppies ..... 75.00 
(b)  If the animal to be adopted has not already been spayed or neutered, upon payment of the adoption fee specified in subsection (a) of this section, the city shall issue to the owner a voucher in the amount of fifty-six dollars and fifty cents ($56.50) for each dog and thirty-four dollars ($34.00) for each cat adopted, which voucher may be negotiated to any participating veterinarian to offset the cost to spay and neuter the adopted animal. 
(c)  From time to time, and upon good cause shown, the city manager is authorized to modify and/or waive adoption fees as established herein. 
(Code 1972, § 5-20; Ord. No. 92-28, § 2, 8-25-92; Ord. No. 95-39, §§ 1, 2, 9-26-95; Ord. No. 99-29, § 2, 8-10-99; Ord. No. 17-11, § 1, 12-21-17) 
Sec. 10-30-29. - Destruction of animals. 
(a)  Any animal suffering from rabies or infected with any infectious or dangerous disease shall be destroyed by the animal control officer. Any healthy animal placed for adoption by the animal control officer may be retained in the shelter for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, and may be retained in excess of ninety (90) days only with specific authorization from the city manager or his authorized representative. In no event shall the number of animals retained at the shelter exceed one hundred twenty-five (125) dogs and thirty-five (35) cats. 
(b)  If the animal control officer determines that the probability of an otherwise healthy animal available for adoption being so adopted is low because of age, appearance or for any other reason, any such animal may be destroyed at any time. 
(Code 1972, § 5-21; Ord. No. 99-29, § 1, 8-10-99) 
Sec. 10-30-30. - Rabies; quarantine. 
(a)  In the event a dog, cat or ferret has bitten a human within the city limits, such animal shall be immediately placed in quarantine for ten (10) days. At the election of the animal control officer, the quarantine may take place at the animal control facility, a kennel in a veterinary hospital or commercial boarding establishment or, upon proof that the animal has received proper inoculation to include rabies vaccination, at the home of the animal's owner. Should the quarantine be at the home of the animal's owner, the animal shall be inside the home or, if outside, be contained in a pen or on a leash so as to not be generally assessable to the public. Moreover, in the event the quarantine is at the home of the owner, the owner shall produce the animal at the request of the animal control officer for the purpose of observation of the animal during said quarantine. At the first sign of illness or behavioral change in the animal, the owner shall be required to have the animal evaluated by a veterinarian. If clinical signs are suggestive of rabies, the animal should be immediately destroyed, tested for rabies and the exposed person(s) notified. 
(b)  Any stray or unwanted dog, cat or ferret which bites a person may be destroyed immediately and the head submitted for rabies examination. 
(Ord. No. 07-27, § 1, 11-8-07) 
Sec. 10-30-31. - Tethering of dogs. 
(a)  The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this code section, unless otherwise specifically stated: 
    Proper enclosure means any structure or device used to restrict a dog to a limited amount of space such as a fenced area, electronic animal confinement system, building, house, pen, or other device or structure out of which a dog cannot climb, dig, jump, or otherwise escape. Proper enclosures must have an adequate space for exercise based on a dimension of at least one hundred (100) square feet per each dog that weighs fewer than twenty (20) pounds and two hundred (200) square feet per each dog that weighs more than twenty (20) pounds. Proper enclosures shall also contain appropriate shelter of sufficient size to allow each dog to stand up, turn around, and lie down. 
    Tethered , also known as direct point chaining , means a dog attached to a stationary object by a chain, cable or similar device commonly used for the size and type of dog involved. 
    Electronic animal confinement system shall mean a commercially produced, functioning electronic fence which utilizes an invisible electrically generated perimeter, in which the animal within the perimeter wears an electronic collar that produces an electric shock when the animal approaches or exceeds the perimeter. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every owner of a dog to ensure that the dog is securely and humanely enclosed within a proper enclosure as a means of primary restraint. Such enclosure must be securely locked at any time the dog is left unattended. When outside the proper enclosure but on the owner's property, it shall be the duty of every owner of a dog to ensure that the dog is humanely secured by a leash or lead and under the control of a responsible and competent person; or off leash but under the direct control of a responsible and competent person who is physically present with the dog, provided that such dog is obedient to that person's command. 
(c)  Any dog that is housed outside of its owner's house shall be housed in a proper enclosure that complies with the provisions of this Code. 
(d)  Direct point chaining or tethering of a dog is prohibited. 
(e)  As a secondary means of restraint to a proper enclosure, a dog may be attached to a running cable line or trolley system providing that: 
(1)  Only one (1) dog may be attached to each running cable line or trolley system; 
(2)  Tethers and cables attaching the dog to the running cable line or trolley system must be made of a substance which cannot be chewed through by the dog (chains are not allowed as tethering material) and shall not weigh more than five (5) percent of the weight of the dog tethered; 
(3)  A running cable line or trolley system must have a swivel installed at each end and be attached to a stationary object that cannot be moved by the dog; 
(4)  The running cable line or trolley system must be at least ten (10) feet in length and positioned at sufficient distance from any other objects to prohibit the tangling of the cable/lead line; must not extend over an object or an edge that could result in injury of strangulation of the dog; and must be of sufficient distance from any fence so as to prohibit the dog from access to the fence; 
(5)  The length of the lead line from the running cable line or trolley system to the dog's harness should allow access to the maximum available exercise area and allow the animal free access to food, water, and shelter. In no event shall the length of the lead line allow for access to less than the square footage required within a proper enclosure as defined in subsection (a) above; or 
(6)  The lead line must be attached (but shall not be padlocked) to a properly fitted harness not used for the display of a current rabies tag and other identification. Collars are prohibited for the purposes of securing a dog to a running cable line or trolley system. 
(f)  If an electronic animal confinement system is used to confine a dog, it shall provide a properly fitted and working signal device that will be worn by the dog to be enclosed. 
(Ord. No. 15-14, § 1, 12-8-15; Ord. No. 18-18, §§ 1, 2, 12-20-18) 
Secs. 10-30-32-10-30-34. - Reserved. 
Article III - DANGEROUS DOG CONTROL[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference- Dangerous dog control, Georgia Laws 1988, pp. 824-834; dog control officer, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20; animal control board, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-24. 

Sec. 10-30-35. - Implementation of state law. 
    This article shall be known and may be referred to as the dangerous dog control ordinance of the city. It is the intention of the governing authority of the city by the adoption of this article to implement the provisions of the Dangerous Dog Control Law adopted and approved by the General Assembly of Georgia on April 4, 1988, and made effective, for enforcement purposes on January 1, 1989, as the same now exists or may hereafter be amended (Georgia Laws 1988, Pages 824 through 834). 
(Ord. No. 88-130, § 1, 12-27-88) 
Sec. 10-30-36. - Mayor and council as hearing board. 
    In lieu of creating an animal control board to hold and conduct the hearings provided for in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-24, all hearings required thereby shall be held and conducted by the mayor and council of the City of LaGrange, the governing authority of the city. 
(Ord. No. 88-130, § 1, 12-27-88) 
Sec. 10-30-37. - Dog control officer; position created. 
    There is hereby created in the city the position of dog control officer as provided in and contemplated by the provisions of the Dangerous Dog Control Law of the State of Georgia (Georgia Laws 1988, Pages 825, et seq.; O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.); immediately upon the adoption of Ordinance No. 88-130, the city manager is hereby authorized and directed to appoint an individual as dog control officer of the city to carry out the duties and responsibilities of the dog control officer as provided in the Dangerous Dog Control Law of Georgia (O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 88-130, § 1, 12-27-88) 
Secs. 10-30-38, 10-30-39. - Reserved. 
Articlele IV - PIT BULL DOGS 

Sec. 10-30-40. - Definitions; standards. 
(a)  As defined and used in this article, the term "pit bull dog" shall refer to any dog which exhibits those distinguishing characteristics which: 
(1)  Substantially conform to the standards established by the American Kennel Club for American Staffordshire Terriers or Staffordshire Bull Terriers; or 
(2)  Substantially conform to the standards established by the United Kennel Club for American Pit Bull Terriers. 
(b)  The current standards of the American Kennel Club and United Kennel Club referred to in this article and incorporated herein shall remain on file in the office of the assistant city manager. 
(Ord. No. 06-37, § 1, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 07-12, § 3, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 4, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 10-30-41. - Registration; fee. 
(a)  In order to insure and monitor compliance with the requirements of this article, no pit bull dog shall be kept, harbored or maintained in the city unless such animal has been registered by the owner with the Animal Control Division of the LaGrange Police Department. 
(b)  Each registration shall include the following: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the dog's owner; 
(2)  Address where dog is harbored, if different from owner's address; 
(3)  A full description of the dog including the sex, color and any other distinguishing physical characteristics of same; 
(4)  Proof of inoculation and tag as required by Code section 10-30-23; 
(5)  Proof of liability insurance or adequate surety bond as required in this article; and 
(6)  Proof of proper enclosure as required in this article. 
(c)  Upon proper registration, city shall provide to the pit bull owner a tag to verify registration which shall be and remain attached to the dog's collar. 
(d)  The fee for registration pursuant this article shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 06-37, § 1, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 10-30-42. - Liability insurance; surety bond. 
    Every owner of a pit bull dog subject to this article shall at all times maintain either: 
(a)  A policy of insurance in the amount of at least fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the owner of the pit bull dog against liability for personal injuries inflicted by the pit bull dog; or 
(b)  A surety bond in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in this state and payable to any person injured by the pit bull dog. 
(Ord. No. 06-37, § 1, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 10-30-43. - Proper enclosure. 
(a)  Every owner of a pit bull dog subject to this article shall at all times maintain for said dog a proper enclosure. A proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a pit bull dog while on the owner's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed or locked pin, fence or structure suitable to prevent the entry of younger children and designed to prohibit the dog from escaping said enclosure. Any such enclosure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog from escaping either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. 
(b)  At any time that a pit bull dog is not confined in a proper enclosure as described herein, the dog shall be muzzled in such a manner as to prevent it from biting or injuring any person or animal, and kept on a leash with the owner or custodian in attendance. 
(c)  An exception to this code section is hereby provided for any pit bull dog being attended to by a veterinary professional, or while participating in any lawful dog show, contest or exhibition sponsored by a dog club, association, society, or similar organization. 
(Ord. No. 06-37, § 1, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 10-30-44. - Impoundment. 
(a)  Upon complaint or upon reasonable grounds to believe that a person owns or is keeping or harboring an unlicensed pit bull dog on any premises within the city, the LaGrange Police Department or animal control officer may cause the matter to be investigated. 
(b)  Any unlicensed pit bull dog found within the city may be seized and impounded at the city animal shelter, during which time the owner may reclaim the animal upon proof of compliance with this article. If the owner of the impounded dog is known, such owner shall be notified of the impoundment. Should the owner fail to reclaim the pit bull within four (4) days from the impoundment, the animal may be adopted if, in the discretion of the animal control officer, said animal does not show aggressive tendencies and is otherwise a candidate for adoption. 
(Ord. No. 06-37, § 1, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 13-02, § 1, 2-12-13) 
Sec. 10-30-45. - Mandatory spay/neuter. 
(a)  Subject to the express exceptions provided in subsection (b) below, it shall be unlawful to keep, harbor or maintain in the city any unspayed or unneutered pit bull dog over four (4) months of age. 
(b)  The prohibition set forth in subsection (a) above shall not apply if a veterinarian licensed in this state shall certify in writing that a specific pit bull dog is medically unfit to undergo the required spay or neuter procedure because of a physical condition which would be substantially aggravated by such procedure or would likely cause the animal's death. Such writing shall also include a description of the likely duration of the physical condition which prohibits the procedure. As soon as such condition ceases to exist, it shall be the duty of the person who harbors or keeps such animal to promptly comply with this code section. 
(c)  Failure to comply with this code section may result in the unspayed/unneutered pit bull to be seized and impounded at the city animal shelter and retained for ten (10) days, during which time the owner may reclaim the animal upon proof of arrangements to comply with this code section. Should the owner fail to make and give proper notice of the arrangements to comply with this code section within ten (10) days from impoundment, the animal shall be destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 06-37, § 1, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 10-30-46. - Violation; penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate the provisions of this article shall upon conviction in the municipal court of the City of LaGrange be punished as provided in section 1-1-6 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 06-37, § 1, 12-19-06) 
Title 15 - PUBLIC SERVICES AND FRANCHISES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Municipal services, § 5.10 et seq. 
State constitution reference- Power of cities to provide certain services, Art. 9, § 2, Par. 3. 
State Law reference- Water resources, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-1 et seq.; damage to utility property, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-7-22, 16-7-25; relocation of facilities of public utilities, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-170 et seq.; water and sewage systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5; public utilities, O.C.G.A. Title 46. 

Chapter 15-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 15-1-1. - Department of public services-Created; director; appointment; removal. 
    There is created the department of public services, the head of which shall be designated as the director of public services. He shall be appointed by the city manager, subject to confirmation by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-44) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 15-1-2. - Same-Powers and duties of director. 
    The director of public services shall, under the general supervision of the city manager, provide administrative and technical direction and general supervision over the design, construction, repair and maintenance of the system of streets and drains; the collection and disposal of refuse; the design, construction, maintenance and operation of a system of sanitary sewers and sewage treatment facilities; the design, location, maintenance and operation of all parks, playgrounds and cemeteries of the city, including records of burials and lot ownership; the preparation and maintenance of official maps of the city, showing streets, utility lines, approximate property lines, watercourses and major features and the maintenance, repair and operation of airports and adjacent publicly owned land, and to that end he shall: 
(1)  Represent the city in contracts with other governmental jurisdictions, contractors and the general public on matters under his general supervision; 
(2)  Review plans and specifications submitted by developers, contractors and engineers for streets, drainage and sanitary sewerage systems prior to final approval and acceptance by the city; 
(3)  Enforce all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to the functions of government under his general supervision; 
(4)  Investigate major and controversial complaints; assist in the preparation of annual budget estimates; exercise budget control; and prescribe general rules, regulations and administrative policies for the department within the framework of the general policies approved by the mayor and council; 
(5)  Prepare construction cost estimates; forecast the long range and annual needs and recommend general policies for operating the department; prepare monthly and annual operating reports as may be required by the city manager or mayor and council; and 
(6)  Perform related duties as may be directed by the city manager or prescribed by ordinance or resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-45) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 15-5; solid waste, Ch. 15-10; parks and recreation, Ch. 15-15; cemeteries, Ch. 15-20; subdivisions, Ch. 25-20. 
Chapter 15-5 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[2] 
Footnotes:

Ch. 25-20; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 30-1 et seq.; scattering refuse, § 15-10-3; unauthorized disposal areas, § 15-10-6; making music on streets and sidewalks, § 30-5-3.
