Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-10-1. - Intent. 
    It is declared to be the intent of the city, in furtherance of its responsibility to protect the public health, safety and well-being of its citizens to protect and enhance the quality of its environment by enacting policies governing the storage, collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste, as that term is hereinafter defined in this chapter, in accordance with the comprehensive state-wide program for solid waste management now in effect in the State of Georgia. It is the purpose of this chapter to establish procedures to regulate solid waste management activities conducted by the city sanitation division, those commercial haulers licensed to handle solid waste generated from commercial and industrial sources and to provide for the uniform prohibition throughout the city of all littering on public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-2. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    Ashes: The residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible material. 
    Biomedical waste: Any solid waste which contains medical residue, pathological waste, biological waste, cultures, and stocks of infectious agents and associated biologicals, contaminated animal carcasses (body parts, their bedding and other wastes from such animals), chemotherapy waste, discarded medical equipment and parts as now or hereafter defined in the Rules of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division. 
    City: The City of LaGrange, Georgia. 
    Collector: The person or persons as defined herein who, under agreements, verbal or written, with or without compensation does the work of collecting and/or transporting solid wastes, provided however, that this definition shall not include an individual collecting and/or transporting waste from his own single-family dwelling unit. 
    Commercial solid waste: All types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. This includes landscaping companies who generate yard trimmings and other solid waste by the establishment and maintenance of landscaping on residential properties and waste generated from an operation conducted from a residence requiring a business license. 
    Commercial hauler: A person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of solid waste collection and/or hauling in the city as a service and for which a fee is charged and received and which is licensed for that purpose by the city. 
    Composting: The controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. 
    Construction/demolition waste: Waste building materials and rubble resulting from construction, remodeling, repair and demolition operations on pavements, houses, commercial buildings or other structures. Such wastes include, but are not limited to asbestos-containing waste, wood, bricks, metal, concrete, wallboard, paper, cardboard, inert waste landfill material and other nonputrescible wastes. 
    Container: A receptacle designed for the temporary reception and storage of solid waste pending transportation to a municipal solid waste landfill or other licensed solid waste landfill or transfer station. 
    Garbage: Any putrescible or nonputrescible, organic or inorganic, combustible or noncombustible wastes, wastes from the preparation, cooking and serving of foods or liquids, market wastes, wastes from the handling and storage of produce, and those items of solid waste normally generated within a residential household which can be properly and safely fitted into an approved solid waste container. 
    Hazardous waste: Any solid waste which is, has been or in the future may be, defined as a hazardous substance by federal, state or local law, or which has hazardous constituent of sufficient quantity as defined in regulations promulgated by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources in Chapter 391-3-11 of the Official Compilation of Rules and Regulations of the State of Georgia. 
    Industrial waste: Solid waste generated by manufacturing or industrial processes that is not a hazardous waste regulated under the Hazardous Waste Management Act and regulations promulgated by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources in Chapter 391-3-Il of the Official Compilation of Rules and Regulations of the State of Georgia. 
    Inert waste: Wastes that will not or are not likely to cause production of leachate of environmental concern. Such wastes are limited to earth and earth-like products, concrete, cured asphalt, rock, bricks, yard trash, stumps, limbs and leaves. 
    Litter: Any kind of discarded and uncontrolled or uncontained solid waste, garbage, trash, dirt, sand, gravel, refuse, debris, dead animal or thing or substance whatsoever, whether liquid or solid, that may be carried or deposited, in whole or in part, by the wind, rain, snow, water, animal, or any other such force into any public or private property, or into and river, public waterway, drain, sewer or receiving basin. 
    Liquid waste: Any waste material that is determined to contain "free liquids" as defined by Method 9095 (Paint Filter Liquids Test), and as described in "Test Methods for the Evaluation of Solid Wastes, Physical/Chemical Methods" (EPA Pub. No. SW-846). 
    Mulching: Chipping, grinding or shredding organic materials, limbs, trees, stumps, yard trimmings and the like into small pieces for the purpose of reuse as landscape bedding, volume reduction prior to final disposal or further processing such as composting. 
    Municipal solid waste: Any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks and means solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds and day use recreational areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste, but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. 
    Municipal solid waste landfill (MSWL): A disposal facility in which any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste or nonhazardous sludges is disposed of under controlled circumstances and by means of placing an acceptable or approved cover thereon. 
    Open dump: An area at which solid waste from one (1) or more sources is left to decompose, burn or which otherwise creates a nuisance or a threat to human health or the environment. 
    Putrescible waste: Waste that is capable of being decomposed by micro organisms, capable of generating noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which during or after decay may serve as breeding areas or feeding material for insects or animals. 
    Recoverable material: A material which has a known use, reuse or recycling potential and which can be feasibly used, reused or recycled. 
    Scavenging: The salvaging of or rummaging through the garbage, trash, disposed products or, solid waste of another by any person, who is not authorized or licensed by the city to pick up and remove the waste, without the consent of the owner or generator of the waste. 
    Sharps: Any discarded articles that may cause punctures or cuts, including but not limited to needles, intravenous tubing, needles, syringes or scalpel blades. 
    Solid waste: Any putrescible or nonputrescible waste or discarded material including solid, liquid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material resulting from residential, industrial, commercial, mining, and agricultural operations and from community activities, but does not include recovered materials. 
    Special waste: Those wastes requiring specific processing, handling or disposal techniques as determined necessary by the director of public services or his designee which are different from the techniques normally utilized for handling or disposal. Examples of such waste types may include, but are not limited to: mining waste; fly ash; bottom ash; sludges; friable asbestos; industrial waste; large dead animals or large quantities of dead animals and residue; foundry waste; petroleum contaminated wastes; municipal solid waste ash; or contaminated soil from the cleanup of a spill. 
    Trash: Organic and inorganic waste that is too large or heavy to be routinely broken down, compressed or otherwise disassembled to fit into the normal solid waste containers authorized for use by a household or business for the collection of its waste. Trash includes, but is not limited to items such as lumber, bedding, furniture, garden tools, etc., but does not include yard trimmings. 
    Unauthorized accumulation: An unauthorized accumulation of solid waste or litter is any amount of either which is not contained or packaged as required by this article and which is stored or allowed to accumulate on any premises in the city in a manner that may create unsanitary conditions, fire hazards, cause offensive and obnoxious odors, provide a breeding place for insects or a harboring place for vermin, invite plundering, endanger the safety of children or adults, reduce property values or in any way or manner affect adversely the health, safety, welfare and well-being of the public. 
    Yard trimmings: The organic material generated from maintenance by an owner or occupant of improved ground areas. Trimmings may include leaves, brush, clippings, shrub and tree prunings and discarded Christmas trees, but does not include grass clippings. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 96-32, § 1, 5-14-96; Ord. No. 02-19, § 1, 5-28-02) 
Sec. 15-10-3. - Receptacles and containers required. 
    Every person in possession, charge or control of any building or premises upon which solid waste is accumulated or produced shall be required to provide and keep in a suitable place readily accessible to the solid waste collection crews of the city, or to the commercial haulers, as the case may be, receptacles and containers suitable for the storage of all such solid waste which will normally accumulate between the established collection dates. The lids or covers of all solid waste containers shall at all times be kept fastened and secured in such manner as to prevent overturning by the elements or by animals. 
    Such lids or covers shall be removed only while the containers or receptacles are being filled or emptied, as the case may be. All receptacles and containers shall be maintained in good serviceable condition at all times. Any receptacle or container which does not conform to the requirements of this chapter or which has ragged or sharp edges or other defects likely to hamper collecting the contents therefrom or injure the public generally, shall be replaced promptly by the user or provider thereof. 
Secs. 15-10-4-15-10-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Formerly, Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, adopted Feb. 27, 1996, had been designated as § 15-10-4, unauthorized accumulations generally; abandoned vehicles. Such section was deleted by Ord. No. 97-11, § 1, adopted Feb. 25, 1997. 
Sec. 15-10-10. - Disposal of ashes. 
    Ashes shall be removed by the owner or occupant of the premises at his own expense and shall not be placed in any container designed for the storage of solid waste. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-11. - Dumping in solid waste containers regulated; scavengers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump garbage, trash, refuse or any other solid waste material in container placed or located for the collection of solid waste when said container belongs to another person unless the person dumping such refuse, garbage or waste shall have the written permission of the person or authorized representative of the person owning the container, paying for it, or on whose property it is located. 
(b)  Scavengers shall conduct their operations in such a manner as not to hinder or interfere with solid waste collection and disposal by either city forces or commercial haulers. Solid waste shall not be scattered by the scavenger at the place of collection or upon any street, alley or walkway in the city, nor shall such solid waste be left by the scavenger in such a condition that it may be scattered by other persons, animals or natural causes. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-12. - Biomedical waste. 
    Biomedical waste originating from facilities which generate less than one hundred (100) pounds per month or those facilities such as single-family residences that are not considered "generators" of biomedical waste per state regulations may dispose of such waste along with other wastes which the city or other commercial hauler collects only if the biomedical waste is put into proper containers according to the following standards: 
(1)  Biomedical waste, except for sharps, shall be placed in containers which are impervious to moisture and have a strength sufficient to preclude ripping, tearing or bursting under normal conditions of use. The containers shall be securely closed as to prevent leakage or expulsion of solid or liquid waste during storage, handling or transport. 
(2)  Sharps will be contained for storage, transportation, treatment and subsequent disposal in leakproof, rigid, puncture-resistant containers which are taped closed or tightly lidded to preclude exposure or loss of the contents. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-13. - Burning solid waste. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of solid waste upon any public or private premises within the city by burning, except as may be specifically permitted by state and/or local regulations. No person shall burn any solid waste in any receptacle or container maintained under the provisions of this chapter from which either the city or commercial hauler collects solid waste for disposal. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-14. - Hazardous waste. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave, deposit, pour, or infiltrate any hazardous waste that may cause or significantly contribute to serious illness or death or that may pose a substantial threat to human health or the environment when improperly introduced into either trash piles, garbage containers, sewers, streams, landfill areas, or any other undesignated areas. Hazardous wastes are among the leavings of a highly technological society and come from many segments of that society, including commerce, industry, hospitals, households, research laboratories, and all levels of government. The substances and materials prohibited by this section are any solid wastes which have been identified, defined or treated as a hazardous waste by the United States Environmental Protection Agency under the provisions of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) of 1976 by enactment by the Congress of the United States, as amended. To further identify such substances, the substances in question must not contain any one (1) or more of the following characteristics: 
(1)  Ignitability, which identifies wastes that pose a fire hazard during routine management; 
(2)  Corrosivity, which identifies wastes requiring special containers because of their ability to corrode standard materials or requiring segregation from other wastes because of their ability to dissolve toxic contaminants; 
(3)  Reactivity or explosiveness, which identifies wastes that, during routine management, tend to react spontaneously, to react vigorously with air to water, to be unstable to shock or heat, to generate toxic gases, or to explode; and 
(4)  Toxicity, which identifies wastes that, when improperly managed, may release toxicants in sufficient quantities to pose a substantial hazard to human health or to the environment. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-15. - Enforcement. 
    The police department and the department of community and economic development shall be the responsible enforcement agencies for gaining compliance with this chapter. 
    Notices of violations may be issued by the heads or the designated employees of other city departments including community development, fire department, police department, solid waste division and streets and drainage division. Notices issued by any department shall be promptly turned over to the police department or department of community and economic development for followup and coordination. Notices issued shall specify a reasonable time limit for compliance. Nothing in this section shall preclude immediate enforcement by a police officer on complaint of any person or upon witnessing any violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Secs. 15-10-16-15-10-20. - Reserved. 
Article II - RESIDENTIAL SOLID WASTE 

Sec. 15-10-21. - Receipt of service required. 
    In order to protect the public health and sanitation, all improved residential properties within the city shall receive regular garbage and trash collection services from the city sanitation division. No owner of an improved residential property shall be exempt or relieved from payment of the monthly collection fee by reason of failure or refusal of such owner or his tenant or tenants, to accept collection and handling services as provided by the city sanitation division. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-22. - Solid waste collection schedules. 
    The solid waste superintendent or his designated representative shall provide a schedule to each residence receiving garbage collection service from the city which shall indicate the day on which collection will be made. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 02-24, § 1, 8-27-02) 
Sec. 15-10-23. - Approved containers. 
    All residential solid waste, except newspapers, stored outside the residence pending collection shall be placed inside approved containers with lids tightly affixed. Approved containers shall be those issued by the city to residential customers pursuant to this article, designed to be rolled to curbside for periodic collection. Under no circumstances will garbage outside of city-issued containers be collected. If necessary, extra containers may be obtained for an additional monthly fee. Each container shall bear a serial number and shall be registered to the assigned customer. All containers shall remain the property of the city. Newspapers shall be bundled and tied and placed separately on top of the container, or placed beside the container for curbside collection. For residential customers opting to receive "premium" service (see section 15-10-24) or mobility-impaired residents, all solid waste must be placed in the city-provided containers. All recyclable items should be taken to a drop-off center. Except when taken to the curbside for scheduled collection, containers shall be located near the residence and outside of fenced enclosures in which animals are kept. Containers shall be used exclusively for the storage and transport of solid waste to the curbside. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 02-24, § 1, 8-27-02) 
Sec. 15-10-24. - Residential garbage collection service levels; container location. 
    Three (3) levels of service for the collection of residential solid waste are provided by the city: 
(1)  Curbside garbage collection: By 6:30 a.m. on the scheduled day for collection, customers place their container on the street shoulder in front of their residence. Containers should be placed approximately four feet from the edge of the roadway, but not so as to pose a physical or visual obstruction to motorists. Where there is insufficient right-of-way adjacent to the roadway, or other topographical difficulties exist which make it unreasonable to conform to the general requirements, customers should place their container at a location mutually agreeable to the customer and solid waste division, after consultation with the solid waste superintendent or his designee. All containers shall be removed from the curbside and returned to the customer's residence no later than 8:00 a.m. on the day following the day of service. 
(2)  Assisted service for households with mobility-impaired residents: Households in which all regular residents are mobility-impaired may apply for assisted collection service at the same fee as levied for curbside collection. City personnel will enter upon the customer's property to collect their solid waste from city-issued container(s) on the scheduled day of collection. 
(3)  Premium service: City personnel will enter upon a customer's property to collect their solid waste from city-issued container(s) on the scheduled day of collection if the customer subscribes to this service level. 
For households subscribing to "premium" service or for those households with mobility-impaired residents, the city-issued container(s) shall be placed so that the collector shall not be required to go more than twenty (20) feet beyond the edge of the driveway, preferably visible from the street. Containers located on private property shall not be serviced until clear access is provided to both the collection vehicle and the path the collector must travel to access container. No containers should be located within garages, carports, basements, breezeways, fenced enclosures or otherwise in the vicinity of articles not considered to be waste by the resident. Collectors shall not be required to collect solid waste from any premises where an animal considered to be vicious is maintained without restraint. If it is not practical to place the container(s) for collection at the location above specified, the solid waste superintendent shall designate the location of the container(s). The owner, his agent or occupant of any residential property, shall release the city from any claim of damage of any kind or nature that may result to the premises or persons located thereon, or for any other claim of damages that may result in the servicing of the residential property because of the entry upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 02-24, § 1, 8-27-02) 
Sec. 15-10-25. - Residential garbage collection practices. 
(a)  Garbage accumulated by residents and properly placed in approved containers shall be collected once each week. 
(b)  Customers placing their garbage at the curbside may utilize either sixty-eight (68) or ninety-six (96) gallon containers provided by the city. Customers subscribing to "premium" service or households with mobility-impaired residents receiving assisted service shall utilize only ninety-six (96) gallon containers provided by the city. 
(c)  Newspaper and cardboard that has been broken down, neatly stacked and tied may be stored adjacent to garbage containers placed curbside for collection. Such uncontainerized solid waste is limited to these two (2) items and shall be limited to one-half cubic yard in size. 
(d)  Household garbage shall be drained of all liquids prior to its being placed in solid waste containers. 
(e)  Pet litter shall be placed in securely tied in a plastic bag not to exceed ten (10) pounds in weight and placed in the container. 
(f)  Disposable diapers shall be placed and tied securely in plastic bags. 
(g)  Packing materials such as styrofoam pellets, excelsior, etc., that can be easily scattered by the elements shall be placed in taped boxes or plastic bags. 
(h)  Customers are responsible for keeping containers clean and free of accumulated waste. Containers may be cleaned with a mild detergent and/or treated with an effective insecticide, if necessary, to prevent a nuisance. Bagging of all waste deposited in the city provided container will minimize the need for cleaning. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 02-24, § 1, 8-27-02) 
Sec. 15-10-26. - Duty of owner/occupant to see that containers are emptied and maintained; lost, stolen or damaged containers. 
    Every owner, occupant, tenant, or lessee of a house or building used for residential, business, commercial or other purposes, is required to maintain responsibility and surveillance over the solid waste receptacles on his/her premises. For households subscribing to curbside garbage collection, it is the owner or occupants responsibility to insure that the container(s) is (are) located on the curb by 6:30 a.m. on the regularly scheduled collection day. For households subscribing to "premium" service, it is the owner or occupants responsibility to insure that the container(s) is (are) located within twenty (20) feet of the driveway by 6:30 a.m. on the regularly scheduled day of collection. City solid waste collectors shall not be responsible for picking up loose and scattered solid waste resulting from improper containerization or lack of maintenance of the generator's solid waste storage area. 
    Any residential container provided by the city which becomes lost or stolen shall be replaced by the city and shall be paid for by the owner of the residence to which the container is assigned. Containers which are damaged through normal usage shall be repaired or replaced by the city. Containers which are damaged through no fault of the city are paid for by the owner of the residence to which the container is assigned. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 02-24, § 1, 8-27-02) 
Sec. 15-10-27. - Trash collection practices. 
    Solid waste or trash of such a nature that it cannot be placed in a receptacle may be placed at the curbside or street side for collection by the city. Such solid waste shall be placed on public right-of-way and collected for disposal twice per month according to the following standards: 
(1)  Debris shall not extend over the sidewalk so as to block pedestrian traffic or fall into or extend over the street so as to hinder vehicular traffic or make it difficult to use motor-driven sweepers. 
(2)  Debris shall not be placed in the gutter, in any ditch or other path of storm water runoff. 
(3)  Trash shall be placed on the right-of-way immediately adjacent to the property from which the trash originated. Trash shall not be placed on vacant lots, parks, across the street from the property on which the trash originated or on another person's property. 
(4)  Trash shall not be placed over stormwater catchbasins, water meters or valve boxes, underneath overhead utility lines or low tree branches, in the vicinity of utility poles and/or guy wires, trees, mailboxes, fire hydrants or steep banks that may impede the collection of the waste, increase the risk of damage to utilities by mechanized loading equipment, or otherwise compromise the safety of the collectors. 
(5)  Solid waste resulting from building construction remodeling and repairs such as plaster, roofing materials, insulation or other rubbish or debris will not be picked up or collected from rental properties, if caused by or generated from contractors or by the owner employing paid or otherwise compensated help. Any such materials will be picked up or collected from an owner occupied property if caused by or generated from work done by the owner-occupant without contractor or otherwise compensated help if such material can be physically managed by city crews. Prior to removal of any such material, the city may require the owner to sign an affidavit or submit other reasonable proof that the work was done without the help of paid or otherwise compensated help. Debris resulting from such activities shall not exceed two (2) cubic yards or four hundred (400) pounds in weight. 
(6)  Rocks, dirt, concrete blocks or bricks are not considered trash and shall not be collected by the city. 
(7)  Household furniture and personal belongings of an evicted tenant, lessee or occupant will not be placed on city property or right-of-way and will not be collected by the city. 
(8)  Old furniture may be placed out for curbside collection, provided it is placed separately from other trash and yard trimmings. 
(9)  Uncontrolled and/or uncontained trash items shall be considered as litter, and the generator shall thereof be subject to the enforcement actions outlined in section 15-10-61. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-28. - Yard trimming collection practices. 
    Yard trimmings, as defined in this chapter, shall at all times be physically separated from containerized garbage and other forms of solid waste (trash) placed curbside for collection. Yard trimmings shall be placed on public right-of-way in such manner as to not obstruct gutters, drains, walkways or streets and shall be collected by the city twice per month according to the following standards: 
(1)  Leaves and pine straw shall be placed in a separate pile from trimmings, clippings, limbs or brush. 
(2)  Small trees, tree trimmings, hedge clippings, shrubbery clippings, limbs, brush and similar materials shall be of a length and/or weight that is manageable by city collection personnel and/or equipment. Said trimmings and clippings shall be placed in a neat stack near the curbline that does not exceed four (4) cubic yards in size or exceed five hundred (500) pounds. 
(3)  No trees, logs, limbs, stumps, roots, dirt, brush or other debris resulting from tree removal, land or lot clearing, grading or landscape maintenance work done by contractors or by the owner employing any help or assistance, paid or otherwise compensated, will be picked up or collected by the city. Paid or otherwise compensated help as used herein shall include independent or licensed contractors but not those persons periodically employed as yard men. Compensation shall also be interpreted to include receiving as compensation the wood, limbs and other residue from such trimming and cutting. Any form of compensation shall place the burden of disposal directly upon the individual or contractor performing the task. 
(4)  No other trash, particularly solid objects such as rocks, glass bottles, wood, pieces of wire, steel or concrete should be mixed with or concealed under yard trimming piles. 
(5)  Yard trimmings shall not be collected by the city for unimproved and/or vacant lots, or multifamily rental units or commercial establishments utilizing the service of a commercial solid waste hauler. 
(6)  Grass clippings resulting from yard cutting, mowing or maintenance activities will not be collected by the city. 
(7)  The location restrictions for placement on public right-of-way as specified in section 15-10-27 shall also apply to yard trimmings. 
(8)  Uncontrolled and/or uncontained yard trimmings shall be considered as litter and the generator shall therefore be subject to the enforcement actions outlined in section 11-10-61. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-29. - Reserved. 
Sec. 15-10-30. - Special collection. 
    The director of public services is authorized to waive the requirements for collection and disposal of yard trimmings and trash during organized community cleanup programs and to provide collection service at the time of the waiver. The director of public services is also authorized to waive the requirements of this section during times of a natural disaster. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-31. - Residential collection fees. 
    The city shall charge fees for collection as follows: 
(1)  Curbside garbage collection. 
a.  Sixty-eight (68) gallon container, per month per residential unit ..... $14.00 
b.  Ninety-six (96) gallon container, per month per residential unit ..... 17.00 
c.  Additional ninety-six (96) gallon container(s), per additional container per month per residential unit ..... 5.50 
(2)  Premium garbage collection service. 
a.  Sixty-eight (68) gallon container, per month per residential unit ..... $27.00 
b.  Ninety-six (96) gallon container, per month per residential unit ..... 30.00 
c.  Additional ninety-six (96) gallon container(s), per additional container per month per residential unit ..... 6.00 
(3)  Households qualifying for physical impairment exemption: 
a.  Sixty-eight (68) gallon container, per month per residential unit ..... $14.00 
b.  Ninety-six (96) gallon container, per month per residential unit ..... 17.00 
c.  Households qualifying for physical impairment exemption are limited to one (1) container per residential unit. 
(4)  Residential trash and yard trimming collection: 
a.  No fee imposed if the solid waste does not exceed the volume, weight and/or other restrictions outlined in sections 15-10-27 and 15-10-28. 
b.  For items exceeding the restrictions outlined in sections 15-10-27 and 15-10-28, the amount to be charged for such loads shall be determined by the superintendent of the solid waste division or his authorized representative. The special handling assessment for excess loads shall be an amount at least equal to the labor, overhead and disposal cost associated with the collection and disposal of the excess load. 
c.  Special assessments will be placed on the customer's next utility bill and are payable in full upon receipt of such bill. 
(5)  Those persons who qualify for the utilities discount as provided in section 20-20-1 et seq. of this Code and for whom a charge is made pursuant to subsection (1)a above shall be eligible for a discount equal to ten dollars and fifty cents ($10.50) per month per residential unit for a ninety-six (96) gallon container and nine dollars ($9.00) per month per residential unit for a sixty-eight (68) gallon container. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 98-14, § 1, 6-23-98; Ord. No. 98-18, § 1, 6-23-98; Ord. No. 02-24, § 1, 8-27-02; Ord. No. 08-14, §§ 1-3, 6-26-08; Ord. No. 08-21, § 1, 7-22-08) 
Secs. 15-10-32-15-10-37. - Reserved. 
Article III - COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL SOLID WASTE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Formerly, Art. III contained § 15-10-37, collection practices, derived from Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, adopted Feb. 27, 1996. Sec. 15-10-37 was deleted by Ord. No. 96-46, § 1, adopted Aug. 27, 1996. 

Sec. 15-10-38. - Approved containers; construction. 
    Small commercial or industrial establishments have the option of utilizing city-issued containers that are designed to be rolled out for periodic collection, as described in sections 15-10-23, 15-10-24, 15-10-25 and 15-10-26. Establishments requiring containers with a larger weekly capacity than ninety-six (96) gallons or a multiple thereof, may use metal or plastic truck-lifted containers specifically designed for such service. Truck-lifted containers shall be provided with a hinged top, receiving channels for truck lifting arms and a drain hole at the bottom of the floor. The owner, agent or tenant thereof, or each business or group of businesses shall provide itself or themselves with a sufficient number of approved individual nondisposable or bulk containers to adequately and properly store all solid waste until removed by a commercial collection service provider. Food service establishments shall use plastic bags as liners in all individual nondisposable solid waste containers and shall place all garbage in plastic bags securely tied before placing garbage in bulk containers. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 02-24, § 1, 8-27-02) 
Sec. 15-10-39. - Commercial collection fees. 
    The city shall charge fees for collection as follows: 
(1)  Curbside commercial garbage collection: 
a.  Ninety-six (96) gallon container, per month per commercial establishment ..... $17.00 
b.  Additional ninety-six (96) gallon container(s), per additional container per month per commercial establishment ..... 12.50 
c.  Commercial customers qualifying under section 15-10-40(b) shall pay a fee as calculated and in an amount determined as provided in section 15-10-39(a) and (b). 
(2)  Premium commercial garbage collection: 
a.  Ninety-six (96) gallon container, per month per commercial establishment ..... $30.00 
b.  Additional ninety-six (96) gallon container(s), per additional container per month per commercial establishment ..... 17.00 
(3)  All schools, colleges, churches, hospitals, fraternal, charitable, recreational and eleemosynary institutions and organizations operated for nonprofit or charitable purposes, with the exception of those institutions which utilize truck-lifted containers, shall be exempt from the payment of collection fees for one (1) ninety-six (96) gallon container placed weekly on the curb for collection. At such institutions generating greater than ninety-six (96) gallons per week, said institution shall have the option of utilizing truck-lifted containers or utilizing additional ninety-six (96) gallon containers. The city shall charge fees for the collection of ninety-six (96) gallon containers from nonprofit or charitable institutions as follows: 
a.  Curbside nonprofit/charitable garbage collection: 
1.  First ninety-six (96) gallon container ..... Exempt 
2.  Additional ninety-six (96) gallon container(s), per additional container per month per location ..... 17.00 
b.  Premium nonprofit/charitable garbage collection: 
1.  Ninety-six (96) gallon container, per month per location ..... $17.00 
2.  Additional ninety-six (96) gallon container(s), per additional container ..... 17.00 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 98-18, § 2, 6-23-98; Ord. No. 02-24, § 1, 8-27-02; Ord. No. 08-14, §§ 4-6, 6-26-08; Ord. No. 08-21, §§ 2, 3, 7-22-08) 
Sec. 15-10-40. - Downtown business district; use of pedestrian trash receptacles and commercial containers. 
(a)  The sidewalk pedestrian trash receptacles located in the downtown business district will be used for pedestrian trash and litter disposal only. No person, firm, or corporation shall use the sidewalk pedestrian trash receptacles for business or commercial rubbish, garbage, or trash nor shall any such person, firm, or corporation place any loose, boxed, bagged or canned business or commercial trash on the sidewalk, street or street right-of-way or public property. 
(b)  The city will place truck-lifted containers at locations designated by the city in the downtown business district. 
    Theme containers shall be issued only by commercial establishments or businesses in the downtown business district and all such commercial establishments or businesses shall use such containers unless a business shall have facilities for disposal on their own premises as required by section 15-10-3 or shall contract with a commercial hauler for removal of such commercial rubbish or garbage. 
(c)  All cardboard boxes shall be crushed and all rubbish or garbage shall be bagged prior to being deposited in such dumpsters. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-41. - Commercial haulers; requirements. 
    Private businesses which operate in the city and provide solid waste collection and disposal services, shall comply with the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  Obtain a solid waste handling permit from the Director of Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, pursuant to O.C.G.A. 128-24. 
(2)  Possess a current license for such business operation in the city. 
(3)  Indemnify, defend and hold harmless the City of LaGrange, its officials, employees and agents, against any and all claims or suits from third parties which may be the result of negligent conduct arising out of the business of collecting, transportation and disposal of solid waste. 
(4)  Use only vehicles and containers which comply with Georgia EPD rules. Waste collection vehicles must be compactor-type trucks, covered or enclosed vehicles, constructed to be substantially leakproof, constructed of durable metal, easily cleanable and designed to prevent litter from escaping during transport. Recycling vehicles shall not be the same ones used for waste collection. Vehicles shall also meet all safety, size and weight requirements of the Georgia Department of Transportation. 
(5)  Reporting requirements: Within thirty (30) days following the end of each calendar quarter, submit to the director of public services the following data regarding waste collection in the city: 
a.  Tonnage figures showing total waste tonnages collected. Catalog this total into (a) residential and (b) commercial/industrial subtotals. 
b.  Tonnage figures showing recovered, recycled or diverted materials by type. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-42. - Trash/yard trimming collection practices. 
    The collection and disposal of trash and/or yard trimmings generated by any facility other than residential and small commercial establishments serviced by the city shall be the responsibility of the owner or operator of such facility. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Secs. 15-10-43-15-10-46. - Reserved. 
Article IV - SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 15-10-47. - Disposal requirement. 
    Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity which transports, pursuant to a contract, whether oral or otherwise, construction/demolition waste generated within the corporate limits of the City of LaGrange shall be required to deliver such construction/demolition waste to the Troup County C&D Landfill. For purposes of this section, the term "construction/demolition waste" shall be as defined in Georgia Department of Natural Resources Rule 391-3-4-.01. 
(Ord. No. 18-12, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 15-10-48. - Unauthorized disposal areas. 
    No person, firm, or corporation shall dump, deposit or dispose of any refuse, garbage, rubbish, or trash other than in a disposal site permitted by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources or in a container defined by and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-49. - Use of refuse disposal area; fees. 
(a)  Refuse will be accepted in and shall be deposited in or brought to the city solid waste disposal facility as hereinafter provided and then only upon payment of the refuse disposal fee specified. Persons failing to comply with the requirements of this section or any other regulations posted at the disposal facility by the site supervisor or the Georgia Environmental Protection Division shall be denied further use of the disposal facility in addition to any other applicable legal sanctions. 
(1)  Refuse originating outside Troup County shall be deposited in the city landfill only pursuant to a specific written contract; 
(2)  The following shall not be delivered to and will not be deposited in or accepted at the city landfill: 
a.  Motor vehicles or any major part thereof, except tires; or 
b.  Grass clippings resulting from yard cutting, mowing, or maintenance activities; or 
c.  Lead-acid batteries; or 
d.  Regulated quantities of hazardous waste as defined in Rules promulgated by the Board of Natural Resources, Chapter 391-3-11; or 
e.  Radioactive waste as defined in Rule promulgated by the Board of Natural Resources Chapter 391-3-9; or 
f.  Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB) waste as defined in 40 CFR, Part 761; or 
g.  Bulk or noncontainerized liquid waste unless the waste is household waste other than septic waste; or 
h.  Tires intermixed with other solid waste (see below). 
(3)  All refuse accepted at the landfill shall be deposited at a location designated by the attendant on duty; 
(4)  Scavenging at the city solid waste disposal facility is prohibited; 
(5)  a.  Charges for disposal of municipal solid waste in the City of LaGrange landfill shall be as follows:

b.  Any person, firm or corporation having an office or place of business in the City of LaGrange other than a commercial hauler, shall have the right of deferred or credit payment of the disposal fees specified herein. Any commercial hauler wherever located or any person, firm or corporation not having an office or place of business in the City of LaGrange shall have the right to arrange for credit or deferred payment of the disposal fees specified herein by making appropriate credit application to the assistant city manager of the city, and upon approval, by depositing with the city security in an amount equal to the estimated refuse disposal fees for a sixty-day period. Any such deposit may be in cash, an irrevocable letter of credit issued by a bank or savings and loan association having an office and place of doing business in the city or by a bond with good and adequate surety thereon approved by the assistant city manager. 
c.  In any instance where credit payment of disposal fees is allowed, all invoices for such fees must be paid within thirty (30) days after the billing date as shown on the invoice. If such disposal fees are not paid within thirty (30) days of such billing date, the right to deliver and deposit refuse in the city landfill shall be immediately suspended and terminated and shall not resume until payment in full is made and the account in brought current.

Article V - LITTER 

Sec. 15-10-50. - Depositing of litter prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or cooperation, in person or by his agent, employee or servant, to cast, throw, sweep, or deposit in any manner in or upon any public way or other public place in the city or in any public waters, drain, sewer or receiving basin within the jurisdiction of the city, any kind of dirt, rubbish, garbage, trash, yard trimmings, leaves, concrete, rock, stagnant water, dead animal, solid waste article, thing or substance whatsoever, whether liquid or solid. Nor shall any person, firm or corporation cast, throw, sweep, or deposit any of the aforementioned items anywhere within the jurisdiction of the city in such manner that it may be carried or deposited in whole or in part, by the action of the wind, rain or snow, into any of the aforementioned places; provided, that this section shall not apply to the deposit of material under a permit authorized by any ordinance of the city, or to goods, wares or merchandise deposited upon any public way or other public place temporarily, in the necessary course of trade, and removed therefrom within two (2) hours after being so deposited; or to articles or things deposited in or conducted into the city sewer system through lawful drains in accordance with the ordinances of the city relating thereto. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-51. - Objects in streets, alleys, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or throw or to leave or abandon on any street, sidewalk, alley or other public way or thoroughfare in the city any glass bottle, or the fragments thereof, or any broken glass or crockery of any kind, nails, tacks or any article or object liable to injure the bare feet of children walking on the streets, sidewalks or alleys, or to injure or puncture the tires of automobiles, motorcycles, or bicycles or the rubber tires of other vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-52. - Handbills; advertising matter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place in or on any unoccupied or unattended automobile or other vehicle in the city or to otherwise distribute anywhere in the city any handbill, circular, pamphlet, poster, postcard or literature of any kind; provided, however, such distribution may be permitted directly to the occupants of business or private residences or to the occupants of occupied vehicles in such manner as not to create a litter problem. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-53. - Trucks and automobiles; littering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or his agent or employee, to operate any vehicle upon any public street, lane, alley, park or reserve in the city unless the cargo is in closed containers, or unless such vehicle is covered by a tarpaulin or otherwise constructed in such a manner as to prevent any part of the cargo contents from falling or being scattered upon any public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-54. - Areas surrounding businesses; cleanliness. 
    The proprietor or person in charge of every business and commercial establishment in the city is hereby required to keep the sidewalks abutting such business, driveways, yards and parking lots and areas clean at all times with sweepings placed in a container to prevent a violation of section 15-10-50. In the case of shopping centers, the owner or person in charge of a center shall be responsible for keeping parking lots, rear areas, drives and connecting or abutting property that is under the same or common ownership or control clean of litter, trash, garbage, and commercial or other solid wastes. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-55. - Providing containers. 
    Every owner, occupant, tenant or lessee using or occupying any commercial, institutional or industrial building or property shall provide adequate litter and trash containers. Such containers shall be required for shopping centers, supermarkets, convenience stores, eating establishments, service stations, business establishments, parking lots, multifamily residential buildings or complexes, churches, schools and colleges. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-56. - Work area; cleanliness. 
    All loading and unloading operations shall be provided with adequate containers by the owner or person in charge of such operations for the deposit of litter and trash created by packing or repacking or loading or unloading operations. The owner or person in charge of the operation outlined in this section shall require persons in their employ or under their supervision to ensure that all litter is placed in a proper container and the area is kept clean. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-57. - Construction sites; demolition sites; cleanliness. 
    The property owners and the prime contractor in charge of a construction site and/or demolition site shall furnish litter containers for litter produced by the construction and by workers. All litter from construction, demolition or related activities shall be picked up and placed in containers by the end of each workday. Provided, however, that construction material and debris which cannot be blown away by the wind or blown or carried away by any other natural force shall not be affected by this subsection until completion of the construction or demolition. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-58. - Reserved. 
Sec. 15-10-59. - Property owners, occupants; sidewalks, etc. 
    The owners or occupants of residential property shall maintain such property, including abutting sidewalks, grass strips, one-half of alleys, curbs or rights-of-way up to the edge of pavement of any public street in a clean and litter-free manner. All litter shall be placed in the container provided for the property for normally scheduled residential solid waste collection. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-60. - Removal of trapped litter. 
    The owner, occupant or lessee of all types of property shall remove all trapped litter and place same in a proper container for collection. Vacant lots, borders, parking lots, embankments, fences, 
walls and sidewalks shall be kept free of litter. Parking lots of all businesses, commercial and industrial occupancies shall be kept free of litter. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 15-10-61. - Prima facie evidence. 
(a)  Litter being thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle or other means of conveyance in violation of any section of this article, shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated this article. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, whenever any litter which is dumped, deposited, thrown, or left on public or private property in violation of this article is discovered to contain any article, including but not limited to letters, bills, publications or other writings which display the name of a person thereon in such a manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be presumed that such named person is the owner of such litter and has deposited or dumped the same in violation of this article. 
(c)  Violations of this article shall be punishable as misdemeanor; and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  By a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) but not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); 
(2)  In the sound discretion of a court in which conviction is obtained, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of-way for a distance not to exceed one (1) mile, any litter the person has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereto by anyone else prior to the date of execution of sentence; or 
(3)  In the sound discretion of the judge of a court in which conviction is obtained, the person may be sentenced to community service or directed to pick up and remove from any public area, public park, private right-of-way, or, with the prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in legal possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that the person has deposited litter, any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence. 
(Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Chapter 15-15 - PARKS AND RECREATION[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) ---

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 15-15-1-15-15-10. - Reserved. 
Article II - PUBLIC PARKS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, adopted May 9, 2017, deleted the former article II, §§ 15-15-11-15-15-18, and enacted a new article II as set out herein. The former article II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1972, §§ 17-11-17-18; Ord. No. 07-29, adopted December 11, 2007; Ord. No. 14-10, adopted August 26, 2014 and Ord. No. 16-12, adopted December 13, 2016. 

Sec. 15-15-11. - Short title; applicability. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Public Park Ordinance for the City of LaGrange" and shall be applicable to and enforced in all parks, playgrounds, recreation centers and any other area in the city owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation, including but in no way limited to the following: 
(1)  Granger Park located on the west side of North Greenwood Street; 
(2)  East Side Park located on the east side of Daniel and the west side of Niles Street; 
(3)  West Side Park located at Jones Street and Boatwright Street; 
(4)  Edgewood and Guinn Street Park located at the intersection of Edgewood Street and Guinn Street; 
(5)  Easy Street Park located on Easy Street; 
(6)  George Harris Baseball Complex located on Ragland Street; 
(7)  Shuford Softball Complex located on Calumet Drive; 
(8)  Lindsey Street Park located behind 217 Lindsey Street; 
(9)  Dunson Field located on Hogansville Road; 
(10)  Calumet Park located on the south side of Hines Street; 
(11)  Jackson Street Park located on Jackson Street; 
(12)  McCluskey Tennis Center located on Hunnicutt Place; 
(13)  Mike Daniel Recreation Center located on Lafayette Parkway; 
(14)  Union Street Park located on the corner of Union and Hamilton Street; 
(15)  William J. Griggs Recreation Center located on Glenn Robertson Drive; 
(16)  Whitesville Road Soccer Complex located on Whitesville Road; and 
(17)  Chris Joseph Track and Field and Soccer Complex located on Fort Drive. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-12. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City means the City of LaGrange. 
    Department means the Troup County Parks and Recreation Department 
    Recreation facility(ies) means any active or passive recreation area, nature area or amenity owned by the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-13. - Hours of operation; rules of operation. 
    All parks in the city shall close at 9:00 p.m. and shall be closed and remain closed until 6:00 a.m. on the succeeding morning. Only those activities authorized in writing by an authorized agent of the Troup County Recreation Commission, or the city manager or designated representative, shall be authorized beyond 9:00 p.m. No person shall be in, on, or around a park after dusk until the opening hour of 6:00 a.m., except in attendance at a scheduled activity authorized by this section. 
(1)  Notwithstanding the park operating hours established herein, the city manager or department representative may establish different opening and/or closing times for any recreation facility or area owned or maintained by the city, which times shall be posted in a conspicuous location(s) in or around the facility or area regulated. 
(2)  There shall be no use of the recreation facility or area affected after the posted closing time. No one shall be allowed on the subject property and there shall be no parking or congregating on the public streets, or parking areas around the property. 
(3)  Rules and regulations specific to each recreation facility shall be posted by the city and/or the department in a conspicuous location. Users of each recreation facility shall comply with said rules and regulations as adopted by the city council, the department or as identified in facility use agreements with specific user groups. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-14. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with or deflate or remove any building, bridges, tables, benches, railings, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereto, signs, notices, whether temporary or permanent, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances thereto, whether real or personal; 
(2)  Damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree, plant or shrubbery; 
(3)  Bring in or dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, trash, garbage, refuse or other waste. If any receptacles are provided, rubbish and other waste shall be deposited in the proper receptacles, but if receptacles are not provided, all such rubbish and other waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(4)  Aggressive horseplay and/or inappropriate behavior will not be tolerated and is cause for removal from said venue. 
(5)  Glass containers of any kind are prohibited. 
(6)  Outside cooking equipment is prohibited from being brought into public parks. 
(7)  Open flames, other than those produced by grills or similar cooking devices specifically mounted and provided as part of the design of these parks, are prohibited. 
(8)  The use of tobacco products is specifically prohibited. 
(9)  The use of motorcycles, dirt bikes, E-bikes, ATV's or motorized vehicles of any kind or similar vehicles designed for off-road use are prohibited within public parks. Motorized wheelchairs are permitted. 
(10)  No bounce houses, tents, or other structures are permitted within public parks unless specifically authorized in advance by the city manager or by a member of the Troup County Recreation Commission. 
(11)  No organized event having more than fifty (50) attendees will be permitted to take place within a public park unless a certified peace officer is hired to provide security for the duration of said event and an official permit has been issued to the user. 
(b)  Each person using a park shall: 
(1)  Comply with the applicable provisions of the state motor vehicle code in regard to the equipment required and the operation of motor vehicles, together with such regulations as are contained in the ordinances of the city; 
(2)  Obey all police officers, traffic officers and park employees, whether such employees are employees of the city or the Troup County Recreation Commission who are specifically by this article authorized to direct traffic whenever and wherever needed in the park and on the streets adjacent thereto; 
(3)  Carefully observe all traffic signs indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping or parking; and 
(4)  Not drive any vehicle on any paved recreational surface or any other park area except the paved park roads, parking areas, or such other areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary parking areas by the person in charge of such park. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-16. - Swimming. 
    No person in a park shall bathe or swim except in areas designated specifically for that purpose and then only within the hours when such activity is authorized. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-17. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    The use, possession, purchase or sale within a park in the city of alcoholic beverages or malt beverages is prohibited at any time. No person shall enter or be in a park in the city while under the influence of intoxicating liquors or malt beverages. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-18. - Pollution or disturbance of springs, ponds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to pollute or disturb any spring, branch, pond or other water within the confines of any of the recreation facilities belonging to the city by throwing sticks, stones, refuse or trash in or by washing the person or objects in such waters. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-19. - Unreasonable disturbances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to handle or discharge any firecracker, airgun, slingshot or other explosive, noisy or destructive article or substance, or throw any stone or other missile in, about or across any of the recreation facilities of the city. 
    No person at any time shall disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area or participating in any activity authorized by the city or by the Troup County Recreation Commission. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-20. - Sales from stands, carts, vehicles. 
    No person in a park shall expose or offer for sale any article or thing nor shall he station or place any stand, cart or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing except and unless such person is operating as a licensed concessionaire, licensed by the city and/or the Troup County Recreation Commission. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-21. - Animals in the parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who harbors, possesses or is in charge of a domestic, restrained or unrestrained animal (such as dogs, cats, etc.) to bring said animal onto parks, tennis courts, playgrounds and outdoor basketball courts. The only exception to this will be animal training classes that are approved by and scheduled through the department as pre-approved areas. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, graze or walk a horse or other type hoofed animal within a recreation facility without obtaining permission from the department. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person who possesses, harbors, or is in charge of any animal not to immediately remove excrement deposited by the animal while in the recreation facility. Animal excrement shall be removed from the facility and disposed from the recreation facility and disposed of in a sanitary means. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Secs. 15-15-22-15-15-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR THE THREAD 

Sec. 15-15-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    The Thread means that certain trail or path, or any portion thereof, designated by the mayor and city council for pleasure or for use as an alternative mode of transportation within the city and includes uses for walking, jogging, running and bicycling. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-51. - Motorized vehicles prohibited. 
    With the exception of motorized wheelchairs, no person shall operate a motorized vehicle in, over, through or upon The Thread or any portion thereof, except when specifically authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-52. - Horseback riding prohibited, except in designated areas. 
    No person shall ride a horse in, over, through or upon The Thread, except in areas designated for such use, and where permitted, no person shall ride a horse in a reckless manner or in any other manner which endangers other users of The Thread. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-53. - Operation of bicycles. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle on The Thread in a reckless manner or in any other manner which endangers other users of The Thread. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-54. - Animals. 
    No person shall bring any animal on The Thread, except when such animal is under the direction and control of its owner and is secured by a leash, chain, or lead of sufficient strength to prevent it from escaping from its owner. As used in this section, the term "animal" shall include any type of animal, including, but not limited to, dogs, cats, and horses. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-55. - Climbing bridges, trestles, etc. 
    No person shall climb the exterior of, repel from, or jump from any bridge, trestle, overpass, wall, cliff, embankment, building, or monument which is located on or adjacent to The Thread. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-56. - Hours of operation. 
    The Thread is open from dawn until dusk each day, and it shall be unlawful for any person to be on The Thread before sunrise or after sunset, unless otherwise and specifically authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-57. - Alcoholic beverages and drugs prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to possess any alcoholic beverages or illegal drugs on The Thread. 
Sec. 15-15-58. - Vandalism or theft of trail amenities. 
    It shall be unlawful to vandalize, mutilate, deface, or steal any portion of The Thread or any amenities thereto. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Sec. 15-15-59. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-1-6. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 5-9-17) 
Chapter 15-20 - CEMETERIES* 
Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-20-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the term "public cemeteries" shall be deemed to include, where appropriate, all cemeteries and/or mausoleums within the city limits which are owned or controlled by the city. 
(Code 1972, § 7-1; Ord. No. 96-47, § 1, 8-27-96) 
Sec. 15-20-2. - Trust fund-Created; administration; annual audit and report. 
    There is hereby created a trust fund to be known as the "City of LaGrange Cemetery Trust Fund," which shall be invested, managed and expended by the city for the maintenance and improvement of any and all mausoleums and cemeteries now or hereafter owned by the city. The administrators of the cemetery trust fund shall be the mayor or a member of the council designated by the mayor who shall serve only while a member of the council and at the pleasure of the mayor; the city manager; and the assistant city manager. The administrators of the cemetery trust fund shall collect and hold the funds paid into the cemetery trust fund, invest the same and expend the income from the trust fund for the purposes provided in this section. The administrators may encroach upon the principal of the trust fund, but only after having received the concurrence of the mayor and council to such encroachment at a regularly scheduled public meeting of the mayor and council. The cemetery trust fund shall be audited annually at the same time the affairs of the city are normally audited. The administrators of the trust fund shall maintain such records and accounts as may be necessary and reasonable by accepted accounting practices in order to reflect clearly and accurately the status of such fund. A written report of the condition of such trust fund shall be made to the mayor and council at least annually but unless otherwise requested by the mayor and council, the annual report of the audit of the trust fund shall be acceptable. 
(Code 1972, § 7-28; Ord. No. 07-12, § 4, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 5, 12-13-16) 
State Law reference- Investment in certain insured deposits, O.C.G.A. § 7-1-793; city as trustee of cemetery funds, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-4 et seq.; investments generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-3; delegation of investment authority to finance officer, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-4; budgets and audits, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-1 et seq.; investment of bond proceeds, O.C.G.A. § 36-82-7; local government investment pool, O.C.G.A. § 36-83-1 et seq.; accounting for public funds, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-1 et seq.; investment in obligations of United States government, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-18. 
Sec. 15-20-3. - Same-Payments into fund. 
    As each crypt in the mausoleum is sold an amount equal to ten (10) percent of the purchase price therefor shall be paid into and become a part of the cemetery trust fund and shall be administered as a part thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 7-29) 
Sec. 15-20-4. - Superintendent; appointment, supervision. 
    There shall be a superintendent of cemeteries, who shall be directly responsible to and under the supervision of the director of public services. 
(Code 1972, § 7-2) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 5-1 et seq. 
  []

Charter reference- Cemeteries, § 5.14. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 5-1 et seq.; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10-20; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 15-5. 
State Law reference- Dead bodies, O.C.G.A. 31-21-1 et seq.; city as trustee of cemetery funds, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-4 et seq.; Georgia Cemetery Act of 1983, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-130 et seq.; forfeiture of abandoned cemetery lots, O.C.G.A. § 44-5-211. 

Sec. 15-20-5. - Opening graves generally; permit. 
(a)  The digging of graves at all public cemeteries in the city shall be performed by either employees of the City of LaGrange under the supervision of the superintendent of cemeteries or by a person, firm or corporation licensed to dig graves in the city; provided such person, firm or corporation shall in each instance have a permit to dig a grave in the public cemetery and shall otherwise meet and comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation having a license to dig graves in a public cemetery must apply for and receive a permit from the superintendent of cemeteries of the city to dig each particular grave, must have and maintain public liability insurance in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) workers' compensation insurance in the statutory amounts, and meet such other minimum insurance requirements as the director of public services may from time to time require. Evidence of any such insurance must be continuously on file with the superintendent of cemeteries or evidence thereof presented to the superintendent of cemeteries with each request for a permit. 
(c)  Additionally, any such person, firm or corporation in order to be licensed and to receive a permit from the superintendent of cemeteries must demonstrate the ability to perform the services required hereby to the satisfaction of the superintendent who shall have the right to refuse a permit or the right to revoke a permit after issued if in his opinion such revocation is in the best interest of the city and the public. 
(d)  At the time of revocation of such permit, the superintendent of cemeteries shall provide such person, firm or corporation with notice of revocation and of their right to a hearing to appeal such revocation to the director of public services. 
(e)  Each permit shall be issued upon the express condition that the permittee agrees to indemnify, save, and hold the city, its officers, agents, or employees harmless of and from any damages to person or property or any claims therefor, and any costs or expenses relating thereto, which may arise, occur or result from any work which may be done pursuant to such permit. 
(f)  Except as provided herein, it shall be the normal practice for any employees under the supervision of the superintendent of cemeteries to open and dig graves only for paupers or only in those cases deemed to be an emergency by the director of public services. 
(Code 1972, § 7-3; Ord. No. 88-110A, § 1, 9-13-88; Ord. No. 96-47, § 2, 8-27-96) 
Cross reference- Burial permits, § 15-20-23. 
Sec. 15-20-6. - Records; enforcing ordinances and regulations; reports. 
    The superintendent shall keep a record of the owners of lots in the public cemeteries and shall not allow any burial on a lot without the authority of the owner. It shall be his duty to see that all regulations and ordinances of the city in reference to such cemeteries are enforced, and to report all violations of same. He shall maintain a system of records sufficient to show the owner of each lot and the name of each person interred in a lot, and such other information as may from time to time be required. 
(Code 1972, § 7-5) 
Sec. 15-20-7. - Objectionable trees and shrubs. 
    If the roots or branches of any trees or shrubs on any lot in a public cemetery shall become detrimental to adjacent lots or drives or unsightly or interfere with the orderly operation of the cemetery, the superintendent shall have the right to enter the lot and remove such trees and shrubs or such parts thereof as he shall determine to be detrimental, unsightly or which interfere with the proper use and maintenance of a public cemetery. 
(Code 1972, § 7-4) 
Sec. 15-20-8. - Wilted flowers, etc. 
    When flowers in public cemeteries become faded, dead or badly wilted, they shall be removed. Artificial flowers, floral arrangements and the like shall be removed without permission when in the opinion of the superintendent they have become faded, soiled, misplaced, scattered, objectionable or unsightly. 
(Code 1972, § 7-6) 
Secs. 15-20-9-15-20-20. - Reserved. 
Article II - INTERMENT 

Sec. 15-20-21. - Lot prices. 
    The mayor and the assistant city manager, either individually or collectively are authorized to execute conveyances of cemetery lots and spaces in public cemeteries in accordance with the schedule of prices in this article, subject to the following covenants and restrictions applicable to the respective cemeteries, which shall be included in any deed of conveyance of such cemetery lots and spaces:
