Sec. 20-10-4. - Same-Subject to change. 
    The rates fixed in section 20-10-3 are based upon rates presently authorized by the Federal Power Commission. In the event the Federal Power Commission shall authorize an increase or decrease in the cost of natural gas to the city, the mayor and council at any regular or special meeting shall have authority by resolution to increase or decrease the cost of gas to customers of the city by an amount substantially equal to the increased or decreased cost to the city. 
(Code 1972, § 24-33) 
Sec. 20-10-5. - Free service. 
    No free service shall at any time be furnished from the gas system. All services shall be furnished in accordance with rates in effect, including services furnished to any county, municipal corporation or other public body. 
(Code 1972, § 24-34) 
Sec. 20-10-6. - Gas services connection charges. 
(a)  The charge for installing natural gas mains, services, and meters within the city's electric territory shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) per service connection. There shall be no charge for installing gas service to residential customers located outside of the city's electric territory, unless gas service is required under the terms of a written development agreement with the city, in which case the three hundred dollars ($300.00) per service connection shall apply. Extension of natural gas service into a new area shall be solely within the discretion of the city based upon the overall economic benefit of the addition. 
(b)  The charge for installing gas services and setting gas meters for all classes of customers, other than residential customers, shall be an amount equal to the materials and labor costs to the city, exclusive of boring. No connection charge shall be applied if the annual revenue from the sale of gas to the customer is projected to exceed the above calculated cost by a factor of two (2). 
(c)  From time to time, the mayor and council may establish and offer incentive programs, including but not limited to rebates, for customers choosing natural gas appliances. 
(Ord. No. 90-8, § 1, 2-27-90; Ord. No. 93-39, § 1, 8-10-93; 04-24, § 1, 7-27-04; Ord. No. 08-20, § 2, 7-8-08) 
Chapter 20-15 - WATER AND SEWERS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 5-1 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10-10; health, Ch. 10-25; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 15-5; solid waste, Ch. 15-10; scattering refuse, § 15-10-3; utilities discount, Ch. 20-20; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 25-5; subdivisions, Ch. 25-20; flood damage prevention, Ch. 25-25; erosion control, Ch. 25-30; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 30-1 et seq. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-15-1. - Bathroom and kitchen facilities; connection to water and sewer. 
(a)  Each living quarter or living unit existing on November 9, 1976, shall have installed as a minimum requirement one (1) commode and one (1) sink. Each existing kitchen shall have installed therein one (1) sink with running water attached thereto, provided the city maintains a water main within two hundred (200) feet of such living quarters. 
(b)  Every dwelling unit constructed in the city after November 9, 1976, shall contain not less than a kitchen sink, lavatory, tub or shower and a water closet, with an adequate amount of both cold water and hot water, all in good working condition and properly connected to an approved water and sewer system. 
(c)  The facilities required by subsections (a) and (b) shall be located within the dwelling unit and shall be accessible to the occupants therein. 
(Code 1972, § 24-46) 
Sec. 20-15-2. - Water service permit; application. 
    All applications for the use of water shall be made in writing on forms furnished by the city. Forms shall be specifically and properly filled in and signed personally by the owner of the premises to be served. An application shall set forth a true description of the property and shall fully set forth the kind of building and the number and character of plumbing fixtures for which water service is desired. It shall bear the name and address of the owner. 
(Code 1972, § 24-47) 
Sec. 20-15-3. - Meters. 
(a)  Generally. Water meters approved by the city shall be attached to all premises where city water is used, unless the city shall otherwise direct. All such meters shall be the property of the city and shall be installed according to the requirements of this chapter, or as provided by the rules of the city. After the installation of the first meter, the city shall keep it in repair and replace it with a new one when necessary, except where it has been damaged by hot water from within the premises or by some malicious act. In such case, the cost of repairs on account of such hot water or malicious act shall be charged to the owner or tenant. Upon failure of any owner or tenant served by a meter so damaged to pay, within thirty (30) days from the date of the bill for the cost of such repairs, the water shall be shut off and service discontinued until such bill has been paid. 
(b)  Separate, when required. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, a separate water meter shall be required for each living unit, living quarters or place of business to which water is supplied by the city; except that a duplex, apartment complex, trailer park or other combination of living units may use one (1) master water meter for the purpose of measuring the water used by all of the individual living units combined, provided the property owner shall assume the responsibility of payment for all water and wastewater charges. For any customer who so uses a master water meter, the monthly bill for said service shall be calculated by the city as follows: 
(1)  The metered consumption shall be divided by the total number of living units to determine average consumption; 
(2)  Average charges shall be calculated using the average consumption and appropriate rate schedule; and 
(3)  Total charges shall be calculated by multiplying the average charges by the total number of living units. The total number of living units is defined as all of the living units and service connections downstream of the master meter regardless of actual occupancy. 
(c)  Receiving water through another's meter. Whenever water service has been shut off for any reason, and it is found that the occupants are using water through another meter or service, the city may transfer charges against them to the meter through which it is found the property is being served; and if such bill or charge is not paid, the city shall shut off and discontinue water from all meters serving such property until such bill is paid in full. 
(d)  Obstructing or concealing. No person shall obstruct, cover up or conceal any water meter so that the city employees cannot find or reach such meter. 
(Code 1972, §§ 24-48-24-51; Ord. No. 98-7, § 1, 3-10-98) 
Sec. 20-15-4. - Connection charges. 
    The charges for establishing water and sewer connections shall be as set forth in this section. The applicable connection price shall be required for each unit or individual occupancy served, as follows: 
(1)  Water connection price: 
a.  For a three-quarter-inch water meter installed in a location in which there is an existing water tap and meter box meeting the city's current specifications, the charge shall be nine hundred fifty dollars ($950.00). 
b.  For a three-quarter-inch meter and box installed in a location in which an existing tap to the same service address can be split and an additional tap is not required, the charge shall be one thousand one hundred dollars ($1,100.00). 
c.  For a three-quarter-inch water meter, box and tap, the charge shall be one thousand two hundred thirty-five dollars ($1,235.00). 
d.  For a one-inch water meter, box and tap, the charge shall be one thousand four hundred dollars ($1,400.00). 
e.  For all water meter installations exceeding one (1) inch in size, or which require work within state rights-of-way, or for such installations which are deemed by the city to be more costly or difficult than a normal installation, the charge shall be eight hundred dollars ($800.00) plus an amount equal to the materials, labor and overhead costs of the city. 
f.  For all water meters exceeding one (1) inch in size which are installed to serve a nonprofit organization qualified under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended, and upon request, the charge shall be the actual and out-of-pocket costs of the city. This rate is only available to 501(c)(3) organizations whose utility accounts are in good standing at the time of the water tap request. 
(2)  Sewer tap charge: 
a.  The connection charge for new residential and commercial sewer service shall be one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). 
b.  For city installation of a new residential or commercial sewer tap, the cost shall be equal to the materials, labor and overhead costs of the city in addition to the connection charge in subparagraph a. 
(3)  Maintenance of sewer taps: The city is obligated to maintain sewer taps from the street right-of-way line to the sewer main located in the street. Sewer taps from the street right-of-way line to the building on private property will be the maintenance responsibility of the property owner. 
(4)  Sewer tap prices: The city may, from time to time, modify the price of sewer tap installation. The customer shall pay the installation price as adopted by the mayor and council and in force as of the date installation of the sewer tap begins. For any customer who has either purchased or placed a deposit with the city for a sewer tap under a previously published price schedule, such customer may elect to be refunded that amount either paid or deposited, in lieu of the sewer tap installation, or may apply said funds toward the appropriate existing price as established by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 24-52; Ord. No. 86-22, § 1, 6-26-86; Ord. No. 87-104, § 1, 10-13-87; Ord. No. 87-106, § 1, 12-8-87; Ord. No. 88-99, § 1, 6-30-88; Ord. No. 89-47, § 1, 12-12-89; Ord. No. 93-26, § 1, 6-22-93; Ord. No. 93-45, § 1, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 95-15, § 1, 5-9-95; Ord. No. 96-1, § 1, 1-23-96; Ord. No. 97-31, §§ 1, 2, 8-26-97; Ord. No. 02-35, § 1, 11-26-02; Ord. No. 04-26, § 1, 7-27-04; Ord. No. 04-28, § 1, 9-14-04; Ord. No. 06-11, § 1, 6-22-06; Ord. No. 06-18, § 1, 8-8-06; Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 3-13-07) 
Sec. 20-15-5. - Turning water on; person authorized; testing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than an employee of the city to turn water into any service pipe, except for the purpose of testing work. If such testing is done, the water must be immediately turned off after the work is finished, and in no case must the water remain on for more than three (3) hours without a permit from the city. 
(Code 1972, § 24-53) 
Sec. 20-15-6. - Water service outside city limits. 
    For all new construction outside of the corporate limits of the city, and upon natural gas service to such structure being available, said availability being within the sole discretion of the city, water service as set forth in this chapter shall be available only to those customers who install at least one (1) natural gas furnace, one (1) natural gas water heater, and at least one (1) additional natural gas outlet sufficient for potential future use for a clothes dryer, range, grill, pool heater or outdoor lighting fixture. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 2, 9-14-04) 
Sec. 20-15-7. - Fire protection service-Subject to city regulations. 
(a)  Water pipes for fire protection must be fitted with such fixtures only as are needed for fire protection. A valve must be placed just inside the premises to control the entire supply. The city shall have power to require all such fire services to be supplied with a meter to be put in at any time, and to make changes from time to time, either as to meters or as to any other part of such appliances. 
(b)  All connections of fire protection services from city mains to the property line shall be made by authorized employees of the city, and all piping, valves, hydrants and connections to such fire services shall be inspected and approved by the city before the water is turned into such service. 
(Code 1972, § 24-60) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10-10. 
Sec. 20-15-8. - Same-Rates. 
(a)  Inside city. Fire protection service water rates are applicable to all customers having water facilities which are designed and used exclusively for the purpose of fire protection and suppression. The following annual charge is for availability of water for fire protection and suppression purposes and is based upon the facilities available for such purpose: 
(1)  Each sprinkler head-$0.12 
(2)  Each hose reel-$20.00 
(3)  Each fire hydrant-$70.00 
(4)  Minimum total annual charge-$100.00 
The annual fire protection service charge shall be prorated and billed monthly on the city monthly utility bill and shall be due and payable as provided in section 20-1-7. 
(b)  Outside city. For each fire hydrant located outside the corporate limits of the city which is activated and for which water pressure thereon is maintained, there shall be an annual charge to the county of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each hydrant, which shall be paid in twelve (12) equal monthly installments. The use of such hydrants shall be limited to use by the authorized members or representatives of the county fire department for fire protection purposes. Effective July 1, 1988, the annual charge to the county of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each hydrant shall be reduced to twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year for each hydrant. 
(c)  Outside city, installation. Effective July 1, 1988, the cost of constructing and installing fire hydrants on public roads outside the city limits in conjunction with waterlines being installed by the City of LaGrange shall be reimbursed by the board of commissioners of Troup County to the city when installation of a hydrant is completed. Subdivision developers installing water facilities on public roads which will become a part of the city water system will remain responsible for the cost of construction and installation of fire hydrants on such public roads in accordance with city specifications. 
(Code 1972, § 24-61; Ord. No. 87-106, §§ 2, 3, 12-8-87; Ord. No. 88-99, § 2, 6-30-88) 
Sec. 20-15-9. - Restriction on outdoor watering of landscapes; penalties. 
(a)  Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants in the corporate limits of the city may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
(1)  Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. section 1-3-3; 
(2)  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or storm water in compliance with applicable ordinances and state guidelines; 
(3)  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. section 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; 
(4)  Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed waste water; 
(5)  Watering personal food gardens; 
(6)  Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of thirty (30) days immediately following the date of installation; 
(7)  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
(8)  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
(9)  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(10)  Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(11)  Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(12)  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or 
(13)  Hydroseeding. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any water customer of the city to use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained within this ordinance. Any persons who shall violate the provisions of this section shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-1-6 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-25, § 1, 12-14-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-25, § 1, adopted December 14, 2010, repealed § 20-15-9, which pertained to water conservation and derived from the Code of 1972, § 24-62 and Ord. No. 87-78, adopted May 26, 1987.

Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-10, adopted June 22, 2006, deleted §§ 20-15-10-20-15-13, and enacted new provisions to be designated as §§ 20-15-10-20-15-12 to read as herein set out. Former §§ 20-15-10-20-15-13 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for history. 
Sec. 20-15-11. - Wastewater system user charges. 
(a)  The wastewater user charge applicable to all users connected to the city's wastewater system, inside or outside the city as appropriate, shall be a flow charge for each one thousand (1,000) gallons of metered water used as follows: 
Inside city: Three dollars seventy-five cents ($3.75). 
Outside city: Five dollars sixty-three cents ($5.63). 
(b)  All persons discharging industrial waste, hauled wastewater, pumpage or septic tank waste into the public sewers shall be charged and assessed a surcharge, in addition to any sewer service charges, if these wastes have a concentration greater than the following "normal" concentrations: 
(1)  Five-day Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD5) of 250 mg/l; or 
(2)  Total suspended solids (TSS) of 200 mg/l; or 
(3)  Total Kjehldahl Nitrogen (TKN) of 20 mg/l; or 
(4)  Total Phosphorus (TP) of 6 mg/l; or 
(5)  Any other pollutants in excess of the "normal" level of such pollutants. 
    The amount of such surcharge shall reflect the cost incurred by the City of LaGrange in handling the excess pollutants. This surcharge shall include a proportionate share of the following: fixed charges for maintenance, operation and replacement of the sewerage system to include sewers, plants, pumping stations and other necessary systems including depreciation and other incidental expenses. 
    The rates of surcharges shall be published and shall be reviewed at least annually by the City of LaGrange in order that the above factors may correctly represent current treatment costs, and may be modified at any time. 
(c)  Upon request by large commercial or industrial customers that demonstrate to the city an anticipated process water loss of at least fifteen (15) percent (water that will not return to the wastewater system), the charge per one thousand (1,000) gallons of metered or estimated wastewater shall be the rate listed above divided by 0.9. The city shall decide whether a metering system or estimation method will be utilized, what type of metering will be required, the length of any testing period, and the frequency of meter calibration. In the event the metering or estimation becomes unreliable in the sole opinion of the city, the metered water volumes shall be used for wastewater billing until a mutually agreeable solution is reached. 
(d)  Wastewater user charges shall be assessed at the "outside city" rates for any sewer facilities available within the Long Cane Creek, Dixie Creek, Jackson Creek and Shoal Creek Watershed Basins Special District, the boundaries of which are the boundaries of the Long Cane Creek Watershed Basin, the Dixie Creek Watershed Basin, the Jackson Creek Watershed Basin and the Shoal Creek Watershed Basin, generally. The geographic parameters of such special districts are described more fully within the exhibits attached to Ordinance Number 09-16 as Exhibits "A" and "B," copies of which are available and on file with the assistant city manager. 
(Ord. No. 06-10, § 1, 6-22-06; Ord. No. 08-31, § 2, 12-9-08; Ord. No. 09-16, § 4, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 10-02, § 1, 2-9-10; Ord. No. 16-12, § 6, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 20-15-12. - Water and sewer adjustment schedule. 
    All bills for water and wastewater services shall be subject to the water and sewer adjustment schedule, and as such shall be respectively increased or decreased by the amount necessary to recover the city's budgeted revenue requirements for water and sewer service as determined by the city, and to insure that coverage ratios for any outstanding bonded indebtedness are maintained. 
(Ord. No. 08-11, § 2, 5-13-08) 
Sec. 20-15-13. - Levelized billing; senior assistance; round up program. 
(a)  Levelized billing option: Residential customers with a good credit history may be offered the option of levelized billing. Details of this billing option are available from the city's customer service division. 
(b)  Senior citizen-Low income assistance: Qualifying customers certified by the city will be eligible for a discount on their monthly bill. 
(c)  Round-up: Customers that do not notify the city of their desire to opt-out will have the total of their utility charges rounded up to the next whole dollar. The proceeds of this round-up will be used to assist low income customers pay their utility bills or as otherwise directed by the LaGrange City Council. 
(Ord. No. 06-10, § 1, 6-22-06; Ord. No. 08-11, § 1, 5-13-08) 
Sec. 20-15-14. - Default of one on two-customer pipe. 
    When two (2) or more persons are supplied by the same service pipe, the failure of either to pay the water bill when due shall authorize the city to turn the water off from such pipe until all the charges for, and terms and conditions of, water service are paid and complied with. 
(Code 1972, § 24-65) 
Sec. 20-15-15. - Water leaks; reduction of bills. 
    In the event a customer shall provide sufficient proof to a customer service representative of the city that a leak has occurred in the plumbing system of such customer, which resulted in a higher utility bill, a reduction in water and sewer services shall be allowed as follows: 
(1)  The customer shall be required to pay a charge for normal water and sewer consumption equal to the average for the prior twelve (12) months at normal rates, excluding abnormal consumption. Water volumes above the calculated normal consumption shall be billed at the average cost to produce and deliver the water as determined by the engineering division. Charges for sewer volumes above the calculated normal consumption shall be waived since it is assumed that the water from the leak did not enter the sewer system. 
(2)  A customer shall receive adjustments for only two (2) consecutive months for the same leak and will have the responsibility of promptly repairing the leak to avoid additional high utility bills caused by the same leak. If extraordinary circumstances are present, the customer service manager may approve additional adjustments to a customer account. 
(Code 1972, § 24-68; Ord. No. 90-63, § 1, 11-27-90; Ord. No. 94-46, § 1, 10-11-94) 
Sec. 20-15-16. - Preventing access or obstructing operation of valves prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall remove or cover a water valve box, a backflow preventer or other city water system device with dirt or other materials so that the cover or top thereof is not visible or direct access to the valve or backflow preventer is not available to city personnel. 
(b)  No person shall operate, vary, or change the adjustment of any water system valve, pressure regulating device, backflow preventer, or other water system control device without first obtaining written approval from the director of the city utility department or his designee. 
(c)  No person shall damage, destroy, deface, impair the function of or otherwise vandalize any portion of the city water collection or distribution system. 
(Ord. No. 90-15, § 1, 4-10-90) 
Sec. 20-15-17. - Fire hydrant use and water tank inspection. 
(a)  No person shall use or obtain water from a city fire hydrant without first receiving a permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Any person desiring to use or obtain water from a city fire hydrant must apply to the water superintendent for a permit on forms provided for that purpose. A water use permit will be issued upon receipt of an appropriate permit application together with an inspection report for all trucks, tanks or containers to be used. 
(c)  The water superintendent will designate the fire hydrant or hydrants to be used for the purposes of this section. 
(d)  Any truck, tank or container to be filled with water obtained from the city public water supply, including but not limited to a city fire hydrant, or to any other connection on private property, must first be inspected and approved by the water superintendent to insure that such truck, tank or container has thereon the permanent installation of an approved air gap, backflow preventor or other approved method of filling the tank. A certificate of inspection will be issued by the water superintendent for those trucks, tanks and containers meeting the minimum requirements. 
(e)  The fee for installation of a fire hydrant meter and backflow device shall be $250.00. A refundable deposit in the amount of $1,000.00 shall also be paid prior to the installation of the meter and backflow device. Said deposit shall be returned to the applicant upon removal of the meter and backflow device should there be no damages to same or other city property attributable to the applicant. 
(f)  Code section 20-15-19 notwithstanding, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provisions of this ordinance by using water from a fire hydrant without a permit and properly installed meter and backflow device shall, upon conviction, be fined $1,000.00 and shall additionally pay the estimated cost of the unauthorized water use to the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-15, § 1, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 07-16, § 1, 5-8-07) 
Note- See editor's note following § 20-15-13. 
Sec. 20-15-18. - Location. 
    All backflow preventers shall be installed in an area or at a location that provides a safe and reasonably convenient working environment for testing and maintenance. The area shall be readily accessible, dry, free from dirt, extreme cold, heat, or existing hazards. 
(Ord. No. 90-15, § 1, 4-10-90) 
Note- See editor's note following § 20-15-13. 
Sec. 20-15-19. - Penalty for violation of sections 20-15-16 through 20-15-18. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provisions of sections 20-15-16 through 20-15-18 shall upon conviction be punished as provided by section 1-1-6 of the Code of the city; provided, however, that each day the violation shall continue shall constitute a separate violation under the terms of this section. In addition to the penalty provided in section 1-1-6 of this Code, the director of utilities may revoke any permits for fire hydrant water use and/or approvals of trucks, tanks, or other containers issued pursuant to the provisions of sections 20-15-16 through 20-15-18. 
(Ord. No. 90-15, § 2, 4-10-90) 
Note- See editor's note following § 20-15-13. 
Sec. 20-15-20. - Fire protection water lines; requirements of public dedication and private ownership. 
(a)  An owner of any currently existing or newly constructed multifamily apartment complex located within the city shall be required to: 
(1)  Dedicate the fire protection water lines on the premises to the city and grant to the city, in writing, a twenty-foot easement (ten (10) feet on either side of the water line) for service and maintenance of said water line. If so dedicated, the owner shall pay to the city twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hydrant per month for each hydrant located on the water line on the premises. Should the owner choose the option outlined in subsection (1) herein, the city shall retain and have the right, in its discretion, to tap such water lines for service to any other entity; or 
(2)  Retain ownership of the fire protection water line and hydrants on the premises, and upon such election grant the city written authorization to make use of said private water line for fire suppression services; install any required backflow prevention device(s); and provide written certification of inspection, maintenance and operating capabilities of the line, backflow prevention device(s) and hydrant annually to the appropriate department(s) of the city. In the event an owner retains ownership of the waterline as described herein, the use of said waterline shall be restricted to use solely by the city for fire protection purposes exclusively unless and until said line is metered by the city. 
(b)  On all new construction, fire protection water lines shall be required to meet all appropriate city specifications and shall be inspected upon installation by the appropriate city department. Regardless of the election made by an owner under this section, said owner shall be responsible for initial installation of all fire and water lines on the premises. Moreover, on all new construction, an owner choosing to dedicate fire protection water lines under subsection (a)(1) above shall comply with the plumbing and construction codes binding upon the city. In the alternative, for new construction for which the owner intends to retain ownership of the fire protection water line and hydrants as set forth in subsection (a)(2) above, the installation of said lines shall conform in all respects to the plumbing and construction codes as are applicable to private individuals under local and state law. 
(Ord. No. 99-31, § 1, 9-25-99) 
Sec. 20-15-21. - Interference with system; unauthorized connections and water use. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall interfere with or in any way meddle with any of the wells, reservoirs, basins, water mains, pipes, plugs, meters or connections of the waterworks; nor make any connection therewith by tapping any of said mains or pipes, or otherwise, without the permission of the city; nor permit any such connections or tapping to be made on premises in his control as owner or tenant; nor use water from such unauthorized connections; nor supply water through such unauthorized connections without a permit from the city for such use of water. No cross connections are allowed. 
(b)  Furnishing water to another; turning off or on without permission. It shall be unlawful for any owner or tenant to supply water to any other property, person or user, from the pipes or meters serving water from the system or to use water from any such water pipe, meter, hydrant or other device or fixture through which water may be drawn or used, without a permit from the city. No person shall turn water off or on from any city water service, unless such person has the permission of the city. 
(c)  Changes in pipes or fixtures. It shall be unlawful for any person to make any changes in water pipes or fixtures, either by extending such pipes to other premises, or within the premises to which water is supplied, which will in any way effect a change in the water rates, without first securing a permit from the city, specifying the nature of the change to be made, such as the number of fixtures, connections and the like. As soon as the work has been executed, such person shall make an immediate report to the city of all such work done by him. 
(d)  Hydrant keys; otherwise taking water. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any key to any fire hydrant except such key as may be furnished to him by the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to take or use water from any fireplug, hydrant, valve, pipe, other device or fixture, opening or connection of the system, or to open any plug, hydrant, valve, pipe or other fixture for the purpose of taking or using water, unless such person shall have permission from the city, or is an employee of the city and is acting on the discharge of his duty as such. No person to whom a permit is issued for the use of water for any purpose whatever, including construction purposes, irrigating, testing, flushing and the like, shall use or consent to the use of water not authorized by permit from the city. The authorized members or representatives of the county fire department shall be authorized to open and close fire hydrants in conjunction with fighting fires or for fire protection purposes. 
(e)  Permit to use hydrant required. No person other than the authorized representatives of the city or the authorized members or representatives of the county fire department as specified in subsection (d) shall be authorized to open and close fire hydrants except as authorized by a special permit from the city. In cases where a permit is granted, charges shall be made as prescribed by the city. 
(f)  Wasting water. If it is found that there is a waste of water in or about any premises to which water is supplied from the system, either by willful waste or by means of a leak in any water pipe or fixture located in or upon such premises, the city may cause the water to be cut off from such premises upon twenty-four-hours' notice to the occupant, unless such waste shall be immediately stopped. Where the water supply is cut off as provided in this subsection, the water shall not be turned on until the cause of the waste is remedied and all water bills and the bill for the cost of cutting off and again turning on the water shall have been paid. 
(Code 1972, §§ 24-54-24-59; Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 9-14-04) 
Secs. 20-15-22-20-15-25. - Reserved. 
Article II - SEWER USE[5] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 93-53, adopted Oct. 26, 1993, repealed art. II, §§ 20-15-26-20-15-50, and added new §§ 20-15-26-20-15-88. Section 4 renumbered former § 20-15-36 as § 20-15-90. Section 5 renumbered the sections of arts. III-V as necessary. See the editor's notes to each of those articles. Article II was formerly derived from Code 1972, §§ 24-71-24-74.6 and Ord. Nos. 92-27 and 93-8. 

Sec. 20-15-26. - Purpose and policy. 
    This article sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly owned treatment works for the city and enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 United States Code, § 1251 et seq.) and the General Pretreatment Regulations (40 CFR Part 403). The objectives of this article are: 
(a)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will interfere with its operation; 
(b)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will pass through the POTW inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or otherwise be incompatible with the publicly owned treatment works; 
(c)  To protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel who may be affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and the general public; 
(d)  To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and sludge from the publicly owned treatment works; 
(e)  To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of operation, maintenance and improvements of publicly owned treatment works; and 
(f)  To enable the city to comply with its National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements, and any other federal or state laws to which the publicly owned treatment works is subject. 
    This article shall apply to all users of the publicly owned treatment works and provides for and authorizes the issuance of wastewater discharge permits; provides for monitoring, compliance, enforcement activities; establishes administrative review procedures; requires user reporting; and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established by this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-27. - Administration. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, the superintendent shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this article. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the superintendent may be delegated by the superintendent to other city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93)

Sec. 20-15-29. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically provided otherwise, the following terms and phrases shall have the meanings hereinafter designated: 
(a)  Act or the Act: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. § 1251 et seq. 
(b)  Approval authority: The State of Georgia, Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division. 
(c)  Authorized representative of user: 
(1)  If the user is a corporation: 
a.  The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice-president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation; or 
b.  The manager of one (1) or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities employing more than two hundred fifty (250) persons or having gross annual sales or expenditures exceeding twenty-five million dollars ($25,000,000.00) (in second-quarter 1980 dollars), if authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures. 
(2)  If the user is a partnership or sole proprietor: a general partner or proprietor, respectively. 
(3)  If the user is a federal, state, or local governmental facility: a director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the government facility, or their designee. 
(4)  The individuals described in paragraphs (1) through (3), above, may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, and the written authorization is submitted to the city. 
(d)  Biochemical Oxygen Demand or BOD: The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidations of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures for five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, usually expressed as a concentration (e.g., mg/l). 
(e)  Building sewer: A sewer line conveying wastewater from the premises of an user to the POTW. 
(f)  Categorical Pretreatment Standard or Categorical Standard: Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by EPA in accordance with sections 307(b) and (c) of the Act (33 U.S.C. § 1317) which apply to a specific category of users and which appear in 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N, parts 405-471. 
(g)  Categories of Users: 
(1)  Residential user (class I); 
(2)  Commercial user (class II); and 
(3)  Industrial user (class III); 
each of which is connected to the POTW. 
(h)  City: The City of LaGrange, Georgia, or the Mayor and Council of the City of LaGrange, Georgia. 
(i)  Commercial User (Class II): Any property occupied by a nonresidential establishment but which is not a significant user and which is not included in the definition of an industrial user (class III). 
(j)  Control Authority: The "superintendent," as defined in this section, or his duly authorized representative. 
(k)  Cooling Water: The water discharge from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or water to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
(l)  Direct Discharge: The discharge or introduction of wastewater directly into the waters of the state. 
(m)  Environmental Protection Agency or EPA: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency or, where appropriate, the regional water management division director, or other duly authorized official of that agency. 
(n)  Existing Source: Any source of discharge, the construction or operation of which commenced prior to the publication by the EPA of proposed categorical pretreatment standards, which will be applicable to such source if the standard is thereafter promulgated in accordance with section 307 of the Act. 
(o)  Food Service Establishments: Any restaurant, eatery, food caterer, cafeteria, hospital, school, institution, motel, hotel, prison, business or similar place other than dwelling units, where food is prepared for sale, delivery, or consumption. 
(p)  Grab Sample: A sample which is taken from a waste stream without regard to the flow in the waste stream and over a period of time not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes. 
(q)  Grease Trap: A device primarily used in the food service industry for removal of oils, greases and food solids from a process waste stream. 
(r)  Indirect Discharge or Discharge: The introduction of pollutants into the POTW from any nondomestic source regulated under section 307(b), (c), or (d) of the Act. 
(s)  Industrial User (Class III): Any nonresidential user identified in division A, B, C, D, E or I of the SICM. Industrial user (Class III) shall also include any significant user. 
(t)  Instantaneous Maximum Allowable Discharge Limit: The maximum concentration of a pollutant allowed to be discharged at any time, determined from the analysis of any discrete or composited sample collected, independent of the industrial flow rate and the duration of the sampling event. 
(u)  Interference: A discharge, which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operations or its sludge processes, use or disposal, and therefor, is a cause of a violation of the city's NPDES permit or of the prevention of sewerage sludge use or disposal in compliance with the following statutory/regulatory provisions or permits issued thereunder, or any more stringent state or local regulations: section 405 of the Act; the Solid Waste Disposal Act; Recovery Act (RCRA); and state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to subtitle D of the Solid Waste Disposal Act; the Clean Air Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act. 
(v)  Medical Waste: Isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood products, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, contaminated bedding, surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes, and dialysis wastes. 
(w)  National Categorical Pretreatment Standard or Pretreatment Standards: Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits applicable to a specific category of industrial users, promulgated by the EPA in accordance with sections 307(b) and (c) of the Act. 
(x)  National Pollution Discharge Elimination System Permit: A permit issued pursuant to section 402 of the Act. 
(y)  New Source: 
(1)  Any building, structure, facility,or installation from which there is (or may be) a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
a.  The building, structure, facility, or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; or 
b.  The building, structure, facility, or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
c.  The production or wastewater-generating processes of the building, structure, facility, or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source, should be considered. 
(2)  Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility, or installation meeting the criteria of subsection (1)b. or c. above but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existing process or production equipment. 
(3)  Construction of a new source as defined under this paragraph has commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun, or caused to begin, as part of a continuous on-site construction program 
(i)  Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or equipment; or 
(ii)  Significant site preparation work, including clearing, excavation, or removal of existing buildings, structures, or facilities which is necessary for the placement, assembly, or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
b.  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contacts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contacts for feasibility, engineering, and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this paragraph. 
(z)  Noncontact Cooling Water: Water used for cooling which does not come into direct contact with any raw material, intermediate product, waste product, or finished product. 
(aa)  Pass-Through: A discharge which exits the POTW into waters of the United States in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or dischargers from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation. 
(bb)  Person: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity, or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents, or assigns. This definition includes all federal, state, or local governmental entities. 
(cc)  pH: A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a solution, expressed in standard units. 
(dd)  Pollutant: Dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, filter backwash, sewage, garbage, sewerage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, municipal, agricultural and industrial wastes, and certain characteristics of wastewater (e.g., pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, BOD, COD, toxicity, or odor). 
(ee)  Pollution: The man-made or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological or radiological integrity of water. 
(ff)  POTW Treatment Plant: That portion of the POTW designed to provide treatment to wastewater. 
(gg)  Pretreatment: The reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to, or in lieu of, introducing such pollutants into the POTW. This reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical, or biological processes; by process changes; or by other means, except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by an applicable pretreatment standard. 
(hh)  Pretreatment Requirements: Any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment imposed on an user, other than a pretreatment standard. 
(ii)  Pretreatment Standards or Standards: Prohibited discharge standards, categorical pretreatment standards, and local limits. 
(jj)  Prohibited Discharge Standards or Prohibited Discharges: Absolute prohibitions against the discharge of certain substances; these prohibitions appear in section 20-15-31. 
(kk)  Publicly Owned Treatment Works or POTW. A "treatment works," as defined by section 212 of the Act (33 U.S.C. § 1292) which is owned by the city. This definition includes any devices or systems used in the collection, storage, treatment, recycling, and reclamation of sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature and any conveyances which convey wastewater to a treatment plant. 
(ll)  Pumpage: The oils, greases, liquids and solids removed from a container by pumping. 
(mm)  Residential User (Class I): Premises used for human residency or habitation. 
(nn)  Sanitary Wastewater: Wastewater discharged into the POTW from the sanitary conveniences of dwellings, office buildings, industrial plants or institutions. 
(oo)  Septic Tank Waste: Any sewage from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, and septic tanks. 
(pp)  Sewage: Human excrement and gray water (household showers, dishwashing operations, etc). 
(qq)  Significant Industrial User: 
(1)  A user subject to categorical pretreatment standards; or 
(2)  A user that: 
a.  Discharges an average of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gpd or more of process wastewater to the POTW (excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling, and boiler blowdown wastewater); 
b.  Contributes a process wastestream which makes up five (5) percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant; or 
c.  Is designated as such by the city on the basis that it has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(3)  Upon a finding that an user meeting the criteria in subsection (2) has no reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, the city may at any time, on its own initiative or in response to a petition received from an user, and in accordance with procedures in 40 CFR 403.8(f)(6), determine that such user should not be considered a significant industrial user. 
(rr)  Slug Load or Slug: Any discharge at a flow rate or concentration which could cause a violation of the prohibited discharge standards in section 20-15-31. 
(ss)  Stormwater: Any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation and resulting from such precipitation, including snowmelt. 
(tt)  Superintendent: The person designated by the city to supervise the operation of the POTW and who is charged with certain duties and responsibilities by this article, or his duly authorized representative. 
(uu)  Suspended Solids. The total suspended matter that floats on the surface of, or is suspended in, water, wastewater or other liquids and which is removable by laboratory filtering. 
(vv)  Toxic Pollutant: Any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the EPA under the provisions of the Act. 
(ww)  User: Any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into city's POTW. 
(ww.5)  Waste receptor: A device primarily used in the food service industry to prevent passage of solids (1/2 inch or larger) from entering into the POTW. 
(xx)  Wastewater: The liquid and water-carried industrial or domestic wastes from dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities and institutions, together with an groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed into or permitted to enter the POTW. 
(yy)  Wastewater Contribution Permit or Wastewater Discharge Permit: The permit issued pursuant to section 20-15-46. 
(zz)  Waters of the State: All streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, reservoirs, aquifers, irrigation systems, drainage systems and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground, natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through or border upon the state or any portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93; Ord. No. 00-22, § 1, 7-11-00) 
Sec. 20-15-30. - General requirements. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or deposit or permit the disposal of any wastewater, sewage, refuse, human or animal excrement or any objectional waste on private or public land except in a manner prescribed in this article. 
(b)  All wastewater shall be discharged to the public sewer system or in a private disposal system in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or permit the use of any privy, privy pit or other unapproved device for disposal of wastewater. 
(d)  Temporary self-contained sewage disposal units for construction sites or special short-duration events are permitted, provided such devices are approved by the city and are removed after the construction is completed or the event is terminated. 
(e)  The owner of all buildings or properties used for residential, manufacturing, processing, commercial, recreation or any other purposes for human occupancy shall at his expense install and maintain plumbing facilities connected to a public sewer if his property is within two hundred (200) feet of a public sewer and, if not, to a private disposal system constructed and maintained in accordance with the provisions of the codes of the city. 
(f)  All private disposal systems shall be inspected and approved by the EPD or the county health department, whichever is applicable, and shall be constructed in accordance with all applicable laws, rules an regulations. 
(g)  If any private disposal system is deemed inoperative, or shall otherwise cause a health problem, such system shall be connected to the public sewer system, repaired or reconstructed to comply with the regulations set out in this article. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Uncover, make connection with, open or otherwise disturb any public water sewer without first obtaining a written permit from the authorized representative of the city; 
(2)  Cover any connection, opening or excavation to the public sewer until inspected and approved by the authorized representative of the city; 
(3)  Remove covers, deface, destroy, disturb, cover or enter any manholes of the public sewer system without permission from the authorized representative of the city; 
(4)  Construct any structure or other facility on or perform any grading or substantially disturb the ground on a sewer easement or right-of-way of the city without submitting a written request to and obtaining approval of the city (plans for such an encroachment may be required); 
(5)  Install, extend, connect, alter or enlarge any wastewater facilities unless plans and specifications are prepared by a qualified person as required by law and such plans and specifications are approved by the authorized representative of the city and the EPD; 
(6)  Use construction materials which are not acceptable to the city or use any such materials which are defective or damaged; 
(7)  Cover pipeline or other appurtenances until such work is inspected and accepted by the authorized representative of the city; 
(8)  Use any wastewater facilities until the city has inspected and approved facilities, and accepted the system for operation and maintenance; or 
(9)  Discharge sanitary wastewater, septic tank effluent or cesspool overflow to any open drain, storm sewer, ditch, stream or well penetrating waterbearing formations; 
(i)  All building sewers, connections, plumbing systems and appurtenances shall be installed and maintained at the user's expense, in accordance with the applicable plumbing code of the city. 
(j)  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; however, a special permit may be granted where enforcement of this requirement will impose undue hardship. The city shall not be responsible for any damage caused by or resulting from any damage caused by or resulting from any single building sewer which serves two (2) or more buildings. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-31. - Prohibited discharge standards. 
(a)  General Prohibitions: No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW any pollutant or wastewater which causes pass through or interference. These general prohibitions apply to all users of the POTW whether or not they are subject to categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements. 
(b)  Specific Prohibitions: No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW the following pollutants, substances, or wastewater: 
(1)  Pollutants which create a fire or explosive hazard in the POTW, including, but not limited to, wastestreams with a close-cup flashpoint of less than one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit (60°C) using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21. 
(2)  Wastewater having a pH less than 5.0 or more than 12.0 or otherwise causing corrosive structural damage to the POTW or equipment. 
(3)  Solid or viscous substances in amounts which will cause obstruction of the flow in the POTW resulting in interference but in no case solids greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
(4)  Pollutants, including oxygen-demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.), released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants will cause interference with the POTW. 
(5)  Wastewater having a temperature greater than one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit (60°C), or which will inhibit biological activity in the treatment plant resulting in interference, but in no case wastewater which causes the temperature at the introduction into the treatment plant to exceed one hundred four (104) degrees Fahrenheit (40°C). 
(6)  Petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin, in amounts that will cause interference or pass-through, but in no case more than one hundred (100) milligrams per liter. 
(7)  Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors, or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems. 
(8)  Trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by the superintendent in accordance with section 20-15-40. 
(9)  Noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, solids, or other wastewater which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are sufficient to create a public nuisance or a hazard to life, or to prevent entry into the sewers for maintenance or repair. 
(10)  Wastewater which imparts color, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions, which consequently imparts color to the receiving stream, thereby violating the city's NPDES permit. 
(11)  Wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes except in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; 
(12)  Stormwater, surface water, groundwater, artesian well water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, swimming pool drainage, condensate, deionized water, noncontact cooling water, and unpolluted wastewater, unless specifically authorized by the superintendent. 
(13)  Sludges, screenings, or other residues from the pretreatment of industrial wastes. 
(14)  Medical wastes, except as specifically authorized by the superintendent in a wastewater discharge permit. 
(15)  Wastewater causing, alone or in conjunction with other sources, the treatment plant's effluent to fail a toxicity test. 
(16)  Detergents, surface-active agents, or other substances which may cause excessive foaming in the POTW. 
(17)  Fats, oils, greases of animal or vegetable origin in concentrations greater than one hundred (100) mg/l. 
(18)  Wastewater causing two (2) readings on an explosion hazard meter at the point of discharge into the POTW, or any point in the POTW, of more than five (5) percent or any single reading over ten (10) percent of the lower explosive limit of the meter. Pollutants, substances, or wastewater prohibited by this section shall not be processed or stored in such a manner that they could be discharged to the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-32. - National categorical pretreatment standards. 
    The federal or national categorical pretreatment standards found at 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N, parts 405-471 are by this reference incorporated in and made a part of this article as if fully contained herein. A copy of such standards are on file in the office of the assistant city manager and the superintendent and are available for public inspection. The interpretation of and enforcement of such standards shall be in accordance with the following: 
(a)  Where a categorical pretreatment standard is expressed only in terms of either the mass or the concentration of a pollutant in wastewater, the superintendent may impose equivalent concentration or mass limits in accordance with 40 CFR 403.6(c). 
(b)  When wastewater subject to a categorical pretreatment standard is mixed with wastewater not regulated by the same standard, the superintendent shall impose an alternate limit using the combined wastestream formula in 40 CFR 403.6(e). 
(c)  A user may obtain a variance from a categorical pretreatment standard if the user can prove, pursuant to the procedural and substantive provisions in 40 CFR 403.13, that factors relating to its discharge are fundamentally different from the factors considered by EPA when developing the categorical pretreatment standard. 
(d)  A user may obtain a net gross adjustment to a categorical standard in accordance with 40 CFR 403.15. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93; Ord. No. 07-12, § 5, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 6, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 20-15-33. - State and local pretreatment standards. 
    Any pretreatment standards now enforced or hereafter adopted by the state are by this reference incorporated herein; and: 
(a)  Shall apply in any case where such state requirements are more stringent than the requirements and limitations contained in this article; and 
(b)  The city shall have the right, in accordance with the provisions of this article, to establish limitations or requirements for discharge into the POTW which are more stringent than the state or federal requirements, if such requirements are deemed necessary or appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-34. - Reserved. 
Sec. 20-15-35. - Reserved. 
Sec. 20-15-36. - Dilution. 
    No user shall ever increase the use of process water, or in any way attempt to dilute a discharge, as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with a discharge limitation unless expressly authorized by an applicable pretreatment standard or requirement. The superintendent may impose mass limitations on users who are using dilution to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements, or in other cases when the imposition of mass limitations is appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-37. - Pretreatment facilities. 
    Users shall provide wastewater treatment as necessary to comply with this article and shall achieve compliance with all categorical pretreatment standards, local limits, and the prohibitions set out in section 20-15-31 within the time limitations specified by the EPA, the state, or the superintendent, whichever is most stringent. Any facilities necessary for compliance shall be provided, operated, and maintained at the user's expense. Detailed plans describing such facilities and operating procedures shall be submitted to the superintendent for review, and shall be acceptable to the superintendent before such facilities are constructed. The review of such plans and operating procedures shall in no way relieve the user from the responsibility of modifying such facilities as necessary to produce a discharge acceptable to the city under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-38. - Additional pretreatment requirements. 
(a)  Whenever deemed necessary, the superintendent may require users to restrict their discharge during peak flow periods, designate that certain wastewater be discharged only into specific sewers, relocate and/or consolidate points of discharge, separate sewage wastestreams from industrial wastestreams, and such other conditions as may be necessary to protect the POTW and determine the user's compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  The superintendent may require any person discharging into the POTW to install and maintain, on their property and at their expense, a suitable storage and flow-control facility to ensure equalization of flow. A wastewater discharge permit may be issued for flow equalization. 
(c)  Users with the potential to discharge flammable substances may be required to install and maintain an approved combustible gas detection meter. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-39. - Accidental discharge/slug control plans. 
    At least once every two (2) years, the superintendent shall evaluate whether each significant industrial user needs an accidental discharge/slug control plan. The superintendent may require any user to develop, submit for approval, and implement such a plan. Alternatively, the superintendent may develop such a plan for any user. An accidental discharge/slug control plan shall address, at a minimum, the following: 
(a)  Description of discharge practices, including nonroutine batch discharges; 
(b)  Description of stored chemicals; 
(c)  Procedures for immediately notifying the superintendent of any accidental or slug discharge, as required by section 20-15-65; and 
(d)  Procedures to prevent adverse impact from any accidental or slug discharge. Such procedures include, but are not limited to, inspection and maintenance of storage areas, handling and transfer of materials, loading and unloading operations, control of plant site runoff, worker training, building of containment structures or equipment, measures for containing toxic organic pollutants, including solvents, and/or measures, and equipment for emergency response. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-40. - Hauled wastewater. 
(a)  Septic tank waste may be introduced into the POTW only at locations designated by the superintendent, and at such times as are established by the superintendent. Such waste shall not violate section 20-15-31 or any other requirements established by the city. The superintendent may require septic tank waste haulers to obtain wastewater discharge permits. 
(b)  The superintendent shall require haulers of industrial waste to obtain wastewater discharge permits. The superintendent may require generators of hauled industrial waste to obtain wastewater discharge permits. The superintendent also may prohibit the disposal of hauled industrial waste. The discharge of hauled industrial waste is subject to all other requirements of this article. Wastes classified as hazardous waste and as defined by RCRA (40 CFR 261) are prohibited. 
(c)  Industrial waste haulers may discharge loads only at locations designated by the superintendent. No load may be discharged without prior consent of the superintendent. The superintendent may collect samples of each hauled load to ensure compliance with applicable standards. The superintendent may require the industrial waste hauler to provide a waste analysis of any load prior to discharge. 
(d)  Industrial waste haulers must provide a waste-tracking form for every load. This form shall include, at a minimum, the name and address of the industrial waste hauler, permit number, truck identification, names and addresses of sources of waste, and volume and characteristics of waste. The form shall identify the type of industry, known or suspected waste constituents, and whether any wastes are RCRA hazardous wastes. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Secs. 20-15-41-20-15-44. - Reserved. 
Sec. 20-15-45. - Wastewater analysis. 
    When requested by the superintendent, an user must submit information on the nature and characteristics of its wastewater within thirty (30) days of the request. The superintendent is authorized to prepare a form for this purpose and may periodically require users to update this information. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-46. - Wastewater discharge permit requirement. 
(a)  No significant industrial user shall discharge wastewater into the POTW without first obtaining a wastewater permit from the superintendent, except that a significant industrial user that has filed a timely application pursuant to section 20-15-48 may continue to discharge for the time period specified therein. 
(b)  The superintendent may require other users to obtain wastewater discharge permits as necessary to carry out the purposes of this article. 
(c)  Any violation of the terms and conditions of a wastewater discharge permit shall be deemed a violation of this article and subjects the wastewater discharge permittee to the sanctions set out in sections 20-15-77 through section 20-15-87. Obtaining a wastewater discharger permit does not relieve a permittee of its obligations to comply with all federal and state pretreatment standards or requirements or with any requirements of federal, state, or local law. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-47. - Reserved. 
Sec. 20-15-48. - Wastewater discharge permitting; new connections. 
    Any user required to obtain a wastewater discharge permit who proposes to begin or recommence discharging into the POTW must obtain such permit prior to the beginning or recommencing of such discharge. An application for this wastewater discharge permit, in accordance with section 20-15-49, must be filed at least ninety (90) days prior to the date upon which any discharge will begin or recommence. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-49. - Wastewater discharge permit application contents. 
    All users required to obtain a wastewater discharge permit must submit a permit application accompanied by a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each discharge point. The superintendent may require all users to submit as part of an application the following information. 
(a)  All information required by section 20-15-60; 
(b)  Description of activities, facilities, and plant processes on the premises, including a list of all raw materials and chemicals used or stored at the facility which are, or could accidentally or intentionally be, discharged to the POTW; 
(c)  Number and type of employees, hours of operation, and proposed or actual hours of operation; 
(d)  Each product produced by type, amount, process or processes, and rate of production; 
(e)  Type and amount of raw materials processed (average and maximum per day); 
(f)  Site plans, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans, and details to show all sewers, floor drains, and appurtenances by size, location, and elevation, and all points of discharge; 
(g)  Time and duration of discharges; and 
(h)  Any other information as may be deemed necessary by the superintendent to evaluate the wastewater discharge permit application. 
Incomplete or inaccurate applications will not be processed and will be returned to the user for revision. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-50. - Application signatories and certification. 
    All wastewater discharge permit applications and user reports must be signed by an authorized representative of the user and contain the following certification statement: 
"I certify under penalty of law that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction or supervision in accordance with a system designed to assure that qualified personnel properly gather and evaluate the information submitted. Based on my inquiry of the person or persons who manage the system, or those persons directly responsible for gathering the information, the information submitted is, to the best of my knowledge and belief, true, accurate, and complete. I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information, including the possibility of fine and imprisonment for knowing violations." 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-51. - Wastewater discharge permit decisions. 
    The superintendent will evaluate the data furnished by the user and may require additional information. Within forty-five (45) days of receipt of a complete wastewater discharge permit application, the superintendent will determine whether or not to issue a wastewater discharge permit. The superintendent may deny any application for a wastewater discharge permit. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-52. - Wastewater discharge permit duration. 
    A wastewater discharge permit shall be issued for a specified time period, not to exceed five (5) years from the effective date of the permit. A wastewater discharge permit may be issued for a period less than five (5) years, at the discretion of the superintendent. Each wastewater discharge permit will indicate a specific date upon which it will expire. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-53. - Wastewater discharge permit contents. 
    A wastewater discharge permit shall include such conditions as are deemed reasonably necessary by the superintendent to prevent pass through or interference, protect the quality of the water body receiving the treatment plant's effluent, protect worker health and safety, facilitate sludge management and disposal, and protect against damage to the POTW. 
(a)  Wastewater discharge permits must contain: 
(1)  A statement that indicates wastewater discharge permit duration, which in no event shall exceed five (5) years; 
(2)  A statement that the wastewater discharge permit is nontransferable without prior notification to the city in accordance with section 20-15-56, and provisions for furnishing the new owner or operator with a copy of the existing wastewater discharge permit; 
(3)  Effluent limits based on applicable pretreatment standards; 
(4)  Self-monitoring, sampling, reporting, notification, and record-keeping requirements; these requirements shall include an identification of pollutants to be monitored, sampling location, sampling frequency, and sample type based on federal, state, and local law; and 
(5)  A statement of applicable civil and criminal penalties for violation of pretreatment standards and requirements, and any applicable compliance schedule. Such schedule may not extend the time for compliance beyond that required by applicable federal, state, or local law. 
(b)  Wastewater discharge permits may contain, but need not be limited to, the following conditions: 
(1)  Limits on the average and/or maximum rate of discharge, time of discharge, and/or requirements for flow regulation and equalization; 
(2)  Requirements for the installation of pretreatment technology, pollution control, or construction of appropriate containment devices, designed to reduce, eliminate, or prevent the introduction of pollutants into the treatment works; 
(3)  Requirements for the development and implementation of spill control plans or other special conditions, including management practices necessary to adequately prevent accidental, unanticipated, or nonroutine discharges; 
(4)  Development and implementation of waste minimization plans to reduce the amount of pollutants discharged to the POTW; 
(5)  The unit charge or schedule of user charges and fees for the management of the wastewater discharged to the POTW; 
(6)  Requirements for installation and maintenance of inspection and sampling facilities and equipment; 
(7)  A statement that compliance with the wastewater discharge permit does not relieve the permittee of responsibility for compliance with all applicable federal and state pretreatment standards, including those which become effective during the term of the wastewater discharge permit; and 
(8)  Other conditions as deemed appropriate by the superintendent to ensure compliance with this article, and state and federal laws, rules, and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-54. - Wastewater discharge permit appeals. 
    Any person, including the user, may petition the superintendent to reconsider the terms of a wastewater discharge permit within thirty (30) days of notice of its issuance. 
(a)  Failure to submit a timely petition for review shall be deemed to be a waiver of the administrative appeal. 
(b)  In its petition, the appealing party must indicate the wastewater discharge permit provisions objected to, the reasons for this objection, and the alternative condition, if any, it seeks to place in the wastewater discharge permit. 
(c)  The effectiveness of the wastewater discharge permit shall not be stayed pending the appeal. 
(d)  If the superintendent fails to act within thirty (30) days, a request for reconsideration shall be deemed to be denied. Decisions not to reconsider a wastewater discharge permit, not to issue a wastewater discharge permit, or not to modify a wastewater discharge permit shall be considered final administrative actions for purposes of judicial review. 
(e)  The action or inaction of the superintendent which results in denial of reconsideration may be appealed to the city manager within thirty (30) days of the date of such denial. 
(f)  Aggrieved parties seeking judicial review of the final administrative wastewater discharge permit decision must do so by filing a complaint with the Superior Court of Troup County, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-55. - Wastewater discharge permit modification. 
    The superintendent may modify a wastewater discharge permit for good cause, including, but not limited to, the following reasons: 
(a)  To incorporate any new or revised federal, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements; 
(b)  To address significant alterations or additions to the user's operation, processes, or wastewater volume or character since the time of wastewater discharge permit issuance; 
(c)  A change in the POTW that requires either a temporary or permanent reduction or elimination of the authorized discharge; 
(d)  Information indicating that the permitted discharge poses a threat to the city's POTW, city personnel, or the receiving waters; 
(e)  Violation of any terms or conditions of the wastewater discharge permit; 
(f)  Misrepresentations or failure to fully disclose all relevant facts in the wastewater discharge permit application or in any required reporting; 
(g)  Revision of or a grant of variance from categorical pretreatment standards pursuant to 40 CFR 403.13; 
(h)  To correct typographical or other errors in the wastewater discharge permit; or 
(i)  To reflect a transfer of the facility ownership or operation to a new owner or operator. 
(Ord. No. 93-53, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 20-15-56. - Wastewater discharge permit transfer. 
    Wastewater discharge permits may be transferred to a new owner or operator only if the permittee gives at least ten (10) days' advance notice to the superintendent and the superintendent approves the wastewater discharge permit transfer. The notice to the superintendent must include a written certification by the new owner or operator which:
