The building official shall have access to all establishments which offer for sale or sell plumbing fixtures for purposes of determining compliance with and enforcement of the provisions of section 20-15-134. 
(4)  In order to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article pertaining to installation of plumbing fixtures in facilities in the unincorporated area of Troup County, which are already connected to the city water supply or for which connection to the city water supply will be requested or required, any building contractor or plumber installing any such plumbing fixtures, as a condition to making or continuing connection to the public water supply, shall certify together with the owner, that the plumbing fixtures installed in all instances comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 91-14A, § 1(7), 6-11-91) 
Sec. 20-15-138. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provisions of this article shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-1-6 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 91-14A, § 2, 6-11-91) 
Chapter 20-20 - UTILITIES DISCOUNT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, adopted August 28, 2018, deleted the former chapter 20-20, §§ 20-20-1-20-20-7, and enacted a new chapter 20-20 as set out herein. The former chapter 20-20 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Tables for the chapter's derivation. 
Cross reference- Electricity, Ch. 20-5; gas, Ch. 20-10; water and sewers, Ch. 20-15. 

Sec. 20-20-1. - Eligibility. 
    There is hereby created a senior discount for utility account holders who are sixty-five (65) years of age or older and meet the qualifications established by the Georgia Department of Human Services for the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) program. 
(Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, 8-28-18) 
Sec. 20-20-2. - Application. 
    Eligible customers shall apply for the discount in the city's customer service office by providing proof of age and total gross annual household income. Household income includes alimony, child support, pension, wages, Social Security, SSDI, SSI, TANF/AFDC, Unemployment, and any other forms of income defined by the Georgia Department of Human Services for LIHEAP eligibility. 
(Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, 8-28-18) 
Sec. 20-20-3. - Discount. 
    The discount to be applied to each monthly utility bill will be based on the services the applicant receives from the city and shall equal eleven dollars ($11.00) for electric service, six dollars and thirty cents ($6.30) for natural gas service, one dollar and forty cents ($1.40) for water service, twelve dollars ($12.00) for a 68-gallon garbage can, and fifteen dollars ($15.00) for a 96-gallon garbage can. 
(Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, 8-28-18) 
Title 25 - COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State constitution references- Planning and zoning, Art. 9, § 2, Par. 4; development authorities, Art. 9, § 6, Par. 3. 
State Law reference- Urban redevelopment, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-1 et seq.; development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.; conduct of directors and members of authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62A-1; resource recovery development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-1 et seq. 

Chapter 25-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 25-1-1. - Department created; appointment of director. 
    There is hereby created the community and economic development department of the city, the director of which shall be the director of community and economic development (referred to in this chapter as the "director"). The director shall be appointed by the city manager subject to confirmation by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-138) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 25-1-2. - Duties of director. 
    The director shall, under the general supervision of the city manager, provide administrative and technical direction to and exercise general supervision over the administration and management of the activities related to improving the condition of housing in the community, promoting job opportunities, rehabilitating and revitalizing neighborhoods, locating and identifying funds and resources available to carry out such activities and the administration, supervision and enforcement of building, plumbing, housing and environmental sanitation codes of the city, and in furtherance thereof, shall: 
(1)  Identify both institutional and financial resources including but not limited to federal, state, local and private funds specifically needed, and which are available to perform the function of economic development and revitalization of neighborhoods in the community; 
(2)  Develop program activities to implement the policies and priorities established and identified by the mayor and council; 
(3)  Enforce all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to governmental functions under his supervision; 
(4)  Package, prepare and assemble applications for specific projects and programs which are necessary or appropriate in the implementation of the goals of the community development department including but not limited to, public and private sector resources; 
(5)  Represent the city in contacts with state and federal jurisdictions relating to matters under his supervision; 
(6)  Identify the existing housing stock characteristics and the housing needs and projection of housing needs in the community in accordance with the goals and objectives identified, fixed and approved by the mayor and council; 
(7)  Perform such other duties or responsibilities as may be delegated to him by ordinance or resolution of the mayor and council, or as directed by the city manager, or as may be required of him or his employees pursuant to direction or designation of the assistant city manager of the city relating to application for, issuance of and enforcement, regulation and collection of fees pertaining to licenses issued or to be issued by the city. 
(8)  Recommend for appointment and after appointment shall administer, direct and supervise the building official or building officials and the plumbing official or plumbing officials, or their respective duly authorized representatives, in the inspection, application and enforcement of all technical codes and regulations now or hereafter adopted by the mayor and council; 
(9)  Perform the administrative duties for the construction board of adjustment and appeals and in furtherance thereof, keep accurate and up to date minutes of the meetings, maintain and preserve the records of the board and perform all administrative functions related thereto; and 
(10)  Organize, assist and participate in the formation of citizens' or advisory committees required or reasonably necessary to assist in the performance of the functions described herein. 
(Code 1972, § 2-139; Ord. No. 90-11, § 1, 3-27-90; Ord. No. 91-22, § 4, 7-23-91; Ord. No. 02-08, § 3, 3-26-02; Ord. No. 02-29, § 5, 9-24-02; Ord. No. 07-12, § 6, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 7, 12-13-16) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 25-5; signs, Ch. 25-10; planning, Ch. 25-15; subdivisions, Ch. 25-20; flood damage prevention, Ch. 25-25; erosion control, Ch. 25-30; zoning, Ch. 25-35. 
Sec. 25-1-3. - Building and plumbing official(s); appointment, duties. 
(a)  The director with the approval of the city manager shall appoint a building official or building officials and a plumbing official or plumbing officials. The building official or building officials and the plumbing official or plumbing officials or their respective duly authorized representatives shall perform all functions and duties prescribed by ordinance or resolution by the mayor and council or specified by the director. In furtherance thereof, the director shall be authorized to appoint inspectors to assist the building official or building officials or the plumbing official or plumbing officials in the performance of their duties and to perform such functions and have such responsibilities as the director may specify and designate. 
(b)  The building official of the city or his designated representative is authorized to investigate and report violations of any of the codes of the city relating to zoning codes, building codes, plumbing codes, erosion and sedimentation ordinance, floodplain ordinance, sign ordinance, tree ordinance, housing codes or any other codes or ordinances which such official is charged with the responsibility of investigating and enforcing. Such officials are authorized to issue and serve citations and summons for appearance before the municipal court for violations of the provisions of such codes or ordinances. 
(c)  The power and authority given hereby under subparagraph (b) of this section does not include the right of arrest or detention, but is merely to authorize issuance of citations and summons and service of the same and the right to investigate and report violations as authorized by subparagraph (b) and shall not make any such official a peace officer of the city as that term is commonly used in this state or as that term is defined by paragraph (11) of Section 16-1-3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
(Code 1972, § 2-140; Ord. No. 90-11, § 1, 3-27-90; Ord. No. 90-43, § 1, 9-11-90) 
Cross reference- Flood damage prevention, Ch. 25-25; zoning enforcement officer, § 25-35-128. 
Sec. 25-1-4. - Building permits, inspections, certificates of occupancy, etc., not to be construed as guarantee. 
    The inspections by the director, the building official, the plumbing official or the duly authorized representatives of either, the issuance of building permits and the issuance by the city of any certificate of occupancy, are done, conducted and performed by such officials of the city in furtherance of a duty to citizens in general and are performed and conducted for the purpose of protecting the safety, health and general welfare of the citizens of LaGrange. No such inspection, permit issuance or certificate of occupancy issuance shall create a special relationship to any specific individual or individuals or to specific property. The city and its officers, agents or employees shall have no liability for the performance of any such inspection, issuance of permits or certificates of occupancy and in no circumstance is any such inspection, issuance of permit or issuance of certificate of occupancy to be construed as a guarantee that specific properties are free from all or any problems. 
(Ord. No. 96-45, § 1, 8-27-96) 
Chapter 25-5 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Codes of technical regulations, § 2.42; building, electrical, gas and plumbing regulations, § 5.23; abatement of nuisance, § 5.24. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 5-1 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10-10; fire prevention and protection division, § 10-10-21 et seq. health, Ch. 10-25; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 15-5; building materials on street or sidewalk, § 15-5-2; franchises, Ch. 15-25; city utilities, Ch. 20-1 et seq.; signs, Ch. 25-10; flood damage prevention, Ch. 25-25; zoning, Ch. 25-35; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 30-1 et seq. 
State constitution reference- Power of city to provide building, housing, plumbing, electrical and other codes, Art. 9, § 2, Par. 3. 
State Law reference- Buildings and housing, O.C.G.A. Title 8; contracts for public works, O.C.G.A. § 13-10-1 et seq.; fire protection and safety, O.C.G.A. Title 25; bonds for public contractors, O.C.G.A. § 36-82-100 et seq.; electrical contractors, plumbers and conditioned air contractors, O.C.G.A. § 443-14-1 et seq.; registration of nonresident contractors, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-30 et seq. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-5-1. - Fire district. 
    As required by section 301.4 (a) and (b) of the Standard Building Code, there is hereby created and established in the city a fire district, the limits of which shall include the following territory in the city, to wit: Commencing at the point of intersection of the centerline of the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad track and the westerly boundary of Main Street and running thence northwesterly along the west boundary of Main Street to its intersection with the south margin of West Depot Street; thence westerly along the south margin of West Depot Street to its intersection with the east boundary of South Lewis Street; thence northerly along the east boundary of South Lewis Street and continuing along the east boundary of North Lewis Street to its intersection with the south boundary of Smith Street; thence easterly along the south boundary of Smith Street to its intersection with the west boundary of Morgan Street; thence southerly along the west boundary of Morgan Street at its intersection with the centerline of the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad track; thence in a southerly direction along the centerline of the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad track to its point of intersection with the west boundary of Main Street which is the point of beginning. 
(Code 1972, § 6-1; Ord. No. 85-26, § 1, 9-24-85; Ord. No. 85-29, § 1, 10-22-85) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10-10. 
State Law reference- Elimination of fire and other hazards to persons and property, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 25-5-2. - Awnings and marquees-Restrictions. 
(a)  Awnings and marquees erected over sidewalks within the fire district shall be supported entirely by metal brackets or hung on metal rods or chains, such brackets, rods or chains to be attached to the building in front of which any such awning or marquee shall be placed; provided, however, wooden supports for such structures shall be permissible outside the fire district. All such awnings and marquees shall be placed with their outer edges at least twelve (12) inches back of the curbline, and the lower or underside of said awning or marquee, including all attachments thereto such as light fixtures, and its supports as required above, shall not be less than eight (8) feet above the sidewalk at the lowest point. 
(b)  The mayor and council may permit the structure supporting marquees to be placed on the sidewalk area of the street right-of-way provided: 
(1)  The plans and specifications of such structure shall otherwise comply with the charter and all ordinances and codes of the city; 
(2)  The structure shall be constructed, placed, and maintained so as not to interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic on the street right-of-way; 
(3)  Adequate lighting is installed, maintained and operated by the owner or tenant of the building to which the marquee is attached, the operation of such lighting system to be approved by the director of utilities; 
(4)  The structure is of a design that is compatible with the design of the adjacent buildings; 
(5)  The owner or tenant shall at his own expense maintain and make all repairs to the structure, however necessitated, at no expense to the city; 
(6)  In the event the mayor and council determine that it is necessary to use said sidewalk area for any public purpose, inconsistent with use by the owner, the owner shall remove the supporting structure at no expense to the city; and 
(7)  The owner shall comply with any applicable laws of the state and regulations of the state department of transportation. 
(Code 1972, § 6-2) 
State Law reference- Obstructing sidewalks or other public passages, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43; regulations of state department of transportation, O.C.G.A. § 32-2-2. 
Sec. 25-5-3. - Same-Permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect an awning or a marquee anywhere within the fire district without first obtaining a permit to do so from the city. 
(Code 1972, § 6-3) 
Sec. 25-5-4. - Heating, ventilation and air conditioning permits. 
    There shall be a charge for the cost of inspections of heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems based upon the following scheduling of charges: 
(1)  For residential structure, there shall be a charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) per heating, ventilation and air conditioning system unit per dwelling unit; 
(2)  For all other structures, there shall be a charge of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per heating, ventilation and air conditioning system unit, not to exceed an inspection fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the entire nonresidential structure, regardless of the number of system units. 
(Code 1972, § 6-133; Ord. No. 85-15, § 3, 6-27-85; Ord. No. 94-21, § 1(b), 6-30-94; Ord. No. 98-17, § 1, 6-23-98; Ord. No. 99-47, § 1, 12-28-99) 
Secs. 25-5-5, 25-5-6. - Reserved. 
Sec. 25-5-7. - Re-inspection fees. 
    Re-inspection of construction or development activities performed by the city pursuant to the provisions of this chapter 25-5 shall, in all instances, require payment in advance of re-inspection fees as follows: 
(a)  For owner-occupied single-family dwellings, a re-inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) each shall be paid for the second or any additional re-inspection; 
(b)  For all other re-inspections including the first re-inspection a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such re-inspection; 
(c)  The term re-inspection as used herein shall not include any inspection initially required as a part of the permitting process. 
(Ord. No. 95-35, § 1, 8-9-94; Ord. No. 04-09, § 4, 3-23-04) 
Article II - ADOPTION OF STANDARD CODES 

Sec. 25-5-8. - Georgia State Minimum Standard Codes. 
(a)  The latest edition of the following Georgia State Minimum Standard Codes, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, as well as Chapter 1 of said codes, shall be enforced within the city: 
(1)  2000 International Building Code; 
(2)  2000 International Mechanical Code; 
(3)  2000 International Gas Code; 
(4)  2000 International Plumbing Code; 
(5)  2002 National Electrical Code; 
(6)  2003 International Fire Code; 
(7)  2000 International Residential Code for One- and Two- Family Dwellings; and 
(8)  Georgia State Energy Code. 
(b)  The latest addition of the following Georgia state minimum standard codes, as well as Chapter 1 of said codes, are hereby adopted and shall be enforced within the city: 
International Property Maintenance Code, 2003 edition as amended by the State of Georgia. 
(c)  In addition to the Standard Codes referenced above, the following appendices of said codes, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, are adopted by reference as though copied herein fully: 
(1)  (2000 International Building Code: Appendices C, D, E, F, G, H, I and J); 
(2)  (2000 International Mechanical Code: Appendix A); 
(3)  (2000 International Plumbing Code: Appendices B, D, E, F and G); 
(4)  (2000 International Gas Code: Appendices A, B and C); 
(5)  (2003 International Fire Code: Appendices B, C, D, E, F and G); 
(6)  (2002 National Electric Code: All appendices); and 
(7)  (2000 International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings: Appendices E, G and H). 
(d)  The International Building Code (2000 International Building Code) is amended as follows: 
(1)  Section 112.1 is deleted, in its entirety, and replaced by a new Section 112.1 to read as follows: 
"In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions and determinations of the building official, there is hereby established the construction board of adjustment and appeals, which shall consists of five (5) members who shall be appointed by the Mayor and Council of the City of LaGrange. The members of the board may be removed from the board at anytime by the Mayor and Council, with or without cause, and shall have the qualifications and terms of office as shall be fixed by the Mayor and Council." 
(2)  Section 112.3 of the International Building Code (2000 International Building Code) is amended by deleting said section, in its entirety, inserting in lieu thereof a new Section 112.3 to be entitled "Further Right of Appeal" and to read as follows: 
"Section 112.3 Further Right of Appeal. Anyone aggrieved by or who disagrees with a decision of the construction board of adjustment and appeals shall have the right to appeal such decision to the Mayor and Council. The decision of the Mayor and Council on any such appeal shall be final, subject however to such additional remedy as any aggrieved party may have at law or in equity." 
(3)  Section 113.3 of the International Building Code (2000 International Building Code) is deleted in its entirety. 
(4)  Section 115 of the International Building Code (2000 International Building Code) is deleted in its entirety.

Section M109.2 Limitations on Authority.

The board shall have no authority to waive requirements of this code.

Article III - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 25-5-17. - Design professional. 
    Construction documents submitted pursuant to requirements of the Standard Building Code shall be prepared by a design professional. The design professional shall be an architect or engineer legally registered under the laws of the state regulating the practice of architecture or engineering and shall affix his or her official seal to said drawings, specifications and accompanying data, for the following: 
(1)  All Group A, E, and I occupancies; 
(2)  Buildings and structures three (3) stories or more high; 
(3)  Buildings and structures five thousand (5,000) square feet or more in area. 
For all other buildings and structures, the submittal shall bear the certification of the applicant that some specified state law exemption permits its preparation by a person not so registered. 
EXCEPTION: Group R3 buildings, regardless of size, shall require neither a registered architect or engineer, nor a certification that an architect or engineer is not required. 
(Ord. No. 02-08, § 4, 3-26-02; Ord. No. 02-31, § 6, 10-22-02) 
Sec. 25-5-18. - Wood frame buildings. 
(a)  No wood frame building erected or altered after November 25, 1980, shall exceed thirty-five (35) feet in height, except that private dwellings may be three (3) stories or forty (40) feet high. This provision does not apply to grain or coal elevators. 
(b)  In no case shall a wood frame building be erected within three (3) feet of the side or rear lot line, nor within six (6) feet of another building. Nothing in this Code section shall be construed to excuse compliance with all applicable aspects of the building codes adopted in section 25-5-16 of the Code. 
(c)  Buildings with wooden framework clad with sheet metal or veneered with brick shall be classed as wood frame buildings. 
(Code 1972, § 6-18; Ord. No. 00-34, § 1, 12-21-00) 
Sec. 25-5-19. - Moving buildings-Dimensions; permit. 
    No building or a portion thereof with dimensions in excess of eighteen (18) feet in width, thirty (30) feet in length and sixteen (16) feet in height shall be moved on the streets of the city unless or until a special permit for such moving shall be obtained from the director of community and economic development or his authorized representative. Such permit shall impose such conditions and contain such restrictions as the director shall deem necessary in order to facilitate the movement so as not to interfere with utilities, traffic and public facilities. 
(Code 1972, § 6-4) 
Sec. 25-5-20. - Same-Prohibited at night. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to move or cause to be moved, or allow to remain, any building on the streets of the city between sundown and sunrise. 
(Code 1972, § 6-5) 
Sec. 25-5-21. - Building code permits. 
(a)  No permit as required by the building code shall be issued by the city until the fee prescribed in this section shall have been paid, and no amendment to a permit shall be approved until the additional fee, if any, due to an increase in the estimated cost of the building or structure, shall have been paid. 
(b)  For a permit for the construction or alteration of a building or structure, the fee shall be based upon the estimated cost of such construction or alterations as follows: 
Estimated Cost Fee $100 or less $10.00 $101 to $15,000 $9.00 per $1,000 $15,001 to $100,000 $135.00 for the first $15,000, plus $4.50 per each additional $1,000 $100,001 to $500,000 $517.50 for the first $100,000, plus $2.50 per each additional $1,000 $500,001 to $1,000,000 $1,517.50 for the first $500,000, plus $1.00 per each additional $1,000 Over $1,000,000 $2,017.50 for the first $1,000,000, plus $0.30 per each additional $1,000  
(c)  For a permit for the removal of a building or structure from one lot to another, or to a new location within the same lot, the fee shall be one hundred five dollars ($105.00). 
(d)  For a permit for the demolition of a building or structure, the fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(e)  The term "estimated cost," as used in this section, means the reasonable value of all services, labor and devices entering into and necessary for the prosecution and completion of the work to the point that the same is ready for occupancy; provided, however, the cost of landscaping, decorating and similar work not necessary for safe and lawful use for occupancy of the building or structure shall not be deemed a part of such estimated cost. 
(f)  No building permit shall be issued to any person for construction of a building on any lot, tract or parcel of land unless the same shall front at least forty (40) feet upon a public street which has been accepted and which is being currently used by the city as a public street. 
(Code 1972, § 6-131; Ord. No. 85-15, § 1, 6-27-85; Ord. No. 94-21, § 1(c), 6-30-94; Ord. No. 04-09, § 1, 3-23-04; Ord. No. 10-12, § 1, 5-25-10) 
Sec. 25-5-22. - Furnishing electricity, conditions. 
    In order to enforce the International Property Maintenance Code, 2003 edition, the city may deny utility service upon a change of occupancy of any dwelling until such dwelling has been inspected and found to be in compliance with the International Property Maintenance Code, 2003 edition, as amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs. 
(Ord. No 02-32, § 1, 10-22-02; Ord. No. 04-23, § 1, 7-27-04) 
Sec. 25-5-23. - Payment upon commencing business; exceptions. 
    Permit and license fees or costs as established by this chapter, as well as elsewhere in the code, shall be paid before commencing business and as a condition precedent for transacting business or practicing an occupation, except as follows: 
(a)  Regulatory fees may be paid after commencing business or the practice of a profession or occupation when: 
1.  The work done or services provided are necessary for the health, comfort or safety of one or more individuals or protection of property. This paragraph shall apply to, but not be limited to the repair, service, or insulation of heating, ventilation and air conditioning equipment system; 
2.  The work done or services provided have no adverse effect on any other person; 
3.  Applicable regulatory and permit fees are tendered to the city within two (2) business days after commencing business or the practice of a profession or occupation and any and all required inspections are made in order to insure compliance with any applicable code; 
4.  The work is commenced or the services are provided within twenty-four (24) hours of receiving the request for such work or service and it is not possible for the person conducting the work or providing the service to obtain a permit prior to commencing due to the hours of operation of the city. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 7-11-06) 
Secs. 25-5-24-25-5-35. - Reserved.
