(b)  Purpose. The purpose of the P-1 parkway zone is to provide for a superior environment along major transportation corridors through the application of an overlay zone. The overlay zone regulations are intended to supplement the regulations of the underlying zone districts and to provide for harmony and compatibility of development over the length of the corridor. This zone is established to protect the public investment in major highways and ensure that these can continue to serve their primary functions of moving volumes of traffic safely. Provisions of the park way zone are intended to expedite the free flow of traffic and reduce the hazards arising from unnecessary points of ingress and egress and cluttered roadside development. The district is intended to enhance the value of adjacent lands by preserving and extending the useful life of the highway, avoiding land uses that conflict with the roadside and the surrounding area and reducing the risks of creating blighted areas. Insuring the attractiveness of roadside uses will contribute to and enhance trade, tourism, capital investment and the general welfare. 
(c)  Regulations of underlying district. Unless otherwise noted in the parkway zone regulations, the regulations of the underlying zoning district shall be maintained and not affected. 
(d)  Establishment of districts. Parkway district boundaries shall be established and from time to time amended on the official zoning map, and may include any highway which is deemed appropriate and its adjacent properties to a specified distance from the centerline of the highway. The mayor and council may apply the parkway zone to any highway corridor upon concluding that: 
(1)  The highway corridor has scenic qualities and natural beauty that should be protected; 
(2)  A major purpose of the highway is to carry through traffic; and 
(3)  Development along the highway in the absence of the parkway zoning provisions could have an adverse impact on its level of service; increase danger and/or congestion in the street; impair the public health, safety, convenience and welfare; and/or impede the maintenance or creation of a convenient, attractive and harmonious community. 
(e)  Conditions. All uses under this section are subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  A site plan is required to be submitted for review and approval for the development of any parcel within the parkway district. The site plan review procedure shall be carried out in accordance with the site plan review ordinance of the city. A site plan shall be submitted and approved prior to any site preparation. 
(2)  The minimum distance between all driveways, curb cuts or access points of any kind onto a service road, frontage road or unified access road to the main highway shall be approved by the state department of transportation. All such entrances shall be constructed of materials that will eliminate the potential for soil and mud to be tracked onto the parkway. 
(3)  No loading or unloading of material shall take place in any front or corner side yard of any parcel which fronts on the highway right-of-way. Buildings will be designed so as to provide service entrances at the rear. 
(4)  No parking shall be permitted on the highway right-of-way. All parcels shall be expected to provide sufficient off-street parking to meet their individual needs. 
(5)  For every four (4) rows of parking spaces delineated, one (1) raised parking island shall be provided, thereby creating separated parking areas to aid in safe and orderly use of the lot and confine vehicular movement to marked drives. Raised or curbed circulation islands shall be constructed at the ends of the rows of parking spaces or at other locations where circulation drives intersect. For all uses providing clientele parking, all circulation drives shall be clearly defined and marked appropriately with arrows and the like to assist public circulation into, on and out of the property and through parking lot areas. 
(6)  Adequate circulation drives shall interconnect all lot access points with all vehicle parking, loading, servicing and like areas and structures, thereby creating an on-site circulation network which, together with any service drives abutting the lot, will provide a safe and convenient means for lot servicing and fire protection. 
(7)  Circulation drives used by vehicles to reach a drive-by sales or service window, depository or similar facility shall be one-way and shall be of sufficient length to prevent a line of waiting vehicles from backing up into a street or onto adjoining property. 
(f)  Use limitations. Land within the parkway zone may be used as permitted in the underlying district in which located, subject to the above conditions and with the following: 
(1)  Junkyards are prohibited. 
(2)  Individual manufactured homes and manufactured home parks shall be prohibited. 
(3)  Sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments are prohibited. 
(4)  Any commercial development shall be subject to the following: 
a.  Coordination of pedestrian and vehicular circulation patterns shall be encouraged between adjacent property owners. 
b.  Such use shall have access designed so as not to impede traffic on a public street intended to carry through traffic. To such end, access via the following means shall be given favorable consideration in site plan review: 
1.  Access to the site is provided by a public street other than one intended to carry through traffic; and/or 
2.  Access to the site is provided by a functional frontage road, service drive or joint driveway which provides controlled access to the site and/or to several adjacent sites; and/or 
3.  Acceleration/deceleration lanes, turning lanes and/or stacking lanes are provided to improve access to the site and/or several adjacent sites. 
c.  All areas subject to vehicular traffic including frontage roads, accessways, loading areas and service areas shall be constructed in accordance with the minimum paving specifications in force in the city at the time of improvement. 
d.  All commercial uses shall provide at least one (1) regular sized garbage container outside of the establishment, adequately screened from the view of the highway. 
e.  All commercial uses shall provide and maintain a landscaped area along the length of their frontage with the highway or service road right-of-way as may be reasonably necessary. 
(g)  Overall landscaping requirements. 
(1)  Any part of the project site not used for buildings or other structures shall be landscaped in an amount equal to ten (10) percent of the vehicular use area. (Vehicular use area includes parking lots, accessways, loading area and service areas.) 
Landscaped islands can count toward overall landscaping requirements; however, only trees and shrubs shall be considered as landscaping elements. 
Landscaping shall include a minimum of one (1) tree for each five hundred (500) square feet of landscaped area. Each tree shall have a caliper of two (2) inches at time of planting. 
(2)  Existing vegetation which meets the requirements of this section should be used as required planting, where practical. 
(3)  All required planting shall be maintained in a healthy and productive condition. 
(h)  Signs. Signs shall be allowed only in accordance with the applicable provisions of chapter 25-10 (Signs) of this Code. 
(Code 1972, app. B, § 80.1; Ord. No. 88-93, §§ 1, 2, 5-24-88; Ord. No. 88-116, § 11, 9-27-88; Ord. No. 89-35, § 5, 9-26-89; Ord. No. 91-12, § 1, 5-14-91; Ord. No. 92-14, § 1, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 95-34, § 9, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 96-42, § 1(o), 6-25-96; Ord. No. 04-22, § 9, 7-13-04; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 09-18, § 1, 11-3-09) 
Sec. 25-35-72. - R-4 zero lot district. 
    The R-4 zero lot line district is established as a transitional zone between residential land use and commercial or industrial land use. The R-4 zone is not intended to provide a vehicle for spot zoning or significantly higher densities than found in adjoining land uses. 
(1)  Principal uses: 
a.  Single-family dwellings; 
b.  Churches and their customary related uses, including cemeteries, provided that all buildings and graves shall be set back at least thirty-five (35) feet from the front property line and twenty (20) feet from any other property line; 
c.  Noncommercial horticulture or agriculture; 
d.  Educational buildings, swimming pools, playgrounds, parks, community centers and other recreational and educational facilities operated on a nonprofit basis, and golf courses; 
e.  Public and private elementary and secondary schools, but not including schools primarily engaged in commercial or industrial trade education, provided all such uses are located not less than fifty (50) feet from any property line; 
f.  Public works and public utility facilities such as distribution lines, transmission lines and towers, electric substations, water tanks and towers, pumping stations, water treatment plants, telephone exchanges and fire stations provided: 
1.  Such facilities are essential to the service of the immediate areas; 
2.  Outside storage of vehicles or materials on the premises shall not be permitted; 
3.  All buildings and facilities shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from all property lines and shall be designed and landscaped in such a way as to blend in with the surrounding area; 
4.  All dangerous apparatus shall be enclosed by a chain-link fence at least eight (8) feet in height; and 
5.  There shall be a densely planted and maintained buffer strip along the rear and side lot lines. Such buffer shall not extend nearer to a street right-of-way line than the established building setback line of the adjoining lots; and 
g.  Zero lot line dwellings. 
(2)  Accessory uses: 
a.  Private swimming pools; 
b.  Nurseries and greenhouses; and 
c.  Other accessory uses that are clearly incidental to the permanent structure. 
(3)  Zero lot line development. The applicant for a zero lot line development shall submit with the application a development plan indicating compliance with and shall abide by the following criteria: 
a.  General: 
1.  Plans must be submitted to the department of community and economic development (DCED) and shall be reviewed by the DCED, department of utilities and department of public services, with city staff, at minimum, reviewing the impact of the proposal on population density, transportation, infrastructure and compatibility with surrounding neighborhoods, after which a report on the development along with each department's comments will be forwarded to the board of planning and zoning appeals, and upon completion of board review shall be forwarded to the mayor and council. 
2.  Plans and specifications shall include: 
(a)  Conceptual plans (including frontal elevations) must be submitted and must show size, height, shape, exterior finish and location of all buildings and proposed improvements to the property. Exterior finish and appearance must be compatible and generally consistent with surrounding structures; 
(b)  Driveway/access plans depicting method by which such access will connect to the public right-of-way; 
(c)  Site plan and landscape plan, including all adjoining properties and improvements; 
(d)  Floor plans of the proposed units; 
3.  Each interior unit shall abut and be separated from the other interior units by an approved wall, such wall to be without openings or other means of passage or visibility between each unit and shall in all cases comply with the current building code. 
4.  Each dwelling unit shall, if multistory, be independently served by interior stairways and by utilities and services. 
b.  Lot size: 
1.  The size of each lot per dwelling unit shall not be less than two thousand (2,000) square feet. 
2.  The minimum distance between contiguous groups or between a unit and a building outside the group shall be not less than sixteen (16) feet at any point. 
c.  Setbacks: 
1.  Front yard, minimum of twenty (20) feet from front property line, except for units fronting on a major thoroughfare, as designated in the LaGrange Comprehensive Plan, as amended, which must be setback sixty (60) feet from front property line; 
2.  Rear yard, minimum of twenty (20) feet to rear property line; 
3.  No side yard is required except at each end of a zero lot line dwelling group where a minimum side yard of eight (8) feet shall be maintained. On corner lots a minimum side yard of ten (10) feet shall be maintained on the street side. 
4.  A buffer shall be provided along any side or rear property line abutting a less intense zoning district as required in section 25-11-55 of this Code. 
d.  1.  Building space: Each applicant shall designate and seek zoning for one of the following classifications: 
(a)  R-4, A-800 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than eight hundred (800) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
(b)  R-4, A-1,000 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than one thousand (1,000) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
(c)  R-4, A-1200 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
(d)  R-4, A-1400 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than one thousand four hundred (1,400) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
(e)  R-4, A-1500 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
(f)  R-4, A-1600 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than one thousand six hundred (1,600) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
(g)  R-4, A-1800 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than one thousand eight hundred (1,800) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
(h)  R-4, A-2000 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than two thousand (2,000) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
2.  Attached building units: The number of attached building units within the various R-4 zoning classifications shall be limited according to average square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages as follows: 
(a)  For dwelling units which average less than eight hundred (800) square feet, the number of attached units shall be not less than three (3) nor more than four (4). 
(b)  For dwelling units which average less than one thousand (1,000) square feet, the number of attached units shall be not less than three (3) nor more than six (6). 
(c)  For dwelling units which average less than one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet, the number of attached units shall be not less than three (3) nor more than eight (8). 
(d)  For dwelling units which average in excess of one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet, the number of attached units shall be not less than three (3) nor more than ten (10). 
e.  Off-street parking shall be provided as required in Code section 25-35-6. A curb cut to allow for otherwise appropriate off-street parking in the front of units shall be allowed for developments with up to three (3) attached units. For developments with four (4) or more attached units no curb cut for parking shall be provided, with all parking and vehicular access required to be provided at the rear of units. 
f.  Deed restrictions: A permit for the construction of zero lot line development shall be issued in accordance with the regulations set forth after evidence has been presented in the form of proposed deed covenants and restrictions requiring the maintenance of jointly owned areas so as to prevent the occurrence of blight by failure of the owner of any unit to maintain the same properly and to assure appropriate provisions for access along a common drive if applicable. 
g.  Any zero lot line development approved hereunder shall have a minimum of three (3) and no more than ten (10) attached single-family dwellings in a row. 
h.  Each lot shall be owned in fee simple. 
i  The alteration of any development plan approved hereunder shall nullify such approval. Such plan, as modified, must be resubmitted to the mayor and council for consideration. 
(4)  [ Appeals and variances. ] The board of planning and zoning appeals shall have no authority to grant a variance as to any issue, matter or grievance relating to an R-4 zone. The mayor and council shall act directly on any appeal related to an R-4 zoning matter. Any request for relief from the requirements of the R-4 zone, to include request for variance, shall be considered as part of the R-4 zoning application, and in conjunction therewith all decisions of the mayor and council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 97-10, § 2, 2-25-97; Ord. No. 06-23, §§ 1-6, 8-22-06; Ord. No. 08-16, § 1, 6-26-08; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 14-06, §§ 7, 8, 4-22-14; Ord. No. 14-13, § 13, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 25-35-73. - R-5 residential single-family district. 
    The R-5 residential single-family district is established to achieve a more efficient use of land as compared with the typical single-family development in order to meet the changing demographic needs of city citizens and to maximize usage of municipal infrastructure. 
(1)  Principal uses: 
a.  Single-family dwellings; 
b.  Churches and their customary uses, including cemeteries, provided that all buildings and graves shall be set back at least thirty-five (35) feet from the front property line and twenty (20) feet from any other property line; 
c.  Noncommercial horticulture or agriculture; 
d.  Educational buildings, swimming pools, playgrounds, parks, community centers and other recreational and educational facilities operated on a nonprofit basis, and golf courses; 
e.  Public and private elementary and secondary schools, but not schools primarily engaged in commercial or industrial trade education, provided all such uses are located not less than fifty (50) feet from any property line; 
f.  Public works and public utility facilities such as distribution lines, transmission lines and towers, electric substations, water tanks and towers, pumping stations, water treatment plants, telephone exchanges and fire stations provided: 
1.  Such facilities are essential to the service of the immediate area; 
2.  Outside storage of vehicles or materials on the premises shall not be permitted; 
3.  All buildings and facilities as allowed in subsection (f) shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from all property lines and shall be designed and landscaped in such a way as to blend in with the surrounding area; 
4.  All dangerous apparatus shall be enclosed by a chain link fence at least eight (8) feet in height; 
5.  A densely planted and maintained buffer strip shall be maintained along the rear and side lot lines. Such buffer shall not extend nearer to a street right-of-way line than the established building setback line of the adjoining lots; and 
6.  Water and sewer lines must be available for the proposed development. 
(2)  By special use permit: Group residential facility and group treatment facility, when authorized by the mayor and council in accord with section 25-35-14. 
(3)  Accessory uses: 
a.  Private swimming pools; 
b.  Nurseries and greenhouses; and 
c.  Other accessory uses that are clearly incidental to the permanent structure. 
(4)  R-5 residential single-family district development: Any applicant for a development under this Code section shall submit with the application a development plan indicating compliance with the following criteria: 
a.  Plans must be submitted to the department of community and economic development (DCED) and shall be reviewed by the DCED, department of utilities and department of public services, after which a report on the development along with each department's comments will be issued to the mayor and council. 
b.  Site plan specifications: The applicant for a development under this section shall furnish a preliminary development plan for the entire development indicating the following: 
1.  Total number of lots for entire development; and 
2.  Planned amenities such as pools, pool houses, tennis courts, etc. 
(5)  Development and lot size: 
a.  The minimum lot width and road frontage within the R-5 district shall be forty (40) feet. 
b.  The minimum lot size per dwelling in an R-5 zoning classification development shall be as follows: 
1.  For an R-5 zoning classification development of ten (10) acres or less, the minimum lot size per dwelling unit shall be no less than four thousand (4,000) square feet. 
2.  For an R-5 zoning classification development between ten (10) and up to twenty (20) acres in size, the minimum lot size per dwelling unit shall be no less than five thousand (5,000) square feet. 
3.  For an R-5 zoning classification development in excess of twenty (20) acres in size, the minimum lot size per dwelling unit shall be no less than six thousand (6,000) square feet. 
(6)  Setbacks: 
a.  Front yard, minimum of twenty (20) feet from front property line; 
b.  Rear yard, minimum of twenty (20) feet from rear property line; 
c.  Side yard, a minimum of eight (8) feet for a three (3) story building and a minimum of five (5) feet for a building with two (2) stories or less. Each corner lot must have a side yard setback of no less than fifteen (15) feet. 
(7)  Building space: Each applicant shall designate and seek zoning for one of the following classifications: 
a.  R-5, A-800 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than eight hundred (800) square feet of heated area exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
b.  R-5, A-1000 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than one thousand (1,000) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
c.  R-5, A-1200 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than twelve hundred (1200) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
d.  R-5, A-1400 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than fourteen hundred (1400) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
e.  R-5, A-1500 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than fifteen hundred (1500) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
f.  R-5, A-1600 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than sixteen hundred (1600) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
g.  R-5, A-1800 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than eighteen hundred (1800) square feet of heated area, exclusive of porches, basements and garages. 
h.  R-5, A-2000 single-family dwelling. No dwelling residence shall be erected on any lot that has fewer than two thousand (2,000) square feet of heated area, exclusive or porches, basements and garages. 
(8)  Parking and driveways. Off-street parking shall be provided as required in section 25-35-6 of this Code. Within an R-5 zoning classification development, each driveway serving an individual unit shall be no less than sixteen (16) feet in paved width for a unit equipped with a garage, and no less than twenty (20) feet in paved width for a unit with no garage. 
(9)  Structure height. The height of any building erected on any lot shall not exceed twenty-five (25) feet in height to the eave on the front side of any residence. 
(10)  Lot coverage ratio. No dwelling unit (which shall for the purposes of this subsection include the heated area plus any garage(s)) shall cover greater than sixty (60) percent of the lot area. 
(11)  Landscaping and greenspace. 
a.  The yards of all lots within the development shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds, from the front property line to not less than thirty (30) feet beyond the rear exterior wall of the dwelling residence (or to the rear property line, whichever is lesser), and extending to the side property lines. 
b.  Upon each lot shall be planted at least two (2) trees, with at least one (1) of the trees being located in the front yard. Further, there shall be at least one (1) additional tree for each one thousand (1,000) feet of disturbed area on such lot in excess of the four thousand (4,000) square foot minimum lot size. 
c.  Except within developments of ten (10) acres or less, at least five (5) percent of the overall development shall be developed as and restricted to greenspace. As used herein, the term "greenspace" shall mean an area, or combination of areas, which shall be developed as a natural area or be relandscaped, and which contribute to the aesthetics or functionality of the development, all in accordance with plans submitted to, and subject to review, approval or required modification by, the director of community and economic development. The decision of the director may be appealed to the planning commission, which appeal shall be heard and decided within sixty (60) days of its filing. 
(12)  Sidewalks. Sidewalks are not required within an R-5 residential development. However, city staff is authorized to consider and approve a more narrow street width within a development if the application for development includes sidewalks. 
(13)  Buffers. A buffer shall be provided along any side or rear property line abutting a less intense zoning district as required in section 25-11-55 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 01-28, § 1, 10-23-01; Ord. No. 06-24, §§ 1, 2, 8-22-06; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 10-15, § 14, 8-24-10; Ord. No. 14-06, § 9, 4-22-14; Ord. No. 14-13, § 14, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 25-35-74. - MXD zone, mixed use development. 
(1)  Purpose and objectives of zone. It is the objective of this zone to establish procedures and standards for the implementation of comprehensively planned, multi-use projects. It is also intended that this zone provide a more flexible approach to the comprehensive design and development of multi-use projects than the procedures and regulations applicable under the various conventional zoning categories. In so doing, it is intended that this zoning category be utilized to foster an overall improved development pattern that emulates the early twentieth century development pattern of LaGrange, which is still found within the historic areas of the city. The specific purposes of the zone are: 
(a)  To encourage orderly, staged development of comprehensively planned, multi-use centers by providing procedures for various zoning and plan approvals, including development phasing; 
(b)  To encourage design flexibility and coordination of architectural style of buildings and signage; 
(c)  To ensure the integration and internal compatibility of applicable residential and nonresidential uses by providing a suitable residential environment that is enhanced and complimented by commercial, recreational, open space, employment and institutional uses and amenities within all land use components of the multi-use project; 
(d)  To ensure compatibility of the proposed land uses with internal and surrounding uses by incorporating higher standards of land planning and site design than could be accomplished under conventional zoning categories and to provide a superior quality of development exceeding that which could be achieved under conventional zoning regulations and procedures; 
(e)  To encourage the efficient use of land by: locating employment and retail uses convenient to residential areas; reducing reliance on automobile use and encouraging pedestrian and other non-vehicular circulations systems; retaining and providing usable open space and active recreation areas close to employment and residential population; and providing for the development of comprehensive non-vehicular circulation networks, separated from vehicular roadways, which constitute a system of linkages among residential areas, open spaces, recreational areas, commercial and employment areas, and public facilities; 
(f)  To provide a superior natural environment by the preservation of trees, natural topographic geologic features, wetlands, watercourses, and open space; and 
(g)  To allow development only in a staged or phased fashion to ensure the adequacy for the provision of public facilities and the concurrent implementation of community amenities. 
    The MXD zoning classification and accompanying development plans may be approved upon findings that the application is proper for the comprehensive and systematic development of the city, is capable of accomplishing the purposes of this zone, is an internally and externally compatible form of development and is consistent with any applicable planning and land use policies of the city. In order to enable the city to evaluate the conformance with the standards contained herein, specific sets of plans shall be submitted in accord with subsection (8) herein, and the city is authorized to approve said plan or plans if such plans are found sufficient to accomplish the above purposes in compliance with the standards and requirements of this zone. 
(2)  Minimum size, location, and development requirements. 
(a)  Minimum area. No land shall be classified in the MXD zone unless it contains a minimum of four (4) acres. Parcels or tracts less than the minimum acreage may be permitted if they are contiguous to an existing MXD zoned area and may be harmoniously integrated into the MXD area, consistent with the objectives and purposes of this zone. 
(b)  Location. Such land shall be located adjacent to and readily accessible from existing or planned roadways that are in an approved construction program and are adequate to service the proposed development. It is intended that adequate access be available to such sites so that traffic does not have an adverse impact on the surrounding area or cause internal circulation or safety problems. 
(c)  Public water and sewer. No development shall be permitted unless served by public water and sewer. 
(d)  Signage. Signs shall be allowed in accordance with the specifications and standards established in the final site plan. 
(e)  Frontage on public streets. Anything to the contrary notwithstanding in any regulation in this Code, lots in this zone shall not be required to have direct access to a public street provided that such condition will promote the creation of affordable housing, or will be designed in such a way as to foster the purposes and objectives of this zone, provided that satisfactory access to a public street is provided over private rights-of-way. 
(f)  Connectivity. Parcels shall not be zoned MXD unless configured to connect to adjacent streets and promote the overall connectivity and increased circulation of pedestrians and vehicles within the city. 
(g)  Revitalization. Parcels of land that are currently developed and in need of revitalization due to the existence of under utilized land or buildings, and dilapidated homes and commercial buildings, should be strongly considered for the MXD zone in order to foster redevelopment and revitalization of the said parcels or areas of the city. 
(h)  Large undeveloped land tracts. Large undeveloped land tracts within the city or land that could be reasonably annexed into the city shall be considered for the MXD zone in order for the city to be planed in a more comprehensive and less piecemeal manner. Large tracts of land should be zoned MXD to include a mix of land uses instead of being developed under one conventional zoning category in order to meet the purposes and objectives of this zone. 
(i)  Traditional neighborhood development principles. Land developed in the MXD zone should be developed consistent with the principles of traditional neighborhood developments, which emulate the historic pattern of development in the city and will be generally more compatible with existing developed areas of the city. These principles are listed below: 
1.  Walkability: Most daily needs can be satisfied within a five- to ten-minute walk of home and work (quarter- to half-mile radius). Pedestrian-friendly street design includes buildings close to the street, front porches, continuous tree cover, on-street parking, hidden parking lots, garages relegated to a rear lane, and narrow, slow-speed vehicular trajectories. 
2.  Connectivity: An interconnected street grid network disperses traffic and increases walkability by allowing most streets to be narrow. A high quality pedestrian network and public realm makes walking comfortable, pleasant, and interesting. 
3.  Mixed-use: A mix of shops, offices, apartments, houses, recreation, and institutional uses on site. Mixed-use within the neighborhood, within the block, and within buildings. 
4.  Diverse housing: A range of types, tenures, sizes, and prices located in close proximity. 
5.  High-quality architecture and urban design: Emphasis on aesthetics, human comfort, and creating a sense of place. Special placement of civic buildings and sites within the community. Human-scale architecture and beautiful surroundings to nourish the spirit. 
6.  Traditional neighborhood structure: Discernable center and edge. Limited size of a maximum of one (1) mile across. 
7.  Increased density: More buildings, residences, shops, and services closer together, to encourage walking and to enable a more efficient use of resources and time. 
8.  Smart transportation: A transportation network connecting neighborhoods, business districts, cities and towns together. Pedestrian-friendly design encourages a greater use of walking, bicycles, roller-blades, and scooters as daily transportation. 
9.  Sustainable: Minimal environmental impact of development and its operations. Less use of finite land and fuel resources, more local production. 
10.  Quality of life: Taken together, all of the above contribute to an improved quality of life for community residents and for the human community as a whole. 
(3)  Uses permitted. 
(a)  Residential. All types of residential uses allowed by right or by special exception in all residential zoning districts shall be permitted, as well as accessory uses thereto. 
1.  The location and type of all residential uses proposed on the site must be shown on the plan submitted in accordance with the requirements of subsection (8) of this section, with the level of specificity increasing at each level of plan review. 
2.  Residential uses may be mixed with proposed commercial/industrial/employment uses, rather than located in a separate residential area on the site, upon a finding by the city council that combining residential and non-residential uses at one location, within a site, will not adversely affect the overall development proposed. 
3.  A lot intended for use for a single-family detached dwelling unit may contain both a principle dwelling unit and an urban cottage under the following restrictions and conditions: 
a.  Maximum floor area of an urban cottage shall be nine hundred (900) square feet of heated, interior space in size. 
b.  Maximum height of an urban cottage shall be two and one-half (21/2) stories or thirty (30) feet. 
c.  There shall be not more than one urban cottage per lot. 
d.  One (1) parking space shall be provided to specifications set forth in the zoning ordinance for each urban cottage. 
e.  Urban cottages shall be counted toward the maximum number of dwelling units permitted in an MXD zoned development. 
f.  In addition to compliance with all applicable city codes and regulations including, but not limited to, those dealing with buildings, fire safety, health and sanitation, property maintenance and rental housing licensing, the construction, occupancy and use of urban cottages shall be controlled by the following restrictions: 
(aa)  The principal residence shall be at least twice the size of the urban cottage. 
(bb)  All urban cottages must comply with the applicable housing code of the city and state set forth for single-family dwellings. 
(cc)  Occupancy of an urban cottage shall be in accordance with the following schedule: 
Unit Size 
(Square Feet) Maximum Occupants 0-699 2 700-899 3  
(b)  Commercial/employment/industrial. All uses allowed by right or by special exception in the C-1, C-2, C-3, OIR-1 and P-1 zones are permitted uses, except for the following uses, which are specifically prohibited: 
Adult entertainment establishments 
Sexually oriented businesses 
Manufacture, compounding, and processing of goods and articles 
Drive-in theaters 
Automobile paint and body repair shops 
Any use identified in a GI or HI zone 
Any agricultural use that includes the keeping or selling of animals (except domestic animals such as dogs, cats or birds) 
1.  The approximate location and general type of commercial, employment and industrial uses proposed on the site must be shown on sketch plan and schematic development plan submitted in accord with subsection (8) herein, with the level of specificity increasing at each level of plan review. 
2.  In order to establish and appropriately mixed character within the entire MXD-zoned area, the following percentages of floor area proposed on site as shown on a sketch plan shall not exceed: 
Retail commercial ..... 60% 
Employment/office ..... 65% 
Other commercial/institutional ..... 15% 
3.  The percentage of floor area within the entire MXD-zoned area proposed on site as shown on a sketch plan shall not be less than thirty (30) percent. 
(4)  Density and intensity of development. 
(a)  Residential. The total number of dwelling units and the corresponding density, as well as the approximate location of such units, shall be established at the time of sketch plan approval pursuant to subsection (8) herein. 
(b)  Lot size supporting commercial facilities and mixed use facilities may be authorized up to one hundred (100) percent lot coverage, provided a parking plan identifying parking alternatives in the immediate vicinity of the building, acceptable to the DRP, is developed for the proposed building. 
(c)  Building heights may not exceed forty-five (45) feet unless waived by the DRP. 
(5)  Minimum green area, landscaping and amenity requirements. 
(a)  The amount of green area, including designated parks, public and private open space, active and passive recreational areas, required for the residential portion of a mixed use development shall be not less than forty (40) percent of the total area shown for residential use. The minimum green area requirement, which shall include designated parks, public and private open space, active and passive recreational areas, for the commercial/employment/industrial portion of a mixed use development shall be not less than twenty-five (25) percent of the total area devoted to commercial/employment/industrial uses, except that comparable amenities and/or facilities may be provided in lieu of green area if the DRP determines that such amenities or facilities are sufficient to accomplish the purposes of the zone, and would be more beneficial to the proposed development than strict adherence to the specific green area requirement. 
(b)  All recreation areas, facilities and amenities, and all open space and landscaped areas, shall be reflected on the application for MXD zone and sketch plan approval stage approved by the DRP. With respect to such areas, facilities and amenities, the site plan or accompanying documents shall reflect: 
1.  That such areas, facilities or amenities shall not be constructed, converted or used for any purposes other than reflected and designated on the site plan unless said plan is amended by prior written consent of the DRP. 
2.  A staging or construction timetable specifying the construction of all recreational areas, facilities and amenities. This staging or construction timetable may be related to the number of residential units under construction or complete, or population levels, or other appropriate standard. The adherence to the performance of such timetable may, at the discretion of the DRP be secured by appropriate bond, letter of credit or security acceptable to the city or by the withholding and suspension of all permits for any project lying within the designated MXD zone. Subsequent to the completion of work, the city manager is authorized to declare as abandoned and forfeited any cash bond posted pursuant to a requirement of this chapter, and to relinquish proceeds thereof to the general treasury of the city, when after giving the applicant or permittee who posted the cash bond thirty (30) days' written notice first by registered mail, and if unclaimed by first-class mail, such applicant or permittee fails to request of the city the return of the cash bond. Upon failure to request of the city the return of the cash bond, as provided herein, the applicant or permittee, its successors, heirs and assigns relinquish all claim to said bond. 
a.  A detailed plan with copies of proposed supporting covenants to be filed among the land records prior to the issuance of building permits, which shall enumerate the property owner's and all successors' obligations for perpetual maintenance of all common areas, green space, recreation areas, facilities and amenities, and all common landscaped areas. 
(6)  Public facilities and utilities. Roads must conform to standards set in the thoroughfare design standards adopted by the city. All utilities shall be underground for MXD developments. 
(7)  Parking requirements. In addition to any other requirements of this Code section, off-street parking shall be provided as follows: 
The DRP, at the time of schematic development plan review, shall determine the appropriate number of spaces. At the time of final site plan approval, the DRP shall determine the final number of spaces, based upon considerations of safety, convenience, pedestrian and vehicular circulation, and added landscaping within parking lot areas. In addition, the DRP may reduce the number of spaces required for any use allowed in the MXD zone where such reduction will meet the purposes of the MXD zone. 
(8)  Application and processing procedures. Procedures for governing the application for the MXD zone and approvals necessary to seek building permits shall be subject to the following multiple step process: 
(a)  Application for sketch plan approval. 
1.  An applicant shall file, together with the prescribed application fee, an application for sketch plan approval as provided by the city, and in addition, shall submit for approval as part of the application for separate approval, a sketch plan reflecting at a minimum, the following: 
a.  The boundaries of the entire tract or parcel. 
b.  The location size, capacity and elevation of all utilities and roads located on all adjacent lands. 
c.  Generalized location of existing and proposed external roads and adjacent land use and development. 
d.  Generalized location and description of various internal proposed land use components, including information as to proposed densities and intensities, proposed size and heights of development. 
e.  Generalized location, description and timing of proposed roads, proposed dedicated public lands and perimeter setback or buffer areas. 
f.  Proposed phasing or staging plan of development, public facilities and information pertaining to the provision of public facilities as required by the city master plan. 
g.  Generalized areas of woodlands, streams and watercourses and other areas intended for natural preservation, as well as an approved forest stand delineation or tree inventory as required by the city tree ordinance (section 25-11-35 et seq.). 
h.  Identify the initial development phase, which would act as a demonstration area for the implementation of the urban and architectural code of the community. This area could also serve as the model home area for builders. 
i.  An illustrative plan providing for the physical layout of the entire development including all streets, lots, parcels, park and open spaces. 
j.  A draft of urban and architectural standards to govern covenants and to be managed by the homeowners association and to act as the MXD compliance document. 
2.  During the sketch plan approval phase, the DRP and developer will engage in meetings and planning sessions to attempt to reach consensus upon an acceptable plan. 
(b)  Application for schematic development plan approval. (Application for the MXD zone) 
1.  A schematic development plan shall be filed for approval, rejection or modification by the DRP of all or portions of the area zoned MXD and reflected within the approved sketch plan, together with the required filing fee. The schematic development plan shall be scaled at one (1) inch equals fifty (50) feet and shall contain, at a minimum, the following: 
a.  Boundary survey and identification plat or survey plat. 
b.  The use(s) of all buildings and structures within the schematic development plan area, as well as existing uses of adjacent property external to the MXD zoned area and proposed uses within adjoining MXD zoned areas. 
c.  The location, height, approximate dimensions and conceptual architectural elevations of all buildings and structures, and the setbacks and densities and/or square footage thereof. 
d.  The location of points of access to the site and all public and private roads, pedestrian and bike paths, in accordance with the applicable thoroughfare design standards. 
e.  The location and setbacks of all parking areas. 
f.  Existing topography including: 
(aa)  Contour intervals of not more than two (2) feet; 
(bb)  An approved forest stand delineation or tree survey of all trees with a diameter at breast height of twenty-four (24) inches or larger; 
(cc)  One-hundred-year flood- 
plains and floodways including base flood elevations; 
(dd)  Other natural features, such as rock outcropping and scenic views; 
(ee)  Utility easements, if any; and 
(ff)  Historic buildings, structures or areas. 
g.  All landscaped areas, proposed conceptual screen planting, open spaces, plazas, malls, courts, commercial signage standards, community identification signage, recreation and amenity areas. 
h.  Proposed phasing or staging plan of development and information relating to such plan's consistency with the provision of public facilities. 
i.  A proposed covenant or other form of agreement indicating how the area will be included in any homeowners association or other organization, and how any open space, community space or amenities located with the area subject to review will be perpetually maintained. 
j.  Eight (8) copies of required preliminary plan/plat submittal for review process (eighteen (18) [inches] by twenty-four (24) [inches]) or of a size acceptable to the director of community and economic development. All plats and supporting information shall also be submitted in digital format as may be required by the director of community and economic development; 
k.  Two (2) copies of previous plat; 
l.  Two (2) drawings that inventory all hardwood trees in excess of twelve (12) inches in diameter, all wetlands, all watercourses and impoundments, and floodplain limits; 
m.  Two (2) copies of the erosion and sedimentation control plan; 
n.  Two (2) copies of the stormwater management plan; 
o.  Three (3) copies (as required in a format outlined in this section) of the utility development plan (water, sewer, gas, electric, telecommunications); 
p.  Transportation plan showing the interconnection on the subdivision and its relationship to all adjoining properties; 
q.  Required fees; 
r.  Project narrative to include description of the type of project and who it will serve, developer information, contractor information, engineer information, contact information, anticipated start dates, completion dates, phasing description (if applicable), description of utility development plans including main sizes, lift station information, communications deployment plan and schedule, stormwater planning narrative, impact statement describing projects effects on surrounding transportation including traffic counts and flows from proposed project and existing counts, a narrative description of how traffic will be managed and controlled (and calmed) as appropriate for the development, description of greenspace and public/community space proposed for the project; and 
s.  Application must be signed by owner, developer and engineer (licensed in Georgia with stamp affixed). 
2.  The DRP shall take action on the application within ninety (90) days after the application is deemed complete. 
3.  Upon approval of the application by the DRP, the developer may file a request for rezoning to MXD by the procedures required within the zoning ordinance. 
(c)  Final site plan review. Following approval of a schematic development plan and rezoning, an applicant shall submit to the DRP a final site plan for approval, which shall be in accord with the approved schematic development plan and shall include the following: 
1.  All information required pursuant to subsection (8)(b) above; 
2.  Proposed phasing or staging plan of development and information regarding consistency of such plan with the provision of public facilities; 
3.  Demonstration of compliance with the approved schematic development plan; 
4.  A proposed covenant, suitable for filing in the deed records of Troup County, which shall indicate in specific language that the property which is the subject of the application is restricted in its use and/or development standards to the schematic development plan and any accompanying or qualifying text material submitted with such plan, as such plan may be approved or modified by the DRP at the time of final site plan review. The covenant to be filed in the deed records shall also indicate that such restrictions shall be in effect until such time as the property may be rezoned, at which time such restrictions shall be removed; and 
5.  A site plan enforcement agreement to be signed by the applicant and the city, requiring the applicant to execute all of the features shown on the site plan and the sequence and timing when said features will be completed. The DRP may in its sole discretion require that a bond, letter of credit or other security of a duration and amount acceptable to the city secure the performance of the terms of the agreement. Subsequent to the completion of work, the city manager is authorized to declare as abandoned and forfeited, any cash bond posted pursuant to a requirement of this chapter, and relinquish proceeds thereof to the general treasury of the city, when after giving the applicant or permittee who posted the cash bond thirty (30) days' written notice first by registered mail, and if unclaimed by first-class mail, such applicant or permittee fails to request of the city the return of the cash bond. Upon failure to request of the city return of the cash bond, as provided herein, the applicant or permittee, its successors, heirs and assigns relinquish all claim to said cash bond. The city shall also have the authority to suspend and withhold any and all permits for any work lying within the MXD zone to assure compliance with the standards and requirements set forth for the designated zone. 
6.  The final site plan shall also comply with those requirements for a final subdivision plan as set forth in section 25-20-11 of this Code. 
(9)  Findings required. 
(a)  The city shall approve MXD zoning and the accompanying schematic development plan only upon finding that: 
1.  The application meets or accomplishes the purposes, objectives, and minimum standards and requirements of the zone; and 
2.  The application and sketch plan will be internally and externally compatible and harmonious with existing and planned uses in the MXD zoned areas and adjacent areas. 
(b)  The DRP shall approve a schematic development plan only upon a finding that: 
1.  The plan is substantially in accord with the approved sketch plan; and 
2.  The plan meets or accomplishes the purposes, objectives and minimum standards and requirements of the zone; and 
3.  The plan will be internally and externally compatible and harmonious with existing and planned uses in the MXD zoned areas and adjacent areas; and 
4.  The existing or planned public facilities are adequate to service the proposed development contained in the plan; and 
5.  The development staging or phasing program is adequate in relation to the provision of public facilities and private amenities to service the proposed development; and 
6.  The plan, if approved, would be in the public interest. 
(c)  The DRP shall approve a final site plan consistent with the findings required in subsection (b) immediately above and upon considerations, determinations and powers set forth in this section. The DRP shall, as a condition of approval, require the posting of all necessary bonds or other security instruments, the execution of required agreements, and recording of covenants. 
(10)  Procedures for amendment. Amendments to a final site plan may be permitted, and are to be approved by the DRP in accordance with the submission requirements of this chapter. 
(11)  Urban and architectural regulations adopted as part of sketch plans. 
(a)  The mayor and council shall adopt, as part of a schematic development plan in the MXD zone, an urban and architectural code as regulations, rules or standards specific and unique to the application under consideration. 
(b)  Such rules, regulations and standards shall apply to: 
1.  Building/structure setbacks and lot coverage; 
2.  The location and type of accessory buildings and structures; 
3.  Type and nature of accessory uses; and 
4.  Appearance of buildings and structures, configuration of building elements and type of building materials. 
Provided however, no such rules, regulations and standards shall exceed any maximum development standard or be less than any minimum development standard or permit any use otherwise prohibited in the MXD zone. All owners of property subject to the final site plan and their assigns shall be notified (by the developer) of such rules, regulations and standards at the time of taking title to property located within the final site plan area. 
(c)  No person, firm or corporation may violate any requirement of this chapter, to include but not limited to deviation from the requirements of the final site plan, and any such violation shall be enforceable by the city and subject to such enforcement and penalties provided by section 1-1-6 of this Code. 
(d)  A community architect shall be commissioned by the developer as a method of ensuring compliance with the urban and architectural code. Said architect shall be retained by the developer and/or homeowner's association until such time as the last lot in the MXD zone at issue is developed. 
(12)  Time for approval, disapproval; appeal. 
(a)  For each submission (application for sketch plan approval, application for schematic development plan approval, and application for final site plan approval) the DRP shall have ninety (90) days to either disapprove or approve the application. If an application is disapproved, the grounds for disapproval shall be stated in writing and transmitted to the subdivider. 
(b)  Such decisions of the DRP regarding application approval or disapproval may be appealed upon written request to the board of planning and zoning appeals within thirty (30) days after written notification of the decision by the DRP has been transmitted by the director of community and economic development to the applicant. The board shall hear and decide whether there is an error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the DRP or other city official based on this Code section. A hearing on the appeal shall be scheduled and heard by the board not later than forty-five (45) days after receipt of the appeal request. At the appeal hearing, the DRP shall make a full report of findings to the board as to actions taken, requirements made, and conditions that have been set relative to the development. The applicant shall likewise be allowed to present its argument on appeal to the board. Appeal filing fees shall be as established by the mayor and council. 
(c)  Any applicant aggrieved by the decision of the board of planning and zoning appeals may seek judicial review by filing for a writ of certiorari in the Superior Court of Troup County within thirty (30) days of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 02-39, § 1, 12-10-02; Ord. No. 08-08, § 12, 4-8-08; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 25-35-75. - Downtown District. 
    All provisions of and requirements for the Downtown District zone are codified in chapter 25-10 (Signs) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 93-67, § 3, 12-28-93; Ord. No. 96-42, § 1(p), 6-25-96; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 25-35-76. - High density residential - limited use zone (HDR-LU) district. 
    The regulations of the HDR-LU district are designed to allow higher density development of single-family residential areas with elements designed in order to provide the basic elements of a balanced, orderly, convenient, walkable and attractive residential area. Within the HDR-LU zoning district, the following uses shall be permitted: 
(1)  Principal uses: 
a.  Single-family dwellings: The square footage of living space per dwelling, which space shall be defined as heated, interior space exclusive of vehicular parking areas, shall be a minimum of nine hundred (900) square feet; 
b.  Swimming pools, playgrounds, parks, community centers and other recreational and educational facilities operated on a nonprofit basis, and golf courses; 
c.  Public works and public utility facilities such as distribution lines, transmission lines and towers, electric substations, water tanks and towers, pumping stations, water treatment plants, telephone exchanges and fire stations, provided: 
1.  Such facilities are essential to the service of the immediate area; 
2.  Outside storage of vehicles or materials on the premises shall not be permitted; and 
3.  All buildings and facilities shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from all property lines and shall be designed and landscaped in such a way as to blend in with the surrounding area. 
(2)  Home occupations: As defined in section 25-35-2, when authorized by the building official. 
(3)  By special use permit: Group residential facility and group treatment facility, when authorized by the mayor and council in accord with section 25-35-14. 
(4)  Accessory uses: 
a.  Customary accessory buildings or uses shall be permitted only in a rear yard, shall be situated not less than ten (10) feet from any property line, and shall not exceed fifteen (15) feet in height; on corner lots such accessory use shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from any side street right-of-way line. 
b.  Signs: Signs shall be allowed only in accordance with the applicable provisions of chapter 25-10 (Signs) of this Code. 
(5)  Off-street parking requirements: As provided in section 25-35-6. 
(6)  Dimensional requirements: Within any HDR-LU residential district, the following dimensional requirements shall apply: 
a.  The minimum size of an HDR-LU classification development shall be five (5) acres; 
b.  Density shall not exceed five (5) units per acre, with such calculation to be made by dividing the number of dwelling units into the size (acres) of the development excluding public rights-of-way and floodplain area; 
c.  Dwelling units shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from the front lot line, five (5) feet from the side lot line, and fifteen (15) feet from any street; 
d.  Minimum building line width, forty (40) feet; 
e.  Minimum lot frontage, forty (40) feet; 
f.  Minimum lot depth, one hundred (100) feet; 
g.  Principal building height maximum, thirty (30) feet; and 
h.  Principal building coverage ratio to lot, maximum thirty-five (35) percent. 
i.  A buffer shall be provided along any side or rear property line abutting a less intense zoning district as required in section 25-11-55 of this Code. 
(7)  Landscaping and greenspace requirements: 
a.  For lots smaller than seven thousand (7,000) square feet, the front, rear and side yards shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds; 
b.  For lots larger than seven thousand (7,000) square feet, the front and side yards shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds; and 
c.  Upon each lot shall be planted at least two (2) trees; however, two existing trees shall be allowed in lieu of planting if said trees are of the type listed within the tree selection list (Code section 25-11-40) and are approved by the building official. 
(8)  Architectural controls: 
a.  Roof pitch for the primary roof structure shall be a minimum of 6:12; 
b.  Roof materials shall be asphalt, fiberglass shingle, cedar, slate or standing seam metal; 
c.  HVAC units shall be either physically located or screened with vegetative or fence buffer so as not to be visible from the right-of-way; 
d.  Garages must enter from rear or side yard or, in the alternative, must be equipped with a garage door; 
e.  Shared driveways are not permitted; 
f.  All utilities shall be underground; 
g.  Street lights shall be required in type and number as determined by city; 
h.  No duplicate exterior elevations (front facade designs) including similar massing shall be constructed on the same street within one hundred twenty-five (125) linear feet in either direction, measured from the center of the front property line. The developer/builder will be responsible for providing documentation certifying compliance with this requirement prior to issuance of any building permit; 
i.  The use of gables, dormers, cornices, chimneys and other design features shall be used to enhance the overall appearance of the homes; 
j.  Exterior materials shall be constructed or clad in either stone, wood, stucco, brick or hardy plank (vinyl may be incorporated around the soffit, gables, eaves and window area for trim); 
k.  Five (5) feet wide sidewalks shall be required on one (1) side of the public right-of-way; and 
l.  The maximum impervious surface of any lot shall not exceed sixty (60) percent. 
(9)  Recreation amenity requirements: For any HDR-LU district development consisting of forty (40) or more dwelling units, the five (5) percent public space requirement shall be for active recreational amenities such as: 
a.  Outdoor playground equipment; 
b.  Picnic area (minimum one (1) table per forty (40) dwelling units); 
c.  Tennis court; 
d.  Basketball court; 
e.  Horseshoe or other lawn activity; 
f.  Walking trail; 
g.  Open park space; and 
h.  Other recreation amenity designed for common use as approved by the director of community development. 
Such recreation amenities must be completed upon the issuance of building permits for fifty (50) percent of the lots within the development. An applicant must submit with the application a documented plan, acceptable to city, providing for perpetual maintenance of such public space. 
(10)  Development requirements: Any applicant for a development under this Code section shall submit with the application a development plan indicating compliance with the criteria required within this Code section, including but not limited to a site plan and landscape plan. 
a.  Plans must be submitted to the department of community development and shall be reviewed by said department, department of utilities and department of public services, after which a report on the development along with each department's comments will be issued to the mayor and council; and 
b.  Site plan specifications: The applicant for a development under this Code section shall also furnish a preliminary development plan for the entire development indicating the following: 
1.  Total number of lots for entire development; and 
2.  Planned amenities such as pools, pool houses, tennis courts, etc. 
(Ord. No. 07-30, § 1, 12-11-07; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 10-15, § 15, 8-24-10; Ord. No. 14-13, § 15, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 25-35-77. - R-7 residential district. 
    The regulations of the R-7 district are designed to work in conjunction with the other residential districts in the code to provide a variety of residential neighborhoods with differing densities and elements of public amenities in order to provide the basic elements of balanced, orderly, convenient, walkable and attractive residential areas. Within the R-7 zoning district, the following uses shall be permitted: 
(1)  Principal uses: 
a.  Single-family dwellings: The square footage of living space per dwelling, which space shall be defined as heated, interior space exclusive of vehicular parking areas, shall be a minimum of 1200 square feet; 
b.  Swimming pools, playgrounds, parks, community centers and other recreational and educational facilities operated on a nonprofit basis, and golf courses; and 
c.  Public works and public utility facilities such as distribution lines, transmission lines and towers, electric substations, water tanks and towers, pumping stations, water treatment plants, telephone exchanges and fire stations, provided: 
1.  Such facilities are essential to the service of the immediate area; 
2.  Outside storage of vehicles or materials on the premises shall not be permitted; and 
3.  All buildings and facilities shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from all property lines and shall be designed and landscaped in such a way as to blend in with the surrounding area. 
(2)  Home occupations: As defined in section 25-35-2, when authorized by the building official. 
(3)  By special use permit: Group residential facility and group treatment facility, when authorized by the mayor and council in accord with section 25-35-14. 
(4)  Accessory uses: 
a.  Customary accessory buildings or uses shall be permitted only in a rear yard, shall be situated not less than ten (10) feet from any property line, and shall not exceed fifteen (15) feet in height; on corner lots such accessory use shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from any side street right-of-way line. 
b.  Signs: Signs shall be allowed only in accordance with the applicable provisions of chapter 25-10 (Signs) of this Code. 
(5)  Off-street parking requirements: As provided in City Code section 25-35-6. 
(6)  Dimensional requirements: Within any R-7 residential district, the following dimensional requirements shall apply: 
a.  The minimum size of an R-7 classification development shall be one (1) acre, and the maximum size of an R-7 residential district shall be five (5) acres; 
b.  The minimum lot size shall be no less than seven thousand (7,000) square feet. Density shall not exceed five (5) units per acre, with such calculation to be made by dividing the number of dwelling units into the size (acres) of the development excluding public rights-of-way and floodplain area; 
c.  Dwelling units shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from the front lot line, seven and one-half (7.5) feet from the side lot line, twenty (20) feet from the rear lot line and fifteen (15) feet from any street; 
d.  Minimum building line width, forty (40) feet; 
e.  Minimum lot frontage, forty (40) feet; 
f.  Minimum lot depth, one hundred (100) feet; 
g.  Principal building height maximum, thirty (30) feet; and 
h.  Principal building coverage ratio to lot, maximum thirty-five (35) percent, and the maximum impervious surface of any lot shall not exceed sixty (60) percent. 
(7)  Landscaping, greenspace and sidewalk requirements: 
a.  The front, side and rear yards shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds; 
b.  Upon each lot shall be planted at least two (2) trees; however, two existing trees shall be allowed in lieu of planting if said trees are of the type listed within the tree selection list (Code section 25-11-40) and are approved by the building official; and 
c.  Five (5) feet wide sidewalks shall be required on one (1) side of the public right-of-way within the development. 
(8)  Architectural controls: For any development which seeks and receives a variance from the dimensional requirements set forth in subsection (5) hereinabove, the following architectural controls shall apply to the development: 
a.  Roof pitch for the primary roof structure shall be a minimum of 6:12; 
b.  Roof materials shall be asphalt, fiberglass shingle, cedar, slate or standing seam metal; 
c.  HVAC units shall be either physically located or screened with vegetative or fence buffer so as not to be visible from the right-of-way; 
d.  Garages must enter from rear or side yard or, in the alternative, must be equipped with a garage door; 
e.  Shared driveways are not permitted; 
f.  All utilities shall be underground; 
g.  Street lights shall be required in type and number as determined by city; 
h.  No duplicate exterior elevations (front facade designs) including similar massing shall be constructed on the same street within one hundred twenty-five (125) linear feet in either direction, measured from the center of the front property line. The developer/builder will be responsible for providing documentation certifying compliance with this requirement prior to issuance of any building permit; 
i.  The use of gables, dormers, cornices, chimneys and other design features shall be used to enhance the overall appearance of the homes; and 
j.  Exterior materials shall be constructed or clad in either stone, wood, stucco, brick or hardy plank (vinyl may be incorporated around the soffit, gables, eaves and window area for trim). 
(9)  Development requirements: Any applicant for a development under this Code section shall submit with the application a development plan indicating compliance with the criteria required within this Code section, including but not limited to a site plan and landscape plan. 
a.  Plans must be submitted to the department of community development and shall be reviewed by said department, department of utilities and department of public services, after which a report on the development along with each department's comments will be issued to the mayor and council; and 
b.  Site plan specifications: The applicant for a development under this code section shall also furnish a preliminary development plan for the entire development indicating the following: 
1.  Total number of lots for entire development; and 
2.  Planned amenities such as pools, pool houses, tennis courts, etc. 
(Ord. No. 08-08, § 2, 4-8-08; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 10-15, § 16, 8-24-10) 
Sec. 25-35-78. - R-8.5 residential district. 
    The regulations of the R-8.5 district are designed to work in conjunction with the other residential districts in the code to provide a variety of residential neighborhoods with differing densities and elements of public amenities in order to provide the basic elements of balanced, orderly, convenient, walkable and attractive residential areas. Within the R-8.5 zoning district, the following uses shall be permitted: 
(1)  Principal uses: 
a.  Single-family dwellings: The square footage of living space per dwelling, which space shall be defined as heated, interior space exclusive of vehicular parking areas, shall be a minimum of one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet; and 
b.  Swimming pools, playgrounds, parks, community centers and other recreational and educational facilities operated on a nonprofit basis, and golf courses; 
c.  Public works and public utility facilities such as distribution lines, transmission lines and towers, electric substations, water tanks and towers, pumping stations, water treatment plants, telephone exchanges and fire stations, provided: 
1.  Such facilities are essential to the service of the immediate area; 
2.  Outside storage of vehicles or materials on the premises shall not be permitted; and 
3.  All buildings and facilities shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from all property lines and shall be designed and landscaped in such a way as to blend in with the surrounding area. 
(2)  Home occupations: As defined in section 25-35-2, when authorized by the building official. 
(3)  By special use permit: Group residential facility and group treatment facility, when authorized by the mayor and council in accord with section 25-35-14. 
(4)  Accessory uses: 
a.  Customary accessory buildings or uses shall be permitted only in a rear yard, shall be situated not less than ten (10) feet from any property line, and shall not exceed fifteen (15) feet in height; on corner lots such accessory use shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from any side street right-of-way line. 
b.  Signs: Signs shall be allowed only in accordance with the applicable provisions of chapter 25-10 (Signs) of this Code. 
(5)  Off-street parking requirements: As provided in City Code section 25-35-6. 
(6)  Dimensional requirements: Within any R-8.5 residential district, the following dimensional requirements shall apply: 
a.  The minimum size of an R-8.5 classification development shall be one (1) acre, and the maximum size of an R-8.5 residential district shall be ten (10) acres; 
b.  The minimum lot size shall be no less than eight thousand five hundred (8,500) square feet. Density shall not exceed five (5) units per acre, with such calculation to be made by dividing the number of dwelling units into the size (acres) of the development excluding public rights-of-way and floodplain area; 
c.  Dwelling units shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from the front lot line, ten (10) feet from the side lot line, thirty (30) feet from the rear lot line, and fifteen (15) feet from any street; 
d.  Minimum building line width, fifty (50) feet; 
e.  Minimum lot frontage, fifty (50) feet; 
f.  Minimum lot depth, none; 
g.  Principal building height maximum, thirty-five (35) feet; and 
h.  Principal building coverage ratio to lot, maximum thirty-five (35) percent, and the maximum impervious surface of any lot shall not exceed sixty (60) percent. 
(7)  Landscaping, greenspace and sidewalk requirements: 
a.  The front, side and rear yards shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds; 
b.  Upon each lot shall be planted at least two (2) trees; however, two existing trees shall be allowed in lieu of planting if said trees are of the type listed within the tree selection list (Code section 25-11-40) and are approved by the building official; and 
c.  Five (5) feet wide sidewalks shall be required on one side of the public right-of-way within the development. 
(8)  Architectural controls: For any development which seeks and receives a variance from the dimensional requirements set forth in subsection (5) hereinabove, the following architectural controls shall apply to the development: 
a.  Roof pitch for the primary roof structure shall be a minimum of 6:12; 
b.  Roof materials shall be asphalt, fiberglass shingle, cedar, slate or standing seam metal; 
c.  HVAC units shall be either physically located or screened with vegetative or fence buffer so as not to be visible from the right-of-way; 
d.  Garages must enter from rear or side yard or, in the alternative, must be equipped with a garage door; 
e.  Shared driveways are not permitted; 
f.  All utilities shall be underground; 
g.  Street lights shall be required in type and number as determined by city; 
h.  No duplicate exterior elevations (front facade designs) including similar massing shall be constructed on the same street within one hundred twenty-five (125) linear feet in either direction, measured from the center of the front property line. The developer/builder will be responsible for providing documentation certifying compliance with this requirement prior to issuance of any building permit; 
i.  The use of gables, dormers, cornices, chimneys and other design features shall be used to enhance the overall appearance of the homes; and 
j.  Exterior materials shall be constructed or clad in either stone, wood, stucco, brick or hardy plank (vinyl may be incorporated around the soffit, gables, eaves and window area for trim). 
(9)  Development requirements: Any applicant for a development under this Code section shall submit with the application a development plan indicating compliance with the criteria required within this Code section, including but not limited to a site plan and landscape plan. 
a.  Plans must be submitted to the department of community development and shall be reviewed by said department, department of utilities and department of public services, after which a report on the development along with each department's comments will be issued to the mayor and council; and 
b.  Site plan specifications: The applicant for a development under this code section shall also furnish a preliminary development plan for the entire development indicating the following: 
1.  Total number of lots for entire development; and 
2.  Planned amenities such as pools, pool houses, tennis courts, etc. 
(Ord. No. 08-08, § 2, 4-8-08; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 10-15, § 17, 8-24-10) 
Sec. 25-35-79. - R-10 residential district. 
    The regulations of the R-10 district are designed to work in conjunction with the other residential districts in the code to provide a variety of residential neighborhoods with differing densities and elements of public amenities in order to provide the basic elements of balanced, orderly, convenient, walkable and attractive residential areas. Within the R-10 zoning district, the following uses shall be permitted: 
(1)  Principal uses: 
a.  Single-family dwellings: The square footage of living space per dwelling, which space shall be defined as heated, interior space exclusive of vehicular parking areas, shall be a minimum of one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet; 
b.  Swimming pools, playgrounds, parks, community centers and other recreational and educational facilities operated on a nonprofit basis, and golf courses; and 
c.  Public works and public utility facilities such as distribution lines, transmission lines and towers, electric substations, water tanks and towers, pumping stations, water treatment plants, telephone exchanges and fire stations, provided: 
1.  Such facilities are essential to the service of the immediate area; 
2.  Outside storage of vehicles or materials on the premises shall not be permitted; and 
3.  All buildings and facilities shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from all property lines and shall be designed and landscaped in such a way as to blend in with the surrounding area. 
(2)  Home occupations: As defined in section 25-35-2, when authorized by the building official.
