(3)  By special use permit: Group residential facility and group treatment facility, when authorized by the mayor and council in accord with section 25-35-14. 
(4)  Accessory uses: 
a.  Customary accessory buildings or uses shall be permitted only in a rear yard, shall be situated not less than ten (10) feet from any property line, and shall not exceed fifteen (15) feet in height; on corner lots such accessory use shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from any side street right-of-way line. 
b.  Signs: Signs shall be allowed only in accordance with the applicable provisions of chapter 25-10 (Signs) of this Code. 
(5)  Off-street parking requirements: As provided in City Code section 25-35-6. 
(6)  Dimensional requirements: Within any R-10 residential district, the following dimensional requirements shall apply: 
a.  The minimum size of an R-10 classification development shall be one (1) acre, and the maximum size of an R-10 residential district shall be twenty (20) acres; 
b.  The minimum lot size shall be no less than ten thousand (10,000) square feet. Density shall not exceed four and one-half (4.5) units per acre, with such calculation to be made by dividing the number of dwelling units into the size (acres) of the development excluding public rights-of-way and floodplain area; 
c.  Dwelling units shall be set back at least thirty (30) feet from the front lot line, ten (10) feet from the side lot line, thirty (30) feet from the rear lot line, and fifteen (15) feet from any street; 
d.  Minimum building line width, sixty (60) feet; 
e.  Minimum lot frontage, sixty (60) feet; 
f.  Minimum lot depth, none; 
g.  Principal building height maximum, thirty-five (35) feet; and 
h.  Principal building coverage ratio to lot, maximum thirty (30) percent, and the maximum impervious surface of any lot shall not exceed sixty (60) percent. 
(7)  Landscaping, greenspace and sidewalk requirements: 
a.  The front, side and rear yards shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds; 
b.  Upon each lot shall be planted at least two (2) trees; however, two existing trees shall be allowed in lieu of planting if said trees are of the type listed within the tree selection list (Code Section 25-11-40) and are approved by the building official; and 
c.  Five (5) feet wide sidewalks shall be required on one (1) side of the public right-of-way within the development. 
(8)  Architectural controls: For any development which seeks and receives a variance from the dimensional requirements set forth in subsection (5) hereinabove, the following architectural controls shall apply to the development: 
a.  Roof pitch for the primary roof structure shall be a minimum of 6:12; 
b.  Roof materials shall be asphalt, fiberglass shingle, cedar, slate or standing seam metal; 
c.  HVAC units shall be either physically located or screened with vegetative or fence buffer so as not to be visible from the right-of-way; 
d.  Garages must enter from rear or side yard or, in the alternative, must be equipped with a garage door; 
e.  Shared driveways are not permitted; 
f.  All utilities shall be underground; 
g.  Street lights shall be required in type and number as determined by city; 
h.  No duplicate exterior elevations (front facade designs) including similar massing shall be constructed on the same street within one hundred twenty-five (125) linear feet in either direction, measured from the center of the front property line. The developer/builder will be responsible for providing documentation certifying compliance with this requirement prior to issuance of any building permit; 
i.  The use of gables, dormers, cornices, chimneys and other design features shall be used to enhance the overall appearance of the homes; and 
j.  Exterior materials shall be constructed or clad in either stone, wood, stucco, brick or hardy plank (vinyl may be incorporated around the soffit, gables, eaves and window area for trim). 
(9)  Development requirements: Any applicant for a development under this Code section shall submit with the application a development plan indicating compliance with the criteria required within this Code section, including but not limited to a site plan and landscape plan. 
a.  Plans must be submitted to the department of community development and shall be reviewed by said department, department of utilities and department of public services, after which a report on the development along with each department's comments will be issued to the mayor and council; and 
b.  Site plan specifications: The applicant for a development under this Code section shall also furnish a preliminary development plan for the entire development indicating the following: 
1.  Total number of lots for entire development; and 
2.  Planned amenities such as pools, pool houses, tennis courts, etc. 
(Ord. No. 08-08, § 3, 4-8-08; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 10-15, § 18, 8-24-10) 
Sec. 25-35-80. - R-12 residential district. 
    The regulations of the R-12 district are designed to work in conjunction with the other residential districts in the code to provide a variety of residential neighborhoods with differing densities and elements of public amenities in order to provide the basic elements of balanced, orderly, convenient, walkable and attractive residential areas. Within the R-12 zoning district, the following uses shall be permitted: 
(1)  Principal uses: 
a.  Single-family dwellings: The square footage of living space per dwelling, which space shall be defined as heated, interior space exclusive of vehicular parking areas, shall be a minimum of one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet; 
b.  Swimming pools, playgrounds, parks, community centers and other recreational and educational facilities operated on a nonprofit basis, and golf courses; and 
c.  Public works and public utility facilities such as distribution lines, transmission lines and towers, electric substations, water tanks and towers, pumping stations, water treatment plants, telephone exchanges and fire stations, provided: 
1.  Such facilities are essential to the service of the immediate area; 
2.  Outside storage of vehicles or materials on the premises shall not be permitted; and 
3.  All buildings and facilities shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from all property lines and shall be designed and landscaped in such a way as to blend in with the surrounding area.

(3)  By special use permit: Group residential facility and group treatment facility, when authorized by the mayor and council in accord with section 25-35-14.

b.  The minimum lot size shall be no less than twelve thousand (12,000) square feet. Density shall not exceed three and three-fourths (3.75) units per acre, with such calculation to be made by dividing the number of dwelling units into the size (acres) of the development excluding public right-of-way and floodplain area; 
c.  Dwelling units shall be set back at least forty (40) feet from the front lot line, ten (10) feet from the side lot line, thirty (30) feet from the rear lot line, and fifteen (15) feet from any street; 
d.  Minimum building line width, eighty (80) feet; 
e.  Minimum lot frontage, eighty (80) feet; 
f.  Minimum lot depth, none; 
g.  Principal building height maximum, forty (40) feet; and 
h.  Principal building coverage ratio to lot, maximum twenty-five (25) percent, and the maximum impervious surface of any lot shall not exceed fifty-five (55) percent. 
(7)  Landscaping, greenspace and sidewalk requirements: 
a.  The front and side yards shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds; 
b.  Upon each lot shall be planted at least two (2) trees; however, two (2) existing trees shall be allowed in lieu of planting if said trees are of the type listed within the tree selection list (Code section 25-11-40) and are approved by the building official; and 
c.  Five (5) feet wide sidewalks shall be required on one side of the public right-of-way within the development. 
(8)  Architectural controls: For any development which seeks and receives a variance from the dimensional requirements set forth in subsection (5) hereinabove, the following architectural controls shall apply to the development: 
a.  Roof pitch for the primary roof structure shall be a minimum of 6:12; 
b.  Roof materials shall be asphalt, fiberglass shingle, cedar, slate or standing seam metal; 
c.  HVAC units shall be either physically located or screened with vegetative or fence buffer so as not to be visible from the right-of-way; 
d.  Garages must enter from rear or side yard or, in the alternative, must be equipped with a garage door; 
e.  Shared driveways are not permitted; 
f.  All utilities shall be underground; 
g.  Street lights shall be required in type and number as determined by city; 
h.  No duplicate exterior elevations (front facade designs) including similar massing shall be constructed on the same street within one hundred twenty-five (125) linear feet in either direction, measured from the center of the front property line. The developer/builder will be responsible for providing documentation certifying compliance with this requirement prior to issuance of any building permit; 
i.  The use of gables, dormers, cornices, chimneys and other design features shall be used to enhance the overall appearance of the homes; and 
j.  Exterior materials shall be constructed or clad in either stone, wood, stucco, brick or hardy plank (vinyl may be incorporated around the soffit, gables, eaves and window area for trim). 
(9)  Development requirements: Any applicant for a development under this Code section shall submit with the application a development plan indicating compliance with the criteria required within this Code section, including but not limited to a site plan and landscape plan. 
a.  Plans must be submitted to the department of community development and shall be reviewed by said department, department of utilities and department of public services, after which a report on the development along with each department's comments will be issued to the mayor and council; and 
b.  Site plan specifications: The applicant for a development under this Code section shall also furnish a preliminary development plan for the entire development indicating the following: 
1.  Total number of lots for entire development; and 
2.  Planned amenities such as pools, pool houses, tennis courts, etc. 
(Ord. No. 08-08, § 4, 4-8-08; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 10-15, § 19, 8-24-10)

e.  Minimum lot frontage, eighty (80) feet; 
f.  Minimum lot depth, none; 
g.  Principal building height maximum, forty (40) feet; and 
h.  Principal building coverage ratio to lot, maximum twenty (20) percent, and the maximum impervious surface of any lot shall not exceed fifty (50) percent. 
(7)  Landscaping, greenspace and sidewalk requirements: 
a.  The front and side yards shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds; 
b.  Upon each lot shall be planted at least five (5) trees; however, five (5) existing trees shall be allowed in lieu of planting if said trees are of the type listed within the tree selection list (Code section 25-11-40) and are approved by the building official; and 
c.  Five (5) feet wide sidewalks shall be required on one side of the public right-of-way within the development. 
(8)  Architectural controls: For any development which seeks and receives a variance from the dimensional requirements set forth in subsection (5) hereinabove, the following architectural controls shall apply to the development: 
a.  Roof pitch for the primary roof structure shall be a minimum of 6:12; 
b.  Roof materials shall be asphalt, fiberglass shingle, cedar, slate or standing seam metal; 
c.  HVAC units shall be either physically located or screened with vegetative or fence buffer so as not to be visible from the right-of-way; 
d.  Garages must enter from rear or side yard or, in the alternative, must be equipped with a garage door; 
e.  Shared driveways are not permitted; 
f.  All utilities shall be underground; 
g.  Street lights shall be required in type and number as determined by city; 
h.  No duplicate exterior elevations (front facade designs) including similar massing shall be constructed on the same street within one hundred twenty-five (125) linear feet in either direction, measured from the center of the front property line. The developer/builder will be responsible for providing documentation certifying compliance with this requirement prior to issuance of any building permit; 
i.  The use of gables, dormers, cornices, chimneys and other design features shall be used to enhance the overall appearance of the homes; and 
j.  Exterior materials shall be constructed or clad in either stone, wood, stucco, brick or hardy plank (vinyl may be incorporated around the soffit, gables, eaves and window area for trim). 
(9)  Development requirements: Any applicant for a development under this Code section shall submit with the application a development plan indicating compliance with the criteria required within this Code section, including but not limited to a site plan and landscape plan. 
a.  Plans must be submitted to the department of community development and shall be reviewed by said department, department of utilities and department of public services, after which a report on the development along with each department's comments will be issued to the mayor and council; and 
b.  Site plan specifications: The applicant for a development under this Code section shall also furnish a preliminary development plan for the entire development indicating the following: 
1.  Total number of lots for entire development; and 
2.  Planned amenities such as pools, pool houses, tennis courts, etc. 
(Ord. No. 08-08, § 7, 4-8-08; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 10-15, § 22, 8-24-10) 
Sec. 25-35-84. - R-IN residential district. 
    The regulations of the R-IN district are designed to work in conjunction with the other residential districts in the code to provide a variety of residential neighborhoods with differing densities and elements of public amenities in order to provide the basic elements of balanced, orderly, convenient, walkable and attractive residential areas. R-IN districts are most appropriately located in areas already developed where in fill housing would be the predominant means of adding to the housing stock. Within the R-IN zoning district, the following uses shall be permitted: 
(1)  Principal uses: 
a.  Single-family dwellings: The square footage of living space per dwelling, which space shall be defined as heated, interior space exclusive of vehicular parking areas, shall be a minimum of the average of adjacent dwellings or the block average if adjacent dwellings are not present or are the exception; 
b.  Swimming pools, playgrounds, parks, community centers and other recreational and educational facilities operated on a nonprofit basis, and golf courses; and 
c.  Public works and public utility facilities such as distribution lines, transmission lines and towers, electric substations, water tanks and towers, pumping stations, water treatment plants, telephone exchanges and fire stations, provided: 
1.  Such facilities are essential to the service of the immediate area; 
2.  Outside storage of vehicles or materials on the premises shall not be permitted; and 
3.  All buildings and facilities shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from all property lines and shall be designed and landscaped in such a way as to blend in with the surrounding area. 
(2)  Home occupations: As defined in section 25-35-2, when authorized by the building official. 
(3)  By special use permit: Group residential facility and group treatment facility, when authorized by the mayor and council in accord with section 25-35-14. 
(4)  Accessory uses: 
a.  Customary accessory buildings or uses shall be permitted only in a rear yard, shall be situated not less than ten (10) feet from any property line, and shall not exceed fifteen (15) feet in height; on corner lots such accessory use shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from any side street right-of-way line. 
b.  Signs: Signs shall be allowed only in accordance with the applicable provisions of chapter 25-10 (Signs) of this Code. 
(5)  Off-street parking requirements: As provided in City Code section 25-35-6. 
(6)  Dimensional requirements: Within any R-IN residential district, the following dimensional requirements shall apply: 
a.  The R-IN classification has neither a minimum nor maximum development size; 
b.  The minimum lot size shall be determined by calculating the average of platted lots existing on the block; and 
c.  Dwelling units shall have the following front lot line, side lot line, rear lot line and street set back requirements: 
1.  The minimum front lot line set back shall be the average of adjacent dwellings or by the block average if adjacent units are not present or are the exception; 
2.  The minimum side lot line set back shall be the average of adjacent dwellings or by the block average if adjacent units are not present or are the exception; 
3.  The minimum rear lot line set back shall be the average of adjacent dwellings or by the block average if adjacent units are not present or are the exception; and 
4.  The minimum street set back shall be the average of adjacent dwellings or by the block average if adjacent units are not present or are the exception; 
d.  The minimum building line width shall be the average of adjacent dwellings or the block average if adjacent dwellings are not present or are the exception; 
e.  The minimum lot frontage shall be the average of adjacent dwellings or the block average if adjacent dwellings are not present or are the exception; 
f.  The minimum lot depth shall be the average of adjacent dwellings or the block average if adjacent dwellings are not present or are the exception; 
g.  The principal building height maximum shall be the average of adjacent dwellings or the block average if adjacent dwellings are not present or are the exception; and 
h.  The maximum principal building coverage ratio to lot shall be the average of adjacent dwellings or the block average if adjacent dwellings are not present or are the exception. 
(7)  Landscaping, greenspace and sidewalk requirements: 
a.  The front and side yards shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds; 
b.  Upon each lot shall be planted at least two (2) trees; however, two (2) existing trees shall be allowed in lieu of planting if said trees are of the type listed within the tree selection list (Code section 25-11-40) and are approved by the building official; and 
c.  Sidewalks shall be required if consistent with existing neighborhood orientation. 
(8)  Architectural controls: For any development which seeks and receives a variance from the dimensional requirements set forth in subsection (5) hereinabove, the following architectural controls shall apply to the development: 
a.  Roof pitch for the primary roof structure shall be a minimum of 6:12; 
b.  Roof materials shall be asphalt, fiberglass shingle, cedar, slate or standing seam metal; 
c.  HVAC units shall be either physically located or screened with vegetative or fence buffer so as not to be visible from the right-of-way; 
d.  Garages must enter from rear or side yard or, in the alternative, must be equipped with a garage door; 
e.  Shared driveways are not permitted; 
f.  All utilities shall be underground; 
g.  Street lights shall be required in type and number as determined by city; 
h.  No duplicate exterior elevations (front facade designs) including similar massing shall be constructed on the same street within one hundred twenty-five (125) linear feet in either direction, measured from the center of the front property line. The developer/builder will be responsible for providing documentation certifying compliance with this requirement prior to issuance of any building permit; 
i.  The use of gables, dormers, cornices, chimneys and other design features shall be used to enhance the overall appearance of the homes; and 
j.  Exterior materials shall be constructed or clad in either stone, wood, stucco, brick or hardy plank (vinyl may be incorporated around the soffit, gables, eaves and window area for trim). 
(9)  Development requirements: Any applicant for a development under this Code section is responsible for researching existing conditions, providing the city with the information required by this section, and shall submit with the application a development plan indicating compliance with the criteria required within this Code section, including but not limited to a site plan and landscape plan. 
a.  Plans must be submitted to the department of community development and shall be reviewed by said department, department of utilities and department of public services, after which a report on the development along with each department's comments will be issued to the mayor and council; and 
b.  Site plan specifications: The applicant for a development under this Code section shall also furnish a preliminary development plan for the entire development indicating the following: 
1.  Total number of lots for entire development; and 
2.  Planned amenities such as pools, pool houses, tennis courts, etc. 
(Ord. No. 08-08, § 8, 4-8-08; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 10-15, § 23, 8-24-10) 
Sec. 25-35-85. - PUD planned unit development. 
    The PUD district provides for innovative concepts in large-scale residential development yet does not forsake a desired setting of openness and a livable environment. Allied uses, public facilities and enclosed recreational uses are allowed. Through the planned unit development process, it is the intent that property will be developed with a unified design providing continuity between the various elements. However, the PUD process is not intended as a device to circumvent general development regulations, densities, standards and good planning practice, and thus includes application requirements that are more rigorous than other rezoning applications and conditional use permits, yet no more onerous than is necessary to enable thorough analysis. 
(1)  Purposes of zone: 
a.  To encourage orderly, creative and imaginative arrangements and mixes of land use in site planning, staged development of comprehensively planned multi-use centers by providing procedures for various zoning and plan approvals, including development phasing; 
b.  To encourage a broader mix of residential housing types including detached and attached dwelling, design flexibility and coordination of architectural style of buildings and signage; 
c.  To ensure compatibility of the proposed land uses with internal and surrounding uses by incorporating higher standards of land planning, site design, and development than could be accomplished under conventional zoning categories; 
d.  To provide a higher level of compatibility and conservation of the natural environment by the preservation of trees, natural topographic geologic features, wetlands, watercourses, and open space; 
e.  To allow development of tracts of land as a single development, in a staged or phased fashion of planned neighborhoods or communities to ensure adequate provision of public facilities and the concurrent implementation of community amenities; and 
f.  To allow for slightly higher gross and net development densities and intensities as an inducement to develop in a manner consistent with the purpose of this ordinance. 
(2)  Principal uses: 
a.  Single-family dwellings; 
b.  Two-family dwellings; 
c.  Multifamily dwellings; 
d.  Condominiums: A type of ownership for attached or detached dwelling units, offices, or other space within a structure, as defined by the provision of title 44, Chapter 3, Article III, of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (O.C.G.A. 44-3-70 et seq.) in which the air space of each unit is independently owned and financed by the occupant, but in which all lands and buildings are owned in common on a proportional, undivided basis and townhouses; 
e.  Home occupations: As defined in section 25-35-2, when authorized by the building official; 
f.  Golf course, swimming pool, clubhouse, community meeting spaces, tennis courts, playgrounds, lakes or similar recreation uses; 
g.  Religious institutions and their customary related facilities; 
h.  Educational institutions; 
i.  Accessory uses: Customary accessory buildings or uses shall be permitted only in a rear yard, shall be situated not less than ten (10) feet from any property line, and shall not exceed fifteen (15) feet in height; on corner lots such accessory use shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from any side street right-of-way line; 
j.  Public works and public utility facilities such as distribution lines, transmission lines and towers, electric substations, water tanks and towers, pumping stations, water treatment plants, telephone exchanges and fire stations, provided: 
1.  Such facilities are essential to the service of the immediate area; 
2.  Outside storage of vehicles or materials on the premises shall not be permitted; and 
3.  All buildings and facilities shall be set back at least twenty (20) feet from all property lines and shall be designed and landscaped in such a way as to bend in with the surrounding areas. 
k.  Boat docks, provided all ordinances and requirements of the "USACE West Point Lake Shoreline Management Plan" pertaining to use of lake shore property and the reservoir are met; 
l.  Signs: Signs shall be allowed only in accordance with the applicable provisions of chapter 25-10-21 (f), (signs), of this Code; and 
m.  PUD Development, operations & maintenance facilities. 
(3)  Conditional uses: Within the PUD district, non-residential uses may be permitted by the mayor and council as a conditional use, subject to the following conditions and requirements: 
a.  Such use must be scaled primarily to serve the residents of the PUD and their guests; 
b.  Such use shall be a necessary commercial or accessory service to the residents of the PUD and their guests, including, for example, uses such as clubs, marinas, restaurants, hotels, grocery, dry cleaners and the like; 
c.  The board of planning and zoning appeals shall review any application for conditional use and make a recommendation to the mayor and council within the time limitations established within code section 25-35-176; 
d.  Any application for conditional use hereunder shall be accompanied by a fee of $250.00; 
e.  The mayor and council shall act upon the recommendation of the board of planning and zoning appeals as to the request of conditional use within thirty (30) days; and 
f.  Any person aggrieved by a decision of the mayor and council under this section may take an appeal to the superior court, which appeal shall be by writ of certiorari which shall be filed within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision of the mayor and council. Upon the filing of such appeal, the clerk of the superior court shall give immediate notice thereof to the city manager and, within thirty (30) days from the time of such notice the city manager shall cause to be filed with said clerk a duly certified copy of the proceedings before the mayor and council, including a transcript of the evidence heard before it, if any, and the decision of the mayor and council. 
(4)  By special use permit: Group residential facility and group treatment facility, when authorized by the mayor and council in accord with section 25-35-14. 
(5)  Off-street parking requirements: As required in section 25-35-6 of this Code. 
(6)  Dimensional requirements: 
a.  Dimensional requirements for overall PUD district: 
1.  PUD must be a minimum of three hundred (300) contiguous acres; and 
2.  A maximum of seventy-five (75) percent of the total PUD may be occupied for residential uses which include streets, alleys, parking areas, private open spaces and courts which abut and service adjacent residences or groups of residences. Such does not include usable open space available for general community use. 
(7)  Open space: 
a.  Greenspace: A minimum of forty (40) percentof the total PUD shall be greenspace as defined in sections 25-20-2 and 25-20-27. Additionally, greenspaces in PUD zones shall include natural areas and lowlands. The greenspace includes areas for community open space and active recreational open space; 
b.  A minimum of twenty-five (25) percent of the total PUD shall be recreational uses and other community open spaces. Open space does not include space devoted to street paving, parking, buildings, or privately owned greenspace in residential lots; and 
c.  A minimum of five (5) percent of the total PUD shall be for active recreational open space such as: 
1.  Outdoor playground equipment; 
2.  Picnic area; 
3.  Tennis court; 
4.  Basketball court; 
5.  Horseshoe or other lawn activity; 
6.  Walking trail; 
7.  Open park space; and 
8.  Other recreation amenity designed for common use as approved by the director of community development. 
Active recreational open space uses may be developed in flood zones, but those areas shall not be counted as part of the active recreational open space requirement unless such areas are perpetually maintained recreational areas (such as a system of trails, etc.) and approved by the city. Such recreation amenities must be completed upon the issuance of building permits for fifty (50) percent of the lots within the development. An applicant must submit with the application a document plan, acceptable to city, providing for perpetual maintenance of such community space. 
(8)  [Number of residences.] The total number of residences shall not exceed an average of three (3) dwelling units per acre in the total PUD. 
(9)  Residential lot dimension and landscaping requirements: 
a.  Minimum lot width shall be forty (40) feet. However, every single-family dwelling shall have access to a street, court, or walkway or other area dedicated to private or public use; 
b.  No residential structure and accessory building shall be erected within twenty (20) feet of any other structure; 
c.  Garages connected to a residence by way of a covered connector shall be considered a single structure; 
d.  The front and side yards shall be covered by sod, or a combination of sod and landscaped beds; and 
e.  Upon each lot shall be planted at least two (2) trees. 
(10)  Multifamily residential dimensional requirements: 
a.  Maximum length of a continuous structure of townhouse or condominiums is eight (8) dwelling units; 
b.  Multifamily parcels shall not exceed twelve (12) units per gross acre of parcel; 
c.  No more than fifty (50) percent of the multifamily parcel area shall be occupied by dwelling units and accessory buildings[AW1]; and 
d.  Off-street parking shall be provided as required in Code section 25-35-6. 
(11)  Building height limits: Maximum height of all structures (as defined in 25-35-2) is forty (40) feet, excluding religious institutions and approved towers or antennas. 
(12)  Roads: 
a.  An interconnected street system that minimizes cul-de-sacs is preferred with stub out to future development provided. Cul-de-sacs are discouraged with the following exceptions:[AW2] Except where topographical or other conditions make a greater length unavoidable due to environmental impacts or[AW3] physical use constraints, as determined by the DRP, cul-de-sacs (dead-end streets) shall not be greater than fifteen hundred (1,500) feet in length. A cul-de-sac shall be terminated at the closed end with turnaround having a pavement diameter of at least ninety-six (96) feet. Paved temporary turnarounds shall be provided for dead-end streets which are scheduled to be extended at a later date; 
b.  Roads shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the subdivision regulations; and 
c.  Roads may have restricted access. 
(13)  Utility service requirements: 
a.  The development must be served by a central sewerage and a central water system sized and constructed to support fire protection; and 
b.  All permanent utilities shall be underground. 
(14)  Architectural controls: 
a.  Roof pitch for the primary roof structure shall be a minimum of 6:12; 
b.  Roof materials shall be asphalt, fiberglass shingle, cedar, slate or standing seam metal; 
c.  HVAC units shall be either physically located or screened with vegetative or fence buffer so as not to be visible from the right of way; 
d.  Garages must enter from rear or side yard or, in the alternative, must be equipped with a garage door; 
e.  Shared driveways are not permitted; 
f.  All utilities shall be underground; 
g.  Street lights shall be required in type and number as determined by city; 
h.  No duplicate exterior elevations (front façade designs) including similar massing shall be constructed on the same street within one hundred twenty-five (125) linear feet in either direction, measured from the center of the front property line. The developer/builder will be responsible for providing documentation certifying compliance with this requirement prior to issuance of any building permit; 
i.  The use of gables, dormers, cornices, chimneys and other design features shall be used to enhance the overall appearance of the homes; 
j.  Exterior materials shall be constructed or clad in either stone, wood, stucco, brick or hardy plank (vinyl may be incorporated around the soffit, gables, eaves and window area for trim); 
k.  Five (5) feet wide sidewalks shall be required on one (1) side of the public right of way; and 
l.  The maximum impervious surface of any lot shall not exceed sixty (60) percent. 
(15)  Other amenities: Prior to approval of PUD zoning, the city may require, by way of a development agreement, sidewalks and other amenities within the development. 
(16)  Application requirements: An application for PUD shall contain the following: 
a.  Site plan: Application shall include a conceptual site plan. The plan shall depict all connections to the public right of way; 
b.  Land uses: The application shall include a list of all land uses proposed to be included in the PUD, the total land area devoted to each of the land uses proposed, the percentage of the total land area within the PUD devoted to each proposed land use, and the projected number of residential units by type; 
c.  Architectural elevations: Applications shall include prospective front elevation of representative building types, for commercial and multifamily uses; and 
d.  Community benefit statement: The applicant shall submit a written statement identifying the relative benefits that will accrue to the city as a result of the property being developed under PUD provisions. This statement is a developer's opportunity to define why the PUD proposal merits approval and how it will serve the community better than a conventional development. 
(17)  Phasing and submittal of development plans: 
a.  Upon successful rezoning, at the time the developer desires to commence development of any phase, the developer shall make submissions for development approvals pursuant to chapter 25-20 (subdivisions) of this Code; 
b.  Each such submission shall be accompanied by a development time table for the proposed and submitted phase or subdivision; 
c.  Site plan specifications: 
1.  The applicant for a preliminary plat approval under this code section shall also furnish a current conceptual master plan for the entire development indicating the following: 
(a)  General road configuration; 
(b)  Residential lot areas; 
(c)  Multifamily lot areas; 
(d)  Planned amenities; 
(e)  Commercial lot areas; 
(f)  Greenspace and open space plan by use; and 
(g)  Other planned uses. 
2.  The plan shall indicate the maximum density proposed for the project, relationship of uses, and approximate location on the property; and 
3.  It is understood that the master plan is subject to modification but is to be submitted to aid in the review of the proposed integration of uses. 
d.  Upon submittal of a preliminary plat and final plat for any phase, the submittal must be accompanied by a certification from the developer designating the following: 
1.  Total acreage of the PUD; 
2.  Total acres in phase and total acres developed in the PUD; 
3.  Number of residential units in phase and total residential units developed (including proposed units) per gross acre of total PUD; 
4.  Residential density developed (including proposed units) per gross acre of total PUD; and 
5.  Percent proposed in phase and developed in PUD for residential, greenspace, open space, parks/recreational areas, other uses, and future development. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 2, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 10-15, § 24, 8-24-10) 
Sec. 25-35-86. - Pegasus Parkway Corridor Overlay. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply as used within this code section: 
    Business commerce sub-district means the business commerce sub-district shall include those parcels adjacent to Pegasus Parkway and zoned C-3 as identified on the Pegasus Parkway Overlay Map. Anticipated land uses within this sub-district include office and commercial uses. 
    Façade means the exterior surface wall of the building which contains the entrance to said building; the wall or that portion of the exterior surface of a building below the eaves which fronts or faces a public way; and in addition twenty (20) feet of return on those exterior surfaces immediately adjoining said portion of the building which fronts or faces a public way. 
    Ground sign means a freestanding sign that is supported by a solid base (other than poles) such that the bottom of the sign face is three feet or less above grade and no air space is visible within or between any portion of the sign display area and sign structure. 
    Industrial sub-district shall include those parcels adjacent to Pegasus Parkway and zoned G-I as identified on the Pegasus Parkway Overlay Map. Anticipated land uses in this sub-district are large scale industrial uses. 
    Net site area means the portion of the property available for development exclusive of any public road right-of-way, stormwater ponds and floodplain area. 
    Portable sign means any sign that is capable of being moved or intended to be moved from one (1) location to another even though the sign may be temporarily affixed to the ground; or that the design of which indicates it is capable of being moved or intended to be moved from one (1) location to another; or that is not permanently affixed to a building or the ground; or that is used in such a manner as to be portable. It is characteristic of a portable sign that the space provided for advertising messages may be changed at will by the replacement of letters or symbols. Removal of wheels, chassis, or frame from a portable sign shall not result in a change of its classification. Vehicles parked for indefinite periods of time and not regularly used in the course of business that contain identifying information about a business shall be considered portable signs. 
    Wall signs means single-sided signs with one (1) visible face applied to or mounted to the wall or surface of a building or structure, the display surface of which if attached to a wall or portico does not project more than fourteen (14) inches from the outside wall of such building or structure, or if on an awning, canopy or marquee, is flush with the material of said awning, canopy or marquee. 
(b)  Purpose. The purpose of the Pegasus Parkway Corridor Overlay is to ensure the functionality of the roadway by moving volumes of traffic safely and to preserve the aesthetic value of Pegasus Parkway including the natural and built environment. 
(c)  Regulations of underlying district. The overlay regulations are intended to supplement the regulations of the underlying zoning district. Unless specifically noted, the underlying zoning district regulations will govern the property with the overlay district providing supplemental requirements. If a conflict arises between the underlying zoning district and the overlay, the stricter of the rules applies. 
(d)  Establishment of overlay. The Pegasus Parkway Overlay shall be defined as the area on the official zoning map and more specifically identified on the Pegasus Parkway Overlay Map. The overlay shall apply to any parcels contiguous to the Pegasus Parkway right-of-way as it presently exists or may exist in the future. 
The Pegasus Parkway Overlay Zoning District shall be divided into two sub-districts, the industrial sub-district and the business commerce sub-district, based on anticipated land use patterns in the overall district. Because of anticipated land use patterns, some standards for development may differ between the two areas. 
(e)  Applicability. All new non-residential development within the Pegasus Parkway Corridor Overlay shall be subject to the requirements of this code section. 
(f)  Requirements. 
(1)  Building Location: In order to locate buildings so as to ensure the provision of adequate open space for outdoor gathering areas, facilities, services and to provide natural indoor light, air and privacy to the extent possible, the following location requirements shall apply: 
a.  Industrial sub-district: No building or structure shall be located closer than fifty (50) feet and no parking areas shall be located closer than twenty-five (25) feet from the right-of-way of Pegasus Parkway. 
b.  Business commerce sub-district: No building, structure or parking areas shall be located closer than fifteen (15) feet from the right-of-way of Pegasus Parkway. 
(2)  Impervious surface ratio: The maximum impervious surface ratio shall be eighty (80) percent. Impervious surfaces include those portions of the net site area covered by the ground floor of any structure, parking lots, sidewalks and private streets and drives. 
(3)  Exterior standards: 
a.  Architectural design: The front facade of a building as well as the main entrance(s) shall be designed as focal points to the building. The main entrances shall incorporate devices such as canopies, overhangs, arcades, raised parapets over the door, larger door openings, display windows, accent colors, and other architectural details such as moldings. The remaining portions of the building shall be designed in a way that complements and/or is consistent with the building's front facade. Architectural design shall create visual interest through the use of different textures, complementary colors, shadow lines and contrasting shapes. Monotonous design shall be avoided. Variation of detail, form, and siting shall be used to provide visual interest. Facades shall be articulated with variations in the building plane and parapet height, materials and colors, entrance canopies, and landscaping. The walls of buildings visible from the corridor shall not extend more than one hundred (100) linear feet parallel (more or less) to the street unless the façade of the building is designed in a way that breaks up the building face into discrete architectural elements, which can be accomplished through the following: 
1.  Façade modulation: stepping back or extending forward a portion of the façade. 
2.  Providing bay windows or repeating window patterns at regular intervals. 
3.  Providing a porch, patio, deck, covered entry to portions of the façade at the ground level, or in the case of buildings containing two (2) or more stories, balconies. 
4.  Changing the roofline by alternating dormers, or using stepped roofs, gables, or other roof elements. 
5.  Changing materials with the change in building plane. 
6.  Changes in rooflines. 
b.  Exterior materials: The following exterior standards shall apply to all buildings: 
The following construction materials shall be permitted: 
1.  Reinforced concrete and masonry . A concrete finish or precast concrete panel (tilt-wall) must have an exposed aggregate, be hammered or sandblasted, or be covered with a cement-based acrylic coating to add visual interest. Masonry includes solid cavity-faced or veneered-wall construction or materials. 
2.  Stucco or gypsum concrete/plaster . These materials shall be complemented with the use of masonry, whether brick, stone, stucco, split-face block, or broken up with the use of landscaping. 
3.  Treated wood . The use of wood paneling or plywood on the front building facade or side building facades when used as a primary exterior building finish is prohibited. 
4.  Structural steel or structural aluminum . The use of corrugated metal panels on front building facades or side building facades is prohibited, although aluminum composite material (ACM) panels are permitted. 
5.  Glass . 
All elevations of the building should be designed in a consistent and coherent architectural manner. Where a change in material, color, or texture along the exterior side of a building is proposed, the demarcation of the change shall occur a minimum of twenty (20) feet on both adjacent sides of the building or to the natural dividing point established by the physical plane of the building. Building colors and textures shall be harmonious and compatible with the colors of other buildings within in the property. 
c.  Roofs: Exposed roof materials shall consist of asphalt shingles, standing seam metal roof or lap seam metal roofing panel, tile or similar roof materials. 
d.  Trash and dumpsters: All trash, refuse debris or garbage shall be contained within an enclosed building or dumpster designed for such purposes. The enclosed building or dumpster shall be located behind the rear of the primary structure and shall be fully screened from public view by a wall or decorative fence. The wall or decorative fence shall be constructed of the same or complementary materials to those used on the primary building and must be twenty-four (24) inches taller than the dumpster or garbage container. The use of landscaping to further decrease the visual impact of the trash enclosures is encouraged. 
e.  Exterior storage: Except during permitted construction periods, all exterior storage of equipment, raw materials or finished products shall be fully screened from the view of Pegasus Parkway by a visual barrier such as a solid screen fence. Such exterior storage shall not exceed the height of the barrier. The barrier shall be a minimum of six (6) feet in height. Additional height or screening such as landscaping may be required based upon the height of the items to be screened. Chain-link fence with vertical slats shall not be permitted. The location of exterior storage shall be regulated by the underlying zoning of the subject property. 
f.  Signs: Signs shall be regulated by chapter 25-10, the Sign Ordinance, except as provided below: 
1.  Properties containing non-residential uses and located in the Pegasus Parkway Corridor Overlay are permitted one freestanding sign per road frontage, which must be approved in accordance with section 25-10-25 and subject to the following standards. The freestanding sign must be a ground sign as defined in this code section. Pole signs are not permitted. The ground sign shall not exceed eight (8) feet in height from ground elevation. Properties containing a single tenant are permitted a maximum ground sign area of fifty (50) square feet. Properties containing multiple tenants are permitted a maximum ground sign area of one hundred (100) square feet. Ground signs shall be set back at least five (5) feet from any street right-of-way, except at intersections where ground signs shall be set back at least fifteen (15) feet from the nearest point of intersection of street right-of-way. Ground signs shall be set back at least seventy-five (75) feet from other ground signs on the same side of the street. 
2.  Properties containing non-residential uses and located in the Pegasus Parkway Corridor Overlay are permitted wall signage on building faces fronting a public street right-of-way, which must be approved in accordance with section 25-10-25 and subject to the following standards. For the purposes of this section, wall signs shall include signs on awnings, canopies and marquees. Wall signage on single-tenant buildings shall be limited to an area of no more than ten (10) percent of the total area of the wall (including windows and doors) provided that in no instance shall either an individual wall sign or the cumulative total of all wall signs on a wall exceed two hundred (200) square feet in area. Wall signs on multi-tenant buildings are limited to ten (10) percent of the front façade of each individual business. Wall signs shall not extend above the top of the wall to which they are attached. 
3.  The following sign types are prohibited in the Pegasus Parkway Corridor Overlay: portable signs as defined in this code section and changing signs as defined in section 25-10-10. 
(4)  Parking and loading: 
a.  Loading areas: Loading areas shall not be located at the front of the primary structure or any side of the primary structure facing Pegasus Parkway. Service entrances and loading areas shall be designed at the rear of the primary structure and if visible due to orientation of the parcel to Pegasus Parkway, then the loading area shall be screened from the view from Pegasus Parkway. 
b.  Parking: Parking should be designed in ways that do not overpower the character of the development nor appear as a dominant feature of the site. With the exception of customer/visitor parking, employee parking is encouraged to be located to the side or rear of the building. All parking areas shall be paved with asphalt or concrete or any other material approved by the city. No parking areas shall be allowed within the following setbacks for Pegasus Parkway: 
Industrial sub-district: Twenty-five (25) feet. 
Business commerce park sub-district: Fifteen (15) feet. 
c.  Traffic circulation: Vehicle circulation patterns shall be designed that will provide for safe and efficient interconnectivity with all access points, parking, loading and pedestrian walk ways. In the business commerce park sub-district, inter-parcel connectivity is encouraged and may be required as deemed necessary by the development review panel (DRP). 
d.  Access: In order to maintain traffic flow on Pegasus Parkway, access points (curb cuts) shall be allowed only in compliance with the standards of the Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT) in force at the time of application. 
(5)  Landscaping: Landscaping shall be required per City of LaGrange City Ordinance. 
(6)  Utilities: 
a.  All telephone and cable television lines, electrical services and distribution lines are encouraged to be placed underground, except for meters, electric and telephone service pedestals, transformers, three (3) phased feeder lines, sub-transmission and transmission lines, electrical substations and such other facilities as the utility may deem necessary to install utilizing "overhead" type construction. 
b.  Above ground utilities shall be located and/or screened with vegetation or walls integrated into the overall site design so as not to be seen from Pegasus Parkway. 
(7)  Lighting: All lighting fixtures designed or placed so as to illuminate any portion of a site shall meet the following requirements: 
a.  Light coverage shall be localized as part of an overall lighting plan. Light fixtures that broadcast light over large areas or that are a source of glare, sky-glow or other light pollution shall not be permitted. 
b.  Cut-offs and lighting shields shall be used to prevent spill over and glare onto adjoining streets. Exposed lighting sources such as unshielded wall packs shall not be permitted. 
c.  Building-mounted lighting shall not extend above the roof line of the building on which it is mounted. 
d.  Parking lot light fixtures shall have a maximum height of thirty-five (35) feet. 
(8)  Allowable uses: Uses shall be permitted in accordance with the underlying zoning district with the exception of the following uses which are specifically prohibited: 
a.  Industrial sub-district. 
1.  Bulk storage of petroleum and petroleum products; 
2.  Repair garages; 
3.  Sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments; 
4.  Storage yards; and 
5.  Truck and bus terminals. 
b.  Business commerce sub-district. 
1.  Agriculture; 
2.  Automobile repair garages, including towing and wrecking services; 
3.  Automobile sales, new and used; 
4.  Boat sales and repair; 
5.  Bulk storage of petroleum and petroleum products; 
6.  Cold storage and freezer lockers; 
7.  Crematories; 
8.  Fabricating shops such as cabinet, upholstery and sheet metal shops; 
9.  Funeral homes and mortuaries; 
10.  Milk distribution (non-bottling) facilities; 
11.  Plumbing shops; 
12.  Radio and television repair shops; 
13.  Sales of motorcycles, boats and similar light vehicles; 
14.  Sales, storage and service of heavy equipment, trucks and machinery; 
15.  Sales, outdoor storage buildings, sheds, carports, and other large merchandise not contained within a building; 
16.  Self-storage facilities; 
17.  Sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments; 
18.  Sign painting and fabricating shops; 
19.  Tattoo parlors; 
20.  Taxi stands; 
21.  Tire recapping and retreading shops; 
22.  Title loan establishments; 
23.  Truck rental and leasing; 
24.  Truck terminals and warehouses; 
25.  Warehousing. 
(g)  Variance procedure. 
(1)  Generally . The request for a variance shall be submitted to the community development department and must clearly identify the proposed variance along with a statement of why the variance is necessary. The community development department will conduct a review of the requested variance and forward the request to the board of planning and zoning appeals. Except for sign variances, a variance from the requirements of the Pegasus Parkway Corridor Overlay shall be governed by City Code section 25-35-152. 
(2)  Signs . A variance from the sign requirements of the Pegasus Parkway Corridor Overlay can be granted in accordance with section 25-10-28 of the sign ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 3-24-15) 
Secs. 25-35-87-25-35-90. - Reserved. 
Article V - AIRPORT ZONING[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note- There are on file in the county and city offices agreements entered into by the city and county with the Civil Aeronautics Administration, now the Federal Aviation Administration. Notes as to the airport property, together with revisions, can be found in Deed Book 55, pages 287, 289, 292 and 315, in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county. 
Charter reference- Airports, § 5.14. 
State Constitution reference- Power of city to exercise the power of zoning, Art. 9, § 2, Par. 4. 
State Law reference- Aviation, O.C.G.A. Title 6. 

Sec. 25-35-91. - Short title; jurisdiction. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as LaGrange-Callaway Airport Zoning Ordinance. The description of airport zones is comprehensive for the LaGrange-Callaway Airport airspace requirements, but enforcement of this article applies only to the incorporated areas of the city. 
(Ord. No. 85-32, § 1, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 25-35-92. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Airport: The LaGrange-Callaway Airport. 
    Airport elevation: The highest point of an airport's usable landing area measured in feet from sea level, which is six hundred ninety-three and forty hundredths (693.40) feet for the LaGrange-Callaway Airport. 
    Approach surface: A surface longitudinally centered on the extended runway centerline, extending outward and upward from the end of the primary surface and at the same slope as the approach zone height limitation slope as set forth in section 25-35-97. The perimeter of the approach surface coincides with the perimeter of the approach zone. 
    Approach, departure, transitional, horizontal, and conical zones: These zones are defined as set forth in section 25-35-96. 
    Board of planning and zoning appeals: A board consisting of members appointed by the mayor and council of the City of LaGrange. 
    Conical surface: A surface extending outward and upward from the periphery of the horizontal surface at a slope of twenty (20) to one (1) for a horizontal distance of four thousand (4,000) feet. 
    Departure Surface: A clear area at the end of runways that provides for pilots to follow standard departure procedures. 
    Hazard to air navigation: An obstruction determined to have a substantial adverse effect on the safe and efficient utilization of the navigable airspace. 
    Height: For the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth in this article and shown on the zoning map, the datum shall be mean sea level elevation unless otherwise specified. 
    Heliport primary surface: The area of the primary surface coincides in size and shape with the designated takeoff and landing area of a heliport. This surface is a horizontal plane at the elevation of the established heliport elevation. 
    Horizontal surface: A horizontal plane one hundred fifty (150) feet above the established airport elevation, the perimeter of which in plan coincides with the perimeter of the horizontal zone. 
    Larger than utility runway: A runway that is constructed for and intended to be used by propeller-driven aircraft of greater than twelve thousand five hundred (12,500) pounds maximum gross weight and jet powered aircraft. 
    Nonconforming use: Any pre-existing structure, object of natural growth, or use of land which is inconsistent with the provisions of this article or an amendment thereto. 
    Nonprecision instrument runway: A runway having an existing instrument approach procedure utilizing air navigation facilities with only horizontal guidance, or area type navigation equipment, for which a straight-in nonprecision instrument approach procedure has been approved or planned. 
    Notification zone: An area within three (3) miles extending in any direction from the threshold end of the nearest runway. 
    Obstruction: Any structure, growth, or other object, including a mobile object, which exceeds a limiting height set forth in section 25-35-97. 
    Person: An individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association, joint-stock association, or governmental entity; such term includes a trustee, a receiver, an assignee, or a similar representative of any of them. 
    Precision instrument runway: A runway having an existing instrument approach procedure utilizing an instrument landing system (ILS) or a precision approach radar (PAR). It also means a runway for which a precision approach system is planned and is so indicated on an approved airport layout plan or any other planning document. 
    Primary surface: A surface longitudinally centered on a runway. When the runway has a specially prepared hard surface, the primary surface extends two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of that runway; for military runways or when the runway has no specially prepared hard surface, or planned hard surface, the primary surface ends at each end of that runway. The width of the primary surface is set forth in section 25-35-96. The elevation of any point on the primary surface is the same as the elevation of the nearest point on the runway centerline. 
    Runway: A defined area on an airport prepared for landing and takeoff of aircraft along its length. 
    Runway Protection Zone (RPZ): An area at ground level off the runway end to enhance the safety and protection of people and property on the ground. 
    Structure: An object, including a mobile object, constructed or installed by man, including, but without limitation, buildings, towers, cranes, smokestacks, earth formation, and overhead transmission lines. 
    Transitional surfaces: These surfaces extend outward at ninety-degree angles to the runway centerline and the runway centerline extended at a slope of seven (7) feet horizontally for each foot vertically from the sides of the primary and approach surfaces to where they intersect the horizontal and conical surfaces. Transitional surfaces for those portions of the precision approach surfaces, which project through and beyond the limits of the conical surface, extend a distance of five thousand (5,000) feet measured horizontally from the edge of the approach surface and at ninety-degree angles to the extended runway centerline. 
    Tree: Any object of natural growth. 
    Utility runway: A runway that is constructed for and intended to be used by propeller driven aircraft of twelve thousand five hundred (12,500) pounds maximum gross weight and less. 
    Visual runway: A runway intended solely for the operation of aircraft using visual approach procedures. 
(Ord. No. 85-32, § II, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 92-17, § 1, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 96-12, § 4, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 25-35-93. - Authority; findings; policy. 
    This article is adopted pursuant to the authority conferred by Article 9, section 2, paragraph 4 of the constitution of the state. It is hereby found that an obstruction has the potential for endangering the lives and property of users of the LaGrange-Callaway Airport, and property or occupants of land in its vicinity; that an obstruction may affect existing and future instrument approach minimums of LaGrange-Callaway Airport; and that an obstruction may reduce the size of areas available for the landing, takeoff, and maneuvering of aircraft, thus tending to destroy or impair the utility of LaGrange-Callaway Airport and the public investment therein. Accordingly, it is declared: 
(1)  That the creation or establishment of an obstruction has the potential of being a public nuisance and may injure the region served by LaGrange-Callaway Airport; 
(2)  That it is necessary in the interest of the public health, public safety, and general welfare that the creation or establishment of obstructions that are a hazard to air navigation be prevented; and 
(3)  That the prevention of these obstructions should be accomplished, to the extent legally possible, by the exercise of the police power. 
    It is further declared that the prevention of the creation or establishment of hazards to air navigation; the elimination, removal, alteration or mitigation of hazards to air navigation; and the marking and lighting of obstructions are public purposes for which a political subdivision may raise and expend public funds and acquire land or interests in land. 
(Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 25-35-94. - Conflicting laws and regulations. 
    If a conflict shall exist between the provisions of this article and any law of the state or any federal law, or any rules or regulations of either, legally adopted and in force, then the more stringent limitation or requirement shall govern and prevail. 
(Ord. No. 85-32, § X, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 25-35-95. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the LaGrange building official to administer and enforce the regulations prescribed in this article. Applications for permits and variances shall be made to the LaGrange building official upon a form published for that purpose. Applications required by this article to be submitted to the LaGrange building official shall be promptly considered and granted or denied. Application for action by the board of zoning appeals shall be forthwith transmitted by the LaGrange building official. 
(Ord. No. 85-32, § VIII, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 25-35-96. - Airport zones. 
    In order to carry out the provisions of this article, there are hereby created and established certain zones which include all of the land lying beneath the approach surfaces, departure surfaces, transitional surfaces, horizontal surfaces, and conical surfaces as they apply to the LaGrange-Callaway Airport. Such zones are shown on the LaGrange-Callaway Airport Zoning map consisting of one sheet, prepared by the Troup County Planning Commission and dated January, 1979, and updated January, 2019 consisting of three (3) sheets, which is, by this reference, made a part of this section. An area located in more than one (1) of the following zones is considered to be only in the zone with the more restrictive height limitation. The various zones are hereby established and defined as follows: 
(1)  Runway larger than utility visual approach zone: The inner edge of this approach zone coincides with the width of the primary outward uniformly to a width of one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet at a horizontal distance of five thousand (5,000) feet from the primary surface. Its centerline is the continuation of the runway. 
(2)  Runway larger than utility with a visibility minimum greater than 3/4 mile nonprecision instrument approach zone: The inner edge of this approach zone coincides with the width of the primary surface and is five hundred (500) feet wide. The approach zone expands outward uniformly to a width of three thousand five hundred (3,500) feet at a horizontal distance of ten thousand (10,000) feet from the primary surface. Its centerline is the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
(3)  Runway larger than utility with a visible minimum as low as three-fourths miles non-precision instrument approach zone: The inner edge of this approach zone coincides with the width of the primary surface and is one thousand (1,000) feet wide. The approach zone expands outward uniformly to a width of four thousand (4,000) feet at a horizontal distance of ten thousand (10,000) feet from the primary surface. Its centerline is the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
(4)  Precision instrument runway approach zone: The inner edge of this approach zone coincides with the width of the primary surface and is one thousand (1,000) feet wide. The approach zone expands outward uniformly to a width of sixteen thousand (16,000) feet at a horizontal distance of fifty thousand (50,000) feet from the primary surface. Its centerline is the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
(5)  Transitional zones: The transitional zones are the areas beneath the transitional surfaces. 
(6)  Horizontal zone: The horizontal zone is established by swinging arcs of ten thousand (10,000) feet radii from the center of each end of the primary surface of each runway and connecting the adjacent arcs by drawing lines tangent to those arcs. The horizontal zone does not include the approach and transitional zones. 
(7)  Heliport approach zone: The inner edge of this approach zone coincides with the width of the primary surface which corresponds in size and shape with the designated takeoff and landing area. The approach zone expands outward uniformly to a width of five hundred (500) feet at a horizontal distance of four thousand (4,000) feet from the primary surface. 
(8)  Heliport transitional zones: These zones extend outward from the sides of the primary surface and the heliport approach zones a horizontal distance of two hundred fifty (250) feet from the primary surface centerline and the heliport approach zone centerline. 
(9)  Conical zone: The conical zone is established as the area that commences at the periphery of the horizontal zone and extends outward therefrom a horizontal distance of four thousand (4,000) feet. 
(10)  Departure Zone: A trapezoidal zone longitudinally centered on the extended runway centerline, one thousand (1,000) feet wide extending outward, and away from the Stop End of Runway for a distance of ten thousand two hundred (10,200) feet to a width of six thousand four hundred sixty-six (6,466) feet. 
(11)  Notification zone: The conical zone is established as the area that commences at the periphery of the horizontal zone and extends outward therefrom a horizontal distance of three (3) miles. 
(Ord. No. 85-32, § III, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 92-17, § 1, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 25-35-97. - Airport zone height limitations. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, no structure shall be erected, altered, or maintained, and no tree shall be allowed to grow in any zone created by this article to a height in excess of the applicable height limitations which are hereby established for each of the zones in question as follows: 
(1)  Runway larger than utility visual approach zone: Slopes twenty (20) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the end of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and extending to a horizontal distance of five thousand (5,000) feet along the extended runway centerline. 
(2)  Runway larger than utility with a visibility minimum greater than 3/4 mile nonprecision instrument approach zone: Slopes thirty-four (34) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the end of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and extending to a horizontal distance of ten thousand (10,000) feet along the extended runway centerline. 
(3)  Runway larger than utility with a visible minimum as low as three-fourths miles non-precision instrument approach zone: Slopes thirty-four (34) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the end of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and extending to a horizontal distance of ten thousand (10,000) feet along the extended runway centerline. 
(4)  Precision instrument runway approach zone: Slopes fifty (50) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the end of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and extending to a horizontal distance of ten thousand (10,000) feet along the extended runway centerline; thence slopes upward forty (40) feet horizontally for each foot vertically to an additional horizontal distance of forty thousand (40,000) feet along the extended runway centerline. 
(5)  Transitional zones: Slopes seven (7) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the side of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and the approach surface, and extending to a height of one hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation which is six hundred ninety-three and forty hundredths (693.40) feet above mean sea level. In addition to the foregoing, there are established height limits sloping seven (7) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the approach surface, and extending to where they intersect the conical surface. Where the precision instrument runway approach zone projects beyond the conical zone, there are established height limits sloping seven (7) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the approach surface, and extending as a horizontal distance of five thousand (5,000) feet measured at ninety-degree angles to the extended runway centerline. 
(6)  Horizontal zone: Established at one hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation or at a height of eight hundred forty-three and forty hundredths (843.40) feet above mean sea level. 
(7)  Conical zone: Slopes twenty (20) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the periphery of the horizontal zone and a one hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation and extending to a height of three hundred fifty (350) feet above the airport elevation. 
(8)  Heliport approach zone: Slopes eight (8) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the end of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and extending to a distance of four thousand (4,000) feet along the heliport approach zone centerline. 
(9)  Departure zone: Slopes forty (40) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the stop end of runway or clearway, for a distance ten thousand two hundred (10,200) feet, to a height of two hundred fifty-five (255) feet above the runway end elevation. 
(Ord. No. 85-32, § IV, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 92-17, § 1, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 25-35-98. - Use restrictions. 
(a)  Generally. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, no use may be made of land or water within any zone established by this article in such a manner as to create electrical interference with navigational signals or radio communications between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for pilots to distinguish between airport lights and other lights, result in glare in the eyes of pilots using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport, create bird strike hazards, or otherwise in any way endanger or interfere with the landing, takeoff, or maneuvering of aircraft intending to use the airport. 
(b)  Prohibited uses. All structures and trees are prohibited in the runway protection zone defined as the first one thousand seven hundred (1,700) foot segment of the approach zone beginning at the end of the primary surface for Runway 13-31 and the first one thousand (1,000) foot segment of the approach zone beginning at the end of the primary surface for Runway 3-21. 
(Ord. No. 85-32, § V, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 88-103, § 1, 8-9-88; Ord. No. 92-17, § 1, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 25-35-99. - Nonconforming uses. 
(a)  Regulations not retroactive. The regulations prescribed by this article shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering, or other change or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming to the regulations as of January 22, 2019, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of nonconforming use. Nothing contained herein shall require any change in the construction, alteration, or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior to January 22, 2019, and is diligently prosecuted. Additionally, nothing contained herein shall prohibit construction of additions or additional floors to existing buildings provided that any such buildings were in use on January 22, 2019, the additions were contemplated and designated at the time of the original construction, and that additional costs were incurred at the time of the original construction to allow for those future additions or additional floors. 
(b)  Marking and lighting. Notwithstanding the preceding provisions of this section, the owner of any existing or extended nonconforming structure or tree is hereby required to permit the installation, operation, and maintenance thereon of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the LaGrange-Callaway Airport to indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport the presence of such airport obstruction. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated, and maintained at the expense of the airport authority. 
(Ord. No. 85-32, § VI, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 25-35-100. - Permits. 
(a)  Future uses. Except as specifically provided in paragraphs (1), (2) and (3) of this subsection, no material change shall be made in the use of land, no structure shall be erected or otherwise established, and no tree shall be planted in any zone created in this article unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted by the LaGrange building official. Each application for a permit shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient particularity to permit it to be determined whether the resulting use, structure, or tree would conform to the regulations herein prescribed. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. All structures and trees within the notification zone shall seek airspace approval by the Airport Manager or the FAA. Structures and trees outside of this zone shall seek airspace approval if required by Federal regulations. No permit for a use inconsistent with the provisions of this article shall be granted unless a variance has been approved in accordance with subsection (d) of this section, using the following criteria: 
(1)  In the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and conical zone, no permit shall be required for any tree less than seventy-five (75) feet of vertical height above the ground, except when, because of terrain, land contour, or topographic features, such tree would extend above the height limits prescribed for such zones. 
(2)  In areas lying within the limits of the approach zones, but at a horizontal distance of not less than four thousand two hundred (4,200) feet from each end of the runway, no permit shall be required for any tree less than seventy-five (75) feet of vertical height above the ground, except when such tree would extend above the height limit prescribed for such approach zones. 
(3)  In the areas lying within the limits of the transition zones beyond the perimeter of the horizontal zone, no permit shall be required for any tree less than seventy-five (75) feet of vertical height above the ground, except when such tree, because of terrain, land contour, or topographic features, would extend above the height limit prescribed for such transition zones. 
Nothing contained in any of the foregoing exceptions shall be construed as permitting or intending to permit any construction, or alteration of any structure, or growth of any tree, in excess of any of the height limits established by this article. 
(b)  Existing uses. Except as provided in section 25-35-99(a), no permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an obstruction or permit a nonconforming use, structure, or tree to become a greater hazard to air navigation than it was on January 22, 2019, or any amendments thereto or than it is when the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for such a permit shall be granted. 
(c)  Nonconforming uses abandoned or destroyed. Whenever the LaGrange building official determines that a nonconforming tree or structure has been abandoned or more than eighty (80) percent torn down, physically deteriorated, or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow such structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning regulations. 
(d)  Variances. Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use property, not in accordance with the regulations prescribed in this article, may apply to the board of planning and zoning appeals for a variance from such regulations. The application for variance shall be accompanied by a determination from the Federal Aviation Administration as to the effect of the proposal on the operation of air navigation facilities and the safe, efficient use of navigable airspace. Such variances may be allowed where it is found that a literal application or enforcement of the regulations will result in unnecessary hardship and relief granted, will not be contrary to the public interest, will not create a hazard to air navigation, will do substantial justice, and will be in accordance with the spirit of this article. Additionally, no application for variance to the requirements of this article may be considered by the board of zoning appeals unless a copy of the application has been furnished to the LaGrange-Callaway Airport for advice as to the aeronautical effects of the variance.
