(4)  The benefit to the public at large as compared to hardship which may be imposed upon an individual property owner; 
(5)  Suitability of the subject property for use under the requested or proposed rezoning; 
(6)  Reasons why property under consideration can or cannot be used in accordance with existing zoning; 
(7)  If applicable, the extent to which the proposed rezoning would create or result in an isolated district or island which is unrelated to adjacent or nearby districts or to the future land use plan or would be detrimental to the development in the area; 
(8)  Whether the proposed zoning amendment is consistent with the comprehensive plan of the city or any other appropriate land use plan, transportation plan or other plans for the development of the community for the area under consideration; 
(9)  The population density of the area or areas which would be affected by the proposed rezoning, taking into consideration the increase on or to public facilities, public utilities, school or streets and traffic patterns and the possible impact on the environment including but not limited to drainage, soil erosion and sedimentation, flooding, air quality and water quality and quantity; 
(10)  Whether existing zoning district boundaries are inappropriately or illogically drawn with relation to existing conditions; 
(11)  Whether the zoning change requested will have the effect of granting the special privilege as contrasted with the public good and welfare; and 
(12)  The effect of the proposed change in zoning, if any, upon the living conditions in the neighborhood and the aesthetics of the neighborhood. 
(Ord. No. 02-37, § 1, 12-10-02) 
Title 30 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Licenses and occupational taxes, §§ 4.15, 5.20. 
Cross reference- Garages, service stations, § 10-20-7; health, Ch. 10-25; bringing fertilizer materials into city, § 10-25-5; animals and fowl, Ch. 10-30; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 15-5; solid waste, Ch. 15-10; parks and recreation, Ch. 15-15; franchises, Ch. 15-25; city utilities, Ch. 20-1 et seq.; community and economic development, Ch. 25-1 et seq.; fraudulent sales, § 35-1-8; slaughtering animals, curing hides, § 35-1-23; labor-management relations, Ch. 35-5. 
State Law reference- Commerce and trade, O.C.G.A. Tile 10; professions and businesses, O.C.G.A. Title 43; specific, business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq. 

Chapter 30-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 95-46, adopted Dec. 21, 1995, deleted former §§ 30-1-1-30-1-25 and designated new provisions as §§ 30-1-1-30-1-24 in lieu thereof. Formerly, the deleted sections pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 94-53, § 1, adopted Dec. 27, 1994, as amended; see the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 30-1-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable costs of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
    Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and his employer withholds FICA, Federal Income Tax, or State Income Tax from such individual's compensation and whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form I.R.S. W-2 but not a form I.R.S. 1099. 
    Director of community and economic development shall be deemed to include the person serving as director of community and economic development of the city and the designated representative of said director. 
    Location or office shall include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. The renter's or lessee's location which is the site of personal property which is rented or leased from another does not constitute a location or office for the personal property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor. The site of real property which is rented or leased to another does not constitute a location or office for the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor unless the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor, in addition to showing the property to prospective lessees or tenants and performing maintenance or repair of the property, otherwise conducts the business of renting or leasing the real property at such site or otherwise conducts any other business, profession, or occupation at such site. 
    Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business and enacted by a local government as a revenue-raising ordinance or resolution. 
    Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees or by another name, which are required by local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or as an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the local government. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Regulatory fees do not include development impact fees as defined by paragraph (8) of O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2 or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development. Regulatory fees shall be determined in accordance with one of the following methods: 
(1)  A flat fee for each business or practitioner of a profession or occupation doing business in the jurisdiction as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-8; 
(2)  A flat fee for each type of permit or inspection requested; 
(3)  An hourly rate determined by the hourly wage or salary, including employee benefits, of the person or persons assigned to investigate or inspect multiplied by the number of hours estimated for the investigation or inspection to be performed; 
(4)  A hourly rate as determined by paragraph (3) of this definition with the addition of other expenses reasonably related to such regulatory activity, such as administrative and travel expenses, multiplied by the number of hours estimated for the investigation or inspection to be performed; 
(5)  For construction projects that are classified as new construction, the number of square feet of construction or the number of square feet of construction to be served by the system to be installed, in conjunction with and limited by the building valuation data, as established from time to time by the International Code Council or by similar data, and in conjunction with and limited by the hourly rate described in paragraph (3) or (4) of this definition; or 
(6)  For construction projects that are classified as renovation and all other construction projects other than those classified as new construction, the cost of the project in conjunction with and limited by the building valuation data that conforms with the principles and methods established from time to time by the International Code Council or by similar data, and in conjunction with and limited by the hourly rate described in paragraph (3) or (4) of this definition. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95; Ord. No. 06-14, § 2, 7-11-06; Ord. No. 13-10, § 1, 8-13-13) 
Sec. 30-1-2. - Violations enumerated. 
(a)  The following acts or omissions are declared to be violations of this title: 
(1)  Engaging in any business, profession, trade or calling without procuring the proper business tax registration to do so as provided in this title, if required, or without registering with the city as required in section 30-1-7; 
(2)  Failing to make the return or statement to the director of community and economic development as required by section 30-1-9(b); 
(3)  Giving or filing, or directing the giving or filing, of any false information regarding any tax due under the provisions of this title or upon which tax due under this title is based or determined; 
(4)  Failing or refusing to permit the director of community and economic development to examine books or records as provided in section 30-1-10; 
(5)  Failure to comply with any federal, state or city law or regulation applicable to the particular business being conducted; or 
(6)  Failure to comply with any of the requirements of this title. 
(b)  Any person who shall fail to pay the occupation tax or administrative fee assessed pursuant to this chapter (by the 1 st day of April) shall, upon conviction therefor in the municipal court, be subjected to a civil fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95; Ord. No. 13-10, § 2, 8-13-13) 
Sec. 30-1-3. - Punishment; revocation of business tax registration. 
(a)  Upon the failure of any business to pay the applicable administrative fee, occupation tax or business license fee, or any part thereof, before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of said returns within the time required herein, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as provided herein, any business tax registration granted by the city under this chapter permitting the owner of said business to do business for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax registrations shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax, administrative fee or business license fee herein provided for is at that time unpaid, or to an individual, firm, or corporation who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the director of economic development, or his designee, in accordance with the provisions found in section 30-1-10. 
(b)  Additionally, in any instance in which a business shall fail to comply with any federal, state or city law or regulation applicable to such business, the mayor and council in their legislative discretion, may revoke or suspend the registration permitting such business to conduct its business or to operate in the city provided the mayor and council shall conclude from evidence produced in a public hearing held, after appropriate public notice, that revocation or suspension, as the case may be, of registration is appropriate and justified. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, in the case of those practitioners whose right to practice or conduct business cannot be suspended or infringed by a local government, only the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the city in the case of delinquent occupation tax, administrative fee or business license fees. Any such practitioner who fails to remit a tax or fee required under this chapter shall, upon conviction of same in the municipal court, be fined in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 3-14-96; Ord. No. 03-15, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-03) 
Sec. 30-1-4. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The occupation tax or other fee imposed in this chapter shall not apply to any business, profession, trade or calling involved solely in interstate or foreign commerce, unless and until the same shall cease to be a part of such interstate or foreign commerce. 
(b)  The legal right of the producer who sells the product of his own farm is recognized, but this right does not authorize any person purchasing goods or other things of value within or without the city to offer the same for sale within the city without proper business tax registration. 
(c)  Before any disabled veteran or blind person shall be granted a permit to enter business without the payment of an occupation fee or tax in the city, such disabled veteran or blind person shall present to the director of economic and community development a certificate of exemption from the payment of such fee issued by the State Commissioner of Veterans' Service. 
(d)  Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to pay an occupation tax or administrative fee for that practice. 
(e)  The occupation tax or other fee in this chapter shall not apply to nonprofit organizations. 
(f)  The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this chapter but may be assessed an occupation tax, administrative fee or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the State of Georgia or by local law: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission; 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under Chapter 3 of Title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness; 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. Section 2-10-105; 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. Section 33-8-8, et seq.; 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. Section 46-7-15; 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. Section 48-5-355; (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls.) 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the State of Georgia, governed by O.C.G.A. Section 48-5-356; 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. Section 48-6-93; and 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. Section 48-13-55. 
(g)  The administrative fee and occupation tax upon real estate brokers shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. Section 48-13-17 and the fee schedule set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-5. - Enforcing officer. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of community and economic development to ensure that the provisions of this title relating to business tax registration, regulatory fees, administrative fees and occupation taxes are observed and enforced. He shall inspect all business tax registrations issued by the city as often as may be necessary to ensure that each such license is proper and sufficient for the business being transacted thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-6. - Registration as a prerequisite to doing business. 
(a)  For calendar year 1996 and any succeeding year thereafter, each person, firm or corporation engaged in business, trade, profession or occupation in the City of LaGrange with a location in the city, shall pay an administrative fee and occupation tax for said business trade, profession, or occupation, obtain the registration required by this chapter and maintain such registration during the current year as a prerequisite to doing and continuing to do business in the city during such year, except in those instances which, under the law of Georgia, local government cannot suspend the right of a practitioner to conduct business. 
(b)  If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the City of LaGrange, and has obtained registration and paid an occupation tax in another jurisdiction, the applicable business tax registration shall be shown to the director of community and economic development or to such officer's designee to any police officer of the city upon request. 
(c)  Unless otherwise allowed pursuant to article V, article VI or article VII of chapter 30-5 or other provision of the city code, any business location in the City of LaGrange shall be operated out of a building as such term is defined within the zoning ordinance of the City of LaGrange [included as chapter 25-35 of this volume]. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 3-14-96; Ord. No. 04-34, § 1, 10-12-04) 
Sec. 30-1-7. - Obtaining on coming into city; registration required; failure to obtain. 
(a)  All persons subject to the occupation tax or other fee pursuant to this chapter shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for the business as described in this chapter, and in default thereof, the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. 
(b)  Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration herein provided for before commencing the same; and any person transacting, or offering to transact in the city any of the kinds of business, trade, profession or occupation without first having so obtained said registration, shall be subject to penalties provided therefor. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-8. - Half-year registration. 
    Any new business, trade, profession or calling which shall begin business in the city after July 1 of any year shall pay an occupation tax or business license fee equal to fifty (50) percent of the amount required for such business, trade, profession or calling for a full year, in addition to the full, non-prorated administrative fee. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-9. - Payment of occupation fee or tax; late fee; interest; filing return. 
(a)  Each administrative fee, occupation fee or other fee due under this chapter shall be paid for each calendar year. Such occupation fee or tax shall be due and payable on the first day of January each year. A penalty of ten (10) percent of the occupation fee, tax or other fee shall be assessed against those persons or other entities described in section 30-1-24 of this article that shall fail to pay the occupation tax or fee imposed hereby on or before the first day of April of each year. If the occupation tax and fees are not paid by the first day of April of each year, interest at one and five-tenths (1.5) percent per month shall thereafter accrue and be due and payable. 
(b)  All businesses classified in section 30-1-24 for which a tax is imposed based upon the number of employees shall, on or before the first day of April of each year, file with the director of community and economic development a return which shall reflect the total number of employees for the previous calendar year. Any person who shall fail to file annually the returns required under this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-1-6 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-10. - Inspection of books and records. 
    The director of community and economic development or his duly authorized agent may inspect the books and records of any business in order to audit or verify any return filed, or to determine the average number of employees of those entities required to pay an occupation tax hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-11. - Prohibited fee or tax. 
    No license fee, administrative fee or occupation tax is intended to be imposed by this title which is prohibited under or by virtue of the laws of the State of Georgia or the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-12. - Location and transferability of registration. 
    Proper business tax registration shall be required at each business location and a registration granted under this title shall not authorize the holder thereof to exercise or carry on the business described in such registration at any place other than that named in the registration; nor shall a registration be transferred from one location to another location, or from one person to another person, unless authorized by the mayor and council and then only as provided by specific ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-13. - Appeal. 
    Any person shall have the right to appeal any decision under the provisions of this title to the mayor and council. Such appeal shall be taken within a reasonable time after the decision complained of or the application of the provisions complained of, but in no event more than thirty (30) days after the decision from which the appeal is taken. Such appeal shall be filed in writing with the director of community and economic development and shall be heard by the mayor and council at the next regular meeting, or at such other time as may be fixed by the mayor and council after giving public notice thereof and due notice to the parties in interest. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-14. - Paying occupation tax of business with no location in Georgia. 
    Registration and assessment of the administrative fee and occupation tax is hereby imposed upon those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the State of Georgia if that business's largest dollar volume of business in Georgia is in LaGrange, Georgia, and the business or practitioner: 
(1)  Has one (1) or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of LaGrange for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-15. - Number of businesses considered to be operating in the city. 
    Where a person conducts business at more than one (1) fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of the administrative fee and flat fee portion of the occupation tax. In computing the per employee component of the occupation tax, businesses which operate in more than one (1) location or place within the city shall be taxed in accordance with section 30-1-24. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-16. - Purpose and scope of tax. 
    The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the occupation tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. Sections 48-13-5 to 48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-17. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
    Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or to satisfy any other regulatory requirement shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, shall evidence that such requirements have been met. Any business required to pay personal property ad valorem taxes of Troup County, Georgia, shall likewise show evidence that the most recent personal property ad valorem taxes assessed have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95; Ord. No. 01-19, § 1, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 30-1-18. - Requirements of public hearing. 
    The mayor and council of the city shall conduct at least one (1) public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution regarding the occupation tax and shall further hold one (1) or more public hearings in any year which revenue from occupation taxes is greater than revenue from occupation taxes from the preceding year, said hearing to be a part of the process of determining how to use the additional revenue. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-19. - Calculation of number of employees. 
    The number of employees of the business or practitioner is to be computed on a full-time position basis or full-time position equivalent basis, provided that for the purposes of this computation an employee who works forty (40) hours or more weekly shall be considered a full-time employee and that the average weekly hours of employees who work less than forty (40) hours weekly shall be added and such sums shall be divided by forty (40) to produce full-time position equivalents. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Sec. 30-1-20. - Occupation tax of practitioners of certain professions and occupations. 
    Practitioners of professions and occupations listed in paragraphs 1 through 18 of subsection (c) of O.C.G.A. section 48-13-9 shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax resulting from application of the other provisions of this chapter; or 
(2)  A fee which shall total four hundred dollars ($400.00) per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid at that practitioner's office or location. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Secs. 30-1-21-30-1-23. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-1-24. - Occupation tax rates; administrative fee. 
    All businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations shall pay to city, according to the schedule set forth in section 30-1-9, an administrative fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per business location within the city, in addition to an occupation tax composed of the following: 
(1)  Seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each business location within the city; and 
(2)  A tax on the number of employees employed by said business within city. The per employee tax rate shall be as follows: 
Number of Employees     Rate  
0 to 4 ..... $ 0.00 
plus 
5-19, each ..... 35.00 
plus 
20-49, each ..... 27.00 
plus 
50-99, each ..... 19.00 
plus 
100-249, each ..... 10.00 
Above 249, no additional per employee tax. 
(3)  The per employee tax set forth in subsection (2) above shall be computed, at the discretion of the business, in aggregate for all locations within the jurisdiction, or separately for each location within the jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 1, 12-21-95) 
Chapter 30-5 - MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS, PERMITS AND LICENSES 
Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-5-1. - Meat inspection. 
    No meats of any kind shall be offered for sale in the city unless such meat has been inspected and passed as fit for human consumption in accordance with state and federal laws and regulations. 
(Code 1972, § 15-57) 
Cross reference- Health, Ch. 10-25. 
State Law reference- Meat inspection, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-60 et seq.; federal and state cooperation, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-63. 
Sec. 30-5-2. - Sanitation of food vehicles. 
    All vehicles having or selling on the street food products of any kind shall have the approval of the sanitary inspector of the county board of health as to sanitary conditions before any license shall be issued to any person for the operation of any such vehicle in the city, such license when issued, to be subject to be revoked by the mayor and council at any time when it is made to appear that the vehicle is not being kept and operated in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(Code 1972, § 15-56) 
State Law reference- Transportation of animals, meat and meat food products, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-110. 
Sec. 30-5-3. - Making music on streets and sidewalks. 
    No person shall make music on the streets or sidewalks for the purpose of begging or to call the attention of passersby to some personal deformity or infirmity of the person making the music or of some person accompanying him. 
(Code 1972, § 15-59) 
State Law reference- Nonprofit corporations, O.C.G.A. § 14-3-1 et seq.; pedestrians soliciting business or contributions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-98; professional fund raisers and solicitors, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq. 
Sec. 30-5-4. - Motor vehicle wrecking or dealing in secondhand parts. 
(a)  As used in this section, "motor vehicle wrecking" is defined as the business of all persons engaged in tearing down and disassembling motor vehicles and selling, at wholesale or retail, secondhand motor vehicle parts. All persons engaged in such business shall be classified separately for the purpose of paying a business license fee or tax and shall pay such license fee or tax as may be fixed therefor in the annual license fee or tax schedule. All such dealers in secondhand motor vehicle parts, buying secondhand motor vehicles, wrecking them and selling the parts are prohibited from buying and selling brass, metals, tags, lead, zinc or other things usually handled in a junkyard; the only business such persons shall be allowed to engage in under this section being that of dealer in secondhand motor vehicle parts, which shall include buying secondhand automobiles, tearing them down and selling the parts. 
(b)  Operators, owners or managers of yards or places of business dealing in secondhand motor vehicle parts or motor vehicle wrecking shall obtain a permit from the mayor and council for the operation thereof and approval of the size of the yard or place of business used in connection therewith. Said application shall state whether a permit has theretofore been granted for such yard or place of business, and shall give such information as may seem advisable to the applicant or requested by the mayor and council. When the application has been filed, the assistant city manager shall give one (1) notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city of the time and place of meeting for consideration of same. Before the mayor and council shall hold a public hearing on any such matter, it shall be the duty of one (1) or more investigators from the police department to make a survey of conditions surrounding such location and to report to the mayor and council at its hearing. After such hearing upon any such application, the mayor and council shall thereupon take final action within thirty-five (35) days from said hearing. 
(Code 1972, §§ 15-60, 15-61; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10-20. 
State Law reference- Junk or metal dealers' records, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-350 et seq.; junkyards near certain highways, 
O.C.G.A. § 32-6-240 et seq.; removal of junked motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4; scrap metal processors, O.C.G.A. § 43-43-1 et seq. 
Sec. 30-5-5. - Shooting galleries-Permit required. 
    Any person desiring to open a shooting gallery in the city shall first deposit with the assistant city manager the license tax prescribed therefor, and then make a written application for a permit to be presented at a regular meeting of the mayor and council. Such permit may be denied, in the discretion of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 15-66; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-5-6. - Same-Admitting minors and drunken persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person conducting a shooting gallery to allow minors, except with the consent of their parents or guardians, or drunken persons, to shoot therein. 
(Code 1972, § 15-67) 
State Law reference- Ordinances on intoxication, O.C.G.A. § 37-8-11. 
Sec. 30-5-7. - Shows-Animal shows or circuses; proximity to residences. 
    It shall be unlawful for any show or circus with animals to operate or exhibit in the city within three hundred (300) yards of any residence, without the written consent of the occupant of such residence. 
(Code 1972, § 15-68) 
Sec. 30-5-8. - Same-Gambling. 
    Licenses granted to circuses or other shows shall not authorize such shows, or any person connected with them, to operate any game of chance, or any gambling or gaming device, or any other game or device prohibited by law. 
(Code 1972, § 15-69) 
State Law reference- Gambling and related offenses, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20 et seq. 
Sec. 30-5-9. - Same-Fire protection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person having in charge, or assisting in the management of any circus, show, horse show, dog show or similar exhibition, to which the public is invited through the sale of tickets of admission or the giving of passes, to permit the attendance of the public in numbers in excess of the number of seats provided, or to fail to provide means of access to, and exit from, such seats, or to permit such means of access and exit to become crowded before, during or after performances. 
(Code 1972, § 15-70) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10-10. 
Sec. 30-5-10. - Skating rinks, etc. 
    No license shall be issued by the assistant city manager to any person for operating skating rinks, walking rinks or rinks of like character, except by order of the mayor and council. Any person desiring such license shall make application therefor, stating the location, size and the kind of structure to be used. The same may be granted by the mayor and council at their discretion. 
(Code 1972, § 15-71; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-5-11. - "Spieling." 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit business or customers by what is commonly known as "spieling" on the streets of the city, or to solicit business or customers by crying out in a loud manner or voice for any business house in the city, or for anyone to stand in front of or near any storehouse or business house or business located in the city and direct, in any manner whatsoever, people to said storehouse or business for the purpose of trading therein. 
(Code 1972, § 15-72) 
Sec. 30-5-12. - Financial institutions business license tax-Levied. 
    Pursuant to O.C.G.A. section 48-6-93, there is hereby levied for each calendar year a business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations and state building and loan associations within the city, at the rate of twenty-five one-hundredths (0.25) percent of the gross receipts of said institutions as defined in O.C.G.A. section 48-6-93 or one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. of 11-22-83, § 1) 
Sec. 30-5-13. - Same-Due date; filing of return. 
    Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. Such returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the state department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in subsection (d) of O.C.G.A. section 48-6-93. The tax levied pursuant to section 30-5-12 shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in said return. The due date of such tax shall be January 1 of each year and shall be due in accordance with the schedule set forth in section 30-1-9 of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 11-22-83, § 2; Ord. No. 95-46, § 2, 12-21-95) 
Secs. 30-5-14-30-5-30. - Reserved. 
Article II - BILLIARD ROOMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1 et seq.; "billiard room" and billiards defined, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1. 

Sec. 30-5-31. - Definitions. 
    Billiard room means any business operated in the city utilizing a minimum of three (3) billiard tables at which persons are permitted to play the game of billiards and for which a charge is made for use of said equipment. 
    Billiards means any of the several games played on a table surrounded by an elastic ledge of cushions with balls which are impelled by a cue and shall include all forms of the game known as "carom billiards," "pocket billiards," and "English billiards." 
    Alcoholic beverages shall be defined as set forth in section 30-20-7 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, § 1, 7-27-99; Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 2-26-13) 
Sec. 30-5-32. - Requirement of license; filing of application. 
    No person shall operate a billiard room in the city without a license. No license to operate a billiard room shall be issued to any person who is not at least twenty-one (21) years of age and a citizen of the United States, nor to one who has been convicted of a felony. Application for a license to operate a billiard room shall be first made to the assistant city manager. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, § 1, 7-27-99; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-5-33. - Regulatory fee. 
    Upon approval of the application, the city shall issue the license for the current year or unexpired portion thereof upon the payment of any applicable business license fee, occupation tax, or administrative fee and the payment of a regulatory fee in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. No. 99-28, § 1, 7-27-99; Ord. No. 99-33, § 1, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 30-5-34. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any establishment which is authorized to sell alcoholic beverages to operate a billiard room between the hours of 1:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m., Tuesday thru Saturday; from 12:00 midnight on Saturday to 12:30 p.m. on Sunday; and from midnight on Sunday to 6:00 a.m. on Monday. It shall also be unlawful to permit any person to remain in such billiard room between such prohibited hours except regular employees or agents performing necessary labor on the premises. 
(b)  The billiard room operating hours prohibition as set forth in this section shall not apply to a business which includes a billiard room if the billiard room is not operated during the prohibited hours. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, § 1, 7-27-99; Ord. No. 00-26, § 1, 10-5-00; Ord. No. 12-23, § 1, 12-11-12) 
Sec. 30-5-35. - Age of admission; gambling prohibited; view of premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to play billiards in, or for any other purpose to enter or remain in, a billiard room in which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale. 
(b)  No gambling of any kind shall be permitted upon the premises of billiard rooms. 
(c)  Every billiard room shall be open to the common public, in accordance with the laws of this state. No part of the room shall be concealed from other parts for the operation of tables; that is, no participants shall be permitted in an enclosed room to utilize private tables. The billiard room shall always be open to inspection by the city police during operating hours. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 2-26-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-05, § 2, adopted February 26, 2013, deleted the former § 30-5-35, and enacted a new § 30-5-35 as set out herein. The former § 30-5-35 pertained to admission of persons under eighteen (18) years of age and derived from Ord. No. 99-28, adopted July 27, 1999. 
Sec. 30-5-36. - Sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  No licensee shall allow, condone or permit customers or patrons to bring, possess or consume alcoholic beverages of their own on the premises. Brown bagging, as defined in section 30-21-1 of the Code, is prohibited on any premises licensed under this article. 
(b)  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, served or allowed to be used in and on the premises of a billiard room or any place operated in connection therewith, unless and except such premises or establishment is an establishment which is authorized to sell alcoholic beverages and derives at least fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross revenues from the sale of products or services other than alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, § 1, 7-27-99) 
Sec. 30-5-37. - Exceptions. 
    This chapter shall not apply to billiard tables or billiard rooms operated by private industrial concerns, Young Men's Christian Associations, religious orders, charitable institutions, state, county or city institutions, fraternal orders or bona fide clubs using such tables for members or employees only. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, § 1, 7-27-99) 
Sec. 30-5-38. - Penalty. 
    Every person, firm or corporation operating a billiard room within the city without having applied for a license shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to the penalties or punishment set forth in Code section 1-1-6. Each day that the billiard room is operated without a license shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, § 1, 7-27-99) 
Sec. 30-5-39. - Grounds for suspension or revocation; notice; hearing; refund. 
(a)  Any license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued by the city to any licensee under this article may be suspended or revoked for due cause as hereinafter defined, and after a hearing has been held by the mayor and council for the purpose of considering any such suspension or revocation. At least five (5) days prior to such hearing, written notice of the time, place and purpose of such hearing, and a statement of the charge or charges upon such hearing is to be held shall be given to the holder of such license for which suspension or revocation is to be considered. 
(b)  Due cause for the suspension or revocation of a license shall consist of a violation of any laws or ordinances applicable to or regulating such business, violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating such business; or failure of the licensee or his employees to promptly report to the police department any violation of the law or ordinances, any breach of the peace, disturbance or altercation resulting in violence which may occur in or upon the licensed premises. 
(c)  The mayor is hereby authorized to suspend any license issued hereunder in an emergency situation, or any situation wherein the mayor deemed such an immediate suspension necessary for the protection of the health and welfare of the citizens of LaGrange, and said suspension may be made effective immediately and shall remain in force until the mayor determines such an emergency is over or until the next regular meeting of the mayor and council, or a meeting called prior to the next regular meeting. 
(d)  When a license is suspended or revoked hereunder, the city shall not refund any portion of the license, occupation, administrative or regulatory fee to the holder of such suspended or revoked license. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, § 1, 7-27-99) 
Secs. 30-5-40-30-5-65. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Formerly, Art. II contained a Div. 2, License, substantive sections thereof being §§ 30-5-46-30-5-49, derived from the 1972 Code, §§ 15-78-15-80, 15-83. Such sections were repealed by Ord. No. 89-7, § 2, adopted Jan. 24, 1989, and the user's attention is directed to § 30-5-32. 
Article III - SIGNERS AND SURETIES OF BONDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Professional bondsmen, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-50 et seq. 

Sec. 30-5-66. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, any person who shall, for compensation, sign any bond for the appearance of any accused person in the recorders court, procure bond for such person or deposit collateral for such person in lieu of bond, shall be deemed a professional bondsman and engaged in business as such. 
(Code 1972, § 15-89) 
State Law reference- Persons deemed professional bondsmen, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-50. 
Sec. 30-5-67. - Violations. 
    Any professional bondsman violating this article shall, on conviction in the recorder's court, be punished for a violation of this Code and shall automatically be barred from signing bonds in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-96) 
State Law reference- Violations of laws pertaining to professional bondsmen, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-55. 
Sec. 30-5-68. - Permit-Required; prerequisite to issuance of license. 
    No person shall carry on or be engaged in the business of professional bondsman until authorized so to do by a permit granted by the mayor and council upon recommendation of the public safety committee. No business license shall be issued to a professional bondsman until such permit has been granted. 
(Code 1972, § 15-90) 
Sec. 30-5-69. - Same-Petition; bond schedules. 
    All persons engaged or desiring to engage in the business of professional bondsmen shall on or before the first day of January, in each year, file with the public safety committee a petition for a permit to engage in such business. Such petition shall contain: 
(1)  A description of all real property in this county owned in fee simple by such person, and the clear market value of each item of real property so scheduled; 
(2)  A description of mortgages, liens or other encumbrances affecting such real property, showing the maturity date and amount thereof; and 
(3)  A statement of the total amount of all bonds upon which the petitioner may, at that time, appear as surety; and a subschedule of all bonds upon which the petitioner may, at that time, appear as surety which have been forfeited and not paid. The mayor and council may require the petitioner to file, in addition, a schedule showing separately the date and penal sum of all of the bonds upon which the petitioner then appears as surety. 
All schedules and subschedules required by this section shall be made under oath by the petitioner; provided, if the petitioner is a firm, each member of the firm shall sign the same, and if a corporation, two (2) principal officers thereof authorized by the corporation's bylaws shall sign the same and the corporate seal shall be affixed. 
(Code 1972, § 15-91) 
Sec. 30-5-70. - Same-Investigation; verification. 
    It shall be the duty of the public safety committee to investigate thoroughly all petitions and to verify all schedules required in this article. Such committee shall not recommend the issuance of a permit to a professional bondsman unless: 
(1)  The petition and accompanying schedules shall clearly show that the petitioner is the owner of real property in this county of a fair market value, in excess of encumbrances, equal to the total of all bonds upon which the petitioner may at that time appear as surety, plus the amount allowed as exemption under the homestead laws of the state; or 
(2)  The petitioner procures and submits to city, in lieu of the real property schedule described herein, a fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) surety bond. 
(Code 1972, § 15-92; Ord. No. 08-26, § 1, 11-6-08) 
Sec. 30-5-71. - Requiring additional schedules. 
    The mayor and council may at all times require professional bondsmen to submit schedules of property and of bonds upon which they appear as surety. In the event such schedules disclose the insolvency or inability of a bondsman to sign bonds because of an excess of liability over assets, the council may bar such bondsman from signing further bonds in the recorder's court for so long as such insolvency or inability exists. Any professional bondsman who shall fail to furnish such schedules within five (5) days after demand, or who shall furnish a false schedule, shall thereafter be barred from signing bonds in connection with cases in the recorder's court. 
(Code 1972, § 15-93) 
Sec. 30-5-72. - Visiting prisoners; signing bonds. 
    No professional bondsman or agent of such bondsman shall be permitted to visit prisoners or to sign bonds for any person imprisoned unless such person shall have previously procured permission from the chief of police or his designated agent. 
(Code 1972, § 15-94) 
State Law reference- Bondsmen in places where prisoners are confined, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-52. 
Sec. 30-5-73. - Loitering, etc., in police station or grounds; calling bondsmen. 
    No professional bondsman shall loiter in the police station or grounds, nor enter the same except when attending court or on business in connection with a case wherein he is surety on a bond, nor shall he speak to any prisoner at the police station unless authorized so to do by the police officer on duty. The police officer shall not grant such authority until he has received from the prisoner a written request naming the bondsman he wishes to see. In cases where no bondsman is named by the prisoner, the station lieutenant shall call bondsmen in rotation until one is secured. 
(Code 1972, § 15-95) 
State Law reference- Bondsmen loitering around courts, jails, etc., O.C.G.A. § 17-6-52. 
Secs. 30-5-74-30-5-90. - Reserved. 
Article IV - PAWNBROKERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Labels on remanufactured or rebuilt items, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-80 et seq.; theft by receiving stolen property, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-7; dealers in used watches, O.C.G.A. § 43-49-1 et seq.; pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.; liens of pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. §§ 44-14-400 et seq., 44-14-403; satisfaction of liens, O.C.G.A. §§ 44-14-408, 44-14-550. 

Sec. 30-5-91. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Pawnbroker: Any person engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers as a part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this paragraph. 
    Pawnshop: The business operated by a "pawnbroker," as defined in this section. 
(Code 1972, § 15-102) 
State Law reference- Definitions, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130. 
Sec. 30-5-92. - Permit application. 
(a)  Any person, before beginning the business of operating a pawnshop or similar place of business, shall file an application with the assistant city manager for a permit to conduct such business. The application for permit shall state the name and address of the applicant, the street and number at which the applicant proposes to operate such business and the names and addresses of all persons having a financial interest in such business. 
(b)  The application for license shall list all convictions, guilty pleas, or pleas of nolo contendere by or against the applicant for a period of ten (10) years preceding the date of such application for violation of any felony or misdemeanor of any state, or of the United States, or any municipal ordinance other than for traffic violations, together with a waiver sufficient to authorize investigation of the criminal record of the applicant, if any. 
(Code 1972, § 15-103; Ord. No. 90-68, § 1, 1-8-91; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
State Law reference- Power of city to exercise supervision of pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136. 
Sec. 30-5-93. - License-Issuance. 
(a)  The applicant for a license pursuant to this article must be a person of good moral character and a citizen of the United States. The issuing authority in determining or considering the good moral character of the applicant shall have the right to take into consideration any appropriate facts revealed by its investigation and by consideration of the application for a permit. 
(b)  No license shall be issued under this article to any person until the permit required by this article shall have been granted by the council. After the permit has been issued by the council, the assistant city manager shall issue such license as may be required for the conduct of such business on payment of the amount required therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 15.104; Ord. No. 90-68, § 2, 1-8-91; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
State Law reference- Power of city to license pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136. 
Sec. 30-5-94. - Same-Revocation; suspension. 
    Any person failing to comply with the provisions of this article or such other ordinances and regulations as may be adopted by the council for the conduct of the business of a pawnshop, shall be subject to having his permit and license to conduct such business revoked or suspended for a definite period of time in the discretion of the council. Such forfeiture and suspension shall result from conviction in the recorder's court of a violation of any provision of this article or any other ordinance or regulation covering the conduct of the business for which such permit and license shall have been issued. The mayor and council may also consider a failure of the permit application to contain any record of convictions required by section 30-5-92 of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 15-105; Ord. No. 90-68, § 3, 1-8-91) 
State Law reference- Power of city to revoke pawnbroker licenses, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136. 
Sec. 30-5-95. - Record of transactions; inspection by police. 
    All pawnbrokers shall keep books wherein shall be entered an accurate, detailed description of all property pledged or sold to them. Such description shall include the name of the maker of the article, any identifying mark or number and a description of the kind of material of which it is made so that such article can be reasonably and definitely identified. There shall also be entered in such book the name, address and age of the person by whom such article was deposited or sold, and the date and hour the transaction was made. If the pawnbroker accepting such article is not personally acquainted with the person making such deposit or sale, the pawnbroker shall require identification sufficient to show the name, age, and address of such person and sufficient to show that the identification information given is not fictitious or false. Such book and the articles pledged or sold shall at all times be subject to inspection and examination by the police. Upon refusal of the proprietors at any time to submit their shops to a thorough inspection by the police, the shops shall be immediately closed and the permit and license revoked. 
(Code 1972, §§ 15-7, 15-106) 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers' records, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-132 et seq. 
Sec. 30-5-96. - Holding period for goods. 
    Any pawnbroker or person operating under a pawnshop license who takes goods on pawn or buys goods, taking full title thereto, the word "goods" being used in this section in the broadest sense and including all kinds of personal property, shall hold such goods so taken in pawn or purchased for at least thirty (30) days before disposing of the same by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. 
(Code 1972, § 15-107) 
Sec. 30-5-97. - Reports of transactions. 
    Every pawnbroker shall complete a daily report, in such form as may be prescribed by the chief of police, of all property pledged to or bought by him during each twenty-four-hour period ending at 8:00 p.m. on the date of such report, such report to show the name and address of the pawnbroker; the time of each transaction; the serial number on the pawn ticket; the amount paid or advanced; a full description of the article, including the kind, style, material, color, design, kind and number of stones in jewelry and all identifying names, marks and numbers; and a description of the person selling or pawning, including the name, address, race, sex, weight and height and such other information as may be required by the chief of police. The form required by this section shall be picked up from each pawnbroker by the police of the city on Monday and Thursday of each week, and the same shall be completed and up-to-date at the time it is picked up. 
(Code 1972, § 15-108) 
Sec. 30-5-98. - Purchases from minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker, pawnshop operator or his agents or employees to receive in pawn or to purchase any goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any character or description from any person who is less than eighteen (18) years of age. Any pawnbroker, pawnshop operator or his agents or employees shall have the burden of requiring identification sufficient to show that any person making a pawn or sale is not less than eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Code 1972, § 15-109) 
State Law reference- Age of legal majority, O.C.G.A. § 39-1-1. 
Sec. 30-5-99. - Sale of knives, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for pawnbrokers to sell, offer for sale or expose for sale any kind of metal knuckles, dirks, sword-in-canes, spears, bowie knives, switchblade knives or any blackjack or any other similar weapons, the possession of which is prohibited by the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-110) 
State Law reference- Carrying concealed weapon, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-126. 
Sec. 30-5-100. - Hours of operation. 
    The hours within which pawnshops may remain open shall be from 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. 
(Code 1972, § 15-111) 
Secs. 30-5-101-30-5-110. - Reserved. 
Article V - PEDDLERS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Peddlers or itinerant sellers of plant seeds, O.C.G.A. § 2-11-27; disabled veterans and blind persons, O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1 et seq.; peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq. 

Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-5-111. - Licenses; taxes. 
(a)  Nothing contained in this article shall exempt any person from payment of licenses or taxes as otherwise provided from time to time. 
(b)  Other than as provided in section 30-5-116 of this article V, it shall be unlawful for any person to peddle or to engage in the business of peddler without first obtaining in force a license therefor as required by section 30-1-7 of this title and paying the appropriate fee therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 15-121; Ord. No. 90-44, § 2, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 94-18, § 1, 6-14-94) 
State Law reference- Peddlers and itinerant traders licensed by probate court, O.C.G.A. § 3-32-1 et seq. 
Sec. 30-5-112. - Vehicles to keep moving. 
    Except as authorized by section 30-5-116 of this article V, all peddlers in the city, when using a vehicle of any sort to transport the goods, wares or merchandise they are offering for sale, shall keep said vehicle moving from place to place; and it shall be unlawful for any such peddler to park said vehicle and make sale from the parked vehicle on the streets, sidewalks or public ways of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-122; Ord. No. 94-18, § 2, 6-14-94) 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq. 
Sec. 30-5-113. - Stands prohibited on streets, etc. 
    Except as provided in section 30-5-116 of this article V, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to peddle, sell or otherwise do or conduct business of any kind or maintain stands for vending goods or other articles on the streets, sidewalks or other public ways of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-123; Ord. No. 94-18, § 3, 6-14-94) 
Sec. 30-5-114. - Hours of operation. 
    Peddlers operating under this article shall do so only from 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. 
(Ord. No. 03-17, § 1, 4-22-03) 
Sec. 30-5-115. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - CONCESSION STANDS 

Sec. 30-5-116. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, a concession stand is defined as being a stand containing not more than twenty-five (25) square feet, designed and to be used for the purpose of selling and delivering sandwiches, hot dogs, hamburgers, non-alcoholic soft drinks and beverages, desserts and related food snacks at the fixed location defined in the license issued pursuant to the provisions hereof. Any such location must be within and be limited to that area bounded on the south by the north right-of-way of Broome Street; on the north by the south right-of-way of Haralson Street; on the west by the west property lines of Bull Street, West LaFayette Square and Church Street; and on the east by the east property lines of Main Street, East LaFayette Square and Ridley Avenue, each such location to meet the criteria hereinafter specified. Such license, when issued, shall be effective only insofar as the city is authorized to license or permit the same as applies to state roads, highways and rights-of-way under the jurisdiction of the state department of transportation. Any other licenses or permits required shall be the sole responsibility of the applicant/licensee. 
(b)  A concession stand and any signage on or attached thereto must conform with design guidelines issued by the LaGrange Downtown Development Authority. 
(Ord. No. 94-18, § 4, 6-14-94) 
Sec. 30-5-117. - Regulations for licensees. 
    Each concession stand authorized and licensed pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be operated in accordance with and shall at all times meet the following criteria: 
(1)  Each license sold shall be for a designated area. 
(2)  Each concession stand must be of a cart design approved by the director of community and economic development of the city and must be capable of and will be removed from the public property or right-of-way daily at the close of business. 
(3)  Such cart may sell only those items specified and named in its license and must have, prior to operation, and maintain during the entire time of operation, all appropriate certifications and approvals required by the health department or any agencies or departments of the state. 
(4)  The concession stand authorized hereby shall: 
a.  Be open and shall be operated only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. and shall not be motorized but can only be hand-pushed. 
b.  The stand must not have any noise-making equipment. 
c.  The neatness and cleanliness of the operator and the concession stand must at all times meet the reasonable criteria established by the department of community and economic development of the city and must be available for inspection at any time requested. 
d.  The license required hereby may be annually renewed, contingent upon inspection and compliance with the provisions of this division. 
e.  There shall be no trash, garbage, waste, etc., deposited or disposed of in the area around the concession stand except in approved and authorized receptacles. 
f.  The owner must agree and must execute an agreement to indemnify, save and hold the city, its officers, agents or employees harmless of and from any claim, damages, costs expenses or other liability that may be imposed upon the city, its officers, agents or employees, resulting from or in any way connected with or reasonably related to the licensing or operation of the concession stand business contemplated hereby and will maintain liability insurance coverage for such purpose, with a company or companies acceptable to the city in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence, which policy of insurance shall show the city, its officers, agents or employees, as additional insured and shall provide to and maintain with the city appropriate certification of insurance. 
(5)  The business authorized by and the license to be issued pursuant to the provisions of this division shall not be operated less than two hundred fifty (250) feet, as measured along the most reasonable traveled route, of any other licensed food concession stand or within one hundred (100) feet, as measured along the most reasonable traveled route, of any licensed food service establishment in existence at the time the license contemplated hereby is to be granted. Additionally, any such concession stand will not be operated within a minimum distance of fifteen (15) feet of any existing or future authorized curb cuts, driveways or intersections; and no such concession stand shall obstruct any entrance to driveways and must at all times be self-sufficient for operating purposes. Under no circumstances will any connecting water lines, electrical lines or other utility connections be made to any such concession stand. 
(Ord. No. 94-18, § 5, 6-14-94) 
Secs. 30-5-118-30-5-125. - Reserved. 
Division 3 - PERMIT 

Sec. 30-5-126. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to go in or upon any private residence, apartment or premises in the city for the purpose of soliciting from the occupants thereof, or to canvass for orders of goods, wares, merchandise or services of any character or description, or for the purpose of offering to give or to furnish, or to give or furnish any goods, wares, merchandise or services to any such occupants to induce or invite such orders, without having first applied for and received from the chief of police a permit to do so. 
(Code 1972, § 15-116) 
Sec. 30-5-127. - Application. 
    Any person desiring to secure a permit under this division shall apply therefor in writing over his signature to the chief of police on forms provided by the city, and such application shall state the: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  Name and address of the person by whom employed; 
(3)  Length of service of such applicant with such employer; 
(4)  Place of residence and nature of the employment of the applicant during the preceding twelve (12) months; 
(5)  Nature or character of the goods, wares, merchandise or services to be offered by the applicant; and 
(6)  Personal description of the applicant. 
Such application shall be accompanied by such credentials and other evidence of the good moral character and identity of the applicant as may be reasonably required by the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 15-117) 
Sec. 30-5-128. - Issuance; expiration. 
    If the chief of police shall determine after reasonable investigation that the applicant is of good moral character and proposes to engage in a lawful and legitimate commercial or professional enterprise, he shall issue the permit applied for, which permit shall expire on the first day of January next after the permit has been issued. 
(Code 1972, § 15-118) 
Sec. 30-5-129. - Carrying, exhibiting. 
    A permit issued under this division shall be carried at all times by the person to whom issued, when soliciting or canvassing in the city, and shall be exhibited by any such person whenever he shall be required to do so by any police officer or any person solicited. 
(Code 1972, § 15-119) 
Sec. 30-5-130. - Revocation. 
    Any permit issued under this division may be revoked by the chief of police for violations by the holder thereof of any of the ordinances of the city or of any state or federal law, or whenever the holder of such permit in the judgment of the chief of police ceases to possess the character and qualifications required by this article for the issuance of such permit. 
(Code 1972, § 15-120) 
Secs. 30-5-131-30-5-145. - Reserved. 
Article VI - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq. 

Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-5-146. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this article, a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor is defined as any person, firm or corporation or any combination thereof, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, and whether a resident of the City of LaGrange or not, that engages in any business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within the corporate limits of the City of LaGrange, and, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any premises other than a permanent building or structure, including but not limited to a motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, boat, public room in hotels, lodging places, apartments or alley for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction. There are excepted from and not included in this definition: 
(1)  Any person occupying any such temporary location that does not sell or offer to sell from stock but merely exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery; and 
(2)  Any person selling or undertaking to sell agricultural products produced or grown by such person. 
No transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor as defined herein shall be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article by reason of any temporary association with any licensed local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business on the premises of, in conjunction with, as a part of or in the name of any such local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(Code 1972, § 15-173; Ord. No. 04-33, § 1, 9-28-04) 
Sec. 30-5-147. - Findings. 
    The mayor and council hereby find, determine and declare that the unregulated and uncontrolled operation of businesses in the city by transient merchants, itinerant merchants or itinerant vendors as defined in this division is subject to abuse and is being abused and it is necessary for such business or businesses to be appropriately defined, licensed and regulated by the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-171) 
Sec. 30-5-148. - Records of complaints, convictions, violations. 
    The assistant city manager, together with the police department and any other law enforcement agencies located in the city, shall keep and maintain a record of all complaints received against any person licensed under the provisions of this article and of any records for convictions or violations of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 15-179; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-5-149. - Limit of operation on any one lot. 
    A transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor may remain and transact business upon any one lot within the City of LaGrange for up to ten (10) consecutive days or consecutive portions of days. Once said transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor has ceased to transact business upon said lot, however, whether after one (1) or up to ten (10) days or portions of days, said merchant or vendor may not conduct business or otherwise remain thereon for sixty (60) days. Merchants participating in events on public property sanctioned and approved by the Downtown LaGrange Development Authority or the Troup County Parks and Recreation Commission shall be exempt from the durational requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 04-33, § 2, 9-28-04; Ord. No. 18-17, § 1, 12-20-18) 
Secs. 30-5-150-30-5-160. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - LICENSE 

Sec. 30-5-161. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor as defined in this article to engage in or operate the business thereof within the city without first obtaining and maintaining in force a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 15-172) 
Sec. 30-5-162. - Application. 
    Applicants for license required by this article shall file a written application signed by the applicant with the assistant city manager, which application shall contain and show: 
(1)  The name or names of the person or persons having management or supervision of the applicant's business during the time the same is proposed to be conducted or carried on in the city; the local address of such person or persons so engaged in the city; the permanent address of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); and if a corporation, the state in which the same is incorporated, whether the corporation is domesticated or licensed to do business in the State of Georgia, the registered agent of the corporation in the State of Georgia and the designated agent for the service of process in the State of Georgia; 
(2)  The place or places in the city where the applicant proposes to carry on the business described in its application; the hours in which the applicant proposes to keep said business open to the public; and the length of time during which the applicant proposes to conduct any such business; 
(3)  The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where the applicant within the six-month period next preceding the date of such application conducted a transient business as described in this article, stating the nature of such business and giving the post office and street address of the location in which such business was conducted; 
(4)  A statement as to the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares and merchandise to be sold; whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or by sample; and whether the same are to be sold by direct sale or by taking orders for future delivery only; 
(5)  Credentials or other necessary written authorization from the person for whom the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act for and on behalf of such person as his representative; and 
(6)  Such other reasonable information pertaining to the identity or character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business that the assistant city manager or his agent may deem necessary or proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. 
(Code 1972, § 15-174; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
State Law reference- Foreign corporations, O.C.G.A. § 14-2-310 et seq. 
Sec. 30-5-163. - Investigation; issuance. 
    Upon receipt of the application required by this division, the assistant city manager shall cause such investigation into the application and the purposes thereof as he may deem necessary for the protection of the public good and welfare. If the application shall be found to comply with the provisions of this article, a license shall be issued in accordance with the provisions thereof but a complete record of the application, the license and the issuance thereof shall be maintained by the assistant city manager as a part of the permanent records of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-175; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-5-164. - Exhibition of license; separate place of business. 
    The license issued pursuant to this article shall be posted conspicuously in the place where the business so licensed is located and conducted. In the event that such person or persons applying for said license shall desire to do business in more than one (1) location within the city, separate licenses shall be required for each place of business and a license shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Code 1972, § 15-176) 
Sec. 30-5-165. - Fees. 
    The applicant for a license under the provisions of this division shall pay at or prior to the time of application, a license fee as specified in section 30-1-24 of this title for each year and for each location for which a license is required in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-177; Ord. No. 86-23, § 3, 6-26-86; Ord. No. 90-44, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 95-8, § 3, 3-14-95) 
Sec. 30-5-166. - Transfer. 
    The license issued pursuant to the provisions of this division shall not be transferred or assigned except as authorized by the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-178) 
Sec. 30-5-167. - Revocation. 
(a)  The license issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the mayor and council after reasonable notice to the licensee and an opportunity for a hearing thereon for any one (1) or more of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statements contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statements made in conjunction with the sale of goods, wares or merchandise; 
(3)  Violation of any of the provisions of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of the licensee of any felony, or of any misdemeanor or crime involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed pursuant to the provisions of this article in an unlawful manner, in a manner to constitute a public nuisance or in a manner to constitute a breach of peace or to constitute a menace to health, safety or the general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing to the licensee, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time, date and place of the hearing thereon. Such notice shall be served on the licensee by handing the same to the person in charge of the licensed business or by mailing the same postage prepaid to the licensee at his last known address or to the designated agent for the service of process or the registered agent of the licensee, at least five (5) days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(c)  Service of the notice shall suspend the license pending the outcome of the hearing, and any business operation conducted pursuant to the provisions of the license shall promptly cease and terminate. 
(Code 1972, § 15-180) 
Secs. 30-5-168-30-5-180. - Reserved. 
Article VII - CARNIVALS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, adopted June 25, 2009, repealed the former Art. VII, Amusement Rides, § 30-5-181, and enacted a new Art. VII, Carnivals, as set out herein. 

Sec. 30-5-181. - Amusement activity defined. 
    Amusement activity means an enterprise principally devoted to offering amusement or entertainment to the public for a price in, upon, or by means of amusement rides in any number or combination, whether or not associated with other structures or forms of public attraction, and which is located at a temporary location. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 6-25-09) 
Sec. 30-5-182. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hold, maintain, conduct or sponsor any amusement activity within the meaning of this article without having first obtained a license and having complied with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 6-25-09) 
Sec. 30-5-183. - Application. 
    All persons desiring a license to conduct an amusement activity shall make written application upon forms available in the office of community development. Such application shall state the name and address of the applicant; the place where the proposed amusement activity is to be located; the nature and character of the activity to be carried on; if a partnership, the names of the partners; and, if a corporation, the names of the corporate officers. The application shall further include the general plan and layout of how the area concerned is to be used, to include parking facilities, and, if applicable, proof that the amusement activity is possessed of a valid permit from the State of Georgia pursuant to the Amusement Ride Safety Act. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 6-25-09) 
Sec. 30-5-184. - Insurance requirement. 
    If for any reason the operator of an amusement activity is not required to have in force liability insurance or other surety pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 34-12-14 (Amusement Ride Safety Act), said applicant shall also present to the city evidence of public liability insurance in an amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to one (1) person; two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for all injuries arising from one (1) accident; and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damages, such insurance to be written by a company authorized to transact business in the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 6-25-09) 
Sec. 30-5-185. - Condition of premises; orderly operation. 
    All premises of an amusement activity shall be kept clean and in proper sanitary condition and, when food is served in connection with the amusement activity, full compliance shall be maintained with the provisions and regulations governing the conditions of premises used for the storage and sale of food for human consumption. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 6-25-09) 
Sec. 30-5-186. - Issuance; fee; duration. 
    If the license application meets the conditions set forth in this article, a license shall be issued for the designated location after payment of a regulatory fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any license issued under this article shall not be valid beyond a period of fourteen (14) days. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 6-25-09) 
Secs. 30-5-187-30-5-200. - Reserved. 
Article VIII - MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Replays on coin-operated devices, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35. 

Sec. 30-5-201. - Definition.
