    All persons engaged in the taxicab business in the city shall have drive-in terminals or stations at which all vehicles shall be parked while not engaged in the actual transportation of persons. No taxicab shall be left parked on the streets of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 25-31) 
Sec. 30-15-27. - Same-Headquarters; separate license for each terminal. 
    All persons engaged in the business of operating taxicabs shall have a designated place of business or headquarters, the location of which shall be stated in the application for license when filed, and upon the issuance, such license shall be good for only one (1) place of business. The location of such headquarters or terminal must be approved by the mayor and council and a license fee must be paid for each terminal or business location. 
(Code 1972, § 25-32; Ord. No. 92-20, § 1, 6-23-92) 
Sec. 30-15-28. - Taxicab markings and lettering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab in the city unless such taxicab shall be equipped as follows: 
(1)  The name of the entity, enterprise or company shall be painted or affixed by decal to and shall appear on the left and right front doors of all vehicles operated as taxicabs; 
(2)  A dome light shall be permanently affixed to the top of any vehicle operated as a taxicab, bearing the term "taxi" or the name of the entity, business or company operating the taxi business. The sign shall be lighted at all times while the headlights of such vehicle are required to be displayed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-8-20; 
(3)  Each vehicle operated as a taxicab by licensee shall either have painted or affixed by decal an identifying number, unique to each vehicle, on the left and right rear quarter panel and on the right-hand side of the most vertical surface of the rear trunk. 
(Code 1972, § 25-33; Ord. No. 96-62, § 4, 12-19-96) 
Sec. 30-15-29. - Stopping in traffic lanes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver of a taxicab to stop his vehicle in a traffic lane on the streets of the city for the purpose of receiving, discharging or waiting for passengers. 
(Code 1972, § 25-34) 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq. 
Sec. 30-15-30. - Cruising. 
    It shall be unlawful for any taxicab driver to cruise the streets of the city for the purpose of soliciting business. 
(Code 1972, § 25-35) 
Sec. 30-15-31. - Number of passengers; compliance with seatbelt and child restraint laws. 
    The operators and drivers of taxicabs in the city are authorized to carry that number of passengers equal to the number of seatbelts available for passenger use. It shall be the responsibility of the operators and drivers of taxicabs to insure that passengers comply with all applicable seatbelt and child restraint laws. 
(Code 1972, § 25-36; Ord. No. 97-9, § 2, 2-25-97) 
Sec. 30-15-32. - Use of vehicle for lewdness, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver of a taxicab operating within the city to permit any person to occupy or use such taxicab for the purpose of prostitution, lewdness or assignation, or to direct, take or transport, or offer to take, direct or transport, any person with knowledge or reasonable cause to know the purpose of such directing, taking or transporting is for prostitution, lewdness or assignation. 
(Code 1972, § 25-37) 
State Law reference- Public indecency, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-8; prostitution, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-9; pimping O.C.G.A. § 16-6-11. 
Sec. 30-15-33. - Drivers' hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any individual to drive a taxicab for more than twelve (12) hours in any one (1) day. 
(Code 1972, § 25-38) 
Sec. 30-15-34. - Type of vehicle; maintenance; inspection. 
    To insure the safety of taxicab passengers and other motorists on the streets of the city, the chief of police, or his designee, shall inspect each taxicab licensed hereunder on an annual basis, the regulatory fee for such inspection being twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per inspection. Such inspection shall include the following: 
(1)  Interior and exterior vehicle. The interior and exterior of each vehicle shall remain in a clean condition and be free of foreign matter and offensive odor and shall present a clean environment for passengers. 
(2)  Equipment and/or conditions. Headlights, tail lights, signal lights, brake lights, interior lights, exhaust system, muffler, tires (including spare tire), vehicle glass including windshield, steering and brakes. 
(3)  It is the intent of this article that any vehicle used as a taxicab will adhere to the minimum requirements and regulations contained in the Code of the City of LaGrange and the laws of the State of Georgia. Vehicle defects disclosed in the above-referenced inspection shall be repaired by licensee immediately. Depending on the nature of the inspection failure or defect, in the discretion of the chief of police, a licensee may be allowed to continue to operate the vehicle as a taxicab prior to reinspection and confirmation that the defect has been corrected. However, in the discretion of the chief of police, should the defect or inspection failure be deemed to significantly affect the safety of the public or taxicab passengers, licensee will not be allowed to operate the vehicle as a taxicab on the streets of the city until the defects disclosed in the inspection are repaired, and the vehicle is reinspected and approved for use by the chief of police. 
(4)  Pursuant to the regulatory power exercised herein, the operator of any taxicab licensed or permitted hereunder shall be subject to periodic unscheduled inspections by the city police department to determine compliance with the provisions of this article. Anyone operating a taxicab within the city limits and subject to the regulations exercised herein shall permit such reasonable, timely and appropriate inspections, the denial of same being grounds for revocation of the applicable license, chauffeur's permit, or both. 
(Code 1972, § 25-39; Ord. No. 96-62, § 5, 12-19-96) 
State Law reference- Equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq. 
Sec. 30-15-35. - Fares-Schedule. 
(a)  The per passenger charge for all persons transported in taxicabs in the city, excluding children age four (4) and under who are in a child passenger restraining system as defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-8-76, and who are in the charge of a nurse, parent or adult person in loco parentis shall, for groups of two (2) or more be a maximum of five dollars ($5.00) for the first passenger and one dollar ($1.00) for each additional passenger and otherwise shall be five dollars ($5.00) per passenger. These rates shall be effective twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week. 
(b)  Each taxicab in operation in the city must have posted continuously in plain view of the passengers riding therein, the rates currently being charged by such taxicab. 
(Code 1972, § 35-40; Ord. No. 96-7, § 1, 2-13-96; Ord. No. 97-9, § 1, 2-25-97; Ord. No. 05-16, § 1, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 08-17, § 1, 7-8-08) 
Sec. 30-15-36. - Same-Posting in vehicle; compliance. 
    Each taxicab shall have posted in a conspicuous place therein a schedule of rates for the transportation of persons within the city. No charge for transportation of any person within the city shall be made in excess of the rates so posted. Said schedule of rates shall be within full view of the passengers of such taxicab, and displayed in such a manner as to be easily ascertained and understood by the passengers. 
(Code 1972, § 25-41) 
Sec. 30-15-37. - Smoking prohibited. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in all taxicabs operating within the City of LaGrange. For purposes of this code section, the term "smoking" shall have such meaning as is established in the Georgia Smoke-Free Air Act of 2005, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 4-25-06) 
Secs. 30-15-38-30-15-50. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - PERMIT TO ENGAGE IN BUSINESS 

Sec. 30-15-51. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated in the city any taxicab unless he possesses a current, unrevoked, written permit for the operation thereof issued by the city through the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 25-18) 
Sec. 30-15-52. - Application. 
    An application for a permit under this division shall be made to the mayor and council by petition, which shall set forth the name, address and place of business of the applicant, if an individual, and if a partnership, the name and address and place of business of each partner, and the place of business, and if a corporation, the name and address of each of the officers of such corporation and the place of business of such corporation; the trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business; the name of the insurance company with which the applicant has made arrangements to secure his insurance as required by the provisions set forth in this chapter, together with the financial statement of such insurance company; a color scheme desired to be used by the applicant; and such other information as may be required or requested by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 25-19) 
Sec. 30-15-53. - Investigation. 
    The mayor and council shall make or cause to be made an investigation, including any hearing deemed necessary, as to each application for permit for the operation of taxicabs. In determining whether a permit shall be issued, the mayor and council may investigate the fitness of the applicant to engage in the business of operating taxicabs, and shall make or cause to be made an investigation in order to determine whether the demands of public convenience, necessity and safety shall justify the issuance of a permit. 
(Code 1972, § 25-20) 
Sec. 30-15-54. - Issuance; denial; transfer. 
    If the mayor and council decide that a permit for the operation of taxicabs shall be granted, they shall grant such permit to the applicant under the provisions set forth in this chapter and the ordinances of the city. Such permit shall not be transferable except upon application to and consent by the mayor and council, and any person operating under such transfer shall not undertake such operation until final approval and transfer has been approved by the mayor and council, and completed, and a new license issued. Should the mayor and council find that the public convenience, necessity and safety do not justify the issuance of such permit, or that the insurance company with or in which the applicant has made arrangements to secure insurance as set forth in this chapter is not a good and responsible company, or that the provisions of the proposed policy do not give ample protection to the public, or that the applicant is not a fit person to conduct the taxicab business, no permit shall be issued, and notice of the action taken by the mayor and council setting forth the reason for the refusal to issue a permit shall be given to the applicant. 
(Code 1972, § 25-21) 
Sec. 30-15-55. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  The operator of any taxicab licensed hereunder shall display inside the vehicle at all times during the operation of the vehicle as a taxicab the valid chauffeur permit of the vehicle operator. The operator shall retain within said vehicle at all times during operation the following information: the current occupational tax receipt and/or regulatory license(s) and proof of insurance as required in this article. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of each taxicab driver, operator or owner, upon finding personal property of a passenger, to immediately return such personal property to its owner, if known, and if not known to immediately forward such property to the city police department. 
(Ord. No. 96-62, § 6, 12-19-96; Ord. No. 05-16, § 2, 10-11-05) 
Secs. 30-15-56-30-15-65. - Reserved. 
Division 3 - CHAUFFEUR'S PERMIT 

Sec. 30-15-66. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a taxicab on the streets of the city without a current, unrevoked chauffeur's permit from the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 25-25) 
Sec. 30-15-67. - Application. 
    Any person being eighteen (18) years of age or older may make application to the chief of police for a chauffeur's permit. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make an investigation of the applicant and the knowledge of the applicant of the traffic regulations of the city and the motor vehicle laws of the state. The chief may issue a chauffeur's permit if he finds that said applicant possesses sufficient knowledge of the traffic regulations and laws. Said permit shall be in writing, signed by the chief of police, and shall bear the corporate seal of the city. Said permit shall state the name, address, sex, race and age, and shall have the signature, of the applicant. The chief of police shall cause to be secured, before the issuance of the permit, a copy of the fingerprints of the applicant, and two (2) photographs. Copies of the fingerprints and photograph shall be retained in the files of the police department if said permit is granted. The applicant shall pay the sum of five dollars ($5.00) to the chief of police upon issuance of said chauffeur's permit, which fund shall be remitted to the city. 
(Code 1972, § 25-26; Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 1-27-04) 
Sec. 30-15-68. - Disqualification. 
    A permit shall not be issued under this division to any person who was imprisoned for a felony and has been released within the last three (3) years. 
(Code 1972, § 25-27; Ord. No. 02-01, § 1, 1-8-02) 
Sec. 30-15-69. - Defacing, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person holding a chauffeur's permit to deface, obliterate, change or destroy the same, or cause the same to be obliterated, defaced, changed or destroyed. 
(Code 1972, § 25-28) 
Sec. 30-15-70. - Display. 
    Every driver of a taxicab in the city shall have his chauffeur's permit displayed in such taxicab in a prominent place at all times so that said permit shall be easily discernible by any passenger of such taxicab. 
(Code 1972, § 25-29) 
Sec. 30-15-71. - Revocation; suspension; renewal. 
(a)  Chauffeurs' permits shall be renewed annually, not later than January 1, regardless of the date of issuance. 
(b)  The mayor and council, upon recommendation of the chief of police or upon motion of one (1) of its members, may suspend or revoke any chauffeur's permit issued by the chief of police, if upon investigation or knowledge, they shall find that the holder of said permit has violated any of the provisions of this chapter, or has been convicted of driving a taxicab while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs, or if said person is suffering from a contagious or communicable disease or defect or impairment of vision or other physical handicap that interferes with his ability to perform adequately his duties as a chauffeur under this chapter, or if said person is not otherwise qualified as described in this article. Before such permit shall be suspended or revoked, notice of intention to revoke or suspend shall be served upon the holder either by registered mail or personal delivery, and said person, if he so desires, shall be given an opportunity to be heard at a hearing conducted by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 25-30) 
State Law reference- Discrimination against the handicapped in employment, O.C.G.A. § 34-6A-1 et seq. 
Secs. 30-15-72-30-15-79. - Reserved. 
Article III - AMBULANCES[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Editor's note- Formerly, Art. III, §§ 30-15-86-30-15-94, pertained to ambulances and was derived from the 1972 Code, §§ 25-53-25-58, as amended. Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, adopted Oct. 22, 1996, deleted such article and enacted a new one designated as Art. III, §§ 30-15-80-30-15-89, which pertained to the same subject matter and is herein set out. 
State constitution reference- Power of city to provide ambulance and emergency rescue services, Art. 9, § 2, Par. 3. 
State Law reference- Emergency medical services, O.C.G.A. § 31-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 30-15-80. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings described to them in this section: 
    Advanced life support means the application of procedures and/or administration of drugs which are included in the cardiac technician or paramedic course as approved by the department of human resources. 
    Ambulance service means the providing of emergency care and transportation on the public streets and highways of this city for a wounded, injured, sick, invalid or incapacitated human being to or from a place where medical or hospital care is furnished. 
    Cardiac technician means a person who, having been trained and certified as an emergency medical technician and having completed additional training in advanced cardiac life support techniques in a training course approved by the department of human resources, is so certified by the composite state board of medical examiners. 
    Emergency medical technician means a person who has been certified by the department of human resources of the State of Georgia after having successfully completed emergency medical care training approved by that department. 
    Paramedic means any person who has been certified as an advanced emergency medical technician by the composite state board of medical examiners before July 1, 1988, or any person who has been certified by that board on or after July 1, 1988, as having been trained in emergency care techniques in a paramedic training course approved by the department of human resources, but all such persons shall be designated on or after July 1, 1988, as paramedics. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, group of individuals acting together for a common purpose, or organization of any kind, including any governmental agency other than that of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 30-15-81. - Applicability of article generally. 
    Except as provided in section 30-15-82 hereof, the provisions of this article shall apply to all emergency ambulances operated within the city, but shall not apply to vehicles operated solely for non-emergency services. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 30-15-82. - Exclusions. 
    This article shall not apply to ambulance calls for service originating outside of the city limits, and all ambulances carrying persons from outside such city limits to a point within the city or through the city shall not be subject thereto. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 30-15-83. - Requirement of franchise. 
    No person shall operate an ambulance or ambulance service on the streets of the city without first obtaining from the mayor and council of the city a franchise as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 30-15-84. - Application; requirements for issuance of franchise. 
    An application for a franchise under this article shall be made with the assistant city manager by petition, which shall set forth the name, address and place of business of the applicant, if an individual, and if a partnership the name and address and place of business of each partner, and the place of business, and if a corporation, the name and address of each of the officers of the corporation, and the place of business of such corporation; the trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business; the name of the insurance company with which the applicant has made arrangements to secure insurance as required by the provisions set forth herein; together with the following information, to wit: 
(1)  Written assurance and proof that all personnel of applicant who will provide ambulance services are certified emergency medical technicians, cardiac technicians or paramedics as those positions are certified by the State of Georgia Department of Human Resources; 
(2)  Written assurance and proof that each ambulance to be used by applicant within the city is certified by the State of Georgia Department of Human Resources; 
(3)  Written assurance and proof that applicant will maintain within the city limits a minimum of two (2) ambulances, neither of which shall exceed sixty (60) months in age (remounted vehicles will be deemed new as of the date the chassis is originally titled), equipped and staffed to provide advanced life support services, as defined by the State of Georgia Department of Human Resources, at all times except when such ambulance(s) shall be outside of the city limits while responding to or on a call for ambulances services, in addition to written assurance and proof that each ambulance maintained hereunder shall be staffed by at least one (1) paramedic; 
(4)  Written assurance and proof that applicant is properly licensed by the State of Georgia to provide ambulance services within the state; 
(5)  Written assurance and proof that the applicant will either install mobile or make available portable radio units for each ambulance operated within the city which are capable of communications with city police and fire department personnel; 
(6)  Written assurance and proof that applicant will maintain a written log of requests for service calls and will in addition make such written records available for inspection by the city upon request all in order to determine compliance with the requirements hereunder; 
(7)  Written assurance and proof that all requirements of this article and all other applicable ordinances of the city and statutes of the State of Georgia have been met and fully complied with in order to engage in ambulance services; 
(8)  Written assurance of state mandated workers' compensation insurance and proof of public liability insurance in an amount not less than 1.5 million dollars ($1,500,000.00) for one injury, not less than 1.5 million dollars ($1,500,000.00) for all injuries out of one (1) accident, not less than 1.5 million dollars ($1,500,000.00) property damage, and not less than 1.5 million dollars ($1,500,000.00) for injuries caused by malpractice; 
    Together with the written application described herein, applicant shall submit to the assistant city manager by certified check a three hundred dollar ($300.00) processing fee to cover expenses of investigation and processing of the application, which fee shall not be refundable. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-15-85. - Approval and denial of license; public hearing. 
    Upon determination by the assistant city manager that the application is complete as to form, it shall be presented to and received by the mayor and council at a regular meeting and shall either be granted, if the application is found to comply with the provisions of this article and if the mayor and council in their legitimate discretion determine that such issuance is in the best interest of the citizens of the City of LaGrange, or denied at such meeting, or any subsequent meeting if the matter is tabled or otherwise postponed. The mayor and council may, in their discretion, call for, advertise and hold a public hearing in order to receive comments on the proposed application for franchise prior to decision. If the application for franchise is approved by the mayor and council, the application will be returned to the assistant city manager with the mayor and council approval thereon. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-15-86. - Revocation. 
(a)  The franchise issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the mayor and council after reasonable notice to the licensee and an opportunity for a hearing thereon for any one (1) or more of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statements contained in the petition for franchise; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statements made in conjunction with the provision of ambulance services hereunder; 
(3)  Violation of any of the provisions of this article; 
(4)  Conducting the business franchise pursuant to the provisions of this article in an unlawful manner, in a manner to constitute a public nuisance, or in manner to constitute a breach of peace or constitute a menace to the health, safety or the general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a franchise shall be given in writing to the franchisee, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time, date and place of the hearing thereon. Such notice shall be served on the franchisee by handing the same to the person in charge of the franchised business or by mailing the same, postage prepaid to the franchisee at his last known address or to the designated agent for the service of process or the registered agent of the franchisee, at least five (5) days prior to the date set forth the hearing. 
(c)  Such service of the notice shall suspend the license pending the outcome of the hearing, and any business operation conducted pursuant to the provisions of the franchise shall promptly cease and terminate. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 30-15-87. - Renewal. 
    Any franchise granted under this article, after issuance, must be renewed annually not later than January 1 of each year; and such franchise shall be considered for renewal only in the event a current franchisee is in full and complete compliance with all of the provisions of this article and all other appropriate ordinances of the city and the laws of this state. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 30-15-88. - Non-transferable. 
    No franchise under this article may be sold, transferred or assigned by franchisee, or by operation of law, to any other person, firm or corporation. Any such sale, transfer or assignment or attempted sale, transfer or assignment shall be deemed to constitute a voluntary surrender of such franchise, which will thereafter be null and void; provided and excepting, however, that if the franchisee is a partnership and one (1) or more of the partners should die, one (1) or more of the surviving partners may acquire, by purchase or otherwise the interest of the deceased partner or partners without effecting a surrender or termination of the franchise; and in such case the franchise, upon notification to the city, shall be placed in the name of the surviving partner. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 30-15-89. - Automatic revocation. 
    Whenever the state shall revoke any license required by the franchisee to operate ambulance services, the franchise granted herein shall be automatically revoked without further action by the mayor and council or any other officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-55, § 1, 10-22-96) 
Secs. 30-15-90-30-15-95. - Reserved. 
Article IV - NONEMERGENCY VEHICLES 

Sec. 30-15-96. - Definition. 
    A nonemergency vehicle shall mean a motor vehicle or invalid car used solely to transport persons who are convalescent, sick or otherwise non-ambulatory, but shall not include and specifically excludes an authorized emergency ambulance. 
(Ord. No. 88-123, § 1, 11-22-88) 
Sec. 30-15-97. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or cause to be operated in the city, a nonemergency vehicle without a current unrevoked license therefor issued pursuant to authority granted by the mayor and council of the city. 
(Ord. No. 88-123, § 1, 11-22-88) 
Sec. 30-15-98. - Application for license; insurance and other requirements. 
(a)  An application for license to operate a nonemergency vehicle in the city shall be made to the assistant city manager and the applicant therefor shall provide proof of public liability insurance in an amount not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for one (1) injury, not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for all injuries out of one (1) accident and not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) property damage and shall meet any and all requirements of and provide the necessary certification for authority to operate a nonemergency vehicle required by the State of Georgia. 
(b)  Each non-emergency vehicle shall have printed on each side thereof appropriate language showing that such vehicle is a non-emergency vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 88-123, § 1, 11-22-88; Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-25-89; Ord. No. 92-23, § 1, 7-14-92; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-15-99. - Passenger rates. 
    The charge per passenger for all persons transported in nonemergency vehicles shall be the current reimbursement rate authorized and approved by the Medicaid Reimbursement System in Georgia as such reimbursement rate may, from time to time, be amended or changed. 
(Ord. No. 88-123, § 1, 11-22-88) 
Chapter 30-20 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[17] 
Footnotes: 
--- (17) ---

Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10-20; health, Ch. 10-25; alcoholic beverages in parks, § 15-15-15; zoning, Ch. 25-35. 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. Title 3; local regulation of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-40 et seq.; local regulation of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq.; local regulation of wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41; ordinances on drinking, O.C.G.A. § 37-8-11. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-20-1. - Inspections of stocks. 
    The assistant city manager, chief of police, or other officer directed by the mayor and council to make inspections to determine whether or not the terms and provisions of this chapter are complied with, are hereby clothed with the power and authority to promulgate and enforce such reasonable regulations and requirements for the stacking and placing and keeping of all retail stocks of malt beverages as will most effectually facilitate such examinations and inspections; and a lawful and continued violation of such reasonable regulations, independent of any or all other causes or reasons, shall be sufficient ground for the revocation of the license and permit of the offending dealer by the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-3; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-20-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 06-02, adopted March 28, 2006, deleted § 30-20-2 in its entirety. Former § 30-20-2 pertained to multiple interests in business and derived from the 1972 Code. 
Sec. 30-20-3. - Penalties and punishment-Generally; suspension or revocation of license and permit by mayor and council. 
    No person shall assist another to evade or avoid the payment of the license or excise tax imposed and provided in this chapter; in addition to other penalties, the license and permit of such offender may be suspended or revoked in the discretion of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 4-5) 
Sec. 30-20-4. - Sales to underage persons. 
    Except as provided in section 3-3-23 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated or in section 3-20-6 of this Code, as either may now or hereafter exist or be amended: 
(1)  The furnishing, delivery, or sale of alcoholic beverages, including but not limited to spirituous liquors, malt beverages, beer or wine to person under twenty-one (21) years of age; 
(2)  The purchase or possession thereof by persons under twenty-one (21) years of age; 
(3)  The use of false or fraudulent identification by persons under twenty one (21) years of age for the purpose of purchasing, obtaining, or securing the delivery of any such alcoholic beverages; or 
(4)  The furnishing, delivery, sale or dispensing of any such alcoholic beverages by persons under twenty-one (21) years of age is prohibited. 
(Code 1972, § 4-7; Ord. No. 88-4, § 1, 2-23-88; Ord. No. 90-21, § 1, 5-22-90; Ord. No. 00-1, § 1, 2-8-00) 
Sec. 30-20-5. - Sales to underage persons; penalties; guidelines. 
(a)  Police department sting operations: 
(1)  The LaGrange Police Department will offer training programs and technical assistance to owners and operators of business with alcoholic beverage license(s). 
(2)  The LaGrange Police Department will utilize persons under twenty-one (21) years of age for undercover "sting" operations. Each business with an alcoholic beverage license will be the subject of said undercover operation on an annual basis, and potentially on more numerous or fewer occasions depending on complaints or other information received by the city. 
(3)  Undercover operations may be conducted for the sale of beer, wine, liquor or any combination of the three (3) depending on the licenses held by a particular business. 
(4)  Each business location and/or license for which a conviction has occurred for the sale of alcoholic beverages to person(s) under twenty-one (21) years of age will be the subject of an undercover investigation at least twice within a 12-month period following said conviction, assuming the location or license retains such license. For the purposes of this Code section, "convictions" will include not only those instigated by the LaGrange Police Department, but also by all other local, state and federal agencies and will also include a plea of nolo contendere, first offender status or forfeiture of bond. 
(5)  On or after July 1, 2016, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2.1, within forty-five (45) days of enforcement action being taken against any business for a violation of this section, the LaGrange Police Department will make notification of the violation to the State of Georgia Department of Revenue, consistent with that state department's notification process. 
(6)  As soon as practical after conviction for sale of alcoholic beverages to a minor has occurred, the LaGrange Police Department will report that conviction to the city manager along with the history of other convictions, if any, for all violations of the alcoholic beverages laws at the location at issue. The city manager, in turn, will report each conviction to the city council at a public meeting. 
(b)  Guidelines for license revocation hearings: 
(1)  The mayor and council shall in all instances determine whether a license revocation hearing will be conducted for any business location or licensee convicted for sale of alcoholic beverages to a person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(2)  The mayor and council may schedule a revocation hearing, at its discretion, for any business location or licensee upon its first offense. License revocation hearings will be scheduled for all business locations or licensees having two (2) or more convictions for the sale of alcoholic beverages to a person under twenty-one (21) years of age within a three-year period. 
(3)  For the purposes of this Code section, all previous convictions prior to the date of the adoption of Ordinance No. 00-1 will be considered by the mayor and council within the guidelines herein established. 
(4)  The following minimum and maximum penalties are hereby established by the mayor and council for use in determining the length of license revocations for business locations or licensees convicted of selling alcoholic beverages to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
Minimum Penalty Maximum Penalty First Offense Letter of warning License suspension of up to 90 days Second Offense 90 days suspension of license violated 120 days suspension of license violated Third Offense 120 days suspension of license violated 180 days suspension of license violated Fourth Offense 180 days suspension of license violated Revocation of all alcoholic beverage licenses for one year  
(5)  All licenses issued to separate individuals, partnerships, firms or corporations operating under the same roof, though licensed separately, will be considered as one (1) licensee for the purpose of this Code section, with offenses treated as applicable to all or any such licensee at location. 
(6)  The mayor and council, in the revocation process, shall consider the past history of positive business practices (as defined below) conducted by the business location or licensee which are intended to limit the sale of alcoholic beverages to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age. In order to be considered as mitigating circumstances, such positive practices must have been implemented by the business location or licensee prior to the date of the violation(s) at issue in the revocation hearing. 
(c)  Positive business practices. Following is a list of practices which business owners, managers and licensees are encouraged to consider, in addition to other available programs, all in order to prevent the sale of alcohol to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age: 
(1)  Employee training programs, for both new employees as well as continuing training programs for existing employees; 
(2)  Written policies giving direction for employees to follow for customers presenting false or altered identifications and customers without identification; 
(3)  Written procedures for employee discipline resulting from a failure to follow guidelines established in order to prevent the sale of alcoholic beverages to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age; 
(4)  Written procedures for testing employees for compliance with state laws and other policies regarding sale of alcoholic beverages to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age. Such may include surveillance and controlled buys instigated by business owners and licensees. 
(5)  A background check on all new employees designed to disclose past violation of applicable alcohol laws; 
(6)  Customer awareness programs relating to company policy and state law on sale of alcoholic beverages to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age; and 
(7)  Positive history of business owners and managers reporting violations of local and state laws, if any, to LaGrange Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 00-1, § 1, 2, 2-8-00; Ord. No. 15-10, § 2, 10-13-15) 
Sec. 30-20-6. - Employment of under age persons. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation having a license to sell alcoholic beverages in the city shall allow, permit or require a person in its employment and who is under eighteen (18) years of age to dispense, serve, sell, or take orders for alcoholic beverages; 
(b)  This section shall not prohibit persons under eighteen (18) years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries or drug stores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold solely for consumption off the premises; 
(c)  It is the intent of this section that bus-boys cleaning tables that may include or have alcoholic beverages thereon, or cashiers accepting payment for orders which may include alcoholic beverages, or hostesses or kitchen employees who may also perform bus-boy or cashier functions will not be deemed to be involved in the dispensing, serving, selling, handling or taking orders for alcoholic beverages unless it can be proven that any such employee is otherwise involved in the dispensing, serving, selling, handling or taking orders for alcoholic beverages prohibited by (a) of this section. 
(Code 1972, § 4-8; Ord. No. 90-21, § 2, 5-22-90; Ord. No. 92-42, § 1, 12-8-92) 
Sec. 30-20-7. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Alcoholic beverages shall mean malt beverages or beer as defined by section 30-20-21, spirituous liquors as defined by 30-20-96 and wine as defined by section 30-20-221 of this Code. 
    Downtown development area shall mean that geographical area within the city which constitutes its central business district, as described and modified from time to time by the governing authority. 
    Nightclub shall mean any class B licensee which derives seventy-five (75) percent or more of total annual gross revenue from the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises, and which may provide for its patrons live entertainment performed onsite, including, but not limited to, music, comedy, readings, dancing or acting. 
    Premises, as pertains to both a class A retail package store and to a class B retail pouring outlet, for the sale of spirituous liquors, alcoholic beverages, malt beverages, beer, or wine shall mean the definite closed or partitioned-in locality wherein the same is sold and for which the license therefor is issued whether the same is a room, shop, or building. Additionally, in-so-far as a class B retail pouring outlet (on-premises consumption) is concerned, premises shall also include an open area or patio connected to the premises and containing direct ingress and egress to and from the licensed premises and which is enclosed by some structure so as to prevent access to or from the open area or patio area without the licensee's knowledge. Such enclosure is not required to be solid nor restrict visibility into or out of the patio or open sales area, but must, in the reasonable discretion of the building official, be of a sufficient height to prevent unauthorized ingress or egress. The only exit from the patio or open sales area other than through the licensed premises shall be an approved fire exit of the type that sounds an alarm in the event of unauthorized use of the exit when no emergency exists. Any licensee desiring to use a patio or open sales area shall submit plans and specifications therefor to the assistant city manager for approval prior to use and such plans and specifications shall otherwise meet and comply with all appropriate rules and regulations of the city relating to zoning and the safe and orderly operation of the premises. 
    For outdoor entertainment facilities with seating capacity of over 700, owned or operated by the Downtown Development Authority of the City of LaGrange, premises shall include those boundaries as approved by the city manager, and may include outdoor areas not otherwise described herein. 
    Security personnel shall mean an individual primarily performing duties related to verifying age for admittance, security, maintaining order or safety, or a combination thereof at a class B licensed establishment. 
(Ord. No. 90-21, § 3, 5-21-90; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 11-09, § 1, 5-24-11; Ord. No. 15-10, § 1, 10-13-15; Ord. No. 16-04, §§ 1, 2, 4-12-16; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-20-8. - Election day sales. 
    In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20, nothing in this chapter shall prohibit the sale of alcoholic beverages on any election day within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-55, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 03-35, § 1, 12-9-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-55, § 2, adopted Oct. 23, 1990, added provisions pertaining to election day sales designated as § 30-20-7. Such section has been renumbered by the editor as § 30-20-8 inasmuch as other provisions are designated as § 30-20-7. 
Sec. 30-20-9. - Definitions pertaining to open containers in vehicles. 
(a)  "Open container" shall mean any container of alcoholic beverage which is open so as to render the same immediately capable of being consumed in whole or in part or upon which the seal of the manufacturer has been breached or broken. 
(b)  "Operation of a motor vehicle" shall be deemed to include driving a motor vehicle or parking a motor vehicle upon any public street or public property in the city or any private property in the city which is open to public access or to vehicular traffic. 
(c)  "Location of an open container in a motor vehicle" shall be deemed to include anywhere in or upon a motor vehicle unless such open container shall be placed in the locked trunk or in the locked glove compartment of such motor vehicle, so that such container is not readily accessible to the driver or a passenger. 
(d)  "Passenger" shall be deemed to include any person in or upon a motor vehicle other than the driver or operator of such motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 90-9115, § 1, 5-28-91) 
Sec. 30-20-10. - Possession of or consumption from open container in vehicle prohibited; exception. 
(a)  No person shall possess an open container of alcoholic beverage or consume alcoholic beverage while operating a motor vehicle in the city. For the purposes of this section, an open container of alcoholic beverages shall be considered to be in the possession of the operator or driver of a vehicle if the same is in the possession of the driver, is readily accessible to the driver and is not admittedly in the possession of a passenger in or upon the vehicle. 
(b)  No passenger in a motor vehicle in the city shall consume alcoholic beverages from or be in possession of an open container of alcoholic beverages while riding as a passenger in or upon a motor vehicle in the city. If an open container is found in any motor vehicle and is not admitted to be in possession of a passenger in such motor vehicle, such open container shall be considered to be in the possession of the operator or driver of such vehicle. 
(c)  In the event of the unexplained or unadmitted presence of an open container of alcoholic beverage in a motor vehicle in the city, it shall be conclusively presumed that such open container is in the possession of the operator or driver of such vehicle and such operator or driver shall be considered to be in possession thereof. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to a motor vehicle driven by a chauffeur or other driver licensed by the city or the driver of a vehicle for hire pursuant to a duly issued certificate of public convenience and necessity in the State of Georgia unless it can be proven that the driver of such vehicle was in possession of an open container. 
(Ord. No. 90-9115, § 1, 5-28-91) 
Cross reference- Traffic generally, Ch. 10-20; drive-in window service of alcoholic beverages prohibited, § 30-20-189; public drunkenness, § 35-1-25. 
Sec. 30-20-11. - License applications; contents and terms. 
(a)  All applications for licenses to sell alcoholic beverages of any kind shall be made in person to the assistant city manager of the city or his designated representative in writing on forms furnished by the city; the application must be completed and signed and shall contain all information reasonably required by the assistant city manager or his designee and shall include but is not necessarily limited to the following: 
(1)  The name, date of birth, current home address and the length of residency of an applicant in the City of LaGrange, in Troup County, and in the State of Georgia; 
(2)  The name, location and description of the premises or place of business to be operated under such license; 
(3)  A statement as to whether the applicant or any person having an interest in the application has made, at any previous time, an application for alcoholic beverage license and if so the disposition of such application; 
(4)  Whether the applicant or any person having an interest in the application, including the record owner of the premises for which licensing is requested, has ever been convicted of a crime, including traffic violations involving driving under the influence of alcoholic beverages or driving under the influence of a Georgia controlled substance, but not otherwise including traffic offenses. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt, first offender status, plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond by a person charged with a crime; 
(5)  Whether a previous license issued to the applicant or any person with an interest in the application has been revoked by the federal government, State of Georgia or any subdivision thereof; 
(6)  Whether any other person, firm or corporation other than a corporation whose stock is publicly sold and listed on a national stock exchange regulated by the federal securities and exchange commission, has any interest directly or indirectly in the profits or losses of the business; 
(7)  A statement that the premises for which the license is sought complies with all applicable zoning and building codes and regulations of the City of LaGrange, but the application shall include to the extent necessary plans and specifications for any new construction, additions to or renovations of the premises for which the license is sought; 
(8)  The application will include information sufficient to show the ownership of the building and shall contain a copy of the lease to the building if the applicant is leasing the building; 
(9)  The payment at the time of application of any and all application fees required by the applicable provisions of the City Code; 
(10)  To the extent required by the appropriate provisions of this chapter, a completed statement of the applicant's financial condition sufficient to show financial responsibility of the applicant; 
(11)  And any and other documentation, information and forms required by other appropriate provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Each application, after filing but prior to consideration by the city manager, shall be advertised and public notice thereof given as required by the appropriate provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  The making of any untrue or misleading statements in the application for license shall, among other reasons, be sufficient cause for refusal, suspension, revocation or cancellation of a license as the city manager or mayor and council may in their discretion deem appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 92-32, § 1, 9-22-92; Ord. No. 02-38, § 3, 12-10-02; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 09-14, § 2, 8-25-09; Ord. No. 14-05, § 1, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-20-12. - Investigations. 
    Upon filing of an application in accordance with the provisions of section 30-20-11, the assistant city manager or designee shall submit the application to the police department of the city for investigation of the applicant and the compliance by the applicant with the terms and provisions of this chapter, for investigation of the criminal history of the applicant and for a recommendation relating to the application. He shall also submit the application to the department of economic and community development of the city of investigate and to insure compliance with the various ordinances, codes and regulations of the city including but not limited to zoning, restaurant occupancy and fire codes and any distance requirements imposed by state law or the ordinances of the City of LaGrange. The police department and the department of community and economic development will report the results of their respective investigations to the assistant city manager within forty-five (45) days of the application and upon receipt thereof, the assistant city manager or designee will report the results of such investigation to the city manager with any recommendations thereon. 
(Ord. No. 92-32, § 1, 9-22-92; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 14-05, § 2, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16; Ord. No. 18-13, § 1, 11-27-18) 
Sec. 30-20-13. - Approval or denial of license. 
    The report on the application for a license shall be received by the city manager and if such application is otherwise complete shall either be granted or denied within fifteen (15) days of receipt; however, should the city manager, in his discretion, determine that the final decision on any application should be deferred to the mayor and council, he shall schedule the matter for a determination at the next available regular meeting of the mayor and council. If the application for license is approved by the city manager, the application will be returned to the assistant city manager and will be referred by said assistant city manager to the department of community and economic development which will have the responsibility of collecting all necessary fees and issuing the appropriate license. 
(Ord. No. 92-32, § 1, 9-22-92; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 14-05, § 3, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-20-14. - Authority to grant or deny license; appeal. 
(a)  Within the guidelines of due process required within O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2, the city manager, based upon the facts set forth in the application and revealed by the appropriate investigations, shall have the authority to approve the application and grant the license, disapprove the application and deny the license, or refer the matter to the mayor and council for final action. The provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2 relating to due process, including but not limited to notification and the right to a hearing, shall be complied with by the city. 
(b)  If the city manager denies an application for a license, the applicant shall be provided notice in writing of the denial which shall include the reason(s) therefor. The applicant shall have the right to appeal such denial to the mayor and council by filing a request for hearing with the city manager no more than ten (10) days following the receipt of the denial notice. The hearing before the mayor and council shall be held not more than thirty (30) days from the date the city manager receives the notice of appeal. The applicant shall have the right to be represented by an attorney at the hearing, at his or her expense, and to present evidence and cross-examine opposing witnesses. Within ten (10) days from the conclusion of the hearing, the mayor and council shall notify the applicant in writing of their decision. 
(Ord. No. 92-32, § 1, 9-22-92; Ord. No. 14-05, § 4, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-15. - Open containers and possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages on public property; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to have possession of an open container or to drink or to consume alcoholic beverages on the streets, sidewalks, alleyways or other public thoroughfares of the city or upon parks, playgrounds or other public property either inside or outside of any vehicle whether moving or parked, or any building or facility thereon, at any time. The prohibition contained herein shall also extend to and shall include the parking lots, public areas and other outdoor premises of any private business which is licensed to sell alcoholic beverages or which is otherwise licensed to conduct business where such areas are normally open to the general public. 
(b)  The prohibitions contained within this section shall not apply as relates to licensed patios or open sales areas pursuant to the provisions of code section 30-20-7; to properties owned or operated by the Downtown LaGrange Development Authority or Downtown Development Authority of the City of LaGrange and upon or within which the sale and/or consumption of alcohol is sanctioned by either Authority; to areas authorized pursuant to a lawfully issued special event permit pursuant to the provisions of code section 30-5-350, et seq.; or to areas authorized pursuant to a lawfully issued sidewalk cafe permit pursuant to the provisions of code section 30-5-315, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 94-38, § 1, 9-13-94; Ord. No. 14-11, § 2, 10-14-14) 
Sec. 30-20-16. - License fee schedule. 
(a)  The license fee schedule for persons, firms, businesses or corporations conducting the sale or manufacture of alcoholic beverages is as follows: 
Spirituous liquors 
    Class A, retail package store ..... $5,000.00 
    Class B, retail pouring outlet ..... 1,600.00 
    Class C, wholesale ..... 2,000.00 
Beer and malt beverages 
    Class A, package sales only ..... 160.00 
    Class B, on premises consumption ..... 270.00 
    Class C, wholesale ..... 100.00 
Wine 
    Class A, package sales only ..... 160.00 
    Class B, on premises consumption ..... 270.00 
    Class C, wholesale ..... 135.00 
(b)  For an application requesting a change in manager at a licensed establishment, the fee shall be one hundred thirty-five dollars ($135.00). 
(Ord. No. 95-46, § 7, 12-21-95; Ord. No. 09-13, § 1, 8-11-09; Ord. No. 12-01, § 1, 1-10-12; Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 2-12-13) 
Sec. 30-20-17. - Brown bagging. 
    For the purposes of this Code section, a brown bagging establishment is defined as a commercial establishment permitting or condoning the practice of allowing customers or patrons to bring, possess or consume alcoholic beverages of their own on the premises of the establishment. It shall be unlawful within the city for a brown bagging establishment to be open to customers or patrons between the hours of midnight and 6:00 a.m., Tuesday through Friday; between the hours of midnight on Saturday to 12:30 p.m. on Sunday; and between the hours of midnight Sunday to 6:00 a.m. on Monday. The owner and operator of a brown bagging establishment shall display a notice containing the prohibitions of this section upon the premises at all times and in such fashion that said notice may be viewed by patrons of the establishment. The owner of each brown bagging establishment shall declare the intent to operate as a brown bagging establishment pursuant to this ordinance at the time of registration to do business in the city, pursuant to section 30-1-7, and for any annual renewal of said registration. 
(Ord. No. 12-22, § 1, 12-11-12; Ord. No. 15-10, § 3, 10-13-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-22, § 1, adopted December 11, 2012, deleted the former § 30-20-17, and enacted a new § 30-20-17 as set out herein. The former § 30-20-17 pertained to brown bagging prohibited and derived from Ord. No. 01-25, adopted September 25, 2001 and Ord. No. 02-13, adopted May 14, 2002. 
Sec. 30-20-18. - Issuance of license to persons with prior convictions prohibited; exception. 
    No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages in the city shall be issued to any person, partnership or corporation where any individual having an interest therein, either as owner, partner, stockholder or having a direct or indirect beneficial or absolute interest, including the record owner of the premises proposed for the license, or the spouse of any such person, shall have been convicted or shall have taken or entered a plea of nolo contendere within a period of five (5) years immediately prior to the filing of such application for any felony or misdemeanor of any state, or of the United States, or of any municipal ordinance, including traffic violations involving driving under the influence of alcoholic beverages or driving under the influence of a Georgia controlled substance, but otherwise not including traffic violations. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty, a plea of nolo contendere, first offender status, or the forfeiture of a bond by a person charged with a crime. If the violation is for a misdemeanor, forfeiture of bond, violation of municipal ordinance, or if there is a plea of nolo contendre, the city manager may, after investigation, waive such conviction as a disqualification. 
(Ord. No. 02-38, §§ 1, 2, 12-10-02; Ord. No. 09-14, § 1, 8-25-09; Ord. No. 10-03, § 1, 3-9-10; Ord. No. 14-05, § 5, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-19. - Purchase, consumption or possession by or for minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase, drink or possess any alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain a place wherein minors are allowed and permitted to come and purchase, drink or posses any alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any parent or other person to buy alcoholic beverages and furnish the same to a minor for consumption. 
(d)  It shall be the responsibility of the licensee of any establishment to examine the identification of patrons to be certain that such patrons are of legal age. A Georgia Driver's License, which is apparently valid upon its face, may be accepted by the licensee or his employee or agent as evidence of age. Notwithstanding the contents of this subparagraph, however, on or after July 1, 2016, and in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 3-3-24.1, any class B licensee defined as a nightclub in section 30-20-7 shall not employ or assign any individual who is less than twenty-one (21) years of age to serve as security personnel as defined in section 30-20-7. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section, a minor shall be a person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, § 2, 4-11-06; Ord. No. 15-10, § 4, 10-13-15) 
Sec. 30-20-20. - Alcohol caterers; event permit for catered functions. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term: 
(1)  Licensed alcoholic beverage caterer means any person, other than a private club, who holds a valid license from the State of Georgia and any county or municipality in this state wherein the caterer's place of business is located which authorizes the licensee to sell, either by the drink or package, wine, malt beverages or distilled spirits. 
(2)  Authorized catered function means a function held at a location within the city for which an event permit has been issued in accordance with this section. 
(b)  Any person who holds a valid license from the county or municipality wherein his place of business is located, including the City of LaGrange, which authorizes the licensee to sell malt beverages or wine by the package or by the drink for consumption on the premises may apply to the city for an "off-premises consumption: malt beverages/wine" license to distribute malt beverages or wine by the drink off-premises within the city at authorized catered functions in conjunction with food service. Applications shall be supported by evidence of required licenses in good standing. 
(c)  Any person who holds a valid license from the county or municipality wherein his place of business is located, including the City of LaGrange, which authorizes the licensee to sell distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine, by the package or by the drink for consumption on-premises may apply to the city for an event permit to sell distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine, by the drink off-premises within the city at authorized catered functions in conjunction with food service. Applications shall be supported by evidence of required licenses in good standing. 
(d)  The event permit application shall be filed with the department of community development and shall be approved or disapproved by the city manager, or his designee, within fourteen (14) days of the filing of a complete application. Such application must include the name of the caterer, together with his license number; the date, time and duration of the event; the name and address of the event host or sponsor, and, if different, the address of the location where the event will be held. The application shall be signed by the licensed alcoholic beverage caterer and the event host or sponsor. If the event host or sponsor is not the owner of the property at which the event will be held, then the owner of the property, or the owner's authorized agent, shall sign the application consenting to the distribution of alcoholic beverages at that location. 
(e)  Each event permit shall require payment of a fifty dollars ($50.00) fee; provided, however, if the caterer maintains a place of business within the City of LaGrange, such fee shall be waived. No event permit shall be issued for more than three (3) consecutive days and a full permit fee shall be assessed for each day of the event. 
(f)  The licensed alcoholic beverage caterer shall provide such personnel as needed to handle all alcoholic beverages served or dispensed at the catered event. This shall include bartending, dispensing, serving, providing, or furnishing of alcoholic beverages. Employees of a licensed alcoholic beverage caterer shall be twenty-one (21) years of age or older in order to handle beverage alcohol at such catered event. 
(g)  In addition to the specific requirements applicable to caterers as required herein, sales of alcoholic beverages by a licensed alcoholic beverages caterer shall be subject to all other applicable regulations of this chapter according to the underlying city alcoholic beverages license held by said caterer. For those caterers who hold an underlying license from another jurisdiction, the regulations will be those which would apply if such caterer's underlying license were issued by LaGrange. 
(h)  Any person violating any of the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-11-4 regulating off-premises consumption sales by licensed alcoholic beverage caterers shall be tried, upon citation returnable to the municipal court, for a violation of this chapter, and, if convicted, punished in the manner hereinafter provided. 
(i)  At the discretion of the city manager, the city may deny an alcoholic beverage catering license or event permit to any applicant found to have violated any local or state law regulation relating to the service or sale of alcoholic beverages while operating within the city. 
(Ord. No. 11-08, § 1, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 12-16, §§ 1, 2, 9-25-12; Ord. No. 12-21, §§ 1, 2, 11-27-12) 
Article II - MALT BEVERAGES OR BEER 
Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-20-21. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    Beer: Any fermented beverage made in whole or in part from malt, and any similar fermented beverage. 
    Brewer: Any person who manufactures malt beverages. 
    License: The authorization by the City of LaGrange to engage in the sale of malt beverages or beer in the city in one (1) of the following classes: 
(1)  Class A license (retail package store). A class A license shall authorize the retail dealer to sell malt beverages or beer in the package only and not for consumption on the premises. 
(2)  Class B license (on-premises consumption). A class B license shall authorize the retailer to sell malt beverages or beer in its original package and/or for consumption on the premises. 
(3)  Class C license (wholesale). A class C license shall authorize the sale by any person, firm or corporation of malt beverages or beer to a licensed retail dealer for the purpose of resale only. 
    Malt beverage: A fermented beverage made in whole or in part from malt, and any similar fermented beverage, but no such beverage shall be sold or manufactured under this article which contains more than six (6) percent of alcohol by volume. 
    Retail dealer: A person, firm or corporation licensed by the city to sell malt beverages or beer at retail within the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-17; Ord. No. 14-05, § 6, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-22. - Sale to intoxicated person. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell to a person in an intoxicated condition or who appears to be in an intoxicated condition any malt beverage, and it shall be the responsibility of the person to whom the permit is issued to enforce this section. 
(Code 1972, § 4-21) 
State Law reference- Sale, etc., of alcoholic beverages to intoxicated persons, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-22. 
Sec. 30-20-23. - Excluding rowdy, intoxicated or disorderly persons. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons granted a permit under this article, and their employees in such place of business, to keep their premises clear of all persons who are rowdy or noisy; who are intoxicated; who fail to keep the peace or who do anything which tends to disturb the peace or cause any other disturbance. 
(Code 1972, § 4-22) 
Sec. 30-20-24. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Class A license (package store). A class A licensee shall not sell, dispense or deliver beer or malt beverages on Sunday except between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. 
(b)  Class B license (on-premises consumption). 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in paragraph (3) below, a class B licensee shall not sell, dispense, serve or deliver beer or malt beverages between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Tuesday through Saturday, and shall not sell, dispense, serve or deliver beer or malt beverages from 1:00 a.m. on Sunday to 6:00 a.m. on Monday. 
(2)  A class B licensee must close its doors to business, must be vacated of all persons except the licensee and any on-duty paid employees or agents, and must cease to do business at or before 2:00 a.m. and remain closed until 6:00 a.m. on each day of the week. 
(3)  A class B licensee which derives at least fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food, or fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging, may sell, dispense, serve or deliver beer or malt beverages between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight on Sunday. 
(Code 1972, § 4-23; Ord. No. 87-89, § 1, 7-28-87; Ord. No. 12-07, § 1, 3-27-12; Ord. No. 15-10, § 5, 10-13-15) 
Sec. 30-20-25. - Wholesaler delivery hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for a wholesale malt beverage dealer to make deliveries of malt beverages before 6:00 a.m. and after 6:00 p.m. 
(Code 1972, § 4-25) 
Sec. 30-20-26. - Delivery vehicle ownership, transportation method restricted. 
    The transportation or delivery of malt beverages for resale within the city shall be by a conveyance owned and operated by a licensed wholesale dealer of malt beverages, licensed to make deliveries in the city, and it shall be unlawful to transport or deliver malt beverages by any other means. 
(Code 1972, § 4-26) 
Sec. 30-20-27. - Confiscation of illegally distributed beverage; punishment of violator. 
    All malt beverages offered for sale in the city by a distributor not licensed to make deliveries in the city, shall be confiscated, and in addition, the distributor punished for a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 4-27) 
Sec. 30-20-28. - Storage of beverages, inspection. 
    Malt beverages received within the city by a wholesale or retail licensee shall be stored only in the premises for which a license is issued and shall be subject to inspection at all times. 
(Code 1972, § 4-28) 
Sec. 30-20-29. - Distance requirements for sale of beer and malt beverages. 
    No person shall sell or offer to sell and no license shall be issued for the sale of: 
(1)  Beer or malt beverages within one hundred (100) yards of any school building, school grounds, or college campus, except for "on-premises consumption" (class B license) sales within the downtown development area, for which there shall be no such distance requirement. This subparagraph shall not apply at any location for which a license has been issued prior to July 1, 1981, nor to the renewal of such license. Nor shall this subparagraph apply at any location for which a new license is applied for if the sale of beer was lawful at such location at any time during the twelve (12) months immediately preceding such application; 
(2)  Beer or malt beverages for "on-premises consumption" (class B license) within one hundred (100) yards of any church building, except within the downtown development area, in which there shall be no such distance requirement; provided however that the distance requirement contained in this subparagraph shall not apply to any person who held a license authorizing "on-premises consumption" of beer or malt beverages on January 28, 1975, but any such license exempted by the provisions hereof shall not be transferable. 
(3)  No person shall knowingly or intentionally sell or offer to sell beer or malt beverages within one hundred (100) yards of an alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the State of Georgia, by Troup County or by the City of LaGrange. This section shall not apply to any business having a license to sell beer or malt beverages which was in effect on July 1, 1981, and which has continued in full force and effect since that date. 
As used in this section, the term "school building" shall apply only to state, county, city, or church school buildings and to such buildings at such other schools in which are taught subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state. 
(Code 1972, § 4-29; Ord. No. 85-24, § 1, 8-27-85; Ord. No. 94-45, § 2, 10-11-94; Ord. No. 16-04, § 4, 4-12-16) 
Sec. 30-20-30. - Growlers. 
(a)  For the purposes of this code section, the term "growler" means a bottle not to exceed a capacity of seventy-two (72) ounces that is capable of being sealed with a screw cap and with a plastic collar over the screw cap and is filled at the time of customer purchase by the licensee or employee of the licensed establishment with beer from a keg for off-premises consumption. 
(b)  The sale of growlers in compliance with this section is authorized for establishments with a class B permit and, to the extent authorized by the Department of Revenue, a class A permit license authorizing the sale of malt beverages. 
(c)  Growlers may only be filled from kegs procured by the licensee from a duly licensed wholesaler. 
(d)  Only professionally sanitized and sealed growlers may be filled and made available for retail sale. 
(e)  Each growler must be securely sealed and removed from the premises in its sealed condition. 
(f)  Consumption on the premises from a growler is strictly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 14-11, § 1, 10-14-14) 
Sec. 30-20-31. - Employees alcohol beverage card (ABC); procedure. 
(a)  No person whose duties involve dispensing, serving, selling, handling or taking orders for malt beverages or beer may be employed by an establishment until such person has been issued an alcoholic beverage card (ABC card) by the police department indicating the person to be employed is eligible for such employment. 
(b)  All persons subject to the provisions of this section shall, within seven (7) days after the date of their first work in an establishment holding a license to sell malt beverages or beer, report to the police department for issuance of an alcohol beverage card. 
(c)  The police department shall make a complete and exhaustive search relative to the criminal record of any person so employed. The ABC card shall be denied or revoked, as the case may be, in the event the applicant employee shall have been convicted within a period of five (5) years immediately prior to the application for an ABC card of any alcohol related offense. The chief of police may, after investigation, waive any such conviction if, within his discretion, such should not constitute a bar to the issuance of an ABC card. 
(d)  Any letter of eligibility for employment issued hereunder shall expire twelve (12) months from the date of the issuance unless earlier canceled by the police department. The police department may prescribe regulations for certifying the eligibility for continued employment without the necessity of a further search relative to the record of that person. The police department may prescribe reasonable fees and times for certifying eligibility for employment and the fees shall be paid by the employer or the employee at the time request for eligibility certification is made. Any such fees shall be approved by the mayor and council of the city. 
(e)  The licensee, or the manager of the licensed premises, shall be responsible for the conduct or actions of the employees and shall have the responsibility of ensuring compliance with the provisions of this code section. 
(Ord. No. 16-04, § 6, 4-12-16; Ord. No. 18-07, § 1, 8-14-18) 
Sec. 30-20-32. - Class D license alcohol awareness training. 
    No class B license for on premises consumption of beer or malt beverages shall issue for a location which is not a restaurant (as defined in Code section 30-20-96) until the manager of said licensed establishment shall have completed the alcohol awareness training required for a sidewalk cafe permit as established in section 30-5-322 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 16-04, § 7, 4-12-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-04, § 7, adopted April 12, 2016, set out provisions intended for use as § 30-20-31. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 30-20-32. 
Secs. 30-20-33-30-20-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Formerly, Div. 1 contained substantive § 30-20-30, which prohibited sale of beer and malt beverages within 100 yards of an alcoholic treatment center, derived from Ord. No. 93-6, § 1, adopted Feb. 9, 1993. Such section was repealed by Ord. No. 94-45, § 1, adopted Oct. 11, 1994. The user's attention is directed to § 30-20-29(3) for similar provisions. 
Division 2 - LICENSES; PERMITS 

Sec. 30-20-46. - Permit and license tax payment, prerequisite to doing business. 
    It shall be lawful to sell malt beverages at retail or wholesale in the city only after the proper permit has been applied for and issued by the city and upon the payment of the proper city license or business tax designated for said business. 
(Code 1972, § 4-34; Ord. No. 92-32, § 2, 9-22-92) 
Sec. 30-20-47. - Sale without permit prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any malt beverage unless he has secured the permit required in this article. 
(Code 1972, § 4-35) 
Sec. 30-20-48. - Conditions of permit embraced in chapter. 
    Any person granted a permit to sell malt beverages in the city may carry on the business only under the conditions and restrictions of this chapter, which are conditions under which such permits are issued. 
(Code 1972, § 4-36) 
Sec. 30-20-49. - Display of permit. 
    The permit issued under this article shall be posted in a conspicuous place in full view of the public. 
(Code 1972, § 4-37) 
Sec. 30-20-50. - Retail sale, permit required. 
    No beer or malt beverages shall be sold at retail in the city except under a license or permit granted pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 4-38; Ord. No. 87-58, § 1, 1-27-87; Ord. No. 89-16, § 1, 6-15-89; Ord. No. 14-05, § 7, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-51. - Issued to stated address; approval required for relocation. 
    The licenses and permits issued pursuant to the provisions hereof shall apply to the address stated therein and shall not be moved to or operated at another address without the written approval of the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 4-39; Ord. No. 89-16, § 1, 6-15-89; Ord. No. 14-05, § 8, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-52. - Grounds for suspension or revocation; notice; hearing; refund. 
(a)  Any license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued by the city to any licensee may be suspended or revoked for due cause as hereinafter defined, and after a hearing is held by the mayor and council for the purpose of considering any such suspension or revocation. At least five (5) days prior to such hearing written notice of the time, place and purpose of such hearing, a statement of the charge or charges upon which such hearing is to be held shall be given to the holder of such license for which suspension or revocation is to be considered. 
(b)  Due cause for the suspension or revocation of a license shall consist of a violation of any laws or ordinances applicable to or regulating such business, violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating such business; or for the violation of any state or federal law or regulation, or for the violation of any city ordinances other than traffic ordinances; or failure of the licensee or his employees to promptly report to the police department any violation of the law or ordinances, any breach of the peace, disturbance or altercation resulting in violence which may occur in or upon the licensed premises. 
(c)  The mayor is hereby authorized to suspend any license issued hereunder in any emergency situation such as civil disorders or natural disasters, or in any situation wherein the mayor deems such immediate suspension necessary for the protection of the health and welfare of the citizens of LaGrange, and said suspension may be made effective immediately and shall remain in force until the mayor determines the emergency is over or until the next regular meeting of the mayor and council, or a meeting called prior to the next regular meeting.
