(d)  When a license is suspended or revoked, the city shall not refund any portion of the license tax to the holder of such suspended or revoked license. 
(Ord. No. 02-38, § 4, 12-10-02) 
Secs. 30-20-53-30-20-55. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 92-32, § 12, adopted Sept. 22, 1992, amended the Code by deleting §§ 30-20-52-30-20-55, which pertained to the contents of application for businesses selling or manufacturing malt beverages, filing and processing the application, denial and appeal of application, and revocation or suspension of permits or licenses. The above mentioned ordinances were derived from Code 1972, §§ 4-40, 4-41, 4-42 and, Ord. No. 89-16, § 1, 6-15-89. 
Sec. 30-20-56. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 89-16, § 1, adopted June 15, 1989, provided for the deletion of § 30-20-56, but did not set out replacement provisions therefor; hence, such section has been reserved. Prior to deletion, § 30-20-56 pertained to permit reinstatement as derived from the 1972 Code, § 4-44. 
Sec. 30-20-57. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 95-46, § 3, adopted Dec. 21, 1995, deleted § 30-20-57, license tax, period. Such provisions were derived from the 1972 Code, § 4-45. 
Sec. 30-20-58. - Nontransferability; issuance to new licensee, resident agent. 
(a)  The holder of any retail license to sell malt beverages or beer in the city must be a person of good moral character and a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted to be a permanent resident of the United States and a resident of the State of Georgia. 
(b)  Licenses or permits issued pursuant to this article may not be transferred from one (1) licensee to another. The city manager may, upon application, issue a new permit or license to a successor in the same business establishment at the same address upon receipt of proof of a bona fide sale or transfer of such business. 
(c)  If the holder of the license for the sale of malt beverages or beer in the city is a corporation or other business entity which is not a bona fide resident of the State of Georgia, the license must be issued to and held in the name of an individual who is a managing officer or agent of the corporation and who must be a resident of the State of Georgia. No license thus granted and issued may be transferred to a successive managing officer or agent without the prior approval of the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 4-46; Ord. No. 87-58, § 2, 1-27-87; Ord. No. 89-16, § 1, 6-15-89; Ord. No. 05-11, § 1, 8-23-05; Ord. No. 08-09, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-08; Ord. No. 14-05, § 9, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-59. - License fees. 
(a)  The applicant for a license to sell beer or malt beverages within the city shall pay the annual license fee required by section 30-1-24 of this Code. 
(b)  If the license is issued during the last six (6) months of a license year, one-half (1/2) of the license amount shall be paid as the license fee for such half year. 
(Code 1972, § 4-47; Ord. No. 87-58, § 3, 1-27-87; Ord. No. 95-8, § 4, 3-14-95) 
Sec. 30-20-60. - Malt beverages; exemptions. 
    Malt beverages containing less than one-half of one percent (.005) alcohol by volume shall not be subject to any tax levied pursuant to the provisions of this chapter but shall otherwise be subject to the provisions of this article relating to the possession, distribution, or sale of malt beverages or beer. 
(Ord. No. 90-21, § 4, 5-22-90) 
Secs. 30-20-61-30-20-75. - Reserved. 
Division 3 - EXCISE TAX 

Sec. 30-20-76. - Noncompliance grounds for license and permit revocation. 
    Any permit or license granted to any person to engage in the business of a wholesale or retail dealer under this article shall be subject to the provisions of this division and a failure to comply with same shall be a sufficient basis and grounds for the mayor and council to revoke the license and permit. 
(Code 1972, § 4-52) 
Sec. 30-20-77. - Tax levied upon wholesale dealers; amount; reports; identifying markings not required; records. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and imposed upon all wholesale dealers selling malt beverages within the city a specific excise tax as follows: 
(1)  The amount of .41666 cents per ounce of malt beverages in bottles, cans and containers of various size sold by each wholesale dealer within the corporate limits of the city. 
(2)  The amount of six dollars ($6.00) for draught or tap beer for each container containing not more than fifteen and one-half (151/2) gallons, and at the same rate for fractional parts thereof for malt beverages sold in or from a barrel or bulk container. 
(b)  Each wholesale dealer selling malt beverages within the city shall file a report by the tenth day of each month showing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of malt beverages, by size and type of container, constituting a beginning and ending inventory for the month, sold within the city. Each such wholesale dealer shall remit to the city on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made, the amount of excise tax due in accordance with this section. 
(c)  No decal, stamp, or other identifying marking shall be required on malt beverages sold within the city. 
(d)  Each wholesale dealer shall maintain records which will correctly reflect the name and address of each person, firm or corporation to whom sales or deliveries are made in the city and the quantities sold and delivered and will produce such names and addresses monthly and produce the quantities sold if requested by the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-53) 
State Law reference- Local malt beverage excise tax, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80 et seq. 
Sec. 30-20-78. - Tax in addition to license fee, etc. 
    The excise tax provided for in this division shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling malt beverages at retail or wholesale, within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-54) 
Sec. 30-20-79. - Penalty for failure to make timely report and remittance; filing of false or fraudulent reports. 
    The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten (10) percent of the total amount due during the first thirty-day period following the date such report and remittance was due and a further penalty of fifty (50) percent of the amount of such remittance for each successive thirty-day period or any portion thereof, during which such report and remittance are not filed. The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the wholesale dealer making such report liable for a penalty equal to one hundred (100) percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. 
(Code 1972, § 4-55) 
Sec. 30-20-80. - Delivery, sale, possession of malt beverages upon which excise tax not paid. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ship to, deliver in the city, sell, offer for sale, or possess within the city any malt beverages upon which the specific excise tax levied hereby has not been paid. 
(Code 1972, § 4-56) 
Sec. 30-20-81. - Aiding in violation. 
    No person shall assist or aid another in violating this article. 
(Code 1972, § 4-57) 
Secs. 30-20-82-30-20-95. - Reserved. 
Article III - SPIRITUOUS LIQUORS 
Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-20-96. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall apply: 
    Adequate parking shall mean one off-street parking space for one hundred fifty (150) square feet of customer service area within the premises of applicant, but not less than five (5) parking spaces. Such off-street parking shall have vehicular access to a street and shall be constructed of all-weather surface; provided, however, where no parking space can reasonably be provided on the same lot, any public or private off-street parking lot may be utilized to fulfill such parking requirement, if the public or private off-street parking lot is within one hundred fifty (150) feet of the premises and if the patrons of the licensee are allowed to use such lot. Provided further, this parking requirement shall not apply to premises located within the C-2 Central Business District. 
    Alcoholic beverages shall mean spirituous liquors as defined herein. 
    Business area shall mean any area which corresponds to the business area designated on the zoning map contained in the zoning ordinance. 
    Church shall mean a permanent building where persons regularly assemble for religious worship. 
    College shall mean only state, county, city, church or other colleges as teach the subjects commonly taught in the common colleges of this state and shall not include private colleges where only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects are taught. 
    Distance shall mean the measurement in linear feet from the nearest wall enclosing the proposed premises of licensee to the nearest wall of any church, or to the nearest property line of any school, college or residence, the same to be measured by way of the nearest traveled road, street or highway, as provided by law. 
    Family shall mean and include any person related to the holder of a license issued under the provisions of this article within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as determined according to the law of this state. 
    Fortified wines are classified as liquor and shall mean any wines or beverages made by fermentation, to which there has been added distilled spirits and where the alcoholic content is more than twenty-one (21) per cent alcohol by volume. 
    License shall mean the authorization by the governing authority of the City of LaGrange to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages in the city in one of the following classes: 
    Class A-Retail package store; 
    Class B-Retail pouring outlet; 
    Class C-Wholesale. 
    Licensee shall mean a person or persons, real or artificial, holding any class of license issued under the terms of this article. 
    Lounge shall mean an area adjacent to a restaurant holding a Class B license. Such lounge may have a bar and provide for the service of mixed drinks, but must be connected with and operated as a part of the restaurant holding such Class B license, and must be owned and operated by the holder of such Class B license. 
    Manufacturer shall mean a producer or bottler of vinous liquors or spirituous liquors. 
    Package store shall mean a geographic location within the City of LaGrange wherein a license may be issued for the sale of packaged spirituous liquors. Such package store must be operated as a distinct business and cannot be operated in conjunction with or as a part of any other business, except only as provided in this article and/or by the law of this state. 
    Person shall mean an individual or individuals, a partnership or partnerships, a corporation or corporations, and an association or associations. 
    Pouring outlet shall mean a restaurant or private club as defined herein for which a Class B license for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption only on the premises has been issued. 
    Premises shall mean the definite closed or partitioned-in locality whether a room, shop or building, wherein spirituous liquors are sold. 
    Private club shall mean: 
(1)  A corporation organized, existing and operating under the laws of Georgia, exclusively for nonprofit, charitable, recreational or fraternal purposes; or 
(2)  An unincorporated association formed and operated exclusively for nonprofit, charitable, recreational or fraternal purposes; 
in existence and operating for such purposes in the City of LaGrange, Troup County, Georgia, on the fifteenth day of June, 1977, no part of the net profits or earnings of which shall inure to the benefit of any member, shareholder, or individual. Such licensed private club shall have the continuing obligation to admit immediately the law enforcement officers of the City of LaGrange, Troup County, State of Georgia, or the United States of America at any time upon presentation of proper credentials. 
    Private residence shall mean a house or dwelling wherein not less than one nor more than three (3) families customarily reside and shall not include an apartment house having facilities for housing four (4) or more families and any residence which has been unoccupied for a period of six (6) consecutive months immediately prior to the filing of an application hereunder. 
    Restaurant shall mean a licensed, commercial, undertaking in the City of LaGrange, engaged predominately in the business of food service, which: 
(1)  Has all required department of health licenses or permits; 
(2)  Has a minimum seating capacity of twenty-five (25); 
(3)  Offers menu service to its patrons and regularly and actually serves a minimum of one meal per day, five (5) days per week; and 
(4)  Which is in an area properly zoned for such purpose, or which is a permitted or conditional use under the zoning ordinances of the City of LaGrange. If such restaurant is operated as a private club, the licensee has the continuing obligation to admit, without question, the law enforcement officers of the City of LaGrange, Troup County, State of Georgia, or the United States of America, at any time upon presentation of proper credentials. 
    Retail sale shall mean selling or offering for sale alcoholic beverages to any member of the public. 
    School shall mean only such state, county, city, church or other schools as teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools of this state and shall not include private schools where only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects are taught. 
    Spirituous liquors shall mean any alcoholic beverages containing alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed with water or other substance in solution, and includes brandy, rum, whiskey, gin, cordials, or other spirituous liquors by whatever name called to include fortified wines, as defined by Federal Alcohol Administration. 
    Wholesaler shall mean any person, firm, or corporation engaged in distribution or selling to retailers for the purpose of resale, any spirituous liquors as defined herein. 
(Code 1972, § 4-100) 
Sec. 30-20-97. - Purposes of article. 
    This article has been enacted for the purpose of promoting the health and general welfare of the city, to establish reasonable and ascertainable standards for the regulations and control of the licensing and sale of spirituous liquors, to protect and preserve schools and churches, to give effect to existing land use, to preserve residential areas with reasonable consideration being given to the character of the area and their peculiar suitability for particular uses, the congestion in roads and streets, and with a general view of promoting desirable living conditions, sustaining the stability of neighborhoods and property values, to protect against the evils of concentration of retail licenses for intoxicating liquors in one family, and/or corporations, and to prevent an undesirable person from engaging in or having an interest in intoxicating liquors or the sale thereof in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-101) 
Sec. 30-20-98. - Compliance with article required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale at wholesale or retail any alcoholic beverages within the city without having first complied with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 4-102) 
Secs. 30-20-99-30-20-110. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - LICENSES; APPLICATION; ISSUANCE 

Sec. 30-20-111. - License required for manufacture and sale. 
    No alcoholic beverages shall be manufactured or sold except under a license granted pursuant to the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 4-106; Ord. No. 92-32, § 3, 9-22-92; Ord. No. 14-05, § 10, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-112. - Application form; content; proceeds; deposit. 
(a)  No application for retail license to sell spiritous liquor shall be granted where the person applying for such license and/or members of such person's family and/or a corporation already hold two (2) interests in a license to sell spiritous liquor by the package at retail within the state. 
(b)  All applicants shall furnish all data, information and records pertinent to the application requested of them by the police department of the city, and failure to furnish such data, information and records within thirty (30) days from the date of such request shall automatically serve to dismiss, with prejudice, the application. All applicants shall submit a completed copy of the Personnel Statement Form ATT-17, State of Georgia Department of Revenue, Alcohol Tax and Control Unit. The applicants, by filing an application, agree to produce for oral interrogation any person or persons requested by the police department of the city and considered as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to such application and/or license issued under the terms of this article. The failure to produce such person or persons within thirty (30) days after being requested to do so shall result in the automatic dismissal of any application pending under this article. 
(c)  Each applicant shall submit a survey by a registered land surveyor showing compliances with all distance requirements contained herein. 
(d)  The city shall require not less than thirty (30) nor more than forty-five (45) days for processing any application for license under the terms of this article. 
(e)  Upon filing of the application with the assistant city manager, the applicant shall deposit in cash or by certified check a processing fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to cover the expense of investigation, and processing the application, which fee shall not be refundable but shall apply against any license granted hereunder. 
(f)  Upon approval, in accordance with the terms of this article of an application for license, the license fee shall be paid by certified check prior to the issuance of a license and within ten (10) days after approval. 
(g)  In the event the applicant is denied a license by the state, the license fee shall be refunded. 
(h)  The foregoing requirements are in addition to and cumulative of the requirements set forth in article I of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 4-107; Ord. No. 92-32, § 4, 9-22-92; Ord. No. 06-02, § 2, 3-28-06; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-20-113. - Advertisement of intent to engage in business; signs posted. 
(a)  All applicants for licenses hereunder shall give notice of the making of an application by advertisement at least twice a week for two (2) consecutive weeks prior to the date of hearing on such application, in the daily newspaper published in the city in which the legal advertisements of the city are published, which notice shall contain a complete description of the location of the proposed business and shall give the name of the applicant and if a partnership, the names of the partners, whether limited or general, and if a corporation, the name of the principal officer of said corporation in the state and the name of the person who will be the manager of the business to which the license will be issued, and the date and time the city manager will hear such application. The advertisement referred to herein shall be of type not smaller than ten (10) point capital and lower case and shall be at least a two (2) inch, two (2) column advertisement. 
(b)  The applicant shall cause to be placed upon the location of the proposed business, a sign or signs, stating the following: 
LIQUOR LICENSE APPLIED FOR HEARING BEFORE THE CITY MANAGER OF THE CITY OF LAGRANGE, GEORGIA, ON THE _______ DAY OF _______, 20___. 
(c)  The sign or signs required by subparagraph (b) shall be not less than twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches and shall face toward all public streets, alleys, sidewalks, or other public property adjoining the proposed location. Such signs shall be placed where they can be easily seen from all public properties adjoining the proposed location. 
(Code 1972, § 4-108; Ord. No. 14-05, § 11, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-114. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 92-32, § 12, adopted Sept. 22, 1992, amended the Code by deleting in its entirety, which pertained to the investigation of application report, as derived from Code 1972, § 4-109. 
Sec. 30-20-115. - Payment of taxes and other debts to the city. 
    The assistant city manager shall cause an inquiry to be made into the tax records to determine if any applicant or other parties interested in an application have any outstanding taxes or special assessments that are delinquent or any other monies owing to the city. No license shall be issued, renewed or considered for issuance or renewal to an applicant which has outstanding and delinquent taxes, special assessments, unpaid utilities, or other monies owed to the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-110; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-20-116. - Issuance of licenses limited to designated area. 
(a)  Manufacturer's license. No manufacturer's license shall be issued to a manufacturer engaged in distilling or blending alcoholic beverages except where such business is to be located in an area of the city which is zoned for industrial uses. 
(b)  Wholesaler's license. No license shall be issued to a wholesaler of alcoholic beverages except where the wholesale business is to be located in an area of the city which is zoned for commercial or industrial uses. 
(c)  Packaged spirituous liquors. No license to engage in the sale of packaged liquors at retail shall be granted except in an area zoned for commercial or industrial uses. 
(d)  Pouring outlet. No license to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises shall be granted unless the restaurant for which the application is made is in an area properly zoned for such purpose, or is a permitted or conditional use under the zoning ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-111) 
Sec. 30-20-117. - Citizenship, residence requirements. 
(a)  No license for the retail sale of spiritous liquors under a class A (package store) license shall be granted to any applicant who is not a citizen of the United States, or an alien lawfully admitted to be a permanent resident of the United States, and who has not resided within Troup County for the one-year period next preceding the date on which the application is made. If the applicant is a corporation, all stockholders in such corporation must meet the requirements contained herein and the license shall be issued jointly to the corporation and a stockholder having a substantial interest therein. If the applicant is a partnership, the requirements contained herein shall be met by all partners, whether general or limited. 
(b)  No license for the retail sale of spirituous liquors under a class B (pouring outlet) license shall be granted to any applicant who is not a citizen of the United States, or an alien lawfully admitted to be a permanent resident of the United States, and who is not a resident of the State of Georgia. No license for the retail sale of spirituous liquors under a class B (pouring outlet) license shall be granted except to the owner and operator of the restaurant or private club as defined herein. 
(c)  If the holder of the license for the sale of spirituous liquors is an individual or business entity which does not meet the residence requirements of this section, the license must be issued to and held in the name of an individual who is a managing officer or agent of the individual or entity and who must meet the residency requirements of this section. 
(Code 1972, § 4-112; Ord. No. 00-25, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 01-32, § 1, 11-27-01; Ord. No. 07-11, § 1, 4-24-07) 
Secs. 30-20-118, 30-20-119. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-38, § 1, adopted Dec. 10, 2002, repealed § 30-20-118, which prohibited issuance of license to persons with prior convictions, and exception thereto, derived from § 4-113 of the 1972 Code. For current provisions dealing with such subject matter, see § 30-20-18. 
 Ord. No. 95-1, adopted Jan. 24, 1995, repealed § 30-20-119. Prior to repeal, § 30-20-119 pertained to the location of businesses and their distances from residences, and derived from the Code of 1972 and Ord. No. 92-32, adopted Sept. 22, 1992. 
Sec. 30-20-120. - Same-Distance from schools and churches. 
(a)  Except for a class B retail pouring outlet located within the downtown development area, for which there shall be no distance requirement, no license shall be issued hereunder where the place of business of the applicant is located with three hundred (300) feet of any church or within six hundred (600) feet of any school ground or college campus, the same to be measured by the nearest traveled road, street, or highway as provided by law. 
(b)  The provisions of this section as to distance from churches, schools and college campuses shall not apply if the applicant for a class B license is a private club and the private club for which the application is made was in business at such location on June 15, 1977, and on that date met all requirements as a private club and otherwise complied with all provisions of this article. 
(c)  No person shall knowingly or intentionally sell or offer to sell any alcoholic beverages or distilled spirits within one hundred (100) yards of an alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the State of Georgia, by Troup County or by the City of LaGrange. This section shall not apply to any business having a license to sell alcoholic beverages or distilled spirits which was in effect on July 1, 1981, and which has continued in full force and effect since that date. 
(d)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49, no packaged spirituous liquor license shall issue for a location within five hundred (500) yards of any other business licensed to sell package spirituous liquors at retail, as measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground; provided, however that this limitation shall not apply to any hotel licensed under this chapter. Moreover, the restriction provided for in this subsection, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49, shall not apply to any location for which a license has been issued prior to July 1, 1997, nor the renewal of such license. Nor shall the restriction of this subsection apply to any location for which a new license is applied for if the sale of the distilled spirits was lawful at such location at any time during the twelve (12) months immediately preceding such application. 
(Code 1972, § 4-115; Ord. No. 94-45, § 3, 10-11-94; Ord. No. 04-07, § 1, 3-9-04; Ord. No. 16-04, § 3, 4-12-16) 
Sec. 30-20-121. - General qualifications. 
    No application for a license hereunder shall be granted if the application, investigation or the evidence presented at a hearing before the city manager shows any of the following conditions to exist: 
(1)  That the applicant or any person owning a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license for which application is made, is of bad moral character, or does not have sufficient mental capacity to conduct the business for which application is made, or who has been dishonorably discharged from the armed services of the United States. 
(2)  If the applicant, or any person having a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the issuance of the license, has had any license issued by the city or by any other city in the state, or by any other licensing authority in the state relating to the manufacture, distribution or sale of alcoholic or malt beverages previously suspended or revoked. 
(3)  That the applicant, or any person who shall have a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license, as a previous holder of a license to sell alcoholic beverages has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business within a ten-year period immediately preceding the date of the application for license hereunder. 
(4)  That any applicant for a retail license hereunder is related to any distributor or wholesaler of alcoholic beverages within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as computed according to the laws of Georgia. 
(Code 1972, § 4-116; Ord. No. 14-05, § 12, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-122. - Number of licenses within family or corporation. 
(a)  No application for a retail license to sell spirituous liquors shall be granted where the person applying for such license and/or members of such person's family and/or a corporation already hold two (2) interests in a license to sell spirituous liquor by the package at retail within the state. No person and/or member of his family and/or a corporation shall own, hold or control any interest whatsoever in more than one (1) class A license or in more than two (2) class B licenses in the city except that a person and/or a member of his family or a corporation may own, hold or control one (1) class A and two (2) class B licenses to engage in the business of selling spirituous liquors in the city. 
(b)  As used in this section, an interest in a license shall be deemed to exist if the person involved is the outright owner of the license, a co-owner of a license, a general or limited partner in a partnership which owns all or any part of a license, a stockholder in a corporation which owns all or any part of a license, an owner, lessor, sublessor of, or stockholder in any corporation owning or leasing, any real estate which is occupied by a package store, pouring outlet, or wholesaler, or shares in any income or corpus of any trust fund or estate having any interest in a package store, pouring outlet or wholesaler. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, no person shall be deemed to have more than one (1) interest in any one (1) license. 
(c)  All applications for license, whether original or for renewal, must be accompanied by a full and complete statement under oath of information relative to any and all interest, as hereinbefore defined in subparagraph (b) in package stores, pouring outlets, or wholesale establishments. This shall include the names and addresses of all persons interested in the ownership of such business together with any interest each person or members of his immediate family has in any other package store, pouring outlet or wholesale establishment; the ownership of the land and building where such retail business is operated; the amount of rental paid for said land and building, and the manner in which the same is determined and to whom and at what intervals the same is paid; the name and addresses (by affidavit from the owner, lessor, or sublessor of such land and building) of all persons having any whole, partial, beneficial, or any other interest in the land and building on and in which such business is to be located; a copy of the proposed lease, and any other information requested by the police department or the city manager pertinent to the application under investigation. 
(d)  Any change in any of the relationships and/or ownership interest contained on the application must be filed with the city manager within thirty (30) days after such change is made and the failure to do so shall be grounds for immediate cancellation and revocation by the mayor and council of any license issued hereunder, or for the immediate denial of any application for a license hereunder. 
(Code 1972, § 4-117; Ord. No. 93-1, § 1, 1-26-93; Ord. No. 14-05, § 13, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-123. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 95-21, § 1, adopted June 13, 1995, repealed § 30-20-123, pertaining to city official, spouse, children having interest in alcoholic beverage license, as derived from the Code of 1972, § 4-118. 
Sec. 30-20-124. - Advertisement of and public hearing on application. 
(a)  No application for a license hereunder shall be acted upon or issued by the city manager until after advertisement and public hearing thereon, as required herein. 
(b)  A public hearing upon all applications for a license hereunder shall be held before the city manager, not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days after the filing of the application. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant for a license to advertise the notice of hearing as required in section 3-20-113(a) as follows: 
Notice of Application for License to Sell Spirituous Liquors. The undersigned has made application to the City of LaGrange for a license to sell spirituous liquors at _______. 
    This application will be heard by the city manager at _______ o'clock a.m./p.m. on the _____ day of _______, 20___, City Hall, 200 Ridley Avenue. 
     Signed  ;hg; _____
Applicant 
(Code 1972, § 4-119; Ord. No. 92-32, § 7, 9-22-92; Ord. No. 14-05, § 14, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-125. - Completion of proposed licensed premises. 
    Where a building in which a retailer proposes to operate under the provisions of this article is at the time of application for such license not in existence, or not yet completed, a license may be issued for such location provided the plans and specifications for the proposed building are filed with the assistant city manager and show clearly a compliance with the other provisions of this article and applicable ordinances of the city. No sales shall be allowed in such establishment until it has been completed in accordance with said plans and specifications and is in conformity with all other provisions of this article and applicable ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-120; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-20-126. - Acceptance and consideration of application after rejection or revocation. 
    When any license or permit to sell alcoholic beverages under this article is revoked by the mayor and council, it shall be unlawful for the assistant city manager to accept and for the city manager to consider any application from the same applicant for a license within twelve (12) months from the time of such revocation by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 4-121; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 14-05, § 15, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-20-127. - Time limit for commencement of business in licensed establishments; nonuse. 
(a)  All holders of licenses hereunder must, within six (6) months after the issuance of said license, open for business the establishment referred to in the license. Failure to open the licensed establishment within six (6) months after the issuance of such license shall serve as the automatic forfeiture and cancellation of such license and no refund of license fee shall be made to the license holder. 
(b)  Any holder of a license hereunder who shall begin the operation of the business authorized in the license, but who shall for a period of six (6) consecutive months thereafter cease to operate the business as authorized in said license, shall upon expiration of such six (6) months period, automatically forfeit such license, which license shall, by virtue of such failure to operate, be cancelled without the necessity of any further action of the mayor and council, and no refund of license fee shall be made to the license holder. 
(Code 1972, § 4-122) 
Sec. 30-20-128. - Payment of license fees; amount; license for each location; penalty. 
(a)  All annual license fees under this article shall be paid in advance, on or before January 1 of each year and any new licensee granted hereunder during a calendar year shall pay the full license fee without proration; provided, however, that if a new license is granted after January 1, the license fee shall be prorated for such initial calendar year in the event that the licensee pays said prorated amount plus the full license fee for the following calendar year. 
(b)  Each person manufacturing or selling spirituous liquors in the city except wholesalers not maintaining a place of business in LaGrange shall pay the annual license tax required by section 30-20-16. 
(c)  Any person licensed hereunder shall be required to renew his license on or before January 1 of each year. Furthermore, if the license fee is not paid by the first day of January of each year, a penalty of ten (10) percent of the license fee shall be assessed, in addition to interest at one and five-tenths (1.5) percent per month. 
(d)  A licensee shall not continue operation after January 1 of any year unless the required license fee is paid on or before that date and any and all licenses required by this code are obtained and the appropriate fee therefor paid by such date. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, the license fee for a Class A spirituous liquors retail package license may be paid in two (2) equal installments, with the first installment being due on January 1 and the remaining installment being due on June 1. Consistent with subsection (c) above, penalty and interest shall accrue after the due date, and no licensee shall continue to operate after January 1 or, if applicable, June 1 unless the required license fee payment is made on or before that date. 
(Code 1972, § 4-123; Ord. No. 87-58, § 4, 1-27-87; Ord. No. 95-8, § 5, 3-14-95; Ord. No. 95-46, § 5, 12-21-95; Ord. No. 10-23, § 1, 11-23-2010; Ord. No. 13-03, §§ 2, 3, 2-12-13) 
Sec. 30-20-129. - Restriction on other mercantile establishment. 
(a)  The holder of a Class A license issued pursuant to this article shall not operate such business in connection with any other retail establishment and no such retail dealer shall sell or offer for sale or display or keep in stock at his place of business spirituous liquors and distilled spirits where are offered for sale, any other product or commodity except the following: 
(1)  Wines, but only if the retail dealer holds a valid and current license to sell wine at said place of business; 
(2)  Malt beverages or beer, but only if the retail dealer holds a valid and current license to sell malt beverages or beer at said place of business; 
(3)  Tobacco products; 
(4)  Beverages containing no alcohol and commonly used to dilute distilled spirits; 
(5)  Ice to be sold in sealed containers; and 
(6)  Paper; styrofoam or plastic cups. 
Provided however should a retail dealer elect to sell malt beverages or beer as provided in subsection (2) of this paragraph (a), such retail dealer shall be subject to all laws and regulations pertaining to the sale of distilled spirits including, but not limited to, the hours of sale and days of sale; and provided further that beverage containing no alcohol and commonly used to dilute distilled spirits as provided in subsection (4) of this paragraph (a) may be dispensed through the use of vending machines, but no beverage alcohol shall be dispensed through any such vending machine. The sale of the products described in subsections (3), (4), (5) and (6) of this paragraph (a) shall not require a license or the payment of a license fee therefor so long as such sales are in conjunction with the Class A license granted hereby. 
(b)  The holder of a Class B license shall operate such business only in connection with a restaurant or a private club as defined herein, and may sell beer (if licensed) and wine (if licensed) for consumption only on the premises and such other items which may normally be associated with the operation of a restaurant or a private club. 
(Code 1972, § 4-124) 
Sec. 30-20-130. - Compliance with laws and regulations. 
    All retail licensees shall meet and continuously comply with all state and local fire and health laws and regulations as the same may now or hereafter exist. 
(Code 1972, § 4-126) 
Sec. 30-20-131. - Solicitation of drinks. 
    No licensee shall require, permit, suffer, encourage, or induce any employee or person to solicit in the licensed premises for herself or himself or for any person other than the patron and guests of the patron, the purchase by the patron of any drink, whether alcoholic or nonalcoholic, or money with which to purchase the same, nor shall any licensee pay a commission or any other compensation to any person frequenting his establishment or to his agent or manager to solicit for herself, himself, or for others, the purchase by the patron of any drink, whether alcoholic or nonalcoholic. 
(Code 1972, § 4-127) 
Secs. 30-20-132-30-20-145. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Formerly Div. 2 contained substantive § 30-20-132, derived from Ord. No. 93-6, § 1, adopted Feb. 9, 1993, which prohibited sale of alcoholic beverages or distilled spirits and wine within one hundred yards of an alcoholic treatment center. Such provisions were repealed by Ord. No. 94-45, § 1, adopted Oct. 11, 1994, and the user's attention is directed to §§ 30-20-120(c) and 30-20-224(3) for similar provisions. 
Division 3 - RENEWAL, REVOCATION AND TRANSFER OF LICENSES 

Sec. 30-20-146. - Annual renewal. 
    All licensees under this article shall be required to renew their licenses annually on forms prescribed by the assistant city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 4-129; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 30-20-147. - License constitutes grant or privilege. 
(a)  All licenses issued under this article shall constitute a mere grant or privilege to carry on or conduct a business covered by such license during the term of the license, subject to the terms and conditions imposed by the charter of the city, this article, and other applicable ordinances of the city and the constitution, laws and regulations of the state and the United States of America applicable thereto. 
(b)  All licenses issued under this article shall have printed on the face the following words: 
"THIS LICENSE IS A MERE PRIVILEGE AND IT IS SUBJECT TO BEING REVOKED AND ANNULLED BY THE MAYOR AND COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF LAGRANGE AND IS SUBJECT TO LAWS, ORDINANCES AND REGULATIONS HEREAFTER ADOPTED." 
(Code 1972, § 4-130) 
State Law reference- Local licenses, due process guidelines, etc., O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. 
Sec. 30-20-148. - Grounds for suspension or revocation; notice; hearing; refund. 
(a)  Any license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued by the city to any licensee may be suspended or revoked for due cause as hereinafter defined, and after a hearing is held by the mayor and council for the purpose of considering any such suspension or revocation. At least five (5) days prior to such hearing written notice of the time, place and purpose of such hearing, a statement of the charge or charges upon which such hearing is to be held shall be given to the holder of such license for which suspension or revocation is to be considered. 
(b)  Due cause for the suspension or revocation of a license shall consist of a violation of any laws or ordinances applicable to or regulating such business, violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating such business; or for the violation of any state or federal law or regulation, or for the violation of any city ordinances other than traffic ordinances; or failure of the licensee or his employees to promptly report to the police department any violation of the law or ordinances, any breach of the peace, disturbance or altercation resulting in violence which may occur in or upon the licensed premises. 
(c)  The mayor is hereby authorized to suspend any license issued hereunder in any emergency situation such as civil disorders or natural disasters, or in any situation wherein the mayor deems such immediate suspension necessary for the protection of the health and welfare of the citizens of LaGrange, and said suspension may be made effective immediately and shall remain in force until the mayor determines the emergency is over or until the next regular meeting of the mayor and council, or a meeting called prior to the next regular meeting. 
(d)  When a license is suspended or revoked, the city shall not refund any portion of the license tax to the holder of such suspended or revoked license. 
(Code 1972, § 4-131) 
Sec. 30-20-149. - Automatic revocation upon revocation of state license. 
    Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license to manufacture or sell at wholesale or retail any alcoholic beverages, the city license to manufacture or sell at wholesale or retail any such product within the city shall thereupon be automatically revoked without any further action by the mayor and council or any officer of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 4-132) 
Sec. 30-20-150. - Removal of signs after revocation. 
    When any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages is revoked, all signs indicating that such beverages may be sold or purchased, shall be immediately removed from both inside and outside the place of business. Upon receipt by the police department of notice of revocation, the police department shall take the necessary steps to see that this section is enforced. 
(Code 1972, § 4-133) 
Sec. 30-20-151. - Revocation upon violation of article. 
    A violation of any of the provisions of this article by the holder of a license issued hereunder shall subject the holder of such license to revocation of said license, as provided herein. 
(Code 1972, § 4-134) 
Sec. 30-20-152. - False information in application. 
    Any material omission from or untrue or misleading information which is contained in an original, renewal or transfer application for a license under this article shall be cause for the denial or refusal of a license, and if any license has previously been granted under such circumstances, the same shall constitute due cause for revocation of such license. Any failure to notify of the change in any relationship as specified in (d) of section 30-20-122 within thirty (30) days after such change is made shall likewise constitute due cause for cancellation, revocation, or suspension of a license issued hereunder. 
(Code 1972, § 4-135) 
Sec. 30-20-153. - Restrictions upon transfers. 
(a)  Licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall not be transferable except as provided in this article. 
(b)  In case of the death of any person owning a license, or any interest therein, the same may, with the approval of the city manager and subject to the terms of this article, be transferred to the administrator, executor or personal representative of the deceased person, or to the heirs at law of the deceased person, if such heirs meet all of the other qualifications contained herein. The license of such deceased person shall be held by the administrator, executor, or personal representative of such deceased person only for the time necessary to complete execution of his estate and dispose of the license or his interest therein, but in no event to exceed six (6) months. 
(c)  Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one (1) or more of the partners in a partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership and to assign his interest in such partnership to one (1) or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. Such withdrawal shall not, however, serve to bring any new ownership into the partnership, unless all provisions of this article are fully complied with, and then only upon the approval of the city manager. 
(d)  Should a transfer of the location be approved, there shall be no pro rata return of any license fee and the new location shall meet all requirements of a new license to be issued hereunder, except payment of license fee and investigation fee. 
(e)  A licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined that additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or expanding the facilities of the business or for building new facilities and where it appears that the licensee himself will directly receive none of the additional capital investment. Under this section an additional partner or new stockholder must be approved by the city manager, as provided hereunder. 
(f)  Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the transfer of a license from an individual or a group of individuals to a corporation in which the existing licensees are the stockholders and the transferred license would be owned and held in the name of the existing license or licensees and the corporation jointly as required by subsection (a) of section 3-20-112. Any such transfer of a license as described in this subsection must be approved by the city manager pursuant to an application meeting the requirements of subsection (a) of section 3-20-112 but shall not require the payment of an additional license fee or investigation fee and shall not require any additional advertisement or investigation or approval of stockholders who were licensees under the previous license. 
(Code 1972, § 4-136; Ord. No. 14-05, § 16, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-154. - Application for new licenses on existing license location. 
    An applicant to obtain a new license at an existing license location, after producing the written agreement of the existing licensee to surrender the existing license and for the issuance of such new license, must meet and comply with all requirements of this article which relate to approval of an applicant but need not comply with those requirements which relate to approval of the location. 
(Code 1972, § 4-137) 
Secs. 30-20-155-30-20-170. - Reserved. 
Division 4 - RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSES 

Sec. 30-20-171. - Authority to regulate licenses. 
(a)  This division is adopted under authority set forth in this article and related laws, and the licenses issued herein shall remain a mere grant or privilege and, in the event of revocation by the mayor and council, the licensee shall not be entitled to a return of any portion of the license fee. 
(b)  Any license granted hereunder shall be a mere grant or privilege to carry on a business licensed during the term of the license, subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this article and related laws, the applicable provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city relating to the business license. 
(Code 1972, § 4-140) 
Sec. 30-20-172. - Employees alcohol beverage card (ABC); procedure. 
(a)  No person whose duties involve dispensing, serving, selling, handling or taking orders for alcoholic beverages may be employed by an establishment until such person has been issued an alcoholic beverage card (ABC card) by the police department indicating the person to be employed is eligible for such employment. 
(b)  All persons subject to the provisions of this section shall, within seven (7) days after the date of their first work in an establishment holding a license to sell spirituous liquors, report to the police department for issuance of an alcohol beverage card. 
(c)  The police department shall make a complete and exhaustive search relative to the criminal record of any person so employed. The ABC card shall be denied or revoked, as the case may be, in the event the applicant employee shall have been convicted within a period of five (5) years immediately prior to the application for an ABC card of any alcohol related offense. The chief of police may, after investigation, waive any such conviction if, within his discretion, such should not constitute a bar to the issuance of an ABC card. 
(d)  Any letter of eligibility for employment issued hereunder shall expire twelve (12) months from the date of the issuance unless earlier canceled by the police department. The police department may prescribe regulations for certifying the eligibility for continued employment without the necessity of a further search relative to the record of that person. The police department may prescribe reasonable fees and times for certifying eligibility for employment and the fees shall be paid by the employer or the employee at the time request for eligibility certification is made. Any such fees shall be approved by the mayor and council of the city. 
(e)  The licensee, or the manager of the licensed premises, shall be responsible for the conduct or actions of the employees and shall have the responsibility of ensuring compliance with the provisions of this code section. 
(Code 1972, § 4-141; Ord. No. 91-44, § 1, 11-12-91; Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 4-27-99; Ord. No. 10-03, §§ 2-4, 3-9-10; Ord. No. 12-18, § 1, 10-9-12; Ord. No. 18-07, § 2, 8-14-18) 
Sec. 30-20-173. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-03, § 5, adopted March 9, 2010, deleted § 30-20-173 which pertained to employment of persons with prior connections and derived from Code 1972, § 4-142. 
Sec. 30-20-174. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 92-42, § 2, adopted Dec. 8, 1992, amended the Code by deleting in its entirety § 30-20-174, pertaining to employment of minors, as derived from Code 1972, § 4-143. 
Sec. 30-20-175. - Sale to minors, incompetents, drunkards prohibited. 
    No licensee hereunder shall sell alcoholic beverages to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years or to any person known to such licensee or his employees to be an habitual drunkard, or who is of unsound mind or who is in a state of noticeable intoxication. 
(Code 1972, § 4-144; Ord. No. 92-12, § 1, 4-28-92) 
Sec. 30-20-176. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Class A (package store). A licensee for the sale of packaged, spirituous liquors shall not engage in the sale of such liquors, except between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. Monday through Thursday; 8:30 a.m. and 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday; and 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. 
(b)  Class B (pouring outlet). 
(1)  Except as provided in subsection (e) below, a licensee for the sale of spirituous liquors by the drink for consumption only on the premises shall not sell, dispense, serve or deliver such liquors between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Tuesday through Saturday, and shall not sell, dispense, serve or deliver such liquors from 1:00 a.m. on Sunday to 6:00 a.m. on Monday. 
(2)  A class B licensee must close its doors to business, must be vacated of all persons except the licensee and any on-duty paid employees or agents, and must cease to do business at or before 2:00 a.m. and remain closed until 6:00 a.m. on each day of the week. 
(c)  Wholesalers. The business hours of any wholesale liquor dealer licensed hereunder shall be from sunup to sundown, exclusive of Sundays. 
(d)  Holidays. Except as provided herein, no licensee for the sale of spirituous liquors shall permit his place of business to be open for the sale of alcoholic beverages or to sell alcoholic beverages on Christmas Day or Thanksgiving Day. 
(e)  Sunday sales. A class B licensee which derives at least fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food, or fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging, may sell, dispense, serve or deliver spirituous liquors between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight on Sunday. 
(Code 1972, § 4-145; Ord. No. 90-55, § 1, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 12-07, § 2, 3-27-12; Ord. No. 15-10, § 6, 10-13-15) 
Sec. 30-20-177. - Keeping or storing without license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating under a license for the sale of beer or wine or both to store or have therein any whiskey or intoxicating liquors without an appropriate license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 4-146) 
Sec. 30-20-178. - Sale or delivery to unlicensed premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a Class A licensee to make deliveries of alcoholic beverages by the package beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by such license. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a Class B licensee to sell or permit the sale of alcoholic beverages except within the physical confines of the licensed premises and then only by the drink as provided under this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a Class A license and a Class B license to be operated jointly and if a Class A license is operated adjacent to a Class B license, such Class A license shall remain a distinct and separate business entity, and must be a separate premises from the establishment which operates a Class B license. 
(Code 1972, § 4-147) 
Sec. 30-20-179. - Wholesale licensees prohibited from interest in other licenses. 
    No person who has any direct financial interest in a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at wholesale shall hold any other license or have an interest in any other license issued under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 4-148) 
Sec. 30-20-180. - Misrepresentation of beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for licensees hereunder or their agents to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill empty bottles or in any manner misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any alcoholic beverage. 
(Code 1972, § 4-149) 
Sec. 30-20-181. - Name of licensee displayed. 
(a)  Each licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverage by the package at retail shall have printed on the front window of the licensed premises the name of the licensee in uniform letters, not less than four (4) inches nor more than eight (8) inches in height and the words "Liquor," "Liquor Store" or "Package Store." Such signs shall not be illuminated. 
(b)  Each licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises shall have at the front entrance thereof, an unilluminated sign measuring not less than two (2) nor more than four (4) inches in height and which shall state: "Alcoholic Beverage Licensee." 
(Code 1972, § 4-150) 
Sec. 30-20-182. - Prices displayed. 
    Each Class A licensee shall have conspicuously displayed within the interior of the licensed premises not less than four (4) copies of a printed price list of the liquors offered for sale; provided, however, that a licensee in lieu of having four (4) copies of a printed list, may have the price placed on the bottle or on the shelf where liquors are exhibited for sale. 
(Code 1972, § 4-151) 
Sec. 30-20-183. - Exterior advertisement. 
    No signs of any kind, painted or electric, advertising spirituous liquors, beer, or wine for sale or advertising any brand or price of spirituous liquors shall be permitted on the exterior or in the window of any licensed premises, except only the name of the licensee referred to in section 30-20-181. No placard or sign which is visible from the exterior of the licensed premises shall make reference to the price of any liquors sold therein, except tags showing the prices of individual bottles or containers, may be affixed to such bottles or containers, or the edge of the shelf whereon such bottles or containers are located, as specified in section 30-20-182. 
(Code 1972, § 4-152) 
Sec. 30-20-184. - Gambling devices or machines, games of chance, etc. 
    No retail dealer in spirituous liquors by the package or by the drink shall permit on his premises any gambling device or machine as the same are now or may hereafter be defined by the statutes or the judicial decisions of the state or the United States of America, or any gambling, betting, or the operation of games of chance or any scheme or device involving the hazarding of money, or any other thing of value in or upon the licensed premises, or any portion thereof, or in any room adjoining the same which is connected or which is leased or controlled by the licensee. 
(Code 1972, § 4-153) 
Sec. 30-20-185. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 06-04, adopted Apr. 11, 2006, deleted § 30-20-185 in its entirety. Former § 30-20-185 pertained to the purchase, consumption or possession by or for minors and derived from the 1972 Code. 
Sec. 30-20-186. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 92-32, § 12, adopted Sept. 22, 1992, amended the Code by deleting in its entirety § 30-20-186, which pertained to misrepresentation of age, as derived from Code 1972, § 4-155. 
Sec. 30-20-187. - Allowing minors on licensed premises. 
    No person who holds a Class A License for the sale of spirituous liquors shall allow any person below age twenty-one (21) to be in, frequent, or loiter about the premises of the licensee, unless such person is accompanied by his parent or legal guardian. 
(Code 1972, § 4-156; Ord. No. 92-32, § 9, 9-22-92) 
Sec. 30-20-188. - Consumption of beverage in package store. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on premises licensed for the sale of package liquor and it shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on said premises. If such licensee shall also have a license to sell malt beverages or wine, it shall likewise be unlawful for any of such items to be consumed on the premises where alcoholic beverages sale is licensed. 
(Code 1972, § 4-157) 
Sec. 30-20-189. - Drive-in window; curb service. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or dispense spirituous liquors from "drive-in" or "service" windows. 
(b)  Curb service or other sales of spirituous liquors outside the building licensed to sell is hereby expressly prohibited. 
(Code 1972, § 4-158) 
Secs. 30-20-190-30-20-205. - Reserved. 
Division 5 - EXCISE TAX, DEALERS, WHOLESALERS, DISTRIBUTORS 

Sec. 30-20-206. - Excise tax, levied; amount, payment, duties of dealers and wholesalers. 
(a)  Scope of section. In addition to all other taxes or license fees heretofore or hereafter imposed upon retail dealers engaged in the city in the business of selling spirituous liquors, as defined under the laws of Georgia, there is imposed and levied upon all hereinafter described dealers within the city an excise tax to be computed and collected as set forth in this section. 
(b)  Basis for computation of tax. The tax levied hereunder shall be computed on the basis of eighty cents per wine gallon for spirituous liquors sold or delivered as hereinafter set forth. 
(c)  Computation, payment, duties of wholesale dealer and distributor. The tax imposed shall be computed and payable monthly. Each wholesale dealer or distributor selling, shipping, or delivering spirituous liquors to any retail dealer in the city shall, as a condition to the privilege of conducting said business in the city. 
(1)  Keep and maintain true and correct records of all sales, shipments or deliveries of spirituous liquors to each retail dealer in LaGrange, such records to be preserved for a period of not less than one year and to be made available on request for the inspection of any duly authorized representative of the city. 
(2)  Collect from each retail dealer in the city at time of delivery of spirituous liquors, the amount of tax due under the terms of this section and hold the same in trust for the city until such tax is remitted to the city as herein provided. 
(3)  On or before the tenth day of each calendar month, each wholesaler shall make a verified and comprehensive report to the city which shall correctly show and reflect all sales and deliveries of spirituous liquors to or for retail dealers in the city for the calendar month immediately preceding the date of said report. Said report shall show the name and address of each retail dealer, the quantities delivered to each retail dealer, the amount of excise tax collected under the terms of this section, and such other reasonable information as may be requested by the city. Said report shall be accompanied by remittance payable to the city for all taxes collected or due, as shown on said report. 
(4)  The excise tax levied in this section is hereby levied upon the retailer licensed to do business in the city and it is the intent of this article to so levy this tax but require the payment of the tax at the time of delivery by the retailer to the wholesaler, who shall have the responsibility of remitting the tax to the city on behalf of the retailer on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, as hereinbefore required. In the event the tax due hereunder is not paid on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, a ten (10) per cent penalty on the gross tax will be levied by the city against each defaulting retailing licensee for whom the tax is not paid on or before the tenth day of the month. 
(d)  Noncompliance by wholesale dealer, distributor. If any wholesale dealer or distributor fails or refuses to make the reports required herein, the city shall notify such dealer or distributor in writing and if the reports are not made and the taxes remitted within five (5) days from the date of such notice, such wholesale dealer or distributor shall be prohibited from making any further deliveries in the city and the retail licensees served by such wholesale dealer or distributor for whom the taxes have not been paid shall be subject to having their license suspended or revoked as herein provided. 
(e)  Unlawful retail sales. It shall be a violation of this article for any person to sell at retail within the city any spirituous liquors on which the taxes herein provided for have not been paid. 
(f)  Unlawful deliveries. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any wholesale dealer or distributor or other person to deliver any spirituous liquors to any retail dealer in the city without at the time of such delivery collecting the excise taxes herein provided for. 
(g)  Violations. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article or who shall assist any retail dealer in spirituous liquors in the city to evade or avoid the payment of the taxes herein provided for shall be guilty of a violation of this section and on conviction thereof in the recorder's court shall be fined or sentenced as provided by this Code and any such person so convicted shall also be subject to having his license suspended or revoked, if he shall be a licensed dealer in spirituous liquors at retail. 
(Code 1972, § 4-160; Ord. No. 00-2, § 1, 2-22-00) 
Sec. 30-20-207. - Wholesalers generally. 
    All wholesale dealers or distributors shall be licensed by the state department of revenue and shall comply with all laws and regulations of such department before they sell or deliver any spirituous liquors in the city. Deliveries and sales shall be made only to retailers licensed under the provisions of this article and all deliveries shall be made in conveyances owned and operated by such wholesale dealers or distributors. 
(Code 1972, § 4-161) 
Sec. 30-20-208. - Retailers to purchase from licensed wholesalers. 
    Retail dealers in spirituous liquors licensed under the provisions of this article shall not buy nor accept deliveries of spirituous liquors from wholesalers, dealers or distributors, except who are licensed by the state department of revenue. 
(Code 1972, § 4-162) 
Sec. 30-20-209. - Regulations governing retail storage. 
    All licensed retailers shall store all spirituous liquors on the premises for which the license was issued and at no other place. All spirituous liquor stock shall be available at all times for inspection by the mayor and council or their duly authorized representatives. Any spirituous liquors found in any retailers stock that is sold or distributed by a wholesaler who is not licensed in accordance with the laws of Georgia to make sales and deliveries in the city shall be subject to immediate confiscation. 
(Code 1972, § 4-163) 
Sec. 30-20-210. - Invoices. 
(a)  Upon each delivery by a licensed wholesaler to a licensed retailer, an invoice in triplicate shall be prepared, showing the quantities and brands of spirituous liquors delivered, together with the price thereof and the excise tax due and collected thereon. The original of such invoice shall be delivered by the wholesaler to the retailer simultaneously with such delivery. The wholesaler shall retain the second copy of such invoice and shall keep it for a period of twelve (12) months after the date of delivery and during such twelve-month period, such invoices shall be made available for inspection by the mayor and council or their duly authorized representatives. Upon request of the city, a copy of such invoice shall be attached to any reports requested or required by the city. 
(b)  Each retail licensee doing business in the city shall keep and maintain the original invoice of each sale to him or purchase by him from a wholesaler of any spirituous liquors for at least twelve (12) months after the date of such purchase and shall maintain records to show the sales of spirituous liquors and any other records required by the city. The city or its duly authorized representative shall have the right to inspect the records of each licensee and make a complete audit of the records of each licensee at any time. Failure of a licensee to properly maintain records showing receipt of spirituous liquors, payment therefor, and payment of the taxes due thereon to the appropriate wholesaler, and records which clearly show the sales, the amount of sales, and the types of sales of each licensee may, at the discretion of the mayor and council, after a hearing as herein provided, result in the revocation or suspension of such license. 
(Code 1972, § 4-164) 
Sec. 30-20-211. - Revocation or suspension of license. 
    The violation of any term, condition or provision of this division in any particular, or as to any detail whatsoever, shall be conclusive cause for the immediate revocation or suspension of any license described in this article. 
(Code 1972, § 4-165) 
Sec. 30-20-212. - Production of records. 
    In conjunction with any application for license, or in conjunction with any license which has been issued under the terms of this article, or in conjunction with the revocation, suspension or cancellation of any license, or in conjunction with any of the hearings contemplated by this article, or in conjunction with the payment or nonpayment of any excise tax levied or to be collected hereunder, the mayor and council shall have the right to subpoena all or any part of the records, books, documents, reports or invoices, of any licensee for the purpose of auditing the records of such licensee, securing compliance by such licensee with the provisions of this article by any licensee, or to show payment or nonpayment of any taxes, fees, charges, or the like due hereunder. 
(Code 1972, § 4-166) 
Sec. 30-20-213. - Aiding in violations. 
    No person shall assist or aid another person in the violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 4-167) 
Secs. 30-20-214-30-20-220. - Reserved. 
Article IV - WINE 

Sec. 30-20-221. - Definitions. 
(a)  The term "wines" as used in this article shall include any wines or other beverages made by fermentation and in which the alcoholic content is less than twenty-one (21) per cent alcoholic by volume and shall not include "fortified wines" as defined by the law of Georgia. 
(b)  The term licensee, license holder or the person to whom a license is granted under this article means an individual who is either the owner or who is a managing officer or agent of the owner of the premises and who must be a resident of the State of Georgia. 
(Code 1972, § 4-170; Ord. No. 87-58, § 7, 1-27-87; Ord. No. 08-09, § 3, 4-22-08) 
State Law reference- "Fortified wine" defined, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2(8). 
Sec. 30-20-222. - Sale lawful; who may sell. 
    The sale of wine in the city is hereby made lawful, but only by the holder of one of the classes of license issued in accordance with the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Class A license (package) shall authorize the sale of wine at retail only in its original package and for consumption only off the premises of such licensee. 
(2)  Class B license (pouring) shall authorize the sale of wine at retail in its original package and/or for consumption on the premises of such licensee. Such class B license shall be issued only to an undertaking in the city which is properly zoned for such purposes or which is a permitted or conditional use under the zoning ordinances of the city. If the applicant is a restaurant operated as a private club, the licensee has the continuing obligation to admit, without question the law enforcement officers of the city, the county, the state or the United States of America, at any time upon presentation of proper credentials. 
(3)  Class C license (wholesale) shall be issued only to those persons who are licensed by the state to sell and distribute wine at wholesale. 
(4)  Application for a license to sell wine shall be made to the assistant city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 4-171; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 16-04, § 10, 4-12-16; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
Cross reference- Zoning, Ch. 25-35. 
Sec. 30-20-223. - Retail licensee; qualifications. 
(a)  The holder of any retail license to sell wines in the city must be a person of good moral character and a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted to be a permanent resident of the United States and a resident of the State of Georgia. 
(b)  Any such licensee shall not have been convicted, within a period of ten (10) years of the date of his application, of a felony or any violation of the laws of this state or any other state, or the laws of this city or any other city of Georgia relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages, wines, or malt beverages. 
(c)  The licensee or license holder or the person to whom a license is granted under this article must be either the owner, or must be a managing officer or agent of the owner of the licensed premises and must be a resident of the State of Georgia. 
(d)  The licensee shall be responsible for the management and operation of the business for which the license is granted. 
(e)  The applicant shall make a sworn statement of his qualifications in accordance with the provisions of this article and shall place the same on file with the assistant city manager before any license is issued. 
(f)  No person shall be granted a license to engage in the sale of wine at retail unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the city manager that such person is of good moral character. 
(g)  Any material misstatement of fact or omission or concealment of fact in the application shall be grounds for the revocation of the license issued and the applicant shall be liable for prosecution for perjury under the laws of Georgia. 
(h)  The city shall make such investigation of the qualifications of each applicant as it may deem necessary. 
(Code 1972, § 4-172; Ord. No. 87-58, § 5, 1-27-87; Ord. No. 00-25, § 2, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 07-12, § 7, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 08-09, §§ 4, 5, 4-22-08; Ord. No. 14-05, § 17, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 16-12, § 8, 12-13-16) 
State Law reference- Perjury, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-70. 
Sec. 30-20-224. - Distance requirements. 
    No person shall sell or offer to sell and no license shall be issued for the sale of: 
(1)  Wine within one hundred (100) yards of any school building, school grounds, or college campus, except for "on-premises consumption" (class B license) within the downtown development area, for which there shall be no such distance requirement. This subparagraph shall not apply at any location for which a license has been issued prior to July 1, 1981, nor to the renewal of such license. Nor shall this subparagraph apply at any location for which a new license is applied for if the sale of wine was lawful at such location at any time during the twelve (12) months immediately preceding such application; 
(2)  Wine for "on-premises consumption" (class B license) within one hundred (100) yards of any church building, except within the downtown development area, in which there shall be no such distance requirement. 
(3)  Wine within one hundred (100) yards of an alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the State of Georgia, by Troup County or by the City of LaGrange. This section shall not apply to any business having a license to sell wine which was in effect on July 1, 1981, and which has continued in full force and effect since that date. 
As used in this section, the term "school building" shall apply only to state, county, city, or church school buildings and to such buildings at such other schools in which are taught subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state. 
(Code 1972, § 4-173; Ord. No. 85-24, § 1, 8-27-85; Ord. No. 94-45, § 4, 10-11-94; Ord. No. 16-04, § 5, 4-12-16) 
State Law reference- Sales of alcoholic beverages near churches, school buildings, etc., O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. 
Sec. 30-20-225. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No holder of a license authorizing the sale of wine at retail in the city, nor any agent or employee, shall do any of the following upon the licensed premises: 
(1)  Knowingly sell wine to a person below age twenty-one (21); 
(2)  Knowingly sell wine to any person while such person is in an intoxicated condition; 
(3)  Sell wine upon the licensed premises or permit wine to be consumed thereon, on any day or at any time when such sale or consumption is prohibited by law. 
(b)  Wine shall be received at or delivered to the premises of the retail licensee by no means other than by a conveyance owned or leased and operated by a wholesale dealer with a permit from the state to sell wine at wholesale. 
(c)  Dealers in wine shall not engage in the sale of wine on Sunday or on any other days prohibited by state law. 
(d)  Any violation of the provisions of this article shall be grounds for immediate revocation of a license issued hereunder. 
(Code 1972, § 4-174; Ord. No. 92-32, § 10, 9-22-92) 
State Law reference- Sale of alcoholic beverages on Sundays, election days and Christmas Day, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. 
Sec. 30-20-226. - Sale without license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or possess for the purpose of sale any wine where such person does not have a license from the city to sell or possess such wine for resale. 
(Code 1972, § 4-175) 
Sec. 30-20-227. - Sales to minors; possession by minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to purchase or for any person to purchase wine for a person below the age twenty-one (21) years; 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person below the age of twenty-one (21) to possess or exhibit fake, fixed, or borrowed credentials in an effort to obtain wine to which such person is not otherwise legally entitled; 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person below age twenty-one (21) to have wine in his or her possession; and no person engaged in the business license and regulated by this article shall make or permit to be made any sales to persons below age twenty-one (21). 
(Code 1972, § 4-176; Ord. No. 92-32, § 11, 9-22-92) 
Sec. 30-20-228. - License fee; transfer of license. 
(a)  The applicant for a license to sell wine within the city shall pay the annual license fee required by section 30-1-24 of the Code. 
(b)  If the license is issued during the last six (6) months of a license year, one-half (1/2) of the license amount shall be paid as the license fee for such half year. 
(c)  A license granted hereunder shall be transferable from a managing officer or agent to another managing officer or agent of the same owner or shall be transferable from one (1) location to another only with the prior approval of the city manager. A license granted hereunder shall not otherwise be transferable from one (1) person to another. 
(Code 1972, § 4-177; Ord. No. 87-58, § 6, 1-27-87; Ord. No. 95-8, § 6, 3-14-95; Ord. No. 14-05, § 18, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 30-20-229. - Taxation.
